Africa News


March 3, 1997


Business and Finance;
South Africa: Clinic Holdings adds Libertas to hospital network


BYLINE: Alide Dasnois, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Cape Town - Private hospital group Clinic Holdings has bought a 64 percent stake in the Libertas Hospital in Goodwood for R15,8 million.

The Johannesburg Stock Exchange-listed Clinic Group bought the holding from D & E Health Benefits, a wholly owned subsidiary of Norwich Holdings. 

D & E will keep a 26 percent stake in Libertas and some of the medical aid societies it manages will hold the balance of the shareholding.

Libertas will be integrated into the network of 26 private hospitals owned by Clinic Holdings.

Clinic Holdings' Mark Palmer said the 196-bed Libertas Hospital fitted perfectly into the group's spread of speciality services. Libertas' rehabilitation facility for spinal injuries and its psychiatry unit would complement the cardiac unit in the City Park Hospital, the arthritis, haematology and oncology specialisations in Wynberg Hospital and the trauma unit at the new N1 City Hospital.

D & E Health Benefits managing director Robin Melville said the sale of Libertas was good for both groups.

"It is not practical to operate a single hospital in the modern trend towards hospital chains, where there are huge synergies in being part of a group operation.

"We see great advantages in joining forces through Libertas with Clinic Holdings," Mr Melville said.

The hospitals in the Clinic group would be added to the list of preferred hospitals for the medical aid societies managed by D & E, he said.

Clinic Holdings already has a tie-up with Southern Healthcare, jointly owned by Anglo American, Southern Life and United Healthcare of the United States, and with Apex Healthcare Network, a joint venture between African Oxygen and Medic-Clinic. Managed health care contracts between Southern, Clinic and Apex were signed last year.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


11 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 3, 1997


Sports - General;
Council gesture mirrors people's faith in Games


BYLINE: Editorial comment, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Cape Town - The Cape Metropolitan Council has given its tacit endorsement to Cape Town's Olympic vision by contributing R2,5-million to the bid effort.

By all accounts Cape Town's Olympian hopes are well founded. International perceptions, despite the grave imprint made by crime, acknowledge the reality of a city not only technically capable of staging a Games that would do credit to Olympic ideals, but which would provide a beautiful and fitting setting for the first African Olympics in the history of the modern Olympic movement.

Naturally, international perceptions are a little different from South Africa's, focused as we are on the challenges and opportunities of the transition, and of casting the foundation for a stable future.

While the South African Olympic vision is no less romantic, it is meshed with the anxieties and hopes that South Africans have about their future.

Last week's R2,5-million contribution to the bid by the Cape Metropolitan Council has underscored two things.

Firstly, support for the bid spans virtually the entire political spectrum, and the project has the confidence of key decision-makers in the city. Secondly, there is lingering concern about how public resources are used when many pressing causes deserve treasury attention.

What should not be forgotten is the fact that the bid itself is geared to stimulating economic growth which will benefit all communities, considerably increase national and local tax revenues, create thousands of permanent jobs, and affirm South Africa's place in the world market.

But, most importantly, it is for these very reasons that three independent and scientifically conducted surveys have shown overwhelming national and local support for the project. Vigilance is vital, but so, too, is an acknowledgement of the informed optimism that is the essential spirit of South Africa's Olympic plan.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


12 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 3, 1997


Sports - General;
Cape Town 3rd in Games poll


BYLINE: Michael Morris, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Cape Town - A poll among seven of the 11 cities bidding for the 2004 Olympics shows Cape Town sharing third place with Stockholm, after Athens and Rome.

The result is not a certain indication of how the International Olympic Committee's selection college will think in Lausanne on Friday, but it is a significant pointer to international perceptions. 

The survey was conducted by the international sports newsletter, Sport Intern, published and edited by Karl-Heinz Huba, who is reputed to be close to IOC president Juan Samaranch and certainly well-connected within the Olympic fraternity.

Mr Huba asked all 11 candidates to name their short-list choices. Four cities declined to take part. Athens, with seven out of seven, was the only city tipped by all candidates as a certainty on the short list. Rome was next with six votes, and Cape Town and Stockholm third with four votes each.

Istanbul, Rio de Janeiro and Seville (which is generally regarded as a rank outsider) each got two votes, and Buenos Aires got only one. Lille, St Petersburg and San Juan were not mentioned.

In January, Sport Intern's assessment of the rankings also put Cape Town in third place after Athens and Rome.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


13 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 3, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Africa and the good news


BYLINE: Special Correspondent Leon Marshall, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1027 words


 

Cape Town - About three decades ago, the idea surfaced that Africa needed its own news service.

That was at the height of decolonisation, and the thought would have been inspired by politics rather than by any great desire to see a free flow of information.

It took a while, till 1983, for it to come to fruition. The Organisation for Africa Unity then set up the Panafrican News Agency (Pana). It never was a success, though. 

Few of the participating governments paid the money they promised. Its problems were compounded by the bad communications systems in most countries. And making matters no easier was the fact that many of Pana's contributing national news agencies were required to write the news the way their governments liked it.

The sad saga was recalled at a conference held in Johannesburg last week to see if the idea could be revived of setting up an Africa news service, or of finding ways of closer cooperation between the continent's media.

The conference was arranged by the Institute for the Advancement of Journalism and was attended by journalists from several African countries.

The purpose was to discuss the need and feasibility of co-operation rather than to take firm decisions. However, despite being so tentative, it differed in such important ways from the first attempt to launch an all-Africa news agency that it must have a much better chance of success than the OAU attempt ever had.

One difference was that it was journalists, not politicians, talking. The theme, Africans Reporting Africa, might have seemed a bit ideological. But it wasn't. It was a practical question: how to improve coverage of Africa, and how to get an Africa perspective into that coverage.

The few times politics came into the discussion, it was mainly to emphasise the need for more light to be shed on government activities in some countries. Politics tended to be treated with fair cynicism.

One of the questions was whether it might be possible for the OAU's Pana to be restructured into a proper continental news agency.

A Pana representative from Dakar, Senegal, thought it could. He admitted Pana was finished as a state-sponsored news agency. But it was being privatised, and, no longer needing to do the bidding of governments, he thought it had the infrastructure and the experience to be turned into a news agency that could provide the Africa perspective.

A journalist from Tanzania doubted this. In her language, she said, the word for excrement sounded much like Pana. It made her think that, from experience of what the agency used to produce, it should at the very least change its name before expecting other media to join in.

A journalist from Nairobi said many countries couldn't make their own news agencies work, so what about Pana which had to rely on these agencies?

Without quite resolving the Pana question, the search switched to, among others, the Inter-Press Service (IPS), which is based in Harare. It is a subscriber service which disseminates news by E-mail but which also makes use of the Sita communications system, used by airlines, to gather information in parts where there are no telephones.

Another agency is Misa (Media Institute for Southern Africa), which is based in Windhoek. Formed in 1989 to serve southern Africa in virtual opposition to what its founders saw as South Africa's information monopolies, it is now eager to link up with this country's media to expand its service. Its only condition for membership is support for media freedom.

This marks another important difference from the earlier attempts to establish an Africa news service - South Africa's becoming part of the African family. There are sensitivities about the potential for "South African imperialism", in the sense of trying to dominate through the power of its economy and communications system.

At the same time, there can be no doubt that for such a venture to succeed, the South African media will have to take a leading part.

It makes great sense for South Africa's media to do exactly that.

But if any one factor is destined to put Africa in touch with herself and with the world, it is the advent of the Internet. Some of the journalists present told about the problems experienced elsewhere on the continent, of there being no telephone links in places and of lines, where they do exist, sometimes being down for weeks mainly as a result of rains.

Yet, in about 30 countries the media already have E-mail.

Representatives at the conference did not speak quite in terms of Deputy President Thabo Mbeki's visions of an African renaissance, and of the information superhighway.

But several argued that it could make life easier for many people if media link-ups, now becoming so much easier through E-mail, helped shed light on conditions in all parts of the continent.

In this way, it was thought, E-mail, and through that the media, could well become Africa's most potent weapon against ignorance, excesses and maladministration.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


14 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 3, 1997


South Africa;
Boraine's boys: letting the sunlight into the city


BYLINE: Andrea Weiss, Metro Correspondent, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1227 words


 

Cape Town - Cape Town city manager Andrew Boraine and his team of executive directors are a quarter of the way into a 100-day programme, and they're " letting the sunlight in".

That is the expression Mr Boraine chooses to describe the new era of open administration which is dawning down at the civic centre.

On this particular day he has agreed to let me sit in on a management meeting and later accompany the team on a visit to Mitchell's Plain.

At the end of the 100 days in mid-May, he and the team intend to repair to Robben Island to assess whether they have achieved their initial targets - including meetings with ratepayers and civic organisations and visits to all 44 wards while steering the municipality through a tricky restructuring period. 

Having a journalist in a management meeting was definitely a first for the city.

Not that there was any real sunlight shining into the city manager's boardroom last Tuesday morning. The net curtains were drawn and you couldn't see the magnificent backdrop of Table Mountain outside. All you could hear was the thundering rattle of the south-easter which places you firmly in downtown Cape Town. They were intent on getting on with the business of launching the city into a new era and not about to be distracted by one of the physical wonders of the world.

Before the meeting, which starts at 8am, there's the usual scramble for coffee, finalising of reports and dealing with urgent phone calls, interspersed with early morning pleasantries.

"I'm fine," replies Mike Marsden, executive director of municipal services, to one such greeting. "Just pressed between one deadline and the next."

David Daniels, in charge of urban planning and economic development, breezes past, saying: "I'm starting the day with a crisis. It's just a normal day..."

Both men are the "old boys" on the team, having worked for the Cape Town City Council for a number of years.

As it happens, Mr Daniels doesn't join us at the management meeting, which runs almost until 1 pm. He is off to a meeting with Sports Minister Steve Tshwete on issues affecting the Olympic bid.

Another member of the team filters in, Philip van Ryneveld, head of finance. The fifth, Ahmed Vawda, in charge of community development, comes to Cape Town from Gauteng. He is the last to arrive - "still getting used to Cape Town traffic", says Mr Boraine.

Also in the meeting are long-standing city officials, assistant city administrator Gill Bolton, deputy city treasurer Peter Lever, and consultant Nico McLachlan, who is helping the municipality through restructuring.

Mr Lever does a double-take at a journalist's presence, saying: "I hope that you're not going to be in on this one."

But, I'm in. The agreement is that the management team will indicate if they think something is too sensitive for publication and I will treat it as an off-the-record remark. Happily, such occurrences are remarkably few and far between.

First up is Mr Lever's presentation on the budget process. It all takes rather a long time but no-one falters in the attention paid to the broad principles which will have to be followed for the next year's budget and the existing constraints which are being laid before them.

Mr Boraine asks a few key questions. How are projects filtered to avoid vested interest? What hangovers from the past are there? How do you balance the need for redistribution with maintaining reasonable levels of service in more affluent areas? And, finally, does the city have an audit of all existing facilities to avoid an ad-hoc, demand-driven approach?

His questions, and the observations thrown out by other members of the team, give an indication of what strategic management is about - anticipating problems and formulating strategies to deal with them.

The rallying cry of the new team is "do more with less", and it becomes patently clear during the budget discussion that this is precisely what will have to happen.

Next up is a quick briefing on the agendas of the executive committee and full council meeting which takes place later in the week, along with a general observation that the team needs to prevent agendas from becoming an " ad-hoc mish-mash" of items.

Then there's a bit of discussion on the joint operating team, otherwise called JOT, which is described as a "holding operation" and has the job of keeping services going during restructuring until the new second level of management is in place. Mr Marsden and Mr Vawda take responsibility for this.

The troubled community of Mandalay, which has been campaigning on the arrears and service delivery, is also discussed. Mr Boraine observes that there has to be caution in dealing with individual communities in an ad-hoc (there's that word again) way, but adds that the council should be able to respond speedily to some relatively straightforward demands. He also suggests that the council should become more pro-active in anticipating community needs to avoid confrontations.

"I'm not saying we mustn't move swiftly to meet the challenges but our job as strategic managers is to go beyond the ad-hoc approach, the pressure cooker approach. We must respond in the context of similar demands from other areas."

By 11 am we're into a debate on housing. There is agreement that the team will have to set extra time aside to focus on this important issue to begin to formulate a housing strategy for the city.

Around noon, lunch is wheeled in but there's only time to grab a plate and continue the meeting, which ends with a quick briefing by Mr Lever on an Olympic funding conundrum.

By 1pm, the troops have rallied and four of the executive directors meet outside the civic centre. Mr Boraine remains behind because he's technically on paternity leave (as the proud father of a week-old son). This afternoon the team are off to Mitchell's Plain.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


15 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 3, 1997


South Africa;
Crash sparks Kloof Nek fury


BYLINE: Lindsay Barnes, Crime Desk, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Cape Town - Cape Town municipality is being hammered for doing nothing to prevent carnage on the notorious death bend at the bottom of Kloof Nek Road in Tamboerskloof.

Continuing demands by residents for something to be done about the corner, scene of many accidents, have been held up by red tape.

After a huge truck carrying building material ploughed into cars and garden walls at the weekend, injuring several people and causing the temporary closure of the road, Tamboerskloof people are demanding urgent action by the council. 

A stumbling-block to proposed changes to the road system was the restructuring of local government and the resultant rapid loss of staff, a spokesman for the municipal roads department said.

Two possible plans, each costing more than R1-million, would be put to the public for a decision, and it was unlikely that construction would go ahead this year, said Leon Bester, Cape Town municipality's assistant city engineer for roads.

The crash caused traffic mayhem for hours, as officials tried to clear the scene and restore order.

The deadly bend at the intersection has been a hot topic for years, and plans to remove the danger have been in the pipeline since 1992.

Two proposals by the roads department were approved by the provincial roads engineer last April but a decision had not been taken on which was the better, said Mr Bester. It was decided to involve the public in the decision and meetings with the community would be held this year.

He could not say what progress had been made on this.

The first proposal was to widen New Church Street into a two-way street where it splits into Upper Buitengracht and the second was to improve the alignment of Upper Buitengracht and Kloof Nek Road to remove the dangerous 90- degree bend where most of the accidents happen.

"Both plans found favour with the provincial roads engineer, but both would require the acquisition of property," Mr Bester said.

"In terms of safety, the changes are needed. It is a question of which scheme is favoured by the public and it is hoped the public participation exercise would be concluded this year," he said.

Calls for the intersection to be changed have been made since 1988 when there were two accidents in which cars went out of control, one of them hitting a bus.

Five people were killed and at least 10 were injured in the accidents.

In another incident in November 1991, an out-of-control, rubble-laden lorry swept through the intersection and hit five cars, injuring four people.

In April 1992, the then Cape Town City Council's planning committee proposed a plan to alleviate the problem, which involved acquiring seven flats, a cafe, a bottle store and a restaurant.

It involved a partial straightening of the "dog-leg" turns motorists have to make when going from Kloof Nek Road via Burnside Road into Upper Buitengracht Street.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


16 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 3, 1997


Business and Finance;
Mugabe in London For Investment Conference


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

LONDON (PANA) - A tight schedule awaited Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe when he arrived in London on Monday, with the most important of his engagements being the keynote address at the Zimbabwe investment conference to be held in two days.

Heading a powerful delegation comprising eight cabinet ministers and at least 50 top industrialists and business persons, he is expected to articulate measures taken by government to improve the investment environment in his country since the last investment conference in London, in 1994. 

Some 300 British companies have total investments of about 636 million U.S. dollars in Zimbabwe, accounting for about 50,000 jobs. Of this investment, about 909 million dollars was realized after 1994.

Britain remains the largest foreign investor in Zimbabwe and is the country's biggest export market and second largest source of imports.

Mugabe is scheduled to have lunch Wednesday with Queen Elizabeth at Buckingham Palace and hold talks Thursday with Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs Secretary Malcom Rifkind.

On Thursday, he will also hold a meeting with London-based heads of missions of member countries of the Organization of African Unity.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


17 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 3, 1997


South Africa;
Pretoria To Investigate Arms Diversion Claim


BYLINE: Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa (PANA) - South Africa says it will investigate media claims that South African arms sold to Uganda in 1996 were now being used by southern Sudanese anti-government forces.

The Sunday Independent newspaper claimed that South African weapons, including armored vehicles, were in the possession of the Sudanese People's Liberation Army. 

"I do not dismiss the reports," Conventional Arms Control Committee Chairman Kadar Asmal said Sunday. "The South African government takes these kind of allegations seriously and we will certainly investigate this."

He said that the government had investigated similar allegations three or four times and "found them to be without any basis."

The newspaper report quoted a source in Kampala, the Ugandan capital, as saying reports from southern Sudan revealed that anti-tank missiles and a mine-clearer of South African origin were being used by the rebels.

Asmal described the report as sensationalist, pointing out that the newspaper conveniently used an unnamed Ugandan source. "The story is irresponsible and injures our reputation as a responsible arms exporter," he said.

He said that Uganda was a reforming country, and that South Africa had only sold offensive weapons to it -- including troop carriers, mine-clearers and machine guns -- as needed by any government. The Ugandan government knew it had to adhere to the end-user certificate which laid down certain rules and regulations regarding responsible use of the weapons received.

He added that it would be easy for South Africa to determine whether Uganda had breached the end-user certificate. If this were so, said, it would have very serious diplomatic implications for the two countries.

"Uganda is much too responsible for this," he said.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


18 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 3, 1997


Zimbabwe;
Zimbabwe Steps Up Fight For Ivory Trade


BYLINE: Patrice Makova, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 934 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - As Zimbabwe prepares to host the 10th Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species in June, bullish animal rights groups in Western countries are on the offensive against the country's attempts to lobby for resumption in ivory trade.

The groups, who claim to be saviours of wildlife, even attempted to convince about 1,500 delegates from 136 countries to move the conference from Zimbabwe to another country which supports the ban.

They have even extended their pressure to influence donors and Western governments to cut aid to countries defying their dictates.

However, local wildlife experts accuse the groups of putting animals before human beings by imposing strict protectionist measures at the expense of the welfare of the people and the ecosystems. 

Of concern to Zimbabwe is the 1989 ban on international trade in ivory which has also affected Botswana and Namibia, with equally huge populations of elephants.

The three countries have in the past unsuccessfully lobbied for the downgrading of the elephant from Appendix I which bans any trade to Appendix II which allows for regulated trade under strict conditions.

A lifting of the ban during the conference would enable Zimbabwe to resume trade of its stockpile of 40 tons of ivory. This would fetch millions of dollars which could benefit the cash-strapped National Parks Department and help fund other government social welfare programmes.

One of the most vocal opponents of Zimbabwe's lobby is Species Survival Network, a consortium of over 30 non-governmental organizations and leading animal rights groups active worldwide, whose principal function is be to ensure that the 1989 ban stays.

"This they will seek to achieve not by calm reasoning but by whipping up public anger to such a fever pitch that would-be traders will need skins like bull elephant hide if they remain stout in their resolve," warns Africa Resources Trust, a locally-based Southern Africa Conservation Trust.

But, local conservationists and government argue that elephants in most of Southern Africa are not an endangered species and are in fact a danger to the environment and human life because of their large and increasing number.

Communal Areas Management Programme for Indigenous Resources (CAMPFIRE) Director Taparendava Maveneke says although elephants in Africa are not healthy in numbers, Southern African countries' elephant populations are increasing to the extent of threatening the survival of other wild species and the whole ecosystem.

At 65,000, Zimbabwe carries twice the number of elephants it can handle at its optimum level of 35,000. Because of their large numbers, the animals have become a menace.

People are being trampled to death or left maimed for life. Crops and the natural vegetation is destroyed while homes are damaged. As a result people live in constant fear of the animals.

Maveneke said the groups who practice "environmental colonialism" still regard the concept of a dark Africa where Western "romanticists" disguised as tourists visit to have a taste of the "wilderness."

"It's Western romanticism to equate people with animals and they say culling is inhuman because they just want to come here to take photographs of our wildlife and get satisfied while local people are denied of a source of income," he said.

The groups, he added, use the political vote in their countries to influence their governments to withdraw support to organizations which they label as supporters of the killing of animals as if it is murder.

Wildlife experts say since the ban on ivory trade, Zimbabwe has lost 29 million U.S. dollars in revenue and continues to lose 44 million dollars annually.

"Africans are sitting on a huge wealth they cannot market because some Western organizations prioritized animals before humans," Maveneke said.

In desperation, one of the groups is funding a pioneer project in South Africa to control elephant populations through contraception as a humane alternative to culling.

"These people are crazy," said a Harare-based conservationist. "They know that the elephant population is highly unacceptable, but do not want Africans to derive benefits from them and recommend birth control pills rather than simply culling the animals for economic gains."

July Moyo, the secretary for environment and tourism said: "Our message is sovereign countries must be free to decide what to do with their own resources rather than leaving a group of people to impose their own ideas."


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


19 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 3, 1997


Libya;
Libya Says Sanctions Hurt But It Can Persevere


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 680 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya (PANA) - Despite the sufferings Libyans have been experiencing because of United Nations sanctions on the country, Tripoli has no plans to cave in, Foreign Minister Omar Montaser has said.

"When you have something imposed on you, you have to stand firm," he told PANA in Tripoli, at the end of the Organisation of African Unity foreign ministers meeting.

Montaser was referring to the United Nations Security Council imposed sanctions because Libya has refused to hand over two bomb suspects to either Britain or the United States. Washington and London insist that Tripoli surrender the men. But Libya says the trial must take place in a neutral country. 

Both men were accused of involvement in the destruction of a PanAm jetliner in 1988 over Lockerbie, Scotland.

Several organizations, including the O.A.U. the Non-Aligned Movement, the Arab League and the Organization of Islamic Conference have called for the sanctions to be lifted.

In financial terms, Montaser estimated the effects of the sanctions to be in the billions of dollars. "The aggravation has been in the health sector with more people dying because they cannot get medical attention abroad," he said.

There is also a shortage of medical supplies putting to risk the health of Libya's 4.8 million people.

Montaser said the rate of rood accidents had risen resulting in at least 2, 000 deaths since the sanctions were imposed in 1992. Justice Minister Ibrahim Bakir died four years ago in a car accident on the Tripoli-Djerba road, on his way to Tunisia for a conference.

Although the embargo has not affected the quantity of Libyan oil, which has an OPEC quota of 1.2 million barrels of crude a day, Montser said production has become more expensive.

He added that production could be affected in future if the sanctions, which ban importation of required equipment for the oil industry, were not lifted.

On Libya's international image, he said it was obvious his country had been misunderstood by many.

"But we don't care," he said. "Understanding people depends on the frame of reference. They hate you whatever you do. Form an opinion and they will not charge their mind."

On the apparent lack of opposition in Libya, he said the Libya political system was based on one of city states as existed in Athens in ancient Greece. This works through 380 assemblies where people air their views at the local congress and through their representatives at the national congress.

Montaser recommended the system to the rest of Africa, in place of what he said was the failed political party system.

On the Tripoli meeting, at which he was elected chairman, Montaser said it was a success. The meeting, the first major one since the imposition of the United Nations sanctions, brought together some 43 ministers.

"It is a message of the people who meddle in the affairs of Africa that Libya has done what is required of her and that a fair solution should be acceptable to the problem of Lockerbie for the sanctions to be lifted," he said.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


20 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 3, 1997


Liberia;
Liberian Peace Process Irreversible - Minister


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 667 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya (PANA) - Liberian Foreign Minister Monie Captan says the march to peace in his war-torn country is irreversible and nothing should be done to derail the process.

"Previous peace plans never achieved disarmament but thanks of Ecomog (the West African peace monitoring force in Liberia), one will say that 90 percent success has been achieved in the programme set out by the Abuja peace accord, "the minister told PANA in Tripoli, Libya, where he attended the just-ended 65th OAU ministerial council meeting.

"We must maintain the schedule, it will be dangerous to let this chance slip, "said Captan, a political science lecturer at Monrovia University before the war broke out seven years ago in Liberia. 

Expressing optimism over what has been achieved, he said, however, that " after a seven-year war, we may not have a perfect election, but it is a beginning of the return of stability.

The Abuja peace plan provides for national election in Liberia on May 30.

Captan said one of the paramount concerns of his transition government was the repatriation and rehabilitation of Liberian refugees who fled from the war that has killed more than 150,000 people.

"We are 2.5 million and 800,000 are outside Liberia as refugees. Holding a national election with that number of persons outside the country is worrisome, "the minister added.

He appealed to the international community to assist in efforts to repatriate the refugees.

Captan, 35, who was first nominated into the Liberian cabinet as minister of state for presidential affairs in 1995 by the ULIMO faction, is in the current interim government as a representative of Charles Taylor's National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL).

He admitted the tribal factor did fuel, but was never the cause of the war in his country, which in July marks the 150th anniversary of independence, as Africa's oldest republic. Liberia was founded by freed slaves from America in 1847.

Captan said liberians looked forward to a leader who would mould the country's various ethnic groups together.

"Our basic concern is the question of national reconciliation and unification, "he said, adding that this called for efforts to ensure ethnic and geographical balance in the future Liberian army, police and in all spheres of governance.

"We need a government of inclusion, power sharing and equity," Captan noted. Referring to the disappointment of Liberians at the lukewarm attitude of he United States in accelerating the Liberian peace process, the minister said the war had taught his people a big lesson.

"The war has allowed Liberians to appreciate that it has been Africans that have come to their rescue," he said.

While sounding appreciative towards America's support for Ecomog, Captan said in the search for solutions to their future problems, Liberians would be "looking towards Africa and not the US."

The minister was optimistic that once peace has been restored, Liberia could rise and play a key role in Africa."War does not destroy a people's history," he concluded.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


21 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 3, 1997


Nigeria;
Nigeria Suspends Cooperation With Zambia


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Nigeria has suspended its technical assistance to Zambia over Lusaka's condemnation of Abuja's alleged human rights violations, it was reliably learnt here on Monday.

Zambia's foreign affairs ministry spokesperson, Chimbala Meleka, confirmed to PANA on Monday that Nigeria had already withdrawn more than 70 nationals working in the Southern African country under its technical Aid corps scheme. 

The staff withdrawn include 37 science teachers, 10 medical doctors, eight pharmacists and 19 nurse tutors.

Meleka said that the Nigerian military government was not happy with Zambia's stand at the last United Nations General Assembly, where Lusaka voted for a resolution condemning Nigeria's alleged human rights violations.

The foreign ministry spokesperson said that Nigeria had officially informed Zambia of the suspension of aid to Lusaka.

"As you may be aware Zambia, has been consistent with her stand concerning human rights violation in Nigeria. Apart from the UN meeting, Zambia had also in 1995 at the Commonwealth Summit, in New Zealand, strongly condemned Nigeria's human rights abuses and this has displeased Nigeria which is now hitting back on Zambia," Meleka told PANA.

22 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 4, 1997


Tanzania;
Trade Account Improves Balance Of Payments


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1300 words


 

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania (PANA) - Tanzania recorded a trade deficit of USD 21.1 million in January 1997, reflecting a decrease of 77.8 percent when compared with the deficit of USD 94.9 million recorded during the corresponding month last year.

The improvement in the trade account was due to an increase in export earnings, reinforced by a decrease in the import bill during the month, according to the Bank of Tanzania review for January.

Export earnings during the month amounted to USD 100 million, 62.4 percent higher than USD 61.6 million recorded the same month last year. 

Good performance of both traditional and non-traditional exports accounted for the increased earnings, according to the review.

Traditional export receipts recorded an increase of 38.9 percent, from USD 47.7 million in January, 1996 to USD 66.2 million during the period under review.

The increase was largely on account of higher export volumes of traditional crops, chiefly coffee, cotton, sisal, tea, tobacco and cashew nuts.

All categories of non-traditional exports, with the exception of petroleum products, registered increases when compared with their respective levels recorded in 1996.

On imports, the bank's review shows that the import bill for January 1997 dropped by 22.6 percent for USD 121.1 million in comparison to USD 156.5 million incurred in January 1996.

All imports during the months of either capital goods, intermediate or consumer goods, decreased.

Capital goods went down by 26.5 percent, from USD 63 million to USD 46.3 million.

While intermediate goods contracted by 19.8 percent from USD 53.9 million to USD 43.2 million, the bill for consumer goods diminished by 20.8 percent from USD 39.9 million to USD 31.6 million.

However, capital goods continued to dominate the import sector with a 39.2 percent share of the total bill. Intermediate and consumer goods categories followed, with 35.7 percent and 26.1 percent shares respectively.

Meanwhile, Tanzanians had to dig deeper into their pockets in January as consumer prices shot up.

The National Consumer Price Index shows prices rose by 5.9 percent during the month.

But Annual rate of inflation dropped from 15.4 percent in December 1996, to 14 percent in January 1997. The decline was mainly due to relatively low price changes in food items.

The food group index accounts for 71 percent of total weight in the consumer basket.

The rents group recorded the highest growth of 27.5 percent followed by furniture and household equipment and recreation and entertainment which registered increases of 19.6 percent and 18.2 percent respectively.

Lowest rates of less than 10 percent increases were in miscellaneous goods and services, education and household operations and maintenance groups.

According to the Bank of Tanzania review for January, the rate of inflation for the year ending the same month represents an improvement of 11.1 percentage points if compared with the inflation rate of 25.1 percent in January, 1996.

In view of the anti-inflationary monetary and fiscal policy measures being pursued by the central bank and the government, the inflation rate is expected to decelerate to 10 percent by end of June this year.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


23 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 4, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Perfect O.A.U Session in Tripoli, But Problems Persist


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1094 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya (PANA) - A record 43 ministers attended the just-ended 65th ministerial council meeting in Tripoli, which hosted the first of such sessions to be held outside the Addis Ababa-based headquarters of the Organization of African Unity (O.A.U).

For Libyans, the presence of an estimated 2,000 people in their capital was a comforting relief from the international isolation arising from United Nations sanctions, which have been on since 1992.

Most delegates commended Tripoli for its near-flawless organisation of the five-day meeting, after an O.A.U summit at the same venue twice failed to hold in 1982 for lack of quorum.

But, beyond the impressive attendance and the predictable expression of solidarity with Libya, it is arguable whether or not the meeting managed to scratch, even superficially, Africa's many daunting political and socio- economic problems. 

While previous such sessions were devoted to the continental body's budgetary and administrative issues, the Tripoli meeting was from the onset bogged down by political crises, especially the the grave situation in eastern Zaire. Parties to the dispute, mainly Zaire and its neighbors Rwanda and Uganda, came prepared, yielding no ground to pleas from other delegates for caution.

The conflict, which continues to produce refugees and other related humanitarian and security problems, has so far defied sub-regional and international mediation.

As the Tripoli meeting was in progress, South Africa was hosting Zaire rebel leader Laurent Kabila. This infuriated Zaire which called it a " legitimization" of the rebellion. Zaire maintained this posture despite assurances to the council by South African Foreign Minister Alfred Nzo that Pretoria had no intention of undermining the continent's efforts to solve the Great Lakes dispute.

After angry exchanges between concerned delegates, the council in its final declaration chose the easy way out by urging cessation of hostilities in the region. It also called on all "foreign troops including mercenaries" to pull out of the country.

However, by far the only consensus on the matter was the council's decision to convene an extra-ordinary summit of the O.A.U.'s Central Organ on Conflict Prevention, Management and Resolution to address the issue. That summit takes place in Lome, Togo, March 25-26. The event should involve all parties to the dispute as well as countries and organizations that have been involved in peacemaking effort.

On Burundi, the council endorsed the submission of the country's foreign minister, Luc Rukingana, that the sanctions imposed on his country be lifted, because of the progress in restoring peace in the country, since the July 1996 coup that returned Maj. Pierre Buyoya to power.

Council also noted the progress in Liberia and Sierra Leone but urged that the peace efforts in the West African countries sustained to stem possible return to hostilities.

Similarly with Angola, council appealed to the international community to continue providing humanitarian assistance.

Unita and the Luanda government were also urged to move faster at forming a government of national unity to end the 30-year-old civil strife in the country. Not much could be said on the horn of Africa, with Somalia's seat still vacant at the O.A.U. However, the factions were asked to abandon hostility and seek peace.

Morocco also remains absent from the O.A.U. over the body's recognition of Western Sahara as a state called the Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic. Rabat pulled out of the continental body because of this recognition.

However, following the re-establishment of Morocco's relations with Ethiopia -- which recognizes the Sahrawi, O.A.U. officials expressed hope that Rabat would rejoin the continental body.

As expected, the council declared its strong support for Libya and urged the lifting of the U.N. sanctions on the north African country.

On the financial level, the O.A.U. secretariat was richer by some three million U.S. dollars. This came in contributions paid by members in what has become a practice by members to pay during scheduled meetings to avoid sanctions.

But observers denounced the practice, which they said often starved the body of needed funds to carry out its obligations.

As at the last count, the organisation was still owed some 36 million dollars in outstanding contributions. Its Special Peace Fund has only three million dollars left.

The meeting again exposed the division among members when it comes to presenting a common front. In elections at international organizations, such as the International Civil Aviation Association, where Africa was expected to present a common candidate, several countries chose to forward individual candidates with the likelihood that none would get the post.

The financial crisis of the Pan African News Agency also came up for discussion. O.A.U. Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim informed council that the Dakar-based news agency could fold anytime due to non-payment of contributions, with arrears totalling some 30 million dollars.

The meeting ended after fixing its next session in May, ahead of the O.A.U. 's 33rd summit in Harare, Zimbabwe, June 2-4.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


24 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 4, 1997


Business and Finance;
182 State Firms Divested In Ghana


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - A total of 182 state-owned enterprises were divested in Ghana by the end of last year, Siegfried Sedziefa, Public Relations Manager of the Divestiture Implementation Committee, said in Accra Monday.

Speaking to the Ghana News Agency (GNA) at the committee's stand at the Indutech '97 fair grounds, Sedziefa said 18 of the divested companies were joint ventures. 

He said the divestiture programme is an ambitious attempt to inject private capital and technology into the economy.

It is also to reduce the size of public sector and improve the performance of SOEs by mobilizing private sector management. He said Ghanaian and foreign firms not on the register were being invited to participate in the programme.

Such firms should submit the full name of their firms, addresses and contact details, date of establishment, and list of directors and shareholders or partners, he said.

They should also submit the names and addresses of bankers and auditors, and a statement of their firm's capabilities. The applications are to be submitted with a non-refundable fee of 50,000 cedis for Ghanaian companies and 100,000 dollars for foreign companies.

Sedziefa said successful firms would be invited for negotiations, adding that consultancy was available.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


25 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 4, 1997


Business and Finance;
Zimbabwe's Gold Output Improving


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Gold production in Zimbabwe exceeded two tons in January amid signs that the price of the yellow mineral has begun to rise after falling to an all-time low in 1996.

Production figures for February were still being compiled, but an official at the Chamber of Mines said on Tuesday it would not be surprising if output was better than the same month in 1996. 

The fall in the gold price, which at one stage sunk to a low of 337 U.S. dollars, has been blamed for the marginal increase in output registered in the country in 1996.

Figures released last week showed that gold production in 1996 reached 24.7 tons worth 276 million dollars, compared with 24.34 tons mined in 1995, then valued at 236 million dollars.

An official of the Chamber of Mines said latest market intelligence showed that the gold price had recovered from its depressed levels in 1996.

"It is improving and like last year, nobody knows why it is going up just as nobody really knew why it dropped last year," the official said.

"There must be a reason but it is not readily apparent," he added.

The decline in the gold price in 1996 resulted in many mines in Zimbabwe scaling-down operations so to cut costs and remain profitable.

A leading producer, Falgold, recently told shareholders that it had been forced to curtail operations because of the impact of the low price.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


26 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 4, 1997


Libya;
Khadafi, Libya's Enigmatic Leader The West Loves To Hate


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 814 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya (PANA) - If out-spoken Libyan leader Muammar Khadafi had his way, Africa would have little or nothing to do with the West for enslaving the black man and refusing to respect his dignity.

He considers as sheer arrogance the unending tension between the white people and their black counterparts over genetic supremacy.

"Often people talk about a white cow and a black cow but they all produce white milk," the Libyan leader told delegates at the just ended 65th O.A.U. ministerial council meeting during a banquet he hosted for them in Tripoli.

He has nothing but contempt for racist apostles, saying the notion had a historical background in the colonization of Africa by European countries. And despite all pretensions to the contrary, Khadafi says this obnoxious concept has refused to disappear. 

"The West views us as slaves only because of our dark or black complexion," he said. "The racists have not rid themselves of this mentality and this will not change."

The Libyan leader would turn to the O.A.U. Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim and remind him the "colonial masters want us to wear ties and suits to make us acceptable."

"With the hostile mentality," he said, "they continue to persist in trying to dominate and subjugate others."

To the outside world, Khadafi cuts the figure of a controversial and largely misunderstood leader.

The 1969 revolution that swept him to power with a government of socialist coloration put him at loggerheads with the West, which accuses Libya of exporting terrorism. Also mooted is the allegation out of fear in European capitals that Tripoli could spread islam at a rate that posed a threat to Western ideals and democracy.

The tension between Khadafi and the West aggravated with the collapse of the Soviet Union, a former ally. Yet the Libyan leader is unbowed and says he owes the West no apology for practicing a system of government he considers best suited to his people.

The system, laid out in his 139-page "Green Book," deals with "solution of economic problems of socialism" and the "social basis of the third universal theory."

In the three-part volume, Khadafi argues that most political systems in the world today were dictatorships "under the cover of false democracy."

The Libyan leader is never minces words in his condemnation of what he considers the duplicity by the West. His two hour speech was no exception.

"Authority", he said "derives from the people," adding that there was no justification for Western countries that practice largely two party systems of government to "impose multiparty system on Africa."

He said "America with about 250 million people operates a two-party system, the same with Britain, but they want Zaire, Algeria (with smaller population), to have many parties with every tribe struggling to have its own party." The result was anarchy.

"I challenge anyone to interfere and ask America or Britain to change their systems of government," he said. "We are not teenagers for the U.S. to come and solve our problems in Somalia and Liberia," he warned, adding that America created the crises in the first peace.

Khadafi said "Africans must solve Africa's problem and we must shut the door on external interference."

Tripoli remains geographically close but politically far from Europe, and this, at great cost to Libya.

How long the country and its people can withstand the orchestrated Western propaganda and virulent onslaught remains to be seen. The question of succession also remains unresolved for now.

At the moment, Libya manifests no visible opposition to the leader of the 1969 revolution, but experts on North African politics postulate that what becomes of the oil-rich country after khadafi could be anybody's guess in a unipolar world where the U.S. is the sole superpower.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


27 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 4, 1997


Business and Finance;
Trading Improves On Ghana Stock Exchange


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - Trading on the Ghana Stock Exchange (GSE) ended Monday on an improved session with total volume traded appreciating.

Total shares went up to 366,340 -- a significant improvement from the 52, 470 shares sold at the last session. 

The GSE All-Share Index gained 0.43 points to open the week at 359.39, up from 358.96.

Shares on offer stood at 827,640 compared to bids of 543,220.

Market capitalization finished higher at 2,747.61 billion cedis as against Friday's close of 2,736.50 billion cedis.

All CFAO and GGL shares on offer were sold: 340,800 from CFAO and 23,300 for GGL.

On the broader market there were two gainers and one loser.

Ashanti Goldfields Company (AGC) gained 100 cedis to end at 21,200 cedis while UNILEVER appreciated by five cedis to close at 775 cedis.

Aluworks was the sole loser, dipping by five cedis to open the week at 1, 340 cedis.

Meanwhile, the following were the average inter-bank exchange rates for Monday, March 3, issued by the Ghana Association of Bankers:

28 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 5, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
WFP Update on Great Lakes Region


BYLINE: World Food Programme


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 974 words


 

Rome - Out of four WFP staff that were threatened with expulsion from Zaire yesterday, three were planned to leave morning 6 March for Brazzaville while a fourth got permission to stay on. Four remaining International Staff of WFP, all in Kinshasa, will support, out of the capital, ongoing distribution programmes in Kisangani and Punia assisted by National Staff and the Catholic Mission in Kisangani.

KISANGANI

As Wednesday afternoon all was calm in Kisangani.

Food distributions to IDP's, estimated to number 35.000, and to small groups of refugees continued in Kisangani, carried out by National Staff of WFP in collaboration with The Catholic Mission. 

The WFP food stock position in Kisangani was (as of the 4th of March): 409 MT

WFP planned to do assessments out of Kisangani to Ubundu and to continue with airlifting food commodities to Punia using small aircraft. One Andover, capacity 6 MT, one Aztec, capacity 5 passengers and one DC3, capacity 3 MT were still stationed in Kisangani.

PUNIA

Since the evacuation of International Staff on Saturday 1st of March, WFP managed to airlift 12 MT of food commodities to Punia. The mission, comprised of the Dutch Minister for Development Co-operation and head of UN agencies Zaire, that visited Punia on the 5th of march estimated the refugee population to number between 4 and 5.000. The 10.000 refugees, spotted by overflights earlier this week, had not arrived in Punia.

UBUNDU

No reports had been received yet of refugees that had arrived in Ubundu. The airstrip of Ubundu has been rehabilitated 8 months ago by the Catholic Mission in Kisangani and can receive DC3 aircraft. The strip is located 3 KM East of the river Zaire. WFP has planned an assessment of the runway during the coming days. WFP has been utilising Ubundu as a transit point for food from Lubumbashi/Kindu upto the last week of February.

**************

SOUTH SUDAN

During the last week in February approximately 1000 Sudanese refugees returned from Zaire. Together with 2000 Sudanese returnees that returned in January the returnees were accommodated in 3 camps near Maridi, 40 km from the Zaire-Sudan border. The 3000 returnees were reported to have arrived from Dungu and Niangara in North-east Zaire. WFP/OLS supplied a 26 food ration to the returnees.

There were no reports of an influx of Zairian and Rwandan refugees into Sudan.

CENTRAL AFRICAN REPUBLIC

WFP CAR reported that a few hundred refugees from Zaire had arrived in the area between Bangassou and Rafai in CAR, 400 km North west of Buta in Zaire. The refugees reported to have arrived from Bondo, a place in Zaire halfway between Buta and Bangassou. Early February 400 Sudanese refugees arrived at Raifa coming from Zaire.

ZAMBIA

Approximately 8000 Zairian refugees arrived in Northern Zambia during the past few weeks entering Mpulungu via Lake Tanganyika. They were relocated in Mbala and Kasama. WFP prepositioned 400 MT of Food Commodities in Kigoma for onward transport by barge to Zambia. Possibilities for local purchase of food commodities was under investigation by WFP. WFP airlifted on the 5th of March 11 MT of non-food commodities for UNHCR from Mwanza to Kasama.

**************

WFP LOGISTICS AND FOOD MOVEMENTS

FROM THE EAST:

An Ilyushin 76 was kept stand by in Mwanza, Tanzania to resume airlift to Zaire (the Eastern route), when circumstances would permit.

FROM THE SOUTH:

From the Southern route (rail from Zambia-Lubumbashi-Kindu, barge Kindu- Ubundu and rail Ubundu-Kisangani) food arrived in Kisangani, 198 MT of Maize, the 28th of February. Due to the security problems in Kindu earlier on, 765 MT of Maize was re-routed in Kamina and will reach Ilebo via Kananga by rail for onward transport by barge via Kasai and Zaire river to Kisangani. Transport of another 500 MT of Maize was kept on hold in Lubumbashi awaiting developments in the country.

FROM THE WEST:

Shipment from the Western route (sea from South-Africa to ports on Zaire and Congo, rail to Kinshasa and Brazzaville, barge to Kisangani) reached ports of Zaire and Congo. 1862 MT of Maize was offloaded in Matadi and 1910 MT in Pointe Noire.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

29 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 5, 1997


East Africa;
Emergency Update No. 118 on the Great Lakes (03/05)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1374 words


 

Nairobi - The government of Zaire called today for the urgent implementation of a UN peace plan calling for a ceasefire and the withdrawal of foreign forces from its soil. A government statement in Kinshasa urged the United Nations to immediately send in international monitors to oversee the withdrawal of foreign troops. The statement followed an announcment in Paris by Zaire's Foreign Minister Gerard Kamanda Wa Kamanda that President Mobutu Sese Seko and the Zairean government had accepted a peace plan proposed by Mohamed Sahnoun, Joint OAU/UN Special Representative for the Great Lakes Region.

The peace plan was endorsed by the United Nations Security Council on February 18 (see IRIN Update 104). The five points call for:

o immediate cessation of hostilities o withdrawal of all external forces, including mercenaries o reaffirmation of respect for the national sovereignty and the territorial integrity of Zaire and other states of the Great Lakes region o protection and security for all refugees and displaced persons and facilitation of access for humanitarian assistance o rapid and peaceful settlement of the crisis through dialogue, the electoral process and the convening of an international conference of peace, security and development in the Great Lakes region 

* The Regional Humanitarian Coordinators Office (RHCO) in Nairobi reports only 9 UN staff are affected by the expulsion order in Zaire, out of the 19 who were evacuated from Kisangani to Kinshasa on Saturday, March 1. According to RHCO, the government order affects UN staff who were based in Kisangani and not those who were on temporary mission. Earlier reports from Kinshasa that three international staff had already left by barge were proved unfounded. International staff affected are preparing to leave. Two NGO members potentially affected by the expulsion statement from the Zairean government said today their organisations had received no direct order to leave.

* Humanitarian sources report that some local staff left in Kisangani have resigned from international organisations over the last few days because they feel "vulnerable to be associated with the UN".

* A government statement broadcast by Zairean state radio said that 25,000 civilians have been murdered since the rebel Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire (ADFL) took over Tingi-Tingi camps in eastern Zaire. According to the government statement, broadcast yesterday, the "precipitous departure of these humanitarian workers from the Tingi-Tingi camp and the town of Kisangani.....is considered by the government to be directly responsible for the slaughter which took place in less than 48 hours" . There has been no independent confirmation of this.

* UNICEF is "extremely concerned" about some 600 children who were on therapeutic feeding before Tingi-Tingi camps dispersed, and another 2,500 on supplementary feeding. Journalists reported on Monday refugees heading towards Kisangani, some 150 kilometers west of the provincial capital - but said the leaders of the column were the fittest. Pictures of refugees on the road show them with swollen feet and in poor condition.

* Quoting a regional military source - who has provided accurate information on rebel movements to date - Reuters says that the ADFL are beseiging Kisangani on three fronts, and that the city could fall in days. The source said rebels were within range of Kisangani on two axis beyond the northern town of Bafwasende, and also advancing on the Lubutu-Kisangani road. The source said the rebels were also gaining ground in mineral-rich Shaba province, with recent gains in Kabolo and Manono - where the ADFL reportedly encounter little resistence.

* Defeated Zairean soldiers surrendered their weapons to rebels today in Kindu, as the ADFL began setting up a new administration, reports Reuters from Kindu. The capture of Kindu last week gives the rebels a key transport hub on the Zaire river and the northernmost working station on a rail line to South Africa. It also has a large airport.

* At least twenty people have died in two separate attacks in Rwanda since last week, report AFP. In the first attack, in Rushashi area near Kigali, ten people died and 21 were injured (see IRIN Update 116). A second attack took place on Sunday or Monday in the northwest region of Ruhengeri, aid officials said. Radio Rwanda did not report the two attacks but broadcast death notices that included one family losing four sons and another eight of its members.

* According to a report by the United Nations Human Rights Operation in Rwanda, the human rights situation in Rwanda has "drastically deteriorated" since the begining of January 1997 - following the repatriation of more than a million people, many of whom were believed to be directly involved in the 1994 genocide. In January, UNHRFOR received reports of the killings of at least 424 persons in 55 incidents; the report said it "represented the highest number of killings since the begining of 1996".

According to the report, the human rights situation is particularly bad in the four prefectures bordering Zaire. In January, of the 424 reported killings, 311 took place in the four prefectures bordering Zaire. Of the 311 killings, 228 were reported in the Ruhengeri Prefecture. According to UNHRFOR, the 424 victims included 78 returnees, 40 genocide survivors and their associates, 14 detainees, and 13 local officials. In January, at least 163 of the 424 killings were reported to be the responsibility of the state, including members of the RPA; 42 were attributed to members of the ex-FAR and militia. UNHRFOR said the deteriorating security situation had also been marked by number of fatal attacks against expatriates working in Rwanda, including the killing of five UNHRFOR staff members, and that human rights activities had been "drastically reduced". UNHRFOR said it had been unable to carry out full monitoring activities during the reporting period.

* The Secretary-General of the United Nations, Kofi Annan, announced he had accepted with regret the resignation, effective March 15, of Jose Ayala-Lasso, High Commissioner for Human Rights. Mr Lasso is to become Minister for Foreign Affairs of Ecuador. The Secretary General said he had appointed ad interim and with immediate effect, Ralph Zacklin, Director of the Office of the Legal Counsel and Deputy to the Under-Secretary-General for Legal Affairs, as Officer-in-Charge during the selection process for a new High Commissioner for Human Rights.

(IRIN erroneously reported - on the basis of information given by Kinshasa - that the Governor of Kisangani had flown to Kinshasa. We apologise to our readers for this error in update 117)

Nairobi, 5 March 1997, 19:35 GMT

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies.
