30 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 5, 1997


Sports - General;
Mac, Symcox to the rescue


BYLINE: John Freudenberg, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1080 words


 

Cape Town - The return of all-rounder Brian McMillan and the addition of a second spinner, most likely Pat Symcox, are vital if South Africa are to have any chance of bouncing back in the series after yesterday's devastating innings and 196-run defeat to Australia in the first test.

South Africa's heaviest loss in the post-isolation era should not provoke panic within Peter Pollock's selection panel, because wholesale changes are not the answer in preventing another whitewash in the second test starting in Port Elizabeth next Friday.

But the batting badly needs some stability and the attack needs more variety on a St George's Park pitch which promises to be of even less help to South Africa's pacemen than the Wanderers was.

McMillan, who missed the first test because of an ankle injury, will have to prove his fitness for Western Province in their Supersport Series match against Natal at Newlands this weekend and should he come through, the selectors shouldn't hesitate to recall him at the expense of Jonty Rhodes at No 6. 

McMillan, with a test average of 42, as opposed to Rhodes' 30, has played a stabilising role in the middle-order, although he has not been comfortable against spin in the past.

The top-order, though, is as unsettled as it's ever been. The form of Gary Kirsten is a big worry, and the question of whether to stick with Andrew Hudson or give Adam Bacher a run wasn't resolved at the Wanderers.

Jacques Kallis, who top-scored with a three-hour 39 in South Africa's disastrous second-innings of 130, deserves a run at No 3 for the remainder of the series but it may take some time for him to take that step up another level. The big mistake the selectors made was not to choose him for the home series against India to allow him to settle into the pivotal position ahead of the tougher Australian contest.

Bacher was chosen at No 3 against India but opening is his preferred role and long-term destiny. Had Kallis been given a decent run instead in a position which has been earmarked for him for some time, the top-order may have had a more solid look by now.

Before the series, many observers believed South Africa had the edge in the pace department but on pitches lacking pace and bounce, that perceived advantage - and Australia's Glenn McGrath and Jason Gillespie were certainly more disciplined at the Wanderers - is negated.

Unless the St George's Park pitch for the second test plays markedly out of character, another spinner in tandem with Paul Adams would seem a necessity.

The fact that Symcox would turn the ball away from the Australian left- handed batsmen might give him the nod for what would be his first test at home.

There is also a good case for Transvaal's Clive Eksteen, the leading wicket- taker in provincial competition this season with 36 scalps.

The second spinner would have to come in at the expense of either Shaun Pollock or Lance Klusener, both of whom lacked variation at the Wanderers. Pollock also seems to have lost a yard of pace since returning from an ankle injury at the beginning of the season.

In both cases, though, the South African selectors should reverse their decision to rest them from the Natal side to play Western Province. They may have to put in noteworthy performances at Newlands to guarantee their test places.

Although Fanie de Villiers might be a long shot because he has been out with injury for several weeks, his cunning swing bowling, experience and ability to conjure something out of nothing was the kind of variation which was lacking at the Wanderers.

Should he play for Northern Transvaal against Transvaal at Centurion Park this weekend - Northerns had not yet finalised their side - then the selectors should at least monitor his fitness.

At this stage of the series, the United Cricket Board must be wishing they had scheduled a test at Kingsmead where South Africa's pacemen may have had a chance.

In truth, though, this Australian team looked so accomplished in all departments of the game during the past five days that the condition of the pitch seems irrelevant.

As far as the Australians are concerned Shane Warne's four-wicket haul at the Wanderers in his 50th test match should leave few in doubt that the masterful leg-spinner is almost back to his best after finger surgery last year had left his career in the balance.

Before the Australians arrived in this country, doubts were raised in South Africa as to whether Warne was the same bowler as the cocky magician who weaved his spell to take 33 wickets in six tests against Kepler Wessels' team in 1993-94.

Although he took 22 wickets in five tests against the West Indies this season, he hadn't taken the spectacular seven or eight-wicket hauls which had been his hallmark. But the only reason he didn't take a bagful at the Wanderers yesterday was because his spin partner Michael Bevan was "taking a lot of Shane's wickets at the tail" as Aussie captain Mark Taylor put it.

Bevan may have wrapped up the tail in next to no time but Warne snared the big fish using his full array of tricks with his leg-break, wrong-un, top- spinner and flipper.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


31 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 5, 1997


Business and Finance;
Black empowerment critics slammed


BYLINE: Business Reporter, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Cape Town - Metropolitan Life chairman Nthato Motlana yesterday hit back at criticism that he and other blacks in high profile positions had not done enough for advancing black empowerment.

Speaking at Metropolitan Life's (Metlife) annual meeting, Dr Motlana pointed out that 38 percent of Metlife's middle management was black - substantially higher than any other company in the South African financial services sector. 

In addition to this, he said, 20 percent of Metlife's senior management and 57 percent of supervisory management was black.

"It is not only the highly visible positions where we are seeking black incumbents, but at every level of decision-making in our business," Dr Motlana said.

Metlife had also been the financier of three black businesses within the National Empowerment Consortium, which acquired Anglo American's 35 percent stake in Johnnic last October.

Dr Motlana sharply criticised the country's efforts in curtailing Aids.

"I will tell you quite openly that I am appalled by the paucity of this country's effort in countering Aids. I am referring not only to Government, but also to our NGOs and the private sector. Neither sufficient money nor attention is being given to the problem."

He also criticised the proposed legislation to prohibit the pre-employment test for HIV infection.

"My quarrel is that the proposed Act is rather short-sighted in its thinking. Such legislation will only entrench the stigmatisation of Aids."

He said HIV-infected persons were already sufficiently protected by the Labour Relations Act which specified that employers may not unfairly discriminate against job applicants with disabilities.

"It is clear that most HIV-infected persons can remain healthy for a significant period of time and cannot, therefore, be prohibited from working."

Dr Motlana was, however, not opposed to pre-benefit medical testing for staff benefits, such as group life insurance.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


32 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 5, 1997


South Africa;
South Africa can't deport freed sex offender


BYLINE: Lindsay Barnes, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Cape Town - Controversial sex offender Dennis Hundermark, deported from Britain and now in Cape Town, cannot be deported as he has South African citizenship.

Department of Home Affairs spokesman Hennie Meyer confirmed Mr Hundermark's citizenship, but said he could be extradited if a warrant for his arrest was issued in another country. 

Mr Hundermark was not wanted on a warrant elsewhere, said Superintendent Jan Swart, head of the Child Protection Unit in Cape Town.

British authorities did not release Mr Hundermark from prison in order to deport him, said Andrew Noble, British High Commission press spokesman.

Mr Hundermark had completed about half of his 16-month sentence in Britain for a sex-related offence.

He was granted the normal remission of sentence for the remaining eight months.

He had been kept in custody for several months while he was awaiting trial and this period counted as part of the sentence, Mr Noble said.

Mr Hundermark was arrested in June, convicted on November 1 and released on February 22.

He was deported to South Africa on the recommendation of the trial judge. Hundermark holds dual South African and Zimbabwean citizenship and he elected to be returned to South Africa.

His deportation from Britain was standard procedure for a non-citizen who had committed a crime and had completed his sentence, Mr Noble said.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


33 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 5, 1997


South Africa;
Kloof Nek: DP calls for urgent traffic probe


BYLINE: Lindsay Barnes, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Cape Town - Traffic systems in Cape Town's City Bowl area need to be reviewed urgently if such serious hazards as the dreaded intersection of New Church Street and Kloof Nek Road are to be eliminated.

This is the view of Democratic Party city councillor Belinda Walker, who serves on the urban planning committee.

She said upgrading the intersection had been the ward's priority for years, but no solution had been found. 

In the latest accident at the weekend, a heavily laden lorry smashed into cars and walls near the intersection.

The municipality has been accused of dragging its feet on the project.

Two proposals for upgrading the intersection were approved by the provincial roads engineer last April. Almost a year later, a public meeting is planned to discuss them.

The first proposal is that Kloof Nek Road and Upper Buitengracht Street be realigned to ease the 90-degree bend.

The second involves widening New Church Street for two-way traffic.

Many top civil engineers in Cape Town were available to undertake the urgent work immediately, said Hillel Turok of the Camps Bay Ratepayers Association's planning committee.

"This horrible corner is a longstanding problem and creates a bumper-to- bumper build-up every morning and every evening. Council must stop dragging its feet and do the job," he said.

He questioned the need to consult residents on the proposals, as people generally were not authorities on road planning and for this reason, civil engineers should look into the plans, he said.

Leon Markovitz, chairman of the municipality's urban planning committee, said something needed to be done urgently about the intersection, but there were many other problem spots in Cape Town, especially in areas where money had not been spent on traffic control.

"We have been in a political situation of change, and while this is not necessarily an excuse for a delay, it's not unusual for it to take that period of time," he said.

"Sometimes an accident like this highlights a particular problem and we need to push it," said Mr Markovitz.

Possible solutions to the city's traffic congestion were more parking zones and better-quality public transport.

Meanwhile, a 12-month transportation study of the inner city was due for completion in June, said Basil Tommy, acting planning co-ordinator of the municipality.

The study, which cost more than R1 million, looked into ways of alleviating traffic congestion and included the use of buses, trains and taxis.

> A report in Monday's Cape Argus on the weekend accident at the New Church Street and Kloof Nek Road intersection incorrectly stated that a red Mazda 323 drove the wrong way along a one-way road and crashed into a large truck.

In fact, the truck drove the wrong way down New Church Street and side- swiped the Mazda, said the car's owner, Mary Ann Pote.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


34 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 5, 1997


Business and Finance;
Now Cape TV battle begins


BYLINE: Andrea Weiss and Joseph Aranes, Staff Reporters, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 760 words


 

Cape Town - Cape Town is locked in a battle to get its own television station instead of having yet another national station forced down its throat.

The fight is on for the all-important new private television licence, after the Independent Broadcasting Authority this week allocated seven new radio licences.

But the prospect of a 24-hour regional television station could be lost to the Western Cape if the IBA goes ahead with plans to issue yet another national licence. 

The people of the Western Cape are being asked to rally behind a campaign to persuade the authority that viewers are tired of what is being dished up nationally and want their own station.

They have less than a fortnight to achieve this, as the authority is to hold hearings in Cape Town later this month to hear objections to its decision to award another national TV licence by October.

The decision to go for another national licence is based on "confidential" research which has not been made available to applicants for a regional licence.

It is a turnaround from earlier plans to create a network of regional television stations focusing on each of the main urban areas of Cape Town, Durban and Johannesburg.

IBA co-chairman Peter de Klerk said the debate on whether to opt for national or regional television was still open and a decision would be taken only after representations by interested groups were made at the public hearings.

Me De Klerk said this decision would have to take into account the viability of a national station versus regional ones, as well as the country's growth rate and the amount of money available for advertising support.

"But we are still a long way off making that decision and will start our deliberations only after the public hearings. Then we will draft a policy which will be our point of reference in determining whether a national channel or a network of regional channels is best," he said.

Leading the campaign for a Western Cape TV station is Channel 6, a Cape consortium in which Cape Newspapers holds a share of less than 15 percent, the limit set for cross-media ownership.

A petition to raise support for regional television is to be circulated at the Cape Argus/Pick 'n Pay Cycle Tour on Sunday and the Life Cycle exhibition at the Good Hope Centre.

The following weekend, Channel 6 aims to take the campaign to shopping centres, asking Western Cape viewers to make their feelings known to the IBA. Channel 6 has been established as a company, with backing from Cape-based companies, to bid for a regional licence which ideally would operate 24-hours a day and include prime-time news and actuality programmes covering the Western Cape in Afrikaans, English and Xhosa.

Other components would include entertainment, sport, weather, game shows, drama, business and crime coverage.

Managing director Glynn O'Leary said he believed the only way television could meet the needs of viewers was through regional TV, which would satisfy language demands and increase access.

He said there was definitely enough advertising money available to support regional television, which could cater for smaller businesses or companies aiming at specific target markets.

A requirement of the Independent Broadcasting Authority Act was that bidders for a licence should prove a need, support and demand for a proposed service.

The campaign aims to find out whether this is true of the Western Cape.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


35 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 5, 1997


Libya;
Amnesty Condemns Libyan Executions


BYLINE: Amnesty International


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

London - Amnesty International strongly condemns the execution yesterday of eight men in Libya. The eight people, six senior army officers and two civilians, were executed in the morning of 2 January 1997.

"These executions are an outrage," Amnesty International said today. "From the moment of their arrest more than three years ago their case has been shrouded in secrecy. They have been held in unknown locations all that time, completely cut off from their families and the outside world, and every trial hearing has been held in camera." 

The six army officers were identified as Colonel Miftah Qarrum al-Wirfalli, Colonel Mostafa Abu al-Qassim Masud al-Kikli, Lieutenant-Colonel Saad Saleh Farag, Major Khalil Salam Mohammad al-Jidiq, Major Mostafa Ihbayl al-Firjani and Major Ramadhan al-Ayhuri. The two civilians were Dr Saad Misbah al-Amin al-Zubaydi and Sulayman Ghayth Miftah.

The men were reportedly charged with "passing defence secrets to foreign states (the United States of America) " and membership of "a banned organization linked to agents of foreign governments". This organization is the National Front for the Salvation of Libya -NFSL, the main Libyan opposition group operating in exile.

The Court acquitted six other army officers, including Lieutenant-Colonel Mohammad al-Ghul and Flight-Captain Sadeq Shaqluf, and two civilians.

The people involved in this case were among dozens arrested and detained in the aftermath of a rebellion by army units around the city of Misrata in October 1993. Three of those executed gave televised "confessions", reportedly as a result of torture, to being American "spies" in early March 1994. They said they had been recruited as American Intelligence agents by members of the NFSL. Trial before the lower military court reportedly took place at the end of 1995. Amnesty International has also received reports that the Supreme Military Court's verdict was given and video-taped about a month ago, but was not made public until 1 January 1997 when the Libyan television announced the news of the death sentences. Espionage is punishable by death in Libya and so is mere membership of an opposition group.

"The blanket of secrecy heightens our fears that the basic human rights of these individuals were disregarded from the outset" Amnesty International said. The organization had repeatedly requested information about their legal status and whereabouts and sent urgent appeals after reports were received that they had been tortured, and then sentenced to death. To date no response has been received from the Libyan authorities.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


36 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 5, 1997


South Africa;
ANC to Meet with Truth And Reconciliation Commission


BYLINE: African National Congress of South Africa


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Johannesburg - In response to further media queries, the ANC wishes to confirm that a high-level ANC delegation led by Acting Secretary-General Cheryl Carolus, will hold a meeting with leaders of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission including Archbishop Desmond Tutu in Cape Town on Friday 7 March at 9h00.

The delegation consists of members of the ANC National Executive Committee sub-committee on Truth and Reconciliation and includes Charles Nqakula, Matthew Phosa, Dullah Omar, Mac Maharaj, Ronnie Mamoepa and Adv. Mongesi Tshongweni.

In its submission to the meeting the ANC delegation hopes to:

* make a formal request to the TRC for the amnesty applications of Clive Derby-Lewis and Janus Walus to be kept in abeyance pending the submission of the ANC report (requested by the TRC) on circumstances leading to the cold- blooded murder of ANC/SACP leader Chris Hani

* strongly urge the TRC to reconsider its decision with regard to the need to reveal names of former police informers allegedly in high government circles.

* discuss further the ANC's perspective on the conduct of a just war against the system of apartheid-dubbed a crime against humanity

* to be briefed on the work and time frames of the TRC including identification of further areas of co-operation to enable the TRC achieve its objectives.

For more information call Ronnie Mamoepa at 082-990-4853

Issued by Department of Information and Publicity P.O. Box 61884 Marshalltown 2107 4 March 1997.

37 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 5, 1997


East Africa;
Emergency Update No. 117 on the Great Lakes (03/05)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1254 words


 

Nairobi - The Zairean government has issued an expulsion order for United Nations and international NGOs personnel who evacuated on March 1 from their duty station in Kisangani. Humanitarian agencies report in Kinshasa that three international personnel left by barge this morning for Brazzaville; others are on standby. The expulsion, which was ordered yesterday, is being urgently appealed by the UN and NGOs. The UN requested to be notified formally and be given at least 24 hours to leave.

International staff were told that the primary reason given for the expulsion order was the UN's alleged failure to properly notify the Zairean government through "normal diplomatic channels" of its intention to relocate staff from Kisangani. The Minister of the Interior, Eboma Ejuku, said it was an irresponsible action that "sowed the seeds of panic and confusion among the Kisangani population". According to the Minister, the actions of the UN and the NGOs in recent months had the effect of destabilising local populations to such an extent that it had "encouraged anti-government elements and rebel forces to attack GOZ positions". 

Senior UN officials called on the Governor of Kisangani on Friday (February 28) to explain the decision of the UN to temporarily relocate its staff. According to the UN, the decision was received "calmly" and the Ministries of Defence, Interior, Foreign Affairs and Prime Ministers Office were consequently verbally notified on March 1.

* Sources in Kinshasa said that the Governor of Kisangani had flown out to Kinshasa today. Journalists report rebels approaching Kisangani from various directions, and say they are within 40 kilometers north of the provincial capital (Bengamisa).

* UN Secretary General Kofi Annan has revived the idea of an international military force in eastern Zaire, saying that unless a ceasefire can be secured, the international community should "study the possibility of using troops to create humanitarian corridors to evacuate the refugees". Annan was speaking at a news conference during a visit to the UN war crimes tribunal for former Yugoslavia in The Hague. He said it was imperative to apply political pressure for a ceasefire and that "all options" should be considered. Discussions in New York on the possibility of international intervention are continuing today.

Several countries had planned to send troops to Zaire in November 1996 but military intervention was abandoned when more than a million Rwandan and Burundian refugees repatriated to Rwanda. The United States and Canada, who sent small advance units for logistical reasons, rejected using force as part of a humanitarian mandate - which many observers and aid workers saw as the lack of will to tackle the the root causes of the crisis.

* Journalists who were flown to Kindu by the rebel Alliance of Democratic Forces of Congo-Zaire (ADFL) report hundreds of people emerging from forest hideouts, days after Zairean soldiers retreated. The ADFL captured the garrison town of Kindu and its airport. According to the journalists, there were no visible signs of battle at the airport and much of the town was " scarred more by looting than by bullets". Residents of Kindu said after Zairean troops fled along with five white mercenaries, Kindu was defended by a 177-strong contingent of former Rwandan soldiers.

* Humanitarian sources in Rwanda say they are unaware of any arrivals of refugees from the dispersed Tingi-Tingi camps in eastern Zaire, some 500 kilometers from the Rwandan border. AP yesterday reported refugees "streaming home" after rebels took over Tingi-Tingi camps - which formerly held some 170, 000 Rwandans. UN agencies and humanitarian sources point out the distance is too great for such an arrival from Tingi-Tingi. A column of refugees from Tingi-Tingi were seen and interviewed by journalists some 150 kilometers from Kisangani on Monday. Another group is heading for Ubundu, to the south, where local officials have directed them.

* The Organisation of African Unity (OAU) rejected a submission at the just- concluded Tripoli meeting by Burundi's foreign affairs representative, Luc Rukingana, that regional sanctions on Burundi should be lifted because there had been progress in restoring peace. It recommended that the sanctions be reviewed "in the light of progress in the peace process in Burundi", confirms OAU spokesman Ibrahim Dagash at the OAU headquarters in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. When asked about the issue of regional sanctions at a press conference, Secretary-General of the OAU, Salim Ahmed Salim, said that sanctions should firmly remain until progress had been made under the conditions imposed by the Regional Sanctions Committee. Regional sanctions were imposed in July 1996 when leader Pierre Buyoya took power by coup.

A record 43 ministers attended the 65th ministerial council in Tripoli. The African news agency PANA reports that despite "near-flawless organisation" it seemed that the meeting "barely managed to scratch the surface of Africa's many daunting political and socio-economic problems". The Zairean crisis was high on the agenda, which provoked angry exchanges between delegates, especially concerning the Zairean governments' fury over South African talks " legitimizing the rebellion". PANA reports that the OAU eventually "took the easy way out" by urging cessation of hostilities in the region, and calling on all foreign troops to pull out of the country.

* The Food and Agriculture Organisation report on the food supply situation and crop prospects in Sub-Saharan Africa ranks Kenya among states with the most unfavourable food conditions. According to the report serious food difficulties are anticipated in the first half of 1997 as a result of failure of the 1996/97 short rains season. In Kenya, the Kenya Red Cross Society yesterday warned that at least 100,000 people in Coast Province alone faced " starvation", reports the Daily Nation. A disaster officer with the Society told the Daily Nation that the worst-hit areas are Kinango and Samburu in Kwale District.

Nairobi, 5 March 1997, 13:40 GMT

(ENDS)

Africa News


March 5, 1997


East Africa;
Emergency Update No. 119on the Great Lakes (03/06


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1494 words


 

Nairobi - The rebel Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire (ADFL) rejected calls for a ceasefire yesterday, saying it would continue to fight until the regime of President Mobutu Sese Seko agreed to one-to-one negotiations. Rebel spokesman Kongolo Mwenze said a UN peace plan - accepted yesterday by the government - worked "against" the rebels, reports AFP. Kinshasa yesterday agreed to a five-point peace plan endorsed by the UN Security Council (see IRIN Update 118). The Zairean government also called for international monitors to oversee its implementation.

* News agencies continue to report ADFL rebels are advancing on three fronts towards the provincial capital of Kisangani, eastern Zaire. Rebel radio in Bukavu, eastern Zaire, said yesterday that "the liberation of the town of Kisangani by Laurent Kabila's troops is only a few hours away". In the recent rapid territorial gains of the rebel Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire (ADFL), such rebel announcements have become characteristic of the "psychological" advance on besieged government towns. 

* CNN reported today that "there was no evidence" of the massacre of 25,000 civilians and refugees in Tingi-Tingi camps, eastern Zaire, alleged by the government of Zaire on Tuesday. Tingi-Tingi camps held some 170,000 Rwandans before they fled last week. According to the CNN report, fleeing refugees left behind "dozens of the sick and dying" and headed off towards Kisangani and Ubundu. However, some of the most vulnerable refugees left the camp in empty food trucks before the exodus and are being given assitance in Kisangani.

* Humanitarian agencies are "urgently examining" ways in which to resume relief operations for refugees and IDPs in eastern Zaire. A United Nations mission flew yesterday to Kisangani and Punia, accompanied by the Dutch Minister for Development Cooperation, Jan Pronk. Tens of thousands of refugees who dispersed from the Tingi-Tingi camps are expected to arrive in Ubundu, south of Kisangani, after being diverted there by the military.While there is little reliable information available on the whereabouts and welfare of the 170,000 refugees, it was expected that the majority would eventually emerge from the forest and mass along the 150 kilometer eastern bank of the Zaire River between Ubundu and Lowa. This is a densely forested area, and leaves refugees with no real escape route if the rebels are successful in their advance on Kisangani.

* The US state department has expressed extreme concern about alleged rebel threats against humanitarian personnel working in Resettlement Camps in Burundi. It said the threats had to be treated seriously, given recent attacks on NGO personnel in Rwanda and the past killings of ICRC and UNHCR staff in Burundi. A public withdrawal of the threat is being demanded.

* In Burundi, two people were killed and another went missing in an overnight attack by Hutu rebels in Rumonge in Bururi, southern Burundi, national radio reported on Wednesday. Seven houses were burnt, and ten others looted. Livestock was killed.

* In its 65th ministerial meeting in Tripoli, the Organisation of African Unity responded to an appeal from Burundi to lift regional sanctions, with the following draft recommendations:

o Commends the leaders of the countries of the Great Lakes Region and the facilitator of the peace process, Mwalimu Julius Nyrere, for their on going efforts to bring about a peaceful and negotiated settlement to the conflict in (Burundi)

o Encourages all the parties to the conflict to work towards ending the cycle of violence and unacceptable killings of innocent people including refugees, especially women, children and the elderly

o Appeals to the countries of the region which imposed sanctions in Burundi to carry out an objective evaluation of the situation prevailing in the country as the result of implementation of the sanctions and to review these sanctions in the light of progress in the peace process

o Appeals to the International Community to continue to provide relief assistance to Burundi, in order to facilitate the socio-economic development and reconstruction of that country.

* Drought, warfare and disease are keeping food from millions of people in 14 countries, despite the fact cereal production is running at record levels in sub-Saharan Africa, says a report released yesterday by the UN Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO). It urges donors and relief agencies to secure the speedy delivery of assistance to eastern Zaire, and to continue emergency assistance to returning refugees and displaced persons in Rwanda, Burundi, Liberia and Sierra Leone. On Zaire, the report described the food situation as "desperate": "Hundreds of thousands of refugees and the local population continue to flee from the conflict and their food and health situation is precarious".

The report also recommends urgency in doing "everything possible" to aid Rwandese and Burundian refugees displaced by fighting between rebels and government troops. On Rwanda, FAO says production of beans, the staple food crop, dropped by 12%. This drop, coupled by the massive return of more than a million Rwandan former refugees, means one third of the Rwandan population is being fed by relief agencies (about 2.6 million people). In Burundi, FAO says distribution of humanitarian assistance is being hampered by insecurity and fuel shortages following the imposition of regional sanctions in July 1996.

* Uganda has sent out an appeal to the internatioanl donors to support more than 2.1 million people faced with starvation. The government has released Ush284 (US$284,000) as an emergency allocation for food, but it is not enough, according to a Ministerial statement in parliament yesterday. The Kenyan Daily Nation reports from Kampala that Ugandan Minister of Labour and Social Welfare, Paul Etyang, that a high-level ad hoc committee is looking into the food needs of people affected in 19 districts in the north, north-east and western parts of the country. The areas are affected by drought and insurgence.

* About 100 mainly Rwandan refugees are stranded at Wilson Airport, Nairobi, after the Kenyan government refused them entry. Reports in the Daily Nation and Kenya Times say the refugees flew in from Kisangani, eastern Zaire, on Saturday and are being held at the airport departure lounge under armed guard. The Daily Nations said the UNHCR yesterday dispatched food and blankets to the group, and had been screening for "genuine cases." More than half the group are women and children. The state-owned Kenya Times said that a church minister and a local businessman were operating a "human trafficking cartel through which refugees fleeing from the trouble spots in the Great Lakes region". It quoted sources within the Immigration and Police department saying the refugees paid foreign currency to be flown to Nairobi, be provided with fake travel documents, and receive immigration documents.

Several hundred Rwandans from Kisangani and Tingi-Tingi camps have arrived in Kenya (before the dispersal of about 170,000 Rwandans from the camps) over the last few weeks, until the "elite exodus" was exposed in the press last week.

Nairobi, 6 March 1997, 13:20 GMT

March 5, 1997


Somalia;
Drought, famine strike south-western Somalia


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 160 words


 

Addis Ababa (ENA) - Drought and famine have occurred in three areas of south-western Somalia, the British Broadcasting Service (BBC) reported on Monday. 

BBC has quoted the National Relief and Rehabilitation Committee (NRRC) appointed by faction leader Hussen Mohammed Aideed as saying, hundred people have died of hunger, thirst and diseases related to malnutrition in Bay, Bakol and Gedo areas in the last two months.

More than 80 per cent of the victims were children between 2 and 7 years of age according to the BBC broadcast.

In the famine stricken areas, domestic animals particularly cattle were dying in dozen due to lack of water and pasture, BBC said.

40 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 5, 1997


Ethiopia;
EJA briefs diplomats on code of ethics, media exhibition


BYLINE: Abebe Gelaw, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

ADDIS ABABA - The Ethiopian Journalists Association (EJA) briefed members of the diplomatic corps Monday on the significance of its planned media World Exhibition Project and content of its newly formulated code of ethics'.

Ato Kefyalew Azeze, President of EJA, Ato Selishi Tesemma members of executive committee and Ato Tamirat Aseffa member of the organizing committee of the exhibition informed the invited guests at the Axum Hotel that both the code of ethics and the exhibition were believed to accelerate the pace of growth and hence maturity of the profession in Ethiopia. "It will uphold the truth that journalism in the country, which is flourishing thanks to Article 29 of the constitution of the FDRE, will no longer lag behind time," Ato Kefyalew said. 

Ato Kefyalew also urged diplomatic missions and other local and international organs to support the exhibition project which is hoped to introduce journalists with the working of media world organizations and equip them with philosophical orientations". Noting the EJA with all its members is "only a conductor in such a move," he added: "It is you who can make this a reality."

Asked about the need for the planned exhibition, the speakers said that as the media was being restructured in the interest of the public which is a radical departure from the old practice, Ethiopian journalists should be acquainted with how the system works in practice in other parts of the world. They also indicated that any party interested in getting involved in such effort may work "hand-in-glove" with EJA. "Thought the idea is that of EJA, we are prepared to share the experience of others. anyone can join us in the realization of the ultimate goal", they said.

Panel members also elaborated at length on the content and objective of the newly formulated code of ethics based on various points raised by the audience.

Africa News


March 5, 1997


Ethiopia;
Court continues hearing testimonies


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - "It is now twenty years since my father dropped us at the school" a prosecution witness told yesterday the first Criminal Bench of the Federal High Court.

The witness, 36, said her father who left them at the gate of the school one day in 1978, never returned home. 

In her testimonies to the court against the former Derg officials, she said somebody called after a month to tell them that he knew the whereabouts of her father, Mengistu Gebre-Hiwot.

"My uncle and his friends who went out to look for may father did not show up again" she related to the court.

A piece of paper stating it was decided that the three including her uncle were to be killed for allegedly being members of the Eritrean People Liberation Front(EPLF) was found in 1991 in the former Ministry of Interior, she added.

Members of the army, searched my house and took with them my two sons one night in March 1978, another witness told the court. He was also released after ten days in custody, he said.

One of them was released after competing his term but his brother, then a second year student in the engineering faculty, was said to have been taken to the headquarters of the Derg, and "we have not even seen his remains," the 140th witness related to the court.

My brother said another witness, who was secretary of the then Ethiopian airlines Trade Unions was among those people wanted by the government and was jailed in various prisons including the headquarters of the Derg after he gave himself up to government officials.

"Since then, I have not seen my brother" said the witness.

The trial was adjourned until March 6, 1997.

LANGUAGE: English

42 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 5, 1997


Business and Finance;
Ethiopia: Over 1,000 workers support CETU re- establishment


BYLINE: Asfaw Gemmeda, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

ADDIS ABABA - Around 1,400 members of 52 basic workers' associations unanimously supported the re-establishment of the Confederation of Ethiopian Trade Unions (CETU) at a meeting held at the Ethiopian Electric Light and Power Authority recreation centre yesterday.

Union members of Ethiopian Coffee Export Enterprise and Commerce, Technic and Printing Industry were all convinced that the reformation of CETU was vital for the protection of the rights and benefits of Ethiopian workers after elaborate discussion on the issue.

Ato Zerihun Atnafu, coordinator of the meeting and vice chairman of the Commerce, Technical and Printing Industry Federation, said that failure of the members of the former CETU to work together in an atmosphere of understanding and properly set time-tables for meeting were some of the causes for the breakup of the organization. 

The failure of the council members of the former CETU to conduct orderly discussions on issues related to relevant labour affairs time and the use of two different scales by the secretariat, which later led to illegal activities, were other reasons which brought about its disintegration, according to Ato Zerihun.

"With a strong CETU,. it is also possible to be in a strong position to protect the legitimate rights and interests of workers", Ato Zerihun remarked, and went on to state that the re-establishment of the countrywide organization was thus most essential.

Ato Kifle Woldemichael, chairman of the audit committee of the commerce, Technical and Industry Workers Associations Federation, on his part said that CETU's future leadership will have the priority task of seeking ways and means of recovering and rehabilitating properties of workers that had either been rendered useless of damaged and looted at various times through still unidentified people.

Ato Kifle went on: "The three seats reserved for organized labour in the House of Peoples' Representatives still vacant because CETU does not yet exist". This, according to him, was the primary reason why major problems facing Ethiopian workers are not brought to the notice of the government and addressed in the way they should under normal circumstances.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


43 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 5, 1997


Business and Finance;
Ethiopia's economic reform programme lays off 15, 460


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - Ethiopia's economic reform programme has laid off 15, 460 civil servants of whom 6,397 are now embraced in five safety-net projects, the Minister in Charge of social and Administrative Affairs in the Office of the Prime Minister told the House of Peoples' Representatives yesterday.

Dr. Kebede Tadesse, the minister, said of the total civil servants dismissed from central executive bodies and development agencies, 988 were transferred to federal and regional institutions. 

Of the remaining, he said, 4,892 were women and 9,580 men.

According to the report Dr. Kebede presented to the house, some 8,075 other workers were also laid off with pre-retirement pension and compensation, that cost the government 30 million birr.

Dr. Kebede, however, said the government has lent 173 million birr in soft loan to those embraced in four transport and one retail trade safety-net projects with some of them now repaying their debts.

As the number of civil servants in Ethiopia is minimal, persons laid-off owing to the programme account for only 3 per cent, the minister added.

Dr. Kebede said, "the number of lay off and the cost the programme demanded is low when compared to similar measures in Ghana, Uganda and Tanzania."

The minister admitted that the dismissal had economic, social and psychological impacts on the families of the persons, refuting a statement by a member of the parliament that "institutions have lost able and experienced personnel due to the reform programme".

LANGUAGE: English

44 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 5, 1997


South Africa;
Review team flies to London to re-negotiate secret Dolphin deal


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 827 words


 

NELSPRUIT - A review team, made up of outspoken critics of the secret R12,2- billion Dolphin Deal in Mpumalanga will be flying to meet with the Dolphin Group's controversial president, Ketan Somaia in London on Wed-nesday.

The team, which includes former Mpuma-langa Parks Board (MPB) member, Dr John Hanks, Environmental Council chairperson, Dr Sue Hart, prominent conservationist, Rupert Lorimer and provincial environmental affairs MEC, David Mkhwanazi, will attempt to convince Somaia to change ten aspects of his 50-year contract with the Mpumalanga Parks Board (MPB).

Dr Hanks resigned from the MPB in protest to the contract, which was signed by MPB head, Alan Gray without any public consultation in November last year.

Dr Hart's watchdog Environmental Council was suspended two weeks ago after repeat-edly criticising both the deal and the provincial government's handling of the issue, while Lorimer was sacked as the MEC's personal consultant after he too criticised the deal in public. 

The contentious deal gives the Dubai-based Dolphin Group all commercial development and transverse rights to six state owned game reserves, the world's second largest canyon at Blyde River Canyon and the historic town of Pilgrim's Rest for 50-years.

In return, Dolphin has pledged to bankroll the MPB's budget for 50-years, an amount estimated to be worth R12,2-billion. In addition, Dolphin has undertaken to build hotels and other infrastructure in Mpumalanga worth R400- million within the next three years.

Rural communities, land claim activists and conservationists has vehemently objected to the deal, pointing out that at least three of the core development areas have gazetted land claims on them, that affected communities were never consulted and that Dolphin's direct financial contributions will only ever support one small parastatal with under 800 staff members.

The provincial government conceded last week that there were flaws in both the agreement itself and in the process leading up to it, after initially branding both the deal's critics and the press as reactionary sabotagers over the past two months.

"We wish to bring development to Mpumalanga, but at the same time we need to be mandated by the people whose lives we are affecting. We need to be sensitive to local community participation, consultation and empowerment during the process," said Mkhwanazi on Monday.

He added that the government had decided to include some of its most outspoken critics on the team to show how seriously it was taking public concerns - now that it was convinced of their validity

Because the contract signed last year is legally binding on the MPB, the review team will attempt convince Somaia to renegotiate ten clauses in the 39- page document.

These include a clause demanding complete secrecy about the deal's specifics for at least 50-years, a 'get out' clause enabling Dolphin to pull out of the deal without any liability should they feel that not enough tourists are visiting the area and a possible increase of MPB directors on the joint venture company which will steer the whole process to ensure more equal representation for the South African public.

The lack of independent environmental impact assessments will also be discussed, as will the pending land claims, the lack of local consultation and a time-table for development programmes.

The team will also attempt to get Somaia to agree to reduce the period of the contract from 50-years to a lower, renewable, series of contracts.

A number of "less significant" issues will also be discussed with Somaia, which possibly include his personal legal problems in Kenya, where he stands accused of defaulting on a R35-million tender with the government there.

Following Somaia's refusal to testify before Kenya's Public Accounts Committee about the issue on three separate occasions, a formal recommendation has been tabled in Parliament demanding legislation be passed that the Kenyan government never again do any business with either Somaia or any company associated with him.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


45 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 5, 1997


South Africa;
Attempts to cancel controversial Dolphin deal could cost taxpayer


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

NELSPRUIT - Mpumalanga's provincial government decided against canceling the controversial R12,2-billion Dolphin Deal because it would have cost almost R250-million in litigation to overturn the 50-year contract between the Mpumalanga Parks Board (MPB) and the Dolphin Group.

The 50-year deal, which created a storm of controversy in the province after details of it were leaked to African Eye News Service last year, gives the Dubai-based Dolphin Group all commercial development and transverse rights to six State owned game reserves, the Blyde River Canyon, Pilgrim's Rest and Loskop Dam.

The deal was signed in secret and no affected communities were consulted about the deal, which includes at least three core development areas with gazetted land claims on them. 

The MPB only admitted to the deal's existence four weeks after signing it, after media reports divulged the specifics from the 39-page document, but still refuses to discuss the contract's terms in public.

Premier Mathews Phosa said during a television interview on Monday night that the government had been on the verge of scrapping the contract last week Thursday but had reconsidered after Dolphin president Ketan Somaia agreed to re-negotiate certain aspects of the 39-page document.

A special review team, consisting of the government's most outspoken critics on the deal, including Dr John Hanks from the World Wildlife Fund (WWF), chairperson of the Environmental Council (EC) Dr Sue Hart and prominent conservationist, Rupert Lorimer, leave for discussions with Somaia in London on Tuesday afternoon.

Explaining that the contract, which was signed without any public consultation by MPB head, Alan Gray, last year November, was legally binding on the province, select standing committee on finance chairman, Chris MacPherson added that it would have been just too expensive to simply cancel.

"What it would actually have meant is that MPB would have had to fight the thing in foreign courts, which would have cost US $50-million or R250-million, " he explained.

"And because the MPB is a government parastatal, that money would come out of public funds - costing the taxpayer."

He added that Dolphin, which is registered in Bermuda but based in Dubai, had already reportedly spent US $3-million setting up the deal.

MPB's board of directors also met during an extraordinary five-hour session on Monday to discuss the deal and media speculation about it.

MPB spokesperson, Gary Sutter, confirmed the sitting but was unable to give a statement about its outcome.

The Board will, however, release a detailed statement later on Tuesdays afternoon, he said.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


46 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 5, 1997


Nigeria;
Nigeria Airways Barred From Britain


BYLINE: Nicholas Ibewuike, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigeria Airways, the country's troubled national carrier, has been barred from flying into Britain because it has no insurance on its aircraft.

The British Civil Aviation Authority informed Nigeria Airways in Lagos Tuesday, to keep out of British airspace until it produced proof that its fleet had insurance cover. 

However, Nigeria Airways Public Affairs Manager Chris Aligbe said the airline would still be flying its Lagos-London routes regularly with leased aircraft. The ban affects only the carrier's aircraft not its flying right.

Recently, Nigeria's apex insurance company, the National Insurance Corporation of Nigeria, withdrew its cover for Nigeria Airways because of the carrier's unpaid premium of 11 million U.S. dollars for 1996.

In February, the Israeli Aviation Authority stopped Nigeria Airways aircraft from flying into Tel Aviv, Israel, for the Christian pilgrimage because it had no necessary insurance cover to make the flight.

However, in a news conference two weeks ago, the managing director of the airline, Peter Gana, said the national carrier had been meeting its insurance obligation.

Gana said that the airline was being overcharged in the insurance premium as it had uncovered inflation of the premium mounting to 16 million dollars for 1994 and 1995.

He said the airline discovered it was paying the highest premium worldwide, with a 56-percent three-year loss ratio which it had paid for the past five years.

Nigeria Airways, it said, also discovered it had been paying excess of average rates currently paid by other African airlines at 0.45 percent and 3 percent of the total value of their aircraft. Nigeria Airways is being charged 6.3 percent.

Nigeria Airways is serving a ban on the Lagos-United States route. Washington slammed the ban on Nigeria in 1993, citing poor security at Nigerian airports.


LOAD-DATE: March 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


47 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 5, 1997


Science and Health;
WHO To Send Malaria Control Experts To Mozambique


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo (PANA) - The Brazzaville-based African Regional office of the World Health Organization (WHO) has promised to send malaria control experts to Mozambique, where the situation of the disease is said to be serious.

WHO regional Director, Dr Ebrahim Samba, told reporters in the Congolese capital that his office and the European Union, in conjunction with the Brazilian and Portuguese governments would be working out a scheme to train doctors locally.

Reacting to reports of reduced AIDS-related deaths due to some medical break-through in the developed world, Samba said the regional office was in contact with leading pharmaceutical companies and other partners to make AIDS medicines available to patients in Africa. 

"These medicines are expensive. They are not available to all Europeans or Americans. But they can be bought in Europe and America. At the moment they are very expensive for Africans. We are working out how best to make them available to Africans," he told journalists.

Meanwhile, at a recent meeting, malaria control experts proposed a three- stage initiative to control the anopheles mosquito transmitted disease.

The first stage will be devoted to the provision of basic support to control programmes while the second and third stages will seek to accelerate and consolidate the control measures.

The experts projected that by the year 2010, at least 50 percent of countries in the 46-nation Africa WHO region will be in the stage of accelerated implementation. The remainder will be in advanced stage of basic support.

Ten years later, all the region's countries are expected to be in the stage of accelerated implementation while in the year 1030, all countries would have completed the stage of programme consolidation with "sustainable control programmes."

Closing the experts' meeting, Dr Samba said efforts would be made to ensure that African governments contribute financially to the malaria control initiative.

Malaria remains one of the continent's most serious health problems. About 75 percent of the population in the African region live in malaria endemic areas. Nearly 18 percent of this population live under the threat of the disease.

Experts estimate that malaria accounts for between 30 to 50 percent of consultations in most of African hospitals.

In 1993, African states adopted a programme of action for the control of malaria, but it has been hampered by financial constraints. About 10 million US dollars have been allocated to malaria control programmes in 1997.


LOAD-DATE: March 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


48 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 5, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Senegal Denounces Return To Anglophone-Francophone Division


BYLINE: Peter Masebu, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - Senegal's foreign minister, Mustapha Niass, has denounced what he says is the re-emergence of the Anglophone-Francophone rift in intra-African affairs.

"The return to outdated diplomacy based on the language differences of colonial powers is a luxury we Africans cannot afford at this time when all efforts should directed at combating poverty," he told PANA.

Niass said this Tuesday at the Leopold Sedar Senghor International Airport, where he had gone to see off his Tanzanian counterpart, Jakaya Kikwete. 

Niass said Africans needed most to "strengthen our regional integration groups, which will serve as bridges towards the African Economic Community" at a time when the prices of Africa's raw materials were still determined from outside.

Africa's linguistic rivalry, mostly between French and English speaking countries, has blocked African efforts to head some top international organizations.

The latest of these occured last week in Tripoli, Libya, where the 65th ministerial council of the Organization of African Unity failed to field a single candidate for post of secretary- general of the International Civil Aviation Organization.

The linguistic cleavage has had a negative impact on other aspects of Pan- African endeavour, including in some sub-regional economic groupings.

However, Niass said Senegal -- a former colony of France in West Africa -- had good relations with Tanzania, once a British colony at the opposite end of the continent.

Earlier, Kikwete delivered a written message from Tanzanian President Benjamin Mkapa, concerning bilateral and continental issues, to Senegalese President Abdou Diouf.

On other issues in Africa, Kikwete said the impact of sanctions imposed on Burundi since the July 1996 coup had forced the Bujumbura military junta to concede many concessions.

However he said, "More efforts will have to be made to bring about reforms in that country."

Kikwete said reports that neighbouring states had widely violated the sanctions could not be confirmed immediately but that it was "natural for sanctions to get eroded if they last for too long."

Kikwete left the Senegalese capital for Port Louis, Mauritius, where he is to head Tanzania's delegation at Thursday's inaugural conference of states bordering the Indian Ocean.


LOAD-DATE: March 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


49 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 5, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
U.N. Says Africa's Fight Against Drug Menace Satisfactory


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 667 words


 

UNITED NATIONS, New York (PANA) - Africa's commitment to fighting drugs remains satisfactory but the continent should speed up the enactment of laws against the menace, a United Nations narcotic control body says.

The body, The International Narcotics Control Board, says in its 1996 report released Tuesday, that African leaders had acted correctly when they adopted a plan for drug control on the continent, in 1996.

The board also describes as commendable, the ratification of the Protocol for Drug Control, which was adopted in 1995, by the 12 nations forming the Southern African Development Community. 

Established in 1968, the board is an agency for the implementation of the U. N. drug control treaties. These include the 1961 Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs, as amended by the 1972 protocol, and the 1971 Convention on Psychotropic Substances.

Preparation of an annual report is part of the tasks mandated to the 13- member board which has its headquartered in Vienna, Austria.

In the 1996 report, released in New York and several other cities worldwide, the board said African countries needed to speed up the process of adopting adequate drug control legislation.

"There are only a few African countries that have made progress in the updating of their drug control laws," it says.

However, it says that Burkina Faso, Egypt, Namibia and Nigeria "have formulated such strategies" and that other African states should do likewise.

Meanwhile, the board has reported an increase in drug trafficking and its abuse in Africa. These drugs are cannabis, cocaine, heroin and methaqualone.

"In Africa, increasing amounts of cocaine are being smuggled out of South America -- mainly Brazil -- through Eastern, Southern and Western Africa into Europe," it says.

The board estimates that 60 percent of all cocaine shipped to South Africa passes through this country. The rest is consumed locally. Now abuse of that derivative, crack, is already creating problems in South Africa and many countries in West Africa. Crack is pure cocaine in crystalline form which is smoked.

The board says that cannabis abuse now abounds in all of Africa's five subregions. Morocco, in the North African subregion, remains the main supplier to Europe. It says that heroin is transported from Asia to African sea and airports for routing to Europe and North America.

Methaqualone abuse and trafficking, the board says, are now widespread in Eastern and Southern Africa.

Officials of the board, who launched the report in New York, refused to comment on the controversial annual U.S. certification process, aimed at gauging how effectively other countries combat drug trafficking.

"The board does not get between bilateral relations of various countries and it has no opinion on that," said Herbert Okun, an American member of the board.

Six countries -- Afghanistan, Burma, Colombia, Iran, Nigeria and Syria -- were decertified by the United States last week for not doing enough to fight drug trafficking. The U.S. certified 23 others.

Decertified countries are cut off from most forms of U.S. assistance and barred from getting loans from multilateral lenders.


LOAD-DATE: March 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


50 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 5, 1997


Zimbabwe;
Crusade Against Sexual Perverts Launched


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - A wide section of the Zimbabwean community, including human rights activists, started a crusade Tuesday against what they said were sexual perverts in the country.

Led by politician Michael Mawema, the crusade said it would transform itself into a pressure group that will lobby Zimbabwe's parliament to enact harsh laws for offenses such as homosexuality, rape, incest and bestiality. 

"The culprit must be whipped 100 times in the public square," he said.

He proposed that sexual perverts be castrated. In addition, the group said it would propose a 20-year mandatory sentence for offenders.

The proposals come in the wake of increased incidents of homosexuality, rape and incest in Zimbabwe. Most prominent was that alleged of the country's former President, the Reverend Canaan Banana. Details of his homosexual rape of his former aide-de-camp were given in court February 24.

"Have you not read of some reverends who sleep with other men? Some reverends, with white colors, Mawema said.

"Zimbabwe is at a moral and political crossroads," Mawema. said. "God commands the death of sexual perverts."


LOAD-DATE: March 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


51 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 5, 1997


Ghana;
Ghana Turns 40, What Lies In Stock ?


BYLINE: Frank Agyekum, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1134 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - Forty years ago, the world's attention was focused on the former Gold Coast which was about to make history, as the first black African country to gain independence, on March 6,1957.

When the country's first president, Dr Kwame Nkrumah, declared: "at long last the battle has ended and Ghana our beloved is free forever," the hearts of the enthusiastic crowd who had gathered at the Old Polo Grounds in Accra, jumped with joy.

That, perhaps, was the proudest moment in the history of Ghana. There was optimism in every sphere of life as goodwill and praise poured in from all over the world. 

With a reserve of about 200 million pounds left over from the British colonial administration, the economy was good. Thanks to this, projects such as the Akosombo Dam, Tema Harbour, and the University of Science and Technology were undertaken.

Ghana became a haven of freedom fighters seeking to lead their countries along that path that Ghana had chartered.

Names such as Robert Mugabe, Sam Nujoma, Nnamdi Azikiwe and Hastings Kamuzu Banda, became common in Ghana.

At the same time that education and health services were free, Ghana's international image was boosted by Nkrumah's Pan-Africanist philosophy which culminated in the founding of the Organization of African Unity (OAU) in 1963.

Soon enough, however, the "honeymoon" came to an end, as economic crunch, among other factors, led to the overthrow of the First Republic in a coup d'etat jointly organized by the military and police.

The National Liberation Council which ushered in the first military administration, was headed by Gen. Joseph Ankrah, who played no part in the coup.

He was soon to be replaced by Brig. Akwasi Amankwah Afrifa who, together Col. Emmanuel Kotoka, and policeman J.W.K. Harley, were the brains behind the coup.

The NLC stayed in power till 1969, when it handed over to the constitutionally-elected government of Dr Kofi Abrefa Busia, who had long been in opposition to Nkrumah.

Busia's Progress Party lasted for two-and-a-half years when it was booted out of office by General Ignatius Kutu Acheampong's National Redemption Council (NRC) in January 1972.

Gen. Acheampong gave, among his reasons for the coup, the devaluation of the cedi by 44 percent and the reduction of the army's budget by 40 percent.

His "Yentua" (we won't pay) policy on Ghana's foreign debts and his " Operation Feed Yourself" programme, designed to make Ghana self-sufficient in food production found favour with the public and many demonstration were held in support for his regime.

But Gen. Acheampong and his NRC, which metamorphosed as Supreme Military Council (SRC), soon ran foul with the people over the issue of Union Government when the soldiers were pressurized to hand over power to a constitutionally-elected government.

His aim in fusing the military and civilians into one government was to avoid partisan politics which he saw as divisive.

Although a referendum showed that the majority of voters were in support of it, the popular feeling was that the result was rigged and there were mass demonstrations against it.

This is set off a widespread agitations leading to the removal of Gen. Acheampong as Head of State, in a Palace coup in 1978 led by General Fred Akuffo, his second-in-command.

Akuffo initiated a series of probes into Acheampong's regime which cashiered him, accused him of sabotaging the economy and confined him to his hometown in the Ashanti Region in 1979.

By this time there was general discontent with the army and although Akuffo repeatedly pledged that he would hand over to a civilian government by September 1979, he was toppled in June 1979, by an uprising of junior military officers led by Flight Lieutenant Jerry John Rawlings.

Rawlings formed the Armed Forces Revolutionary Council (AFRC) whose "house- cleaning exercise" resulted in the execution of former heads of state Afrifa, Acheampong, Akuffo and other high-ranking military officers.

Despite its popularity and revolutionary zeal, the AFRC handed over in September 1979 to Dr Hilla Limann and his People's National Party (PNP) which had won the elections.

The Limann's administration was to last for only two-and-a-half years before being kicked out by Flt. Lt. Rawlings who accused them of mismanagement and incompetence.

Rawlings formed the Provisional National Defence Council (PNDC) and ruled for 11 years before dumping his military clothes for civilian garb, to enable him to contest elections in 1992.

Rawlings as Presidential Candidate of the National Democratic Congress (NDC) won the ensuing elections to form the first government of the Fourth Republic.

Last December, he and his party went on to win the second elections of the Fourth Republic, to make his government the first ever to serve out a full term in Ghana.

As the world's attention is once again focused on Ghana, many will be wondering what the next 40 years hold in store for this country.

Will it also turn out nine Heads of State and an economy reeling under the pangs of a Structural Adjustment Programme or a nation of "milk and honey" which will be both the political and economic leader of Africa?


LOAD-DATE: March 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


52 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 6, 1997


South Africa;
Tutu Says Truth Panel May Investigate Informers


BYLINE: Truth and Reconciliation Commission


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Cape Town - Statement by Archbishop Desmond Tutu, chairperson of the Truth And Reconciliation Commission, March 5, 1997.

The Truth and Reconciliation Commission is to give strong consideration to investigating allegations that people now in government acted as informants for the Security Police in the apartheid era. 

I have noted the decision of the TRC's Amnesty Committee this week that it does not consider the naming of alleged informants to be appropriate for the present purposes of the Committee in the hearing that it is currently conducting in Pretoria.

I shall be discussing the matter fully with the Amnesty Committee. However, I do not understand that their decision necessarily precludes other sections of the Commission from conducting an investigation, at least for purposes other than those of the amnesty process.

Should the Commission decide to investigate the matter, we would first call for statements from those making the allegations. Then, in terms of the recent Appellate Division judgment requiring us to give adequate notice of allegations implicating individuals, we would give the individuals 21 days' notice to prepare a response, and take the matter from there.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


53 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 6, 1997


East Africa;
Emergency Update No. 120 on the Great Lakes (03/06)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1267 words


 

Nairobi - Hundreds of people are fleeing Kisangani, eastern Zaire, ahead of a feared arrival of rebels, reports AFP. From Kisangani, AFP reports that the quay is full of men, women and children trying to bargain for places in boats leaving Kisangani.

Today pirogues and other vessels were leaving "crammed full of residents desperate to get out". The rebel Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire (ADFL) is reported to be besieging Kisangani. Hundreds of thousands of refugees are also believed to be near the town, reports AFP. 

A column of several thousand people approaching Kisangani was spotted yesterday when a UN mission overflew the area with Dutch Minister of Development Cooperation, Jan Pronk. Pronk said he expected the first of the refugees to reach Kisangani by the weekend. Pronk met representatives of the Zairean government and aid organisations in Kisangani, and said the best option would be to locate the refugees near Ubundu, 200 kilometers southeast of Kisangani.

* In an overflight of the Ubunda area today, the World Food Programme reports the arrival of groups of refugees in Ubundu. According to WFP, the Ubundu airstrip was not good enough for the DC3 to land. WFP plans to evaluate the condition of the airstrip tomorrow with a smaller plane, and hopes to carry out an assessment of the newly arriving refugees. Today, WFP delivered 9 tons of food to Punia, in two planes.

* More than 120 Zairean soldiers have surrendered to rebel troops in Kindu since the ADFL took over, reports news agencies. The rebels say they recovered about 100 assault rifles, including M-16 submachine guns, Kalashnikovs, an armoured car and munitions. The ADFL have been repeatedly broadcasting radio messages appealing to government troops to surrender. Rebels say that among those taken prisoner in the Kindu fight are former Rwandan soldiers.

In Kindu, the ADFL rebels have encountered problems as well as applause by the local population, according to an AFP report. Villagers became angry with the ADFL "justice minister" Kongolo Mwenze, when he said he had asked district leaders and traditional chiefs to appoint new authorities for Maniema Province. A crowd of nearly 1,000 "caused an uproar" and shouted that such people were puppets of President Mobutu Sese Seko. Mwenze had to call a temporary halt to the meeting; he told journalists that it was difficult to avoid using the already established local figures when setting up a new administration. Mwenze also asked villagers for financial contributions to the ADFL cause, and called for civil servants to work without pay. He declared the war must have priority. Kindu is still recovering from extensive looting by retreating government soldiers, and markets and businesses have been brought to a standstill.

* Regional sources say rebels are advancing into Kasais and Shaba province - Kabila's home area - where they appear to have support from the local population. The latest rebel conquest, Manono, is said to have been taken with a fight this week. Observers speculate that Lumbumbashi - a strong opposition area with a history of political secessionist sentiment - is likely to independently declare itself under rebel control.

* Zairean state-radio said on March 3 that the Zairean Human Rights Association (Azadho) "had confirmed the massive killings bing carried out in the Masisi and Rutshuru areas by the Rwandan troops sent to help Laurent Kabila". The broadcast said there was talk of "a real genocide of Hutus" by the ADFL rebels and the Rwandan troops. It said alarm was raised in the wake of the stance of the Belgian government.

* Martin Griffiths, Regional Humanitarian Coordinator for the Great Lakes region told a news conference in New York that UN plans to repatriate almost 400,000 Rwandan refugees from eastern Zaire were "well-advanced" - but said all depended on the issue of security and of separation of Rwandan militia from genuine refugees. Griffiths added that the UN hoped there would be two land corridors passing through the border town of Bukavu, and said "some kind of international monitoring" would be required.

* The US State Department said on Wednesday that it was too early to send a multinational force to Zaire. Spokesman Nicholas Burns said Washington had formally asked rebel leader Laurent-Desire Kabila on Tuesday to open humanitarian corridors for the movement of refugees back to Rwanda "this week" . Burns said there was no committment by the US to a multinational force, as recently suggested by UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan.

* Vatican Radio reported yesterday that it had unconfirmed reports that nine Rwandan priests and 3 nuns were killed in Kalima on February 25, after the ADFL took control. According to the broadcast, the priests and nuns had come from Bukavu and asked to go to Kasongo, near to Kalima, but had not been able to travel because of lack of transport.

* The Zairean government has ordered a popular private television station to shut down for three months for violating a ban on political broadcasts, report Reuters. The owner, Ngongo Luwowo, said his Tel Kin Malebo (TKM) channel would ignore the order, describing it as "illegal". TKM is one of the most watched private TV stations, and has built an audience on its lively political debates.

* Zambia has appealed to donors to assist the government to deal with the influx of Zairean refugees. Zambia's home affairs minister, Chitalu Sampa, told parliament in Lusaka that 29 refugees have died and that conditions for refugees from Zaire are congested, with inadequate shelter, feeding and medical facilities. The refugees are at Mpulungu port, northern Zambia, the main refugee port entry. The minister said that as of last month, the number of refuges was 240 in Kaputa, 327 in Chienge, 1,470 in Natende and 738 at Maheba refugee camp in north western Zambia. Humanitarian sources say that some of the Zairean soldiers arriving refuse to be considered as refugees.

Nairobi, 6 March 1997, 1:00 GMT

(ENDS)
