54 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 6, 1997


South Africa;
Cosatu strike threat over workers' Bill


BYLINE: Thabo Mabaso, Business Reporter, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Cape Town - The Congress of South African Trade Unions (Cosatu) has threatened to embark on sustained mass action this month that could culminate in a national general strike if employer organisations do not accept the federation's proposals on employment conditions.

Cosatu Western Cape secretary general Tony Ehrenreich told a news conference in Cape town yesterday that the deadlock with employer organisations could only be broken by decisive action.

He said mass action, scheduled to start on March 10, would comprise human chains and pickets during lunch hours. 

"But as time goes on and if there is no progress in the negotiations, it will start encroaching on working hours," Mr Ehrenreich said.

The Employment Standards Bill sets basic conditions of employment for South African workers. It pulls together the old Basic Conditions of Employment Act and the Wage Act to protect the most vulnerable employees, notably farm and domestic workers.

The federation has called for six-month's maternity leave with four months being paid, a 40-hour working week, which can be phased in over a five-year period, double pay for working on Sundays, and barring children below the age of 16 years from employment to be included in the Bill.

Mr Ehrenreich said the national strike would be on May 12.

The last national strike by Cosatu was in April last year, and was aimed at the controversial lockout clause in the new Constitution.

Cosatu placed worker turnout at 75 percent for that strike.

"We want to impress on employers that these demands are serious," Mr Ehrenreich said.

"If we are going to change the mindset of business it will be in the tried and tested ways that are familiar to us."

Some economic and political observers have criticised Cosatu in the past for over-robust tactics that harmed the country's economy and made it difficult for its alliance partner, the African National Congress, to implement its macro-economic strategy.

The strategy envisages the creation of one million jobs and a six percent economic growth rate by the year 2000.

Mr Ehrenreich, however, dismissed the accusations and said the federation had to protect its members, anyway it could, from possible exploitation.

"We have a responsibility to our members and we are not going to shirk away from that responsibility," he said.

The Bill has still to go before the influential National Economic Development and Labour Council (Nedlac) and Parliament - a process that could take the whole of 1997.

Meanwhile, the South African Chamber of Business (Sacob) has criticised Cosatu's mass action plans, saying that it did not know what purpose a strike would serve.

"In our view, the Employment Standards Bill is a complicated piece of legislation and Cosatu should let the negotiations take their natural course," Sacob labour spokesman Janet Dickman said.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


55 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 6, 1997


Sports - General;
We'll make it, Olympic chief says


BYLINE: Michael Morris, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 707 words


 

Lausanne - There is no doubt Cape Town will be among the four or five shortlisted cities in the race for the 2004 Games.

This is the confident prediction of Sam Ramsamy, head of the National Olympic Committee of South Africa and the country's representative on the International Olympic Committee.

"Having observed the nuances, I believe there is no doubt we will make it in the first four or five," he said. 

His optimism is shared today by Sports Minister Steve Tshwete, who said: " My own feeling is that there is no way Cape Town is not going to be on the shortlist."

He said his confidence "derives in part from the interaction we have had with a number of prominent individuals in the Olympic movement".

These predictions came as the South African bid team made its final 20- minute presentation to the selection college at the IOC's headquarters at Vidy today. The presentation emphasised, but did not rely on, the sentiment inherent in the African bid.

Now there is nothing more to be done but wait for the verdict of the college, due to be announced at 2pm SA time tomorrow.

Cape Town was third in line to make its presentation this morning, after Stockholm and San Juan. Dr Ramsamy opened the presentation with an undertaking that a Cape Town Games would match international standards and take heed of the lessons from previous Games.

IOC discussions this week reveal that while there is general satisfaction with the outcome, financially and otherwise, of the Atlanta Games, there was considerable unease at the level of commercialism and at the insufficient involvement of the public sector and specifically local government, in Atlanta itself.

Dr Ramsamy also made it clear that all sports federations in South Africa backed the bid, which had his "unqualified endorsement".

Cape Town mayor Theresa Solomon spoke next, making the point that infrastructural improvements in the city - some of which were highlighted in the evaluation commission report and will be essential for a successful Games - are part of broader strategic initiatives to redress past imbalances and tackle the legacy of apartheid.

Mr Tshwete said the Games in Africa would make "a real, practical difference to the lives of millions of young people".

He introduced a five-minute video message from Deputy-President Thabo Mbeki, who conveyed the Government's full support of the project, and highlighted its significance for Africa.

"Your acceptance of this bid will send a strong signal to the rest of the world that this is the beginning of the African renaissance." He concluded: " If I consider the history of your distinguished movement, then it seems to me that there has never been a city, a time, a place that is more exciting for the Olympic movement than Cape Town in 2004."

Mr Ball focused on the technical expertise of the bid team and hundreds of professional volunteers who have helped to shape the plan, and on sketching the outline of the plan itself.

The team - which, in addition to those closely associated with the bid, included Speaker Frene Ginwala and Olympic medallist Marianne Kriel - had gathered in a room in the Royal Savoy Hotel, effectively the Cape Town bid's headquarters, in Ouchy near the lakeside yesterday, for a brainstorming session on the script.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


56 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 6, 1997


South Africa;
Finance Minister Trevor Manuel and Budget '97


BYLINE: Zubeida Jaffer, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1614 words


 

Cape Town - He rises from his chair, strides across the spacious office to his desk, picks up his bleeper and studies it intensely.

Figures cross the tiny screen. "See, the RSA bond rate is 15,1 this morning. The US Treasury long bond is 5,44," says Finance Minister Trevor Manuel. "I can tell you where the rand is trading, where the dollar is trading and what our bond rates are."

By his own admission, these were not matters which concerned him a year ago. "This is what I feed on every day now." 

Next week, Mr Manuel will be recorded in history as the first African National Congress minister to table a budget constructed by an ANC-led government. While the details remain a closely-guarded secret until 2.15pm on March 12, the minister this week provided insights into the thinking behind the Budget plan.

Drawing up a budget for a country was, he said, not all that different from drawing up a household budget. "If consistently from one month to the next, you are spending more than you earn, you are going to run into very serious difficulties," he said. "You have to exercise choices about what you can afford and what you cannot. Countries face the same constraints."

South Africa is spending more than it earns in revenue.

The country also owes financial institutions more than R300-billion, a third of this incurred over the past three years.

Paying the debt has become an important part of the government's budgetary commitment. "This debt places a burden on the country because the government has to repay it at the same interest rate as any member of the public," he said.

Why this obsession with paying off the debt when South Africans were in such desperate need of jobs and social services? He explained that the country was competing to capture markets by entering into trade agreements. A 5,1 percent deficit was not considered a healthy sign by international investors. "We try and fight against these people, but they say we represent a risk for as long as we do not prove that we are committed to living within our means," he said.

A country like Botswana has no deficit. Instead, it enjoys a surplus of 11, 2 percent. Compared with South Africa's 5,1 Brazil has a deficit of one percent, Iran 1,4 percent, Turkey seven percent, the US four percent and Sweden 12,2 percent.

The other dimension to the debt problem was that government departments were not using monies allocated to them. Last year, R9-billion was unspent because departments lacked capacity. The government had to pay interest on the unused R9-billion. "This makes it very difficult to consider further borrowings."

He could not accept the argument that borrowing more money would automatically solve the problems facing the country. "We already have to pay R1,35-billion in interest on the R9-billion we have not used," he said. "The worst thing we can do is to borrow money we cannot spend."

Throwing money at a problem, he feels, is not always the solution. For example, there was a perception that fighting crime was hampered because the police did not have enough vehicles. The police force of about 130 000 had about 35 000 vehicles, which meant one vehicle for every four police people. The force worked in three shifts, meaning there were never more than 50 000 persons at work at any one time, making 35 000 vehicles more than adequate. The problem was how these vehicles were being used and the fact that it had been discovered that a third of the force did not have driver's licences.

"These are not problems of resources, but of management and capacity which Safety and Security is addressing," he said.

"I could double the Safety and Security budget, but do they necessarily have the means to spend the money?"

The finalisation of the Budget since August last year has been a period of " taking pretty hard decisions".

"At the end of the day, there are always greater demands than resources," he said. He has had to find ways to satisfy different ministries, to satisfy markets and to satisfy trade union demands.

"What you do in making a budget is not an exact science," he said. "It is the art of combining different policy strands and applying certain economic tests."

Uppermost in his mind has been crime and job creation. Crime has to be reduced so that the quality of life of all South Africans can be improved and so that conditions can be created to attract investors.

Investment was crucial because this created jobs, he said. The government was committed to creating the economic environment to expand the domestic market and to extend into foreign markets. "We cannot look only to the domestic market," he said. "The domestic market is small."

To illustrate his point, he described the potential of toothbrush manufacturing. As an example, the production of toothbrushes would lead to more jobs and more people being able to buy toothbrushes in South Africa, but if the government were to strike a trade agreement with China and India for these toothbrushes, many more people would get jobs and many more South Africans would have money to buy toothbrushes.

There are millions of people in these countries who need all sorts of basic goods. Part of creating the economic environment for job creation was to send out the right signals so that speculative investment could come into the country through the JS

Mr Manuel insists this is a reality of the global economy since the end of the Cold War. "Our choices have been limited. This is becoming a seamless world."

Years ago, countries related to one another through trade. This represented 80 percent of all interactions. Today, trade constitutes only 20 percent and the 80 percent of interactions taking place is made up of the decisions taken by fund managers who move billions of dollars around the world every day.

"The turnover of the JSE is in the order of seven billion dollars a day," he said. "This drives exchange rates, interest policies and shifts the values of entire economies. You ignore it at your peril."

For this reason, Mr Manuel has become attached to his little black box. The beeper tells him at what levels world markets are trading. It gives him an idea how fund managers will be reacting. They will be on alert when he makes his speech next week.

If they read the signals as positive, they will move capital onto the JSE. " If there is a big inflow of capital, the interest rate will drop off to 10 or 12 percent," he said.

"That will feed through the economy and by the time you speak to your bank manager about a housing loan, the interest rate will be more manageable. The investments also give local companies access to foreign savings which they can then use to create jobs."

Why could there not be a discussion with lending institutions in this country to agree to the government paying back its debt at a lower interest rate?

"The problem is that the lending institutions are insurance companies and pension funds," he said.

This meant that the government owed money to ordinary South Africans.

For this reason, he was trying to move the country away from a tradition of easy borrowing from these companies.

"We are saying to them, don't run to the government, invest in the real economy."

Over the years, investments have gone into salaries of civil servants and government bureaucracy. "We want investments to go into manufacturing and other services."

Despite the critics, he is convinced that the inflow of capital onto the JSE will provide the impetus for a further inflow of permanent investment in the form joint ventures between foreign and and local business bringing the jobs which South Africans so desperately need.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


57 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 6, 1997


South Africa;
Duo convicted of Hermanus murders


BYLINE: Dennis Cavernelis, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Cape Town - A Panorama man and a teenager were today convicted in the Cape High Court of murdering three black Hermanus residents in a drunken killing spree.

Wilfred Jordaan, 26, and the 17-year-old went on a "donder jol" on September 2, 1995, intent on "dondering a few kaffirs", the court heard during the two-week trial.

The pair stood impassively in the dock today as Mr Justice J H Conradie convicted them and ordered them held in custody while awaiting sentence. 

They were found guilty of the murders of Catherine de Wet, whose skull was fractured when she was bludgeoned to death with a steering wheel lock, Eric Mjikiliso, also beaten to death with the lock, and Nkosana Bushula, who was beaten with the lock and stabbed before Jordaan drove over him.

They were convicted of assault with intent to do grievous bodily harm for an attack on Richmond Qwathikazi.

Eachhad attempted in evidence to minimise his role in the attacks and had blamed the other, but they were equally responsible, said Judge Conradie.

He said the attacks had been "so violent ... the accused must have realised (that the injuries they were inflicting) were going to be fatal".

The judge rejected an argument that Jordaan had been "too drunk to have the criminal capacity to form the intent to commit murder".

He said both accused had clear memories of the events of the night the three people were killed. The judge ordered them to be held in custody until sentence was passed.

Jordaan had been out on R3 000 bail and the youth had been out on warning.

Refusing to allow the pair to remain free, the judge said: "Circumstances have changed dramatically ... and it seems to be accepted that the accused will go to prison."

Argument in aggravation and mitigation of sentence is still to be heard.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


58 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 6, 1997


Science and Health;
Intensive search launched after human bones found in field


BYLINE: Mzilikazi wa Afrika, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

MALELANE - Police in Mpumalanga are launching an intensive search of a veld at Kaapmuiden, near Malelane, after they found scattered human bones and shredded clothing laying in a ten square metre area.

No skull was, however found, leading police to suspect that more bones may be found in a shallow grave in the area. 

Police spokesperson, Sergeant Thabisile Gama, confirmed on Tuesday that the bones have been sent for post mortum tests and said that investigators expected the results by Friday.

"The million dollar question at the moment is 'where is the skull'. The shredded clothes found with the bones has convinced us that the bones are human, so there must be a skull somewhere," she added.

"We can't be sure that there are no more bones or clues and so are using a fine tooth comb on the scene to ensure that we miss nothing."

Gama said police are still uncertain whether the bones belong to a murder victim or to a person killed by wild animals.

Kaapmuiden is near the Kruger national Park, from which wild animal often roam into surrounding populated areas.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


59 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 6, 1997


South Africa;
Press waging "unwarranted vicious" war against Dolphin deal


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 707 words


 

NELSPRUIT - The press was accused of waging an "unwarranted and vicious war of words" on Mpumalanga's secret R12,2-billion 'Dolphin Deal' by the board of directors of the Mpumalanga Parks Board (MPB) on Tuesday afternoon.

The 50-year deal, which gives the Dubai-based Dolphin Group exclusive commercial development and transverse rights to six State owned game reserves, Loskop Dam, the Blyde River Canyon and Pilgrim's Rest, was signed secretly by MPB head Alan Gray last year without any public consultation.

In return for the monopoly on the province's key tourism attractions, Dolphin has undertaken to fund MPB's budget deficit over 50-years and also erect infrastructure in the province totalling at least R300-million over the next three years. 

Gray estimates that the budgetary support of his 900 person parastatal will be worth at least R12,2-billion over 50-years.

After the provincial government reversed its unquestioning support of the deal last week and announced the creation of a review team consisting of the deal's most outspoken critics, MPB's board convened an extra-ordinary on Tuesday.

A statement issued after the meeting insists that the media "hullabaloo" over the past few weeks is the result of personal agendas and of "different people interpret(ing) the Dolphin deal's clauses in different ways - often out of context and without any insight or back ground as to why they were included".

Both the MPB and Dolphin, however, continue to refuse to release copies of the 39-page contract for public debate, citing a fundamental confidentiality clause in it which demands total secrecy of all the contract's terms for at least 50-years.

Expressing concern that the professionalism of both the MPB and its CEO, Alan Gray were being brought into question by negative publicity, the Board's statement stressed that Gray had at all times abided by the rules and relevant enabling legislation.

The statement added that Gray had the Board's full support and warned that unless decisive measures were taken to speedily resolve the controversy surrounding the deal, nature conservation in Mpumalanga faced a very uncertain future.

Charging that both the deal's critics and the media had hidden agendas, the Board said that these agendas could not be allowed to override the provincial interest and had to be brought into the open.

Supporting the new review team's trip to London, where it will meet with Dolphin president, Ketan Somaia, in an attempt to convince him to renegotiate ten "flaws" in the contract, the Board stressed that the contract remained legally binding on the government regardless of whether changes were made or not.

"Although Mr Somaia has agreed to revisit clauses in the contract, if (it) is cancelled, it could cost the province in the region of R250-million for breach of contract," the statement reads.

The statement also emphasised that the Board found it noteworthy that less than three percent of Mpumalanga's land surface was currently classified as conservation areas and that only 0,02 per cent of this was targeted for development by Dolphin

The statement fails to mention that Dolphin holds exclusive commercial control of the entire 0,02 per cent area and therefore has exclusive access and use of the entire area.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


60 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 6, 1997


Ghana;
Rawlings Calls For End To War In Zaire


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 654 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - Ghanaian President Jerry Rawlings appealed Wednesday to the warring parties in eastern Zaire to stop fighting and seek a political solution to their conflict.

He said the war, being fought between Zairian government forces and rebels known as the Banyamulenge, could engulf other countries in the subregion if not ended quickly.

Rawlings said this when he met with the secretary-general of the Organization of African Unity, Salim Ahmed Salim. Salim is a guest at Ghana's 40th Independence Anniversary celebrations being observed today. 

Rawlings said the Zairian conflict was giving Africa "a disastrous and disgraceful image" and that it was apparent that only negotiations could stop the war from escalating.

Therefore, he said visit to South Africa last week by rebel leader Laurent Kabila for talks with President Nelson Mandela on ending the war was commendable.

Rawlings urged Salim to redouble his efforts at finding a solution to the conflict.

"The role you play in trying times has been outstanding," he told Salim. " It is only in an atmosphere of stability that we can stabilize our economies."

Salim said Ghana's 40th independence anniversary celebration was "a special occasion for the whole of Africa because Ghana's independence heralded a new era for Africa."

He said now that the liberation struggle against colonial occupation was over, the focus should now on economic emancipation and ending conflicts within and between African states.

Ghana, Salim said, had been active in resolving some of these conflicts. Ghanaian troops first took part in U.N. peacekeeping efforts July 1960 in Congo's, now Zaire, secession crisis.

Salim told Rawlings, "As we celebrate your anniversary, we should reflect on what is happening in Africa now."

Salim added: "We look forward to a brighter future for Ghana and Africa and Ghana to continue to be a source of inspiration to us."

He mentioned the current conflict in Zaire and in general those of the Great Lakes region saying, "Africa has to face up to these challenges, drawing inspiration from Liberia."

In Liberia, devastated by seven years of civil that began in 1989, West African leaders sent peace monitoring troops to end the conflict and help the country to holding general elections now scheduled for May.

"Things have changed in the war-torn country," Salim said.

At the height of the fighting, leaders of the Economic Community of West African States decided in 1990 to send the troops, know as ECOMOG.

Salim later told reporters that the conflict in Zaire could still be solved although the O.A.U.'s peace efforts had not yet borne fruit.

So, the continental body is scheduled to hold a summit on the conflict March 26 in Togo.

"Time is not on our side. There is mass suffering in Zaire," he said. " Zaire is the heartland of Africa. Whatever happens to Zaire can affect the whole of the continent."


LOAD-DATE: March 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March 6, 1997


East Africa;
East African Passports To be In Use In April


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

KAMPALA, Uganda (PANA) - The East African Common Passport and Inter-State Pass will be launched in April, Uganda's minister of state for foreign affairs, Rebecca Kadaga, has said.

The presidents of Kenya, Tanzania and Uganda will on April 25 meet in Dar- Es-Salaam to sign for the travel documents, the Uganda state-owned New Vision newspaper reported Thursday, quoting Kadaga. 

She said that each president will travel with his own copy of the passport and inter-state pass after the ceremony.

"Our people have been spending longer hours filling and signing forms at every cross point but we want to avoid such delays," Kadaba said. "This is one step forward in harmonizing relationships between the people of East Africa."

She said people in the region had common interests and lot to share in their culture, trade, labor and in other areas.

In 1992, officials of the three countries started negotiations for the revival of East African Community after its collapse in 1977. Legal instruments to revive cooperation among the three states were signed March 1996 in Arusha, Tanzania.

Kadaba said each travelling document will be accompanied by a form containing three sets of questions to be answered by the applicant intending to travel.

Africa News


March 6, 1997


Zambia;
Zambian President Threatens To Sack Erring Envoys


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Zambian President Frederick Chiluba threatened Thursday to sack his diplomats who take unilateral positions on international matters without first getting directives from Lusaka.

"I don't want to be embarrassed because someone has failed to consult and vote in the wrong direction. I will fire anyone who does so," he said.

Chiluba was speaking at the swearing in ceremony of Zambia's ambassador to Egypt, Patrick Kafumukache, and his envoy to Germany, Elias Chipimo.

"Zambians are taking diplomatic jobs as retirement packages for them and they forget that they are representatives of the president. I will not accept this anymore," Chiluba said.

Zambia recently supported a United Nations resolution condemning Nigeria's alleged human rights abuses. Abuja retaliated by suspending technical assistance to Lusaka.

This bought home at least 70 Nigerians working in Zambia under the technical aid corps scheme, something similar to the United States Peace Corps.

Chiluba expressed disappointment with the foreign ministry for failing to send regular information to missions abroad on current issues in Zambia.

He said lack of information had attributed to the bad picture painted abroad on Zambia concerning democracy and on the fairness of the 1996 general elections.

His government, he said, had achieved landmark successes in economic and democratic reforms but most countries were unaware of them because they lack information from the country's representatives.

Africa News


March 6, 1997


Nigeria;
Nigerian Court Rules On Who Defends Abiola


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - The Nigerian Federal High Court in Lagos has ruled that Godwin Ajayi will continue as the leading defence lawyer for the detained, Moshood Abiola, who faces treason charges.

The court's ruling came on Wednesday, ending the one-year legal dispute between two senior Nigerian lawyers over who defends Abiola, who is charged with treason for declaring himself president in 1994. 

Ajayi's position was challenged last year by Kola, one of Abiola's children, who claimed he had his father's mandate to change the defence counsel for alleged lack of progress in the trial, which began in 1994.

The dispute had pitted Kola against his step mother, Kudirat, one of Abiola's wives who was killed by unknown gunmen last year.

Kola had wanted to replace Ajayi with Rotimi williams, while the outspoken Kudirat, before she was killed by unidentified gunmen in Lagos on June 4, 1996, had insisted that Ajayi should continue with the case.

Ruling on an application brought by Williams, Justice Babatunde Belgore of the Federal High Court said the issue of representation should have been settled by a litigant before going to court.

He therefore rejected Williams' application that Abiola be brought to court to choose his defence counsel.

There was no indication if Williams intended to appeal against the ruling. Legal experts say that such an appeal could only delay the millionaire's trial even further.

Abiola, who claimed victory in Nigeria's 1993 presidential election, cancelled by Gen. Ibrahim Babangida before he retired, is awaiting trial for treasonable felony for declaring himself president of the country in June 1994.

Despite local and international pleas for his release, the government of Gen. Sani Abacha has insisted the trial should go ahead because Abiola violated the law of the land.


LOAD-DATE: March 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March 6, 1997


Tanzania;
Tanzania Seeks Help For Zairian Refugees


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

KIGOMA, Tanzania (PANA) - Tanzania has launched an international appeal for assistance to enable it cope with the increasing number of Zairian refugees flocking into its western region of Kigoma, on the shores of Lake Tanganyika.

Making the appeal here, the Principal Secretary in the Prime Minister's Office, Ben Moses, told a delegation of ambassadors and representatives of the United Nations system who are touring Kigoma that the government has given sanctuary to refugees but needed assistance to resettle them. 

Moses said the refugees influx was so abrupt that the government was lacked the means to finance the upkeep of more than 253,000 Zairian refugees.

The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) Representative in Kigoma, John Adu, said that if the influx continued at the present rate of 1, 000 per day, then every month, a new refugee camp will have to be opened.

Between 1,000 and 1,500 refugees were being received at the Kibilizi Port in Kigoma everyday.

Adu said his agency was now sending Zairian refugees to Lugufu camp which, as of Tuesday, had 25,000 refugees. They come mostly from Fizi area in eastern Zaire where the Zairian army is fighting rebel forces.

The United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) Representative Victor Angelo, leading the strong-powered delegation of high ranking officials from Dar es Salaam-based embassies on Wednesday visited refugee camps at Kigoma's Lake Tanganyika Stadium, National Milling Corporation and the Ministry of Home Affairs holding ground.

The embassies which sent representatives to Kigoma are Poland, The Netherlands, Belgium, Finland, France, Denmark and Italy. UNICEF and the World Food Programme Country Director Ms Lacy are among members of the delegation. The delegation visits Mtambila, Moyobosi and Nyalugusu refugee camps in Kasulu District on Thursday.


LOAD-DATE: March 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

65 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 6, 1997


Ghana;
Rawlings Urges Ghanaians To Build On Past Achievements


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 680 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana (PANA) - President Jerry John Rawlings on Thursday appealed to Ghanaians to gird their loins, forget the past and build on the achievements they have made over the past 40 years.

"If we have deserted our goals and ideals as a people, this is the time to return to them," he said, when addressing a colorful parade of school children and some voluntary organizations to climax Ghana's 40th independence anniversary.

Ghana, which got its independence from Britain on 6 March 1957, became the first black Sub-Sahara African country to win its flag independence. 

The parade was witnessed by several foreign dignitaries including President Henri Konan Bedie of Cote d'Ivoire and former President Julius Nyerere of Tanzania.

Madam Fathia Nkrumah, the Egyptian-born widow the Ghana's first president, Kwame Mkrumah, and the Organization of African Unity (OAU) Secretary-General, Salim Ahmed Salim, were also in attendance.

Rawlings said the nation must see beyond its present circumstances "and move forward to the targets we have set and use our faith as a driving power to get to where we want to go."

He said every nation has its share of struggles of one kind or another and Ghana is no exception.

"We each have a part to play and that part does not include fault finding and blind criticism because civic responsibility means doing something and not complaining that something ought to be done."

Rawlings said the time had come to redefine patriotism "because except we combine all of our efforts we will not get far.

"It is not the duty of one person but every man, every woman and every child. Those who refuse to contribute and will not allow anyone else to give of themselves must step aside."

He said Ghanaians must not despair even if things go wrong as things would sometimes do.

"As we must march forward we must remember that it takes courage and perseverance. It takes a desire to succeed." "It takes vigilance and hard work, faith in God as well as in ourselves as a nation and in our dreams and visions. Let us not take for granted what has cost men and women their lives," Rawlings said.

Rawlings said as the nation celebrates it 40th anniversary "let us strive to finish the work which began four decades ago."

"To bind up the national wounds and do all to achieve and cherish lasting peace among ourselves and with all nations."

"It is my desire that we will each become a light of hope and of truth, peace and love. Each of us a flame burning corruption and dishonesty, greed and viciousness once and for all," the President said.

Rawlings commented for the first time on the alleged financial scandal involving A-Life Supermarket and some officials of the Ghana Commercial Bank and said it was criminal for the bank to give one person loans amounting to billions of cedis.

He said small scale industrialists find it difficult to get loans from banks but it is an irony that a trader could get such huge amounts from a bank to set up stores.

"This is economic murder," the President said.


LOAD-DATE: March 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March 7, 1997


Burkina Faso;
CPJ Condemns Attack on Radio Director


BYLINE: Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

New York - Text of a letter from William A. Orme, Jr., executive director, Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ), to President Blaise Compaore of Burkina Faso, March 5, 1997.

The Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) writes to condemn the February 19, 1997 attack of Moustapha Tambiano, president general of Horizon-FM radio station, a Voice of America affiliate, by four supporters of the ruling Congress for Democracy and Progress (CDP) party. Tambiano was attacked in front of the CDP's offices in Ouagadougou and at the United States Embassy following the February 16th airing of commentary on the station's call-in program, "Sondage Democratique."

As a nonpartisan organization of journalists committed to the defense of our colleagues' rights worldwide, CPJ condemns the attack on Tambiano as a violation of press freedom and his right to hold and express opinions and ideas. These rights are guaranteed by Article 19 of the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights, Article 19 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, and Article 9 of the African Charter on Human and Peoples' Rights, to which we respectfully remind Your Excellency, Burkina Faso is a signatory.

Your Excellency, we urge you to do everything within your power to ensure a thorough investigation of this attack and a prompt arrest and trial of those found responsible for this battery. We also urge you to guarantee the protection of journalists' sources and the media's right to practice their profession freely and safely.

For information, contact Committee to Protect Journalists, 330 Seventh Avenue, New York NY 10001, U.S.A. Tel:+1 212 465 1004, Fax:+1 212 465 9568. Kakuna Kerina (x 103), kkerina@cpj.org, or Selam Demeke (x 118), demeke@cpj. org. Internet: http://www.cpj.org/.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Niger;
CPJ Protests Attack on Niger Radio Station


BYLINE: Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

New York - Text of a letter from William A. Orme, Jr., executive director, Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ), to Ibrahim Barre Mainassara, president of the National Salvation Council of Niger, March 5, 1997

The Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) writes to strongly protest the destruction of equipment estimated at US$ 80,000 at the offices of Radio Anfani (FM 100), a Voice of America affiliate, by five unidentified armed men wearing military uniforms who stated they were following orders.

The men broke into Radio Anfani's office on March 1, 1997, at 3:30 a.m. and held the security guard/janitor on duty at gunpoint while they ransacked and destroyed the station's broadcasting equipment. The station was forced off the air until March 3, 1997 due to this incident. 

As a nonpartisan organization of journalists committed to the defense of our colleagues' rights worldwide, CPJ condemns the vandalization of Radio Anfani, as a violation of press freedom. These rights are guaranteed by Article 19 of the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights, Article 19 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, and Article 9 of the African Charter on Human and Peoples' Rights, to which we respectfully remind Your Excellency, Niger is a signatory.

Your Excellency, we urge you to do everything within your power to ensure a thorough professional investigation of this case, as well as the prompt arrests and trials of those found responsible of this crime. We also urge you to guarantee the protection of the media's right to practice their profession freely and safely.

For information, contact Committee to Protect Journalists, 330 Seventh Avenue, New York NY 10001, U.S.A. Tel:+1 212 465 1004, Fax:+1 212 465 9568. Kakuna Kerina (x 103), kkerina@cpj.org, or Selam Demeke (x 118), demeke@cpj. org. Internet: http://www.cpj.org/.

Africa News


March 7, 1997


Zambia;
CPJ Protests Arrest of Zambian Journalist


BYLINE: Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

New York - Text of a letter from William A. Orme, Jr., executive director, Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ), to Frederick Chiluba, president of the Republic of Zambia, March 5, 1997.

The Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) writes to condemn in the strongest terms the arrest and imprisonment of Masautso Phiri, special projects editor for the privately owned newspaper The Post, on February 11, 1997. Phiri was sentenced to three months in jail by the Supreme Court of Zambia on charges of contempt of court, following an article entitled " Praising God Loudly" which was published in the December 11, 1996 issue of The Post. The article alleged that the seven judges of the Supreme Court had been paid a total of K7 billion (US$5 million) to rule in favor of the state in a case where opposition parties challenged the candidacy of President Frederick Chiluba in the November 18, 1996 elections. 

As a nonpartisan organization of journalists committed to the defense of our colleagues' rights worldwide, CPJ condemns the arrest of Phiri as a grave attack on press freedom and a blatant violation of his right to hold and express opinions and ideas. These rights are guaranteed by Article 19 of the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights, Article 19 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, Article 9 of the African Charter on Human and People's Rights, and the 1991 Windhoek Declaration on Promoting an Independent and Pluralistic African Press, all to which, we respectfully remind Your Excellency, Zambia is a signatory.

We strongly urge Your Excellency to do everything in your power to dismiss the charges against Phiri and to ensure his immediate and unconditional release.

For information, contact Committee to Protect Journalists, 330 Seventh Avenue, New York NY 10001, U.S.A. Tel:+1 212 465 1004, Fax:+1 212 465 9568. Kakuna Kerina (x 103), kkerina@cpj.org, or Selam Demeke (x 118), demeke@cpj. org. Internet: http://www.cpj.org/.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


69 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 7, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Women: Pillars Of Living Church


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1574 words


 

Nairobi - Many in the church and outside say that without women's participation, churches would grind to a halt, as reported by APS Correspondent Sam Gonza.

The fact that women are pillars of the living church is underscored by the findings of study teams that the World Council of Churches (WCC) sent to each of its over 300-member churches in more than 100 countries worldwide, as part of the Ecumenical Decade of the Churches in Solidarity with Women (1988-1998). But there is also the general lament that women are still frustrated by the churches' failure to admit them into critical areas of decision making and participation.

At its first Assembly held in Amsterdam, Netherlands in 1948, the World Council of Churches (WCC) heard a ground breaking report on the role and status of women in the church. Fifty years later, come 1998, the Eighth General Assembly, to be held in Harare, Zimbabwe, and which will also coincide with the ecumenical council's 50th anniversary and the end of the WCC Ecumenical Decade of the Churches in Solidarity with Women (1988-1998), will listen to emphasis on the pivotal role that women play as pillars of the living church. But at Harare, there will be a special plea to the churches to commit themselves to enlarging women's participation in key areas of Church life. 

Study teams sent out as part of the WCC Ecumenical Decade in Solidarity with Women reported that around the world, Christian women witness to the image of God within them. "The hope of renewal for church and society rests in this witness. Wherever we went as living letters to the churches, the women's love for the church and their willingness to commit themselves to work in church were strikingly evident. All over the world women are the pillars of the church," the teams concluded.

Women are always active, strong and ready to carry forth the church's mission.

The teams were inspired by evidence of women's determination to overcome oppression. They met women in the churches who were working in their local and national context to roll away the stones of violence, racism, economic injustice and exclusion. "There are women with enormous zest for life, who struggle for life, who are committed to social political change, who are resisting the forces of death," the team noted.

Among examples of women's determination and resistance were; women running crisis centres for victims of rape and battering; women involved in credit cooperatives and revolving loan funds; women organising community soup kitchens and feeding centres; literacy andvocational training programmes and women working with refugees, migrants and internally displaced people.

There are also an increasing number of women who are breaking their silence and speaking out, campaigning against violence or harmful cultural practices.

Sadly, just as evident were many churches' failure to fully receive and respond to women's gifts and challenges, to admit women to key areas of participation.

In their report, the study teams accentuate the fact that women are the majority in most congregations and the keenest participants in the spiritual and liturgical life of the church.

A Togolese church president told the team that he had discovered that women kept his church alive, that without the women there would be no life and hardly any regular activities in the church. "If the women were to leave, we would have only decision-makers without doers," he told the WCC team visiting member churches in the African nation.

The teams concluded that women are active in a wide variety of lay ministries-diakonia, fund raising, teaching and counselling in parish life. " They gain strength and satisfaction from all these kinds of participation even if their contribution is not always recognised and they are unable to attain leadership in these areas."

Significantly on their travels, the study teams also met women - both feminist theologians and lay women - who are ready to assume new roles in the church. "These women are determined to draw out the liberating strands of their faith. They nurture a vision of the church that is a community of women and men, that listens to hopes, dreams, frustrations, that is a source of liberalization."

In their report, the WCC teams point out that some women have found no place in the church to nurture their deep spiritual yearning and, after much frustration have started alternative church movements as new ways of being the church, of expressing their spirituality.

"It could be said that, rather than these women leaving the church, it is the hierarchical church which abandoned them. As one woman put it; Sometimes you have to leave the church in order to go back to the church," noted the WCC study.

For example in Switzerland, a woman remarked that women often feel the only way they can get "out of the playroom" is to act quite independently of the established church. "Yet the renewal of the church must depend on the valuing and honouring-often financially as well-the talents of all its members equally, and not just paying lip service to the community of women and men."

In Madagascar, a small group of young women theologians, students and wives of students shared with the visiting WCC team their struggle to be admitted and accepted and their pain of not being allowed to the ministry to which they felt called.

"We learned that what had been represented to us as an achievement of the church-the admission of female students to the faculty-was in fact a victory they had won after a long fight," the visiting team noted.

In Kenyan churches, the number of top women in positions of hierarchical responsibility is "infinitesimal," the team there observed. "It became clear that most churches have neither a policy nor developed a theological position to empower women to become clergy, theologians or lay readers in significant positions of majority decision-making in the church in Kenya."

The excuse given in some churches which accept the ordination of women, but do not have enough pastors, is that women in the church do not really wish to take advantage of the opportunities to become pastors. Other churches do not actively promote or encourage women to put themselves forward for the ordained or theological ministry.

In Ghana, they found among the reasons cited for the failure of women to participate in leadership, was that "women are their own worst enemies, because when given the opportunity to elect women, they elect men!"

The teams' report says as a rule, women may find it extremely difficult to voice discontent in the presence of men in general and church leaders in particular.

"Time and again during our visits, women said little or expressed general satisfaction in the presence of men or male church leaders, but eventually, when the men were not there, told us quite a different story. And occasionally it happened that our visit encouraged women to speak out for the first time about being denied a place in church structure, even in the presence of the head of the church," noted the WCC study.

In South Africa for example, most meetings included male leadership. The latter always assumed the role of moderators and spokespersons even when the questions were directed to the women present. "The women themselves, in almost all cases, would not respond immediately and waited, as if they also expected the minister, bishop, or whoever to be the one to respond. "We detected some degree of uneasiness on the part of the male leaders when we posed questions to the women and some hesitancy on the part of the women," the WCC team said.

In Zambia, men were often the first to tell how things were for women. "But when the women in the same meetings finally spoke, their assessment of their own situation was radically different from that given by the men."


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


70 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 7, 1997


Zaire;
Bitter Pill For Ailing Mobutu


BYLINE: APS Correspondent, All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1934 words


 

Kinshasa - In poor health, Zairean President Mobutu Sese Seko is facing one of his worst crises ever since advancing rebels in this central African nation took up arms in the eastern regions of North and South Bukavu.

Sprawling Zaire must be weighing heavily on President Mobutu Sese Seko, who was recently in France convalescing following a prostate cancer operation and on an official tour of Morocco, appealing for help to regain control of the eastern region, currently held by rebels.

The Morocco tour came shortly after a Zairean army counter-offensive to regain the North and South Bukavu regions collapsed and the Zairean Tutsi rebels, known as the Banyamulenge, started gaining ground and securing footholds in two other neighbouring regions in a lightning onslaught also aimed at overthrowing the long-ruling Mobutu.

Mobutu, who arrived in the North-West African country on February 4 was seeking aid from his traditional ally, King Hassan II, just as Zaire's official news agency, AZAP was announcing a massive recruitment drive, asking boys aged 15 to 18 to sign up at the nearest police station.

During his Moroccan visit, Mobutu met with King Hassan, who in 1977 provided troops to help down a rebellion at Kolwezi, a major mining centre in Shaba province. 

But a rebel spokesman scoffed at the bid, saying: "We are no longer in the era where Morocco can easily aid Mobutu. Times have changed. Morocco should understand that."

Togo, another traditional ally of Zaire, has said there was no question of it sending troops to Zaire, while in Cairo a senior Egyptian official said on February 4 that Zaire had asked for "political support," but denied there had been a request for military aid.

France, another former ally, has ruled out supplying military aid to Kinshasa, citing an European Union arms embargo against Zaire, but there were indications that Chad was willing to send in a force to help Mobutu.

Announcing the Zairean Armed Forces (FAZ) recruitment drive on February 4, AZAP said new forces were needed to deal with "the aggression...by regular Rwandan and Ugandan troops allied with Kabila's rebels."

So far the FAZ, stymied by severe logistical and financial problems, has remained largely on the defensive in the face of rebel advances, managing only to rescue an area near Walikale in North Kivu province.

FAZ soldiers, who currently earn an average of one dollar a month and have not been paid in months, have already staged two rebellions in the capital Kinshasa.

Although the Zairean government has flown fresh men and munitions to the Watsa area, the rebels have already taken the wind out of the FAZ counter- offensive, which the government vowed two weeks ago would be "sweeping and crushing."

By capturing the key port of Kelemie on the banks of Lake Tanganyika on February 3, the rebels have not only extended the territory under their control in the east of the country, but can now boast a bridgehead in Zaire's resource-rich Shaba province.

Led by Laurent-Desire Kabila, they are now present in four provinces -- North and South Kivu, which they have controlled since November, Haut-Zaire and Shaba. Their holdings stretch some 1,000 kilometres along Zaire's eastern border with Uganda, Rwanda, Burundi and Tanzania.

Building on their strength, the rebels issued an ultimatum on February 4, giving the government until February 21 to open negotiations or face a " general offensive."

But Lubmana Kapasa, head of the Zairean presidential press service, said in Rabat, where President Mobutu Sese Seko was seeking assistance; "There is no question of having a dialogue with the rebels for the simple reason that these people are puppets manipulated by Rwanda and Uganda.

"You don't hold dialogue with a traitor. War remains the only solution to ending the rebellion and the position of the Zairean government has not changed one iota on this subject," he said, referring to Kabila.

Meanwhile, Zairean authorities, welcoming a proposal by visiting European Union special envoy for a regional meeting prior to any international conference on the Great lakes region cautioned that it wants "invading forces" off its soil.

In a broadcast on national television, EU envoy Mr. Aldo Ajello, following a meeting with Zaire's Foreign Minister, said his responsibility was to seek a peaceful way out of the crises in the region.

Apparently seeking to shrug off the loss of Kalemie as well as setbacks in the north-east, FAZ spokesmen in Kisangani, the capital of Haut-Zaire and headquarters of the government counter-offensive, have reiterated that the rebels were backed by professionals, and not the ragtag rebels who first took up arms in September, a reference to Kinshasa's repeated accusations against Rwanda, Uganda and Burundi of involvement in the fighting, charges all the three countries have strongly denied.

The FAZ spokesman, who requested anonymity, also charged for the first time on February 5 in Kisangani that the rebels had managed to obtain military equipment, which included communications equipment and mortars, that was sent to a neighbouring country late last year for a multi-national intervention force that never materialized.

But other sources in Kisangani have also claimed that the FAZ was being backed by former Rwandan Hutu soldiers, who are held responsible for the 1994 genocide in their country, which left between 500,000 and one million dead, most of them minority Tutsis and moderate Hutus.

The rebel advance has now triggered a new movement of refugees in the region, which has previously housed hundreds of thousands of refugees from neighbouring Rwanda, most of whom have since returned home.

Some 40,000 refugees and some 7,000 Zairean civilians are reported by the UN High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), to have left camps in Shabunda on February 5 and fled after learning that the rebels had captured Katshungu, a town some 45 kilometers away. Shabunda has since also fallen to the rebels.

"All the refugee sites in Shabunda are empty," an UNHCR statement released in Geneva said, quoting a top UNHCR official in the region, Dillah Dumaye.

The FAZ, underpaid and under-equipped, appear in increasing disarray in the face of a well-disciplined and well-supplied rebellion.

Amid the raging fighting in the eastern Zairean regions, the UN High Commissioner for Refugees Sadako Ogata embarked on a tour of the restive Great Lakes region central Africa on February 6 to see first-hand the plight of refugees who are at once victims of war and international indifference.

"We have to try to give them some kind of humanitarian assistance to save their lives and come to a solution," she said prior to her trip to Zaire, Kenya, Burundi, Rwanda and Tanzania that will continue up to February 15.

Progress was made when 1.2 million Rwandan Hutus recently trekked home in biblical fashion after more than two years in exile, putting aside fears of Tutsi reprisals for the genocide of 1994.

Some 600,000 Rwandans and Zaireans continue to struggle in a living hell in eastern Zaire, transformed into a vast battlefield as rebels confront government forces.

Ogata said that first, she wanted to ensure that a minimum of humanitarian aid reaches refugees who are living in makeshift camps where high mortality ates are the norm.

Secondly, she will press for control over armed extremists who continue to lord it over refugee camps, scaring people from returning to their homes, and finally, she hoped to organize the return of as many more Rwandan refugees as possible by convincing the various sides involved to create free-travel zones in eastern Zaire, but she faces enormous obstacles.

A logistical nightmare makes it difficult to get relief aid to three camps housing 200,000 refugees, while humanitarian groups have also been unable to reach tens of thousands, maybe hundreds of thousands, of Rwandans and Zaireans who have been wandering around eastern Zaire for months.

Politics on the ground have also further complicated matters. The Zairean authorities want relief flights to be inspected in Kinshasa before going on to the refugee camps, as flights coming from Uganda are accused of sending troops to fight alongside Zairean rebels.

Kigali states for its part that the Rwandan refugee camps outside its borders are teeming with former Hutu soldiers and their families, who are hostile to its Tutsi-led government, but disarming the militias is a task that lies outside the scope of the UNHCR.

"There has to be some kind of separation effort made, not just by civilians like us, but by police or some kind of military force," said Ogata, who favours creating an international "stand-by" force that could snap into action on orders from the United Nations.

Finally, creating security zones for refugees in eastern Zaire to return home by foot or truck will require long negotiations with all parties in the area, she noted.

Ogata does not hide her relative impotence in the face of a reluctance by third countries to get involved in the Zairean conflict and to help ease refugee suffering.

Of the crisis, she said: "It is not going to be solved so soon, overnight. But at least international attention and determination have to be mobilized."

In Tanzania, where 220,000 refugees from Burundi are lingering on, Ogata is looking for guarantees that the government will not expel them back to their country, where a civil war continues.

Some 122 refugees were killed upon their return to Burundi last month after having been forced out of Tanzania.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997

Africa News


March 7, 1997


Science and Health;
Harmless Yet Dangerous 'Cut'


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1960 words


 

Nairobi - The uvula has always been cut, say traditional practitioners and adherents. But medical experts argue that if 'that harmless cut in the mouth' must be performed, then all necessary sanitary precautions should be taken, as reported by APS Correspondent George Mwangi.

Mary Ngotho, 20, could not even brave it to hold her baby as the traditional uvula cutter (daktari wa kilimi in Kiswahili) prepared to perform what this young mother believed was a crucial operation.

Her grandmother, visiting Mary's family last Christmas, had diagnosed the child's uvula as sick and insisted that it should be removed. She had accompanied her granddaughter to the makeshift clinic in the city outskirts to supervise the cutting. 

And when Mary appeared hesitant at the eleventh hour, her grandmother harshly reminded her why they were at the clinic; "What is better? To let the doctor cut the uvula or to let it kill the baby?" Upon which she took the child from its mother and held it firmly, ready for the "doctor". Perhaps terrified, the one-year-old let out a scream.

There was no anaesthesia. The traditional uvula cutter held the baby's jaws with his left hand to force the mouth wide open. Then he put a table spoon in the mouth, apparently to hold the tongue back and when the uvula end is clipped to fall in it. With a pair of long surgical tongs, he held the uvula still, while with a pair of surgical scissors he clipped its tip. Then he removed the spoon with the small piece of flesh in it.

It was very quick - about one minute. The operation was over. Perhaps due to the immense pain, the baby did not cry much. There was no after-cut treatment. They paid Kshs 50 (about one US dollar) and left the "clinic".

Traditional uvulectomy is still practised in most parts of Africa especially among the Bantu tribes. In Kenya, it is commonly carried out among the Kikuyu, Akamba, Kalenjin and Maasai among others. A spot-check in the Kenyan capital, Nairobi, will more often than not reveal that most people got their uvula cut at childhood, regardless of their present age or ethnic group.

It is not known when and where the practice started. As common with African knowledge and philosophy, it is documented in the mind and handed down through generations. However, traditionally before the introduction of surgical instruments now in use, the Kikuyu used a rugaa, a local cutting tool made from cow hide.

But what is uvula and why is it cut? The uvula can be defined as a small cone shaped piece of flesh that hangs from the back of the roof of the mouth, bordering the nasopharynx.

In the medical world, the uvula has no known function in human anatomy. Bacterial or viral infection may cause inflamation. In the former, antibiotic treatment is usually recommended while in the latter case, the swelling subsides in a few days. Uvulectomy - the cutting of the uvula - can only be medically preferred in cases where there is a tumour or a cancerous growth on the uvula.

In Kenya, government, mission and most private hospitals and clinics do not recommend uvulectomy. Dr. A. Patel, a practising surgeon in Nairobi says uvulectomy is not traditionally or medically practised in the Indian sub- continent.

An American paediatrician Dr. Jackob Havenen, currently working in Kikuyu Mission Hospital says uvulectomy is not carried out in America and Europe. " Even in a case where the throat may be too narrow, obstructing breathing and swallowing, doctors remove the tonsils but not the uvula."

Traditionally, mothers who seek uvulectomy for their babies complain that the uvula is too long, causing the baby to have coughs and vomit. They also believe that if the uvula is not cut, it will interfere with the child's voice development, eventually leading to stammering in adulthood.

However, medical experts disagree with this belief. Dr. D. Simiyu, a paediatrician and lecturer at Nairobi University says; "In the natural history of child development, a child will normally have coughs seven to eight times. Since traditional uvulectomy is done at a time when the child's immune system is not fully developed, this coincidence makes mothers believe it is the uvula which causes the cough, although in actual sense the uvula has nothing to do with the cough. Whether it is cut or not, it does not make any difference."

Dr. Peter Mugwe, an Ear, Nose and Throat (ENT) specialist notes that mothers seek uvulectomy due to lack of knowledge. He explains: "Children will have colds and coughs usually at night, which may have something to do with the nasal passage blockage and their weak immune system. Vomiting is a digestion problem, while voice development is determined by the vocal cords. Therefore, proper treatment for these diseases should be sought instead of treatment on other secondary factors, in this case, removing the uvula. This is also against medical practice and ethics."

In case of an inflamation of the uvula or uvulitis, Dr. Mugwe says the uvula appears long, swollen, reddish or has pimples at the tip.

A qualified physician would advise on treatment.

Mr. Anos O. Opiyo, who runs a private child health clinic in a Nairobi estate, notes that mothers will bring their babies to see him before or after uvulectomy. "Before - a mother will ask if the uvula should be cut as she is not sure whether it is the one causing the cough. After - now a mother will be sure it is not the uvula causing the cough, as the child is still coughing, and she is now seeking proper medical treatment."

Residential traditional uvula cutters can be found in mostly low- income suburbs but they maintain a low profile as they operate without licences.

Mr. Peter Mukono, a traditional uvula cutter, running a "clinic" some 25 kilometers from the city centre, had this to say about his trade; "It is in my family. I inherited it from my late father who got it from my grandfather. Firstly, when a mother brings a child I look in the mouth to see whether the uvula is long, reddish and with pimples before I accept to cut it. Not everybody can cut it, there is a way of doing it. It has to be precise and at a particular point."

There is no "after-cut" treatment although some traditional practitioners advice their patients to take aspirins or a ginger soda to relief the pain. Charges range from between Ksh 50 and Kshs 150 (1 US$ = Ksh 55) in Nairobi and parts of Central Province. On average, Mr Mukono attends to ten patients per day.

But not all mothers support uvulectomy. Mrs Muthoni Kimaru, 35, says she will never take any of her children for an uvulectomy. She narrates an incidence she witnessed in a local district hospital early last year-"In the children's clinic, there was a mother in the queue with a baby who looked seriously ill. Its face was turning pale. But the frightened mother kept her place in the line for some time. But then some women noticed her baby looked seriously ill and urged her to jump queue and see the doctor. We later learnt that she had taken the child for an uvula cut in a quack's clinic in the town's slum area. The child's uvula had been cut wrongly, resulting in excessive bleeding. It was too late to save the baby's life."

A social worker Mrs Ruth Okare says it is inhuman to subject a child to such unnecessary pain. "Nowadays there are proper means of treatment, why resort to an unnecessary primitive way?" she poses.

But traditional uvulectomy is not confined to children alone. Even adults who were not cut in childhood may opt for it if the uvula becomes persistently inflamed.

Esther Muthoni, 23, a bank employee, recently had her uvula cut. "It is now better than having it make me occasionally sick," she said. Muthoni got her uvula cut at Ndumberi village, about 20 kilometers from the city centre.

Traditionalists argue that uvulectomy used to play a significant role in the old days when there were no hospitals.

"It was our God given wisdom to treat uvula sickness," said Mumbi Kangu, 60. But she notes that since medical treatment is available today then there is no need for uvulectomy. But as an after thought, she asks, "If you say it has no function in the body, why don't they cut it instead of the treatment which will be recurrent and costly especially nowadays when we pay even in government hospitals?"

Although traditional uvula cutters operating in Nairobi generally take basic precautions by boiling their tools in water, still there is a danger of spreading disease through blood contamination as the tools may not be consistently sterilized after every use.

On the other hand, in rural areas, sanitary measures may not be taken seriously due to a lower level of awareness and general illiteracy. Traditional uvula cutting thus puts the health of many children and adults at the risk of contracting diseases such as the Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome - HIV/AIDS, tetanus and syphilis.

Other complications that are likely to occur as a result of the infected wound include septicaemia (blood poisoning), which would definitely cause further complications. Excessive bleeding, especially if the child is haemophilic or the uvula is cut wrongly can result in anaemia - or worse - death. Ironically, much as the cut is done to stop coughing, the wound itself may end up causing an irritating cough.

As Dr. Simiyu puts it, "if uvulectomy is done through the right process, it is a harmless tradition and thus difficult to die." But it is up to the Ministry of Health to establish acceptable working grounds with the traditional uvula cutters so that the necessary sanitary measures are observed in their practice.

In addition, the public should be enlightened on the dangers of uvula cutting by quacks. "As it does not make any difference medically whether it is cut or not - those doing it must be warned to do it hygienically," observes Dr. Simiyu.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


March 7, 1997


Kenya;
Clergy Want More Time Openness on Issuing IDs


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Nairobi - A cross section of Kenyans including clergy say the deadline set for the issuance of second generation Identity Cards (IDs) should be extended and obstacles in the process eliminated so that all deserving citizens can be accommodated in the nation-wide exercise.

On January 30, President Daniel arap Moi extended the previous January 31 deadline by a month, up to the end of February.

Many Kenyans argue that the February 28 deadline would not be adequate, given the many obstacles that hamper the process of registering for new generation IDs. These range from relaxed officers, corruption and lack of enough manpower to handle the situation effectively. 

"I only need to walk out of my office to see the long queues of Kenyans - young and old, desperately chasing this new ID," says Rev. Canon Peter Njoka, the Provost of Nairobi's All Saints (Anglican) Cathedral.

His church compound is housing one of the nation-wide centres that have been set up for the exercise.

Rev. Njoka doubts that the extra time of one month would enable deserving Kenyans register for the IDs. "Definitely one month will not be enough. We need more time for this exercise and it is my hope that President Moi will reconsider the idea of extending the current deadline for the exercise if requested to do so by Kenyans," the Provost observed.

The Kenyan President announced the extension of the previous January 31 deadline upon request by University of Nairobi students who had hosted him for dinner at their campus.

The Anglican clergy wondered why registration of the national identity card, normally a continuous process, should be linked with deadlines or general elections scheduled late 1997. "The exercise should be an on-going process. We should not neglect the fact there is always a Kenyan or Kenyans attaining 18 years, (the age of majority) every day," he told this writer.

Asked if he had concrete reasons to believe that the ID registration exercise is being linked to the country's forthcoming general elections, Rev. Njoka, retorted; "Well at least this is the general thinking among Kenyans and it is up to the government to prove them wrong.

"For me, the process of registering persons for national identification is normal and genuine. It should be delinked from any other business for a free and effective process," he added.

At a press conference, called on January 28, two days before President Moi extended the IDs' deadline from January 31 to February 28, Kenya's Episcopal Conference had addressed the issue of "delinking" the issuance of the new IDs to the forthcoming general elections.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


73 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 7, 1997


Uganda;
Bishop In Unprecented Attack On Uganda's President;


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 600 words


 

Kitgum, Uganda - Kitgum Anglican Bishop Marclord Baker Ochola II has made a scathing attack on Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni for refusing to talk peace with Ugandan rebels of the Lord's Resistance Army (LRA) led by Joseph Kony.

Speaking at a requiem mass for a senior government official killed by the rebels early this month, the bishop reminded Ugandans that in the end everyone will face death. He went on to say every government in the world - " even if it stays in power for 500 years will go......"

Kitgum District of Northern Uganda is home to Uganda's Acholi people. Early 1997, the Lord's Resistance Army, comprising many ex- Ugandan Army soldiers who served previous regimes, descended on several villages in the district, killing as many as 300 innocent civilians. 

The government of Uganda says these raids are facilitated by the Sudanese government, which it charges supports various rebel groups in Northern Uganda. Sudan has denied such accusations, counter charging that Uganda facilitates rebels of the Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA).

Bishop Ochola, in what observers see as an unusually one-sided attack on the government in Kampala, said if President Museveni wants to finish the Acholi people, he should not use Kony rebels, but should turn his guns onto the people and finish them directly.

The Kitgum bishop said talking peace with the rebels does not mean the government is weak or defeated but the purpose would be to stop the killing and displacement of innocent people. More than 200,000 people are believed to be displaced due to the current fighting in Northern Uganda.

Throughout much of 1996, Uganda's Catholic bishops also urged President Museveni to talk peace with the rebels. Museveni has consistently rejected those pleas saying the rebels had committed unforgivable atrocities against the people.

However, the government has instituted a policy of pardoning rebels who surrender. The President says such amnesty does not apply to the leaders of the rebel groups in the north, because they are the mastermind of the atrocities against innocent civilians.

Following Bishop Ochola's denunciation of the government, Uganda's Vice- President Dr. Specioza Kazibwe rapped religious leaders advocating talks with the rebels, saying doing so created a false belief among rebel ranks that they are supported by religious leaders. "Even the Bible commands; 'Do not kill' yet these bishops say if he is killing talk to him," she observed.

Meanwhile, a Verona priest was recently dragged from the altar by rebels of the West Nile Bank Front (WNBF) and taken to the mission house where rebels took away property worth thousands of dollars. The WNBF are allied to the LRA but operate in north-western Uganda.

Italian Fr. Silvano Renzo of Ladonga Parish, was conducting early mass when some 20 rebels descended on the church and forcibly removed him from the altar. There were no reports of injury among the congregation.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.
