Africa News


March 7, 1997


Science and Health;
Controversial Claims On Aids Origin


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 907 words


 

Accra - During a recent visit to Ghana, African-American biochemist Dr. Jack Felder, 57, charged that the HIV/AIDS virus was deliberately engineered by American germ warfare scientist.

He also went on to say that polio vaccines and other drugs being sent to Africa could contain the Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS) virus.

His claims about AIDS-polio vaccine linkage caused a lot of fear since his statement coincided with a nation-wide anti-polio immunization campaign funded by the World Health Organization (WHO) and the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF).

Reacting to the claims by Dr. Felder, the American Embassy here described the accusation as "scurrilous". The embassy described Dr. Felder, a one time employee of the Army's Natick Laboratories - biological research laboratories - as "an eccentric." 

Ghana's leading medical scientist Dr. Francis Nkrumah asserted angrily that there was "no iota of truth" in Dr. Felder's claim linking polio vaccination to HIV."

Now a new book published in the United States late last year is set to fuel the apprehension of millions of people worldwide. Entitled, Emerging Viruses - the Story of AIDS and Ebola, it was researched by an American dentist Dr. Leonard Horowitz, who worked on it since 1990.

The new title reproduces United States Defence Department papers of 1970, relating to Dr. Henry Kissinger's directive to American scientists to produce AIDS type viruses.

The book traces the mass outbreak of AIDS in the early 80s to the 1974 vaccination with a Hepatitis B Vaccine that it claims was first tested on the gay (homosexual) community and mentally retarded children in New York.

The author claims that later the same year, this same vaccine was tested in Eastern Zaire, Central Africa and North-Western Uganda. Dr. Horowitz says this contamination was by accident.

Dr. Horowitz who claims he stumbled on the evidence in 1990 told the Voice of America - Voices of Africa programme that the AIDS viruses came originally from monkeys that had been modified by a team of American researchers led by Dr. Robert Gallo - the man reputed to have discovered the HIV or AIDS causing virus.

He claims the researchers had modified the viruses to see if primate (i.e. originating from monkeys or chimpanzees) viruses could cause cancers in humans.

"The primate virus - the HIV precursor - was first implanted in white cells which allowed it to bridge the gap between human and primates. That is how the jump occurred," the researcher explains.

Dr. Horowitz says that Dr. Gallo virtually told a lie about "discovering" the HIV virus. A substantial amount of research with these modified viruses were done in north-western Uganda.

According to Dr. Horowitz, other key players in the development of the killer virus included a founder of an American drug company and biological warfare expert who came to the United States from Germany after the Second World War.

Citing 1970 Department of Defence appropriation papers, the book blames Dr Henry Kissinger,United States Secretary of State at the time as the author of the campaign to develop anti-immune system viruses for warfare purposes. The Department of Defence papers show $10 million was made available to researchers for the purpose.

Others who have blamed Dr. Kissinger include Capt. Joyce Riley of the Texas- based Gulf War Veterans Association.

She told the World Wide Christian Radio that she had stumbled across papers implicating Dr. Kissinger by accident while researching the series of strange diseases that have reportedly killed 15,000 Americans since the end of the Gulf War in 1991.

But an official of the Washington-based National Cancer Institute who contributed to the Voice of Africa programme said the retro- viruses (the class of HIV precursors found in primates such as monkeys) had modified themselves naturally and entered the human body through food and other pathways.

Dr. Raoul Benveniste insisted on the programme that the technology for the modification of viruses was not available at the time. "The retroviruses are only present in African primates. This is why the disease originated in Africa," he said.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


75 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 7, 1997


South Africa;
Law Versus Ethics In South Africa


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 614 words


 

Cape Town - As South Africa's new Constitution, regarded as one of most liberal in the world, came into effect on February 3, one of its significant features was already being embraced by citizens eager to exercise their rights.

The new basic law replaced the interim constitution under which the country has been governed since the historic all-race elections in April 1994, and opened the way for the next elections that must take place before April 1999.

One of the constitution's most significant features is a new Bill of Rights which outlaws racism, prohibits capital punishment and permits abortion. 

About 20 women sat quietly in a busy ward of the sprawling Baragwanath hospital in Johannesburg the same day the constitution took effect, to seek to become among the first in South Africa to have newly-accessible, legalized abortions.

However, only eight were given oral abortion pills or were booked for surgery later in the week and the rest told to return another day to Baragwanath, listed in the Guineas Book of World Records as the world's largest hospital.

At other hospitals in Gauteng, which encompasses Johannesburg and Pretoria, health officials experienced a similar "considerable demand" for abortions, provincial officials said.

The new abortion law -- one of the most liberal in the world -- came into effect with the new constitution on February 3, amid acclaim from Nelson Mandela's ruling African National Congress (ANC) and howls of protest from opposition and religious groups.

The Roman Catholic Church, Dutch Reformed Church and various Islamic groupings have staged frequent and vocal anti-abortion protests, claiming the medical procedure amounts to murder.

Frederik de Klerk's conservative National Party has also steadfastly opposed the liberalization of abortion laws it created during the previous regime, and said that February 3 was a "dark day" for South African morality.

Despite the criticism, the ANC last October passed the legislation, which allows all women and girls access to abortions in public institutions during the first 12 weeks of pregnancy and in the first 20 weeks in certain cases.

But more than a dozen other hospitals have announced they will not be able to perform any abortions at all because they do not have staff willing to be involved in the ethically-controversial procedure.

Every year, more than 250,000 women, mostly black, have illegal "backstreet" abortions performed. Of these, at last 425 die in hospital as a result of infections and bleeding, according to official figures.

Until now, only about 1,000 women who have been raped, become victims of incest, or whose pregnancy poses a danger to their lives, have qualified each year for legal abortions in South Africa.

Thousands of others, however, have had abortions in private clinics that charge an estimated 1,500 rand ($350) or more to have the operations performed discreetly, if illegally.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


76 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 7, 1997


Sudan;
New Appointment In Torit Diocese


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Torit, Southern Sudan - Fr. Johnson Mutek Akiyo has been appointed the Vicar General of Sudan's Torit Diocese, about 1,200 kilometres south of Khartoum.

His appointment was announced by the Diocesan Bishop Paride Taban, at the close of the annual general assembly held at the Chukudum Pastoral Centre from February 3 to 7, 1997. 

The new Vicar General, a Sudanese, takes over from Fr. T. Leo, who has retired upon completion of his term of office.

Other appointments made at the assembly attended by delegates from Sudan, Kenya and Uganda were Fr. Victor Okot as the secretary of Torit Diocese, Nairobi office, and Fr. Victor Gira as Parish Priest of Palotaka in the same diocese. The newly ordained Fr. Loum Sunday Joseph, was appointed Fr. Gira's assistant.

The Torit Diocese was established in 1983 and is one of the four Catholic sees in southern Sudan currently under the control of the 0rebel group, Sudanese People's Liberation Army (SPLA).

The other dioceses in the war-torn region are Rumbek, headed by Monsignor Caesar Mazzolari, El-Obeid headed by Max Macram Gasis and Tambura Yambio which is headed by Joseph Gasi.

The SPLA which is led by Colonel John Garang, has fought with the Sudanese Islamic Government since 1983, demanding for the establishment of a democratic government that recognises and respects the rights of all Sudanese.

This year's general assembly was opened by Fr. Tim Galvin, an Irish, working with displaced people at New Kush, about 1,500 kilometres south of Khartoum.

Fr. Galvin then handed over to four facilitators who included Fr. Akiyo. Others were Fr. Dominic Otware, head of Torit's Central Deanery, Mr. Cyprian Okuye, a logistics officer in the diocese and Mrs Theodore A.D. Lotto, the former Diocesan Executive Secretary in Nairobi.

Over 50 delegates participated in the assembly, during which several office bearers in the Torit Diocese presented reports on their pastoral activities in 1996.

The last day of the assembly saw the delegates break into four small discussion groups each with a topic to tackle. The topics included pastoral care, education, relief and health and management and development.

For Fr. Loum, ordained only six months ago, the assembly was quite an eye opener. "I learned a lot since people were very open and exchanged views freely," he said in a post-assembly interview. "I was happy to learn that the people already in the field know what they are doing."


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


77 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 7, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Many Voices Breeding Church Division


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 907 words


 

Nairobi - A regional committee on refugees meeting here has decried divisions in the Church today, saying such splits make churches speak with many voices, leading to contradictions.

The East African Refugee Regional Committee, organized here by the All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC) noted that the region is at cross-roads and full of challenging issues.

Addressing the February 10 to 13 meeting, the AACC Executive Secretary for International Affairs and Coordinator for Refugee and Emergency Services Rev. Ngoy Mulunda-Nyanga challenged the churches in the conflict torn East African region to review their role of keeping people's hope alive by acting quickly to alleviate suffering.

Rev. Mulunda likened the situation in the region to "people crossing a lake when the storms are raging." 

He told participants drawn from Uganda, Egypt, Ethiopia and Kenya, the raging storm has been felt in Burundi, Sudan, Somalia, Rwanda, and to some extent, Kenya, with Zaire currently going through a similar phase. Djibouti, a member of the regional body was not represented.

The head of the International Affairs desk regretted that Uganda, which had experienced some rough periods in its history was still going through situations that subject people to suffering but it seems to have been forgotten as little is said about the war in some parts of the country.

Citing tribalism and ethnicity as the major factors around which conflicts revolve, Rev. Mulunda however acknowledge that the two were very challenging to Christians.

He described identity with a tribe or ethnic group as a holy covenant instituted by God and asserted that the Church should promote that covenant, because belonging to a particular tribe is not bad as "it is our identity."

In conflicts, Rev. Ngoy said it is wrong to condemn one tribal group against the other as has happened in some countries.

He called on the church to preach the ministry of reconciliation, forgiveness and forgetting wrongs done.

Pointing out that the message of reconciliation is not being emphasized by the church today, the head of the AACC International Affairs desk wondered whether the church is still capable of standing in the midst of problems and proclaiming reconciliation boldly.

He also took issue with the slow manner in which churches have responded to conflicts, likening the church to someone riding on a donkey instead of a horse to help save a situation. If churches were quick enough to respond to situations, they would have been able to diffuse some tensions before they exploded and assumed dangerous proportions, Rev. Mulunda added.

"Out of darkness, we are the light of this region and must stress reconciliation even if some governments do not want to accept it," the AACC official remarked.

He also underscored the need for the church to link up with other groups in dealing with tensions, analyzing and interpreting issues. And went on further to challenge the local churches not to always wait for either the Nairobi- based AACC or other ecumenical agencies in Europe to initiate action.

Ms Zewdita Lakew of the Ethiopian Orthodox Church (EOC) Refugee and Returnee Affairs Department observed that there was competition between the local and international organizations in providing relief assistance and other projects in conflict areas. She accused international organizations of taking advantage of the local organizations instead of supporting the latter.

Her assertion was supported by a Kenyan Methodist clergy who said this kind of competition was very vivid in Kenya and gave as an example a case involving an international agency and a local churches' organization, both providing health assistance in the arid North-Eastern Kenya.

On the uprooted people, the regional committee said ongoing programmes should be reviewed so as to work towards meeting the needs of the refugees and other uprooted people, especially now that funds are dwindling in the face of emerging priorities.

Mr. Henry Odraa Raga from thee AACC Refugee Desk cautioned that funds were no longer easily available from traditional donors, thus the need to tap financial assistance from alternative sources.

Mr. Odraa Raga noted that those charged with the responsibility of alleviating suffering, particularly the regional committees, should work with even more commitment. He suggested that members gain exposure to different situations and develop new insights in their work.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March 7, 1997


Nigeria;
Tailor Charged With Insulting Abacha


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

LAGOS - A suspected member of a fundamentalist Shiite Muslim group, charged with insulting Nigeria's military ruler, General Sani Abacha, and other prominent officials in the ruling junta has been remanded in custody until February 21.

Bashir Musa, from the Fagge district of Kano, Abacha's hometown in northern Nigeria, was charged at a magistrates court on February 5 with illegal preaching and inciting disturbances, judicial officials said.

Prosecutor Tijjani Ochej told the court that the accused was arrested on January 30 at a local mosque after heaping abuse on Abacha and the Emir of Kano Alhaji Ado Bayero, the officials said. 

Musa, a tailor by trade, criticized Nigeria's military rulers for refusing to allow the country, which is predominantly Muslim in the north and mainly Christian and animist in the south, and has a secular constitution, to be transformed into an Islamic state, judicial officials added.

Judge Ahmed Jijjani Muazu accepted the prosecution's argument that Musa constituted a threat to public order, and remanded the accused in custody.

In a related development, the police chief in neighbouring Kaduna state, Yakubu Shuaibu, has warned that Shiite sect members who fled a police crackdown last year could unleash a terror campaign in neighbouring states.

"Members of the religious sect have abandoned Kaduna, and they could find a conducive atmosphere (for their activities) in some nearby areas," he told journalists.

Shiite sects have increased their profile over the past 17 years in Nigeria, notably in the northern Kano, Kaduna, Sokoto and Katsina states.

Forty-six suspected Shiite sect members arrested last December in Sokoto (north-west) were early last month charged with breach of the peace and unlawful assembly.

They were arrested for allegedly criticizing government officials and insulting the Nigerian establishment.

Police said at least six people were killed and many others were injured following clashes between Shiite fundamentalists and policemen last September in Zaria, a major town in Kaduna state.

The clashes broke out when fundamentalists demanded the release of their leader, El Zak-Zaki, who was arrested on September 12 following bloody clashes between Muslim fundamentalists and Christians in Kafanchan, in the same state. Two people died and 15 others were injured in those clashes.

Since the arrest of the Shiite leader, no news of his whereabouts or conditions of his detention has filtered out.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


March 7, 1997


Liberia;
Liberia Said Safe For Elections


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 747 words


 

MONROVIA - The Commander of the ECOWAS intervention force in Liberia, ECOMOG, General Victor Malu, has declared this West African country "safe for elections," saying they should be held in May as scheduled.

Reports quote General Malu as saying the disarmament of some 60,000 guerrilla fighters had largely been completed.

His February 10 statement came only two days after what analysts described as a veiled threat from former chief warlord, Charles Taylor of the National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL) if the elections were delayed. 

The disarmament was begun late last November and was expected to be completed on January 31, but due to slow pace at the initial stages, a one- week extension was given.

General Malu said the Nigerian-led force, sent to Liberia in 1990 by the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS), would now focus on elections, the final stage of a regional peace plan to end seven years of civil war.

"With the success achieved in the just concluded phase, we have begun to see the light at the end of the tunnel. Liberians and all parties to this conflict have completely demonstrated their resolve to end this fratricidal crisis," General Malu is reported as telling a two-day West African army chiefs' meeting in Monrovia.

The chiefs-of-staff were to assess the security situation and advise foreign ministers from the nine-nation ECOWAS committee on Liberia, who were due to meet here last week.

General Malu told journalists that 91 per cent of armed guerrillas had turned in their weapons by February 7, the end of a voluntary disarmament period and that the country was "safe for elections." We will be recommending elections nation-wide," he added.

Reports also indicate that the United States expects to contribute up to $6 million for the elections and its Ambassador to Liberia, William Milan has expressed hope that the timetable would be maintained.

"I would be surprised if they decided not to go ahead with the elections. I believe ECOWAS is committed to the Abuja schedule," he said in apparent reference to the last peace accord signed in Abuja, Nigeria, last August. "I think that the United States and other donors and supporting countries are also committed to that schedule."

On February 8, Taylor warned that any attempt by Liberia's donors or the United Nations to shift presidential and legislative elections from next May as scheduled under the Abuja accord, could trigger a crisis.

His NPFL launched the war on Christmas Eve in 1989 against slain military dictator, Samuel Doe and the UN estimates that more than 150,000 people have since been killed.

"Our side will find it virtually impossible to accept that elections cannot happen in May. We want to make it clear that we have demonstrated our ability to fight a war, disarm our people and demobilize them. They should now give us the opportunity to hold elections," Taylor told reporters.

Taylor's warning follows proposals for free and fair elections prepared by the UN and backed by donors as well as foreign electoral experts.

Analysts say if the proposals are adopted, the polls could be delayed well beyond May. Contained in the proposals are the composition of a new electoral commission, registration of voters and the use of proportional representation.

The NPFL leader went on: "Everybody knew about the schedule of the implementation we signed. If there is deception involved, that means that everything is changed. I can tell you this much. When you begin to change things and schedules and plans, you open up a pandora's box. There is a possibility and even a probability of crisis."


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


80 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 7, 1997


South Africa;
Gambling Act could cause industry problems


BYLINE: Llewellyn Jones, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

Cape Town - South Africa's gambling industry could be headed for disaster unless the authorities rethink their gambling policies.

This was the message given by a group of academics in the Waterfront yesterday after a 20-month long research project funded by Sun International.

Brian Kantor, the Dean of the Faculty of Commerce at the University of Cape Town, said the major problem lay within the Gambling Act. 

He said the group believed the Act had been promulgated without careful consideration to policy and objectives for the industry and the country as a whole.

This had left developers and other interested parties without clear guidelines, and could lead to a situation such as that in Namibia where legislation of the gambling industry had gone "horribly wrong".

The group's report said that the legislation on licences in Namibia had been passed too quickly without a proper understanding of the "potentially very dangerous" social and economic consequences of an inadequately regulated industry.

The Namibian government had done this in response to pressure from would-be developers and casino operators.

The result was that there were too many licensed gambling houses, each struggling to remain profitable.

In South Africa, the academic team estimated, people were willing to spend (or lose) up to 1 percent of after-tax income on gaming. The Western Cape's potential share of estimated gaming spending was R700 million a year, they said, compared to R1,7 billion in Gauteng.

The research report was particularly critical of the number of licences given to Gauteng, believing that they could wipe out the gambling industry in the North West Province, and still struggle to remain profitable as they competed among themselves.

"Clearly you cannot isolate the gambling market in any one province, and cross provincial effects must be taken into account," Professor Kantor said.

International experience had shown that gambling was not a tourist market, and that casino income depended largely on local custom.

"Tourism will not drive casino revenues," Professor Kantor said.

Enormous effort and resources had already been expended on gambling developments in South Africa without the players "knowing the rules of the game yet".

Professor Kantor also said that the licensing authorities should also become "far more prescriptive, in other words follow a process similar to tendering where clear guidelines are set".

"Otherwise it is all bound to end up in the courts as has already happened in Mpumalanga."


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


81 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 7, 1997


South Africa;
ANC hails move to name apartheid state's spies


BYLINE: Clive Sawyer, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 814 words


 

Cape Town - The African National Congress today welcomed the Truth Commission's decision to disclose names of those who had informed for the apartheid state, saying it would counter a snowballing disinformation campaign.

A delegation of the ANC's national executive and sub-committee on truth and reconciliation met Truth Commission head Archbishop Tutu for talks on this and other issues in Cape Town today.

Acting secretary-general Cheryl Carolus, speaking at a media briefing after the meeting, said the ANC was "very happy" with the decision, because full disclosure was an essential part of the TRC process. 

Archbishop Tutu said earlier that those who were to be unmasked would be given 21 days' notice.

Ms Carolus said the risks of not disclosing the identities of informers were to be seen already in the "mischief and disinformation" in certain media reports, including those which had claimed Defence Minister Joe Modise had been on the payroll of the previous government.

Another example was reports about Communist Party chief Chris Hani's murder.

Ms Carolus said the ANC had used today's meeting to get clarity from the commission about questions the party would be expected to answer in further submissions and hearings.

It had been agreed that the ANC would give evidence at a hearing in May, although detailed written submissions would be made before then to give the commission time to prepare.

The ANC had emphasised to the commission that it saw its armed struggle as part of a just war against apartheid.

She said the amnesty applications by Mr Hani's murderers, Clive Derby-Lewis and Janusz Walus, had been discussed.

The ANC did not want these delayed, but in fact wanted the matter investigated in depth. "We have indicated already that we believe the murder of Chris Hani was part of a broader plot to undermine the processes underway (at the time of his death)."

The ANC earlier made it clear that it wanted full disclosure of the names of those in the media, trade unions and student organisations who had spied for the previous government.

ANC spokesman Ronnie Mamoepa confirmed that the party's demand for disclosure went beyond the names of those now in senior government posts who are said to have been informers.

It was clear from ANC deputy president Thabo Mbeki's letter to the Truth Commission last week that complete disclosure of all those who had been informers was required, Mr Mamoepa said.

Meanwhile, the Truth Commission may subpoena Jacques Hechter, one of six former security police officers applying for amnesty, if he refuses to disclose the identities of his informants.

Commission deputy head Alex Boraine said Captain Hechter, if he refused to co-operate, could be summoned to a behind-closed-doors hearing where he could be forced to disclose the names.

In the ANC submission to the commission last year, it was claimed that more than 600 members of the movement had betrayed their comrades to security police in the apartheid era.

Senior defence sources have said that the degree of penetration of the liberation movement by the former security forces was high.

Destruction of at least some records by military intelligence may complicate efforts to verify claims about turncoats.

Some records of the pre-1994 National Intelligence Service are also said to have been destroyed or otherwise have gone missing.

Sapa reports that Mr Modise has provided the commission with some leads about who gave the orders for defence force records to be destroyed.

Members of today's ANC delegation to the meeting with Archbishop Tutu included Dullah Omar, Charles Nqakula, Mathews Phosa, Mac Maharaj, Mr Mamoepa, and Mongesi Tshongweni.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

March 7, 1997


South Africa;
Milk sachets may help find schoolgirl


BYLINE: Norman Joseph, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Cape Town - A major Western Cape dairy is printing a photograph of missing Goodwood schoolgirl Liezl-Mari Goosen on its milk sachets in a bid to help police find her.

Bonnita marketing-director Marius Kritzinger said his company had been approached by the girl's family and the Goodwood community "who have distributed more than 50 000 posters". 

The company agreed to the venture after consulting the Child Protection Unit and Liezl-Mari's parents.

"Part of our social responsibility programme is to help communities in distress," said Mr Kritzinger.

The sachets will be distributed throughout the Western and Southern Cape and it is estimated that Liezl's photograph will be seen by more than 250 000 people a day.

From today the picture, a short description of Liezl in Afrikaans and English and the telephone numbers of the Child Protection Unit and Crime Stop will appear on Bonnita sachets of milk.

Liezl, 13, a pupil at J G Meiring High School, disappeared on January 22 on the way from her Goodwood home to school to attend an athletics practice.

Weeks after her disappearance, a man driving a silver BMW tried to lure an eight-year-old girl into his car near where Liezl-Mari is thought to have disappeared.

Dozens of Goodwood residents called police about a motorist cruising the streets near schools.

Witnesses helped police compile an identikit of the man. Police emphasised he could not be linked to Liezl-Mari.

Recently a man was arrested for trying to lure a Standard 9 pupil into his car.

Child Protection Unit head Jan Swart said the man had several indecent assault cases pending "but we had to release him as no crime was committed on the pupil".

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


March 7, 1997


South Africa;
Hermanus killer could do it again, pyschologist warns


BYLINE: Dennis Cavernelis, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Cape Town - A man who murdered three black Hermanus residents in a killing spree could kill again if he did not have long-term therapy, a psychologist has told the Cape High Court.

Martin Yodaiken was giving evidence in mitigation of sentence for Wilfred Jordaan, 26, of Panorama. 

Jordaan and a 17-year-old youth from Hermanus were convicted yesterday of murdering Catherine de Wet, Eric Mjikiliso and Nkosana Bushula, who were bludgeoned to death with a steering wheel lock. They were also found guilty of assaulting Richmond Qwathikazi. The attacks happened in the Hermanus area on September 2, 1995.

Mr Yodaiken, who gave the court a psychological assessment of Jordaan, said he had a dysfunctional family background in which his father beat his wife and had numerous affairs - 77, according to his wife.

Jordaan's mother was aggressive and hostile towards him and his two siblings.

Jordaan's parents were not "models of self-restraint" and Jordaan was unable to learn to control his impulses.

Mr Yodaiken said Jordaan desired the approval of others and would submit to those he perceived to be more important than himself. Jordaan did not have a history of violent or aggressive behaviour, at school or when he was in the navy.

He had not derived satisfaction from the killings - "I don't think he intended to kill anyone" - but from the camaraderie he felt with the youth, Mr Yodaiken said.

"There was approval (by the youth of his actions) and that's the danger. He will seek approval from anyone, even a stranger." "Under the right circumstances he could be led into anything that is the danger of his type of personality."

Mr Yodaiken said Jordaan would need long-term psychotherapy and imprisonment would be a suitable punishment for him.

The trial continues.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


March 7, 1997


South Africa;
Huge boost for Cape Flats


BYLINE: Jermaine Craig, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

Cape Town - A vast new project is being planned to unleash an economic boom for impoverished Cape Flats communities and create thousands of jobs.

The Sheffield Road-Symphony Way road development will link the Philippi area to the Bellville central business district, creating an economic corridor along which major development can take place. 

It is envisaged the project will create the conditions for attracting businesses to the route, creating employment for thousands of people.

A project on the R250-million Olympic priority list, the development is one of the main recommendations of the Metropolitan Spatial Development Framework, a key aim of which is to reverse the apartheid era's separation of disadvantaged communities from the city's conventional business districts.

The proposed development is also crucial for Cape Town's Olympic bid, as it will improve access to and from Philippi, which has been earmarked as the venue for badminton during the games.

Philippi East has been identified as an economic node which will complement the central business districts of Cape Town, Bellville and Claremont-Wynberg.

Terrence Smith of Symphony Way Consultants, who are working on the draft designs, said the development formed part of the Cape Metropolitan Council's plan to increase the efficiency of the city's transport network - road and rail - up to 2020.

He said the consortium had been inundated with calls from developers and other business people about possible investment in the area.

"Already a major shopping complex is being planned on the corner of the N2 and Delft Main Road."

The proposed road link will also improve transport for thousands of students at the University of the Western Cape and the Peninsula Technikon.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


85 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 7, 1997


South Africa;
We're into the final


BYLINE: Michael Morris, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 894 words


 

Lausanne - We've made it! Cape Town, and the rest of South Africa and Africa with it, have joined the race for Olympic gold in a four/five way contest for the Games of 2004.

The city's bid came through the tough 11-city selection process with flying colours to join Rome, Athens, Stockholm and Buenos Aires in the gruelling six- month race to the finish on September 5, when the South Africans return to Switzerland for their final date with the International Olympic Committee.

Cheers of joy, and tears of relief, marked the announcement of Cape Town's inclusion in the shortlist by Marc Hodler, chairman of the IOC selection college, at 2.30pm at the lakeside Olympic Museum.

For the bid teams, the air of mounting excitement and anticipation was almost unbearable in the run-up to Mr Hodler's announcement at the press conference. 

For many, nearly exhausted by months of pressure and hard work, the news seemed almost too good to be true.

An ecstatic Chris Ball declared: "It's a magnificent achievement for South Africa to be in the finals of this extraordinary competition, particularly so soon after the political transformation of our country.

"We are enormously encouraged by the extent to which the selection college has acknowledged the technical elements of the bid, because that puts us on an equal footing with all the other cities at the beginning of the race.

"Now the fun and excitement begins."

The National Olympic Committee of SA chief, Sam Ramsamy, beamed: "We are elated and overjoyed. This is a great day for us all."

He cautioned, though, that "our task only begins now because we are in very tough competition with Rome, Athens, Stockholm and Buenos Aires, and they all have formidable bids.

"Nevertheless I am confident that on September 5 the IOC will give us the Games because our overall package is undoubtedly the best."

Said Sports Minister Steve Tshwete: "This is the greatest piece of news for our country since the elections in 1994. It is a breath of fresh air that will blow across the face of South Africa, southern Africa and the continent.

"It will stimulate growth, there's no doubt about that...it will stimulate tourism in Cape Town and throughout the region, and revive the commitment to sport among our young people."

Now the time had come when the bid deserved everybody's support. "What we need now is for everyone to rally fully behind the city of Cape Town, the young and old, the rural and urban people, everyone. It is ours to lose, and it is our dream come true."

Looking ahead, Mr Ball said: "There is no one city that can run faster than any other...the result will depend on the reaction of IOC members who visit us and how they see the competitive merits of the various cities in the context of the needs of the IOC.

"Some of them will vote parochially, but a lot will stand apart and say: Let's look at what's right for the IOC at this point in history. It is for this reason that we have an extraordinary chance of competing successfully."

He paid tribute to the many people in the bid team, in the city, province and government, in Nocsa and the business community, and to the people of Cape Town who had supported and encouraged the bidding exercise. "Now the fun and excitement starts and I hope everyone will assist and participate in what should be a fulfilling six months for South Africa. This will be like day and night cricket every month from now until September."

Parliamentary Speaker Frene Ginwala said: "This is our opportunity to add something that's really important to the Olympic movement. This is not a reward for what has happened in our past and we must see it as a way to add something new, to show that the Olympic Games can be a vehicle to make a practical difference to people's lives. This is the developmental nature of our bid, and that's what South Africa is all about."

Dr Ramsamy, Mr Ball and other members of the team went straight into a meeting, as did the other successful teams, with top IOC officials to discuss various technical matters relating to the next phase of the bidding process.

The bidding effort will intensify dramatically from here on, as the team pulls all the stops to influence IOC voters and make sure perceived weaknesses are effectively tackled.

The challenge now is to make the most of the city's chance and pull off the miracle in September of becoming host city for the 2004 Games.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March 7, 1997


South Africa;
Council begins considering towns for membership of Afrikaner homeland


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

NELSPRUIT - The capital of Mpumalanga, Nelspruit, is one of a number of provincial towns currently being investigated by the Afrikaner Volkstaat Council for possible inclusion in a Afrikaner self-determination sub-region.

The Council's chairman, Mars de Klerk, will visit Nelspruit and surrounding towns during a tour of what they term the Drakensberg-Northern District between 5 and 8 March. 

This region, which includes Mpumalanga and parts of the Northern Province, is one of the areas identified by the Council as having a strong enough Afrikaner population for self-determination to be realised.

Towns to be visited by the Council include Ermelo, Nelspruit, White River, Hazyview, Graskop, Blyde River, Ohrigstad, Lydenburg and Dullstroom.

Both Mpumalanga's Freedom Front (FF) members of the provincial legislature live in Ermelo but were unavailable for comment about the Council's visit or plans.

Towns such as Nelspruit, Hazyview and White River have an over-whelming majority of black residents, while smaller rural towns such as Dullstroom are holiday/ tourism towns for Gauteng based trout fishermen. None of the mayors of the towns targeted by the Council wanted to comment about the possibility of finding themselves in an Afrikaner Volkstaat, but a number of mayors did say that had not yet been approached for interviews or discussions on the matter.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


87 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 7, 1997


South Africa;
Bid to save secret Parks Board deal creates more controversy


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1014 words


 

NELSPRUIT - A supposed rescue mission to London earlier this week to save Mpumalanga's controversial R12,2-billion deal with the Dubai-based Dolphin Group may have only added to the public furore surrounding the secret deal, which gave away some of South Africa's key tourist attractions for 50-years.

The chairman of Mpumalanga's legislative standing committee on public accounts, Chris MacPherson, expressed his reservations about the rescue team's amendments to the deal on Friday, pointing out that the only reason his committee had originally approved the commercialisation of game reserves in the province was to secure private sector funding for the Mpumalanga Parks Board's (MPB) budget. Dolphin's guarantee to contribute roughly R12,2-billion to the MPB over a 50-year period was withdrawn in London on Wednesday, when the South African delegation insisted on various changes to the secret 39- page contract between Dolphin and MPB. One of the core demands was that the contract period be reduced from 50 to 25-years. 

Dolphin agreed to the changes but said that as a result, they couldn't guarantee the whole budget deficit anymore and have instead offered to pay the MPB 7 per cent of turnover from the exclusive commercial development rights granted to them in six State owned game reserve, Blyde River Canyon and Loskop Dam.

The MPB needs private sector funding for both its projected budget deficit and its normal operating budget after Mpumalanga's provincial government discovered that it could only give MPB R10,5-million for the 1997/ 98 financial year.

MPB had asked for R53-million as an absolute minimum, to cover its personnel and salary expenses - 80 per cent more than government is able to give.

The original contract, which was signed without any public consultation by MPB head Alan Gray in November last year, outraged rural communities, land claim activists and conservationists who pointed out that MPB had "sold" national assets for 50-years even though many of the key tourism sites did not fall under MPB control.

Rural communities also pointed out that they had gazetted land claims on at least three of the core development areas.

Land claims are only gazetted once the Land Commissioner is certain that they are realistic.

The "rescue" mission to London, headed by Mpumalanga environmental affairs MEC, David Mkhwanazi was put together after central government threatened to step into the furore caused by the deal.

Admitting that the MPB had erred by attempting to keep the terms of the contract secret for 50-years, Mkhwanazi convinced Dolphin president, Ketan Somaia, to drop the entire confidentiality clause in the contract.

Other "flaws" which have been removed from the original contract include exclusive commercial rights to the Manyeleti Game Reserve and the historic town of Pilgrim's Rest.

Manyeleti, which is described as the last remaining piece of undeveloped " Big Five" bush in Africa, is administered by the Northern Province and not by Mpumalanga.

Pilgrim's Rest is administered by Mpumalanga's public works department and not by MPB. Although Dolphin is still pledging R410-million investment in the province in 3-years, only 30 per cent of this will be from foreign exchange. When the deal was first publicly announced, all investment was supposed to be forex.

To assist with the reduced budgetary support, Dolphin has now pledged 25 per cent of all its profits to the MPB as well as promising surrounding communities 20 per cent equity stakes in the various joint venture companies which will operate the reserves.

No financial value has been put to these figures.

"The MPB, as a parastatal, is fully accountable to the provincial legislature and we only approved their commercialisation programme because they needed to get private sector funding. If guarantees for the complete underwriting of the deficit have been withdrawn, then MPB has no business signing any deals," said public accounts chair, Chris MacPherson, on Friday.

Stressing that the aim had not been to commercialise parks just for the sake of commercialising, MacPherson added that other investors would perhaps be prepared to meet MPB's deficit.

"I would find it very strange if the MPB, which did not accompany Mkhwanazi to London, accepted being forced into a corner by agreeing to development regardless of the benefits," he added.

MacPherson also expressed his concern that Mkhwanazi as MEC had taken control of negotiations, without any MPB consultation.

"The MPB is a separate en-Acted parastatal and cannot just be suspended by the MEC or otherwise interfered with unless the legislation governing it is altered by this province's Legislature," he explained.

"If we start allowing MECs or other politicians to ignore the law, then we might as well pack up the legislature and all go home."

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


March 7, 1997


South Africa;
Students call to strip De Klerk of honours


BYLINE: George Mthethwa, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

EMPANGENI - The South African Student's Congress (Sasco) at the University of Zululand demanded on Tuesday that former president FW de Klerk be stripped of his honoury LLB degree from the university.

De Klerk was awarded the honoury degree in 1995, in recognition for his contributions to the peaceful dismantling of Apartheid. 

A memorandum setting out the demand was submitted to university management on Tuesday afternoon.

The memorandum also demanded the unconditional and immediate registration of 800 unregistered students. Sasco wants the university to use funds earmarked for renovating university buildings to be used to wipe off these student's current debts.

"Management won't respond (to these demands) as the demands come from a political formation that has no mandate to tackle such issues," said University's public affairs manager, Mr Carl de Villiers in reaction.

SASCO motivated its call for De Klerk to be stripped of his honoury degree by maintaining that De Klerk's government was involved in atrocities against the masses of the country.

"Management will only respond to de-mands brought by the Student Representative Council, since it has a legitimate mandate," said Mr de Villiers.

He added that the registration deadline for all 800 unregistered students was on March 7 and said that funds allocated for renovations would be used for repairing dilapidated buildings and not to settle debts.

Swaziland;
Suspected Swazi car thieves escape from police


BYLINE: Mzilikazi wa Afrika, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

WAKKERSTROOM - Two Swaziland citizens escaped from the Wakkerstroom Police Station's holding cells on Sunday night by forcing their cell door open with an unknown iron object.

Police only discovered that the men were missing when a duty officer discovered four other prisoners from the same cell wondering around the police station's corridors. 

After being rounded up by "surprised" station personnel, the four prisoners told police that they had woken up to discover their cell door wide open and the two Swazis missing.

They had then decided on the spur of the moment to "take a walk around".

The two remaining escapees, Dumisani Dlamini (18) and Poloex Simelane (21) were arrested last week on vehicle theft charges and were due to appear in court on Monday.

Police suspect that the men will attempt to flee back to Swaziland by crossing the border illegally.

Africa News


March 7, 1997


Swaziland;
Unions threaten more border blockades unless King unbans parties


BYLINE: Mzilikazi wa Afrika, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

SECUNDA - The Congress of South African Trade Unions (Cosatu) in Mpumalanga has threatened further blockades of border posts with the Kingdom of Swaziland if discussions between Swaziland's government and the Swaziland Federation of Trade Unions (SFTU) in Mbabane on Wednesday are not successful.

SFTU is demanding that the Swaziland government reverse a 1973 royal decree which bans all political parties and is also demanding that the government repeals the current state of emergency.

Cosatu and affiliated unions in Mozam-bique expressed their support of SFTU's demands after the Swaziland government arrested a number of union leaders for insurrection and for orgnaising the four week old strike currently crippling Swaziland's economy. 

Two of Swaziland's biggest foreign earners, sugar and forestry are reportedly losing at least R3-million per day because of the strike.

When the government refused to release the union leaders this week, Cosatu bused supporters to the Oshoek and Golela border posts on Monday and prevented 36 trucks from using the gates.

Hailing the blockade as a success, Cosatu's spokesperson, Norman Mokoena, denied police allegations on Tuesday that Cosatu demonstrators had intimidated at least two truck drivers at the Oshoek gate.

"Cosatu has never subscribed to intimi-dation and never will. We are here to support SFTU, which also belongs to the South African Trade Union Co- ordinating Council like we do. We will not use violence to get our message across," he insisted.

Oshoek police inspector, Maureen Britz, however said on Tuesday that Cosatu members led by their assistant secretary general, Zwelinzima Vavi, had repeatedly taunted and intimidated two truck drivers who attempted to cross into Swaziland.

Inspector Britz added that although no petition was handed in on the South African side of the border, a 27-point memorandum was handed to the Swaziland government by SFTU members on Monday.

"But in contrast, things were back to normal on Tuesday, with all vehicles passing into and from Swaziland without any interference," she added.

Police at the Golela border post also reported that the situation was back to normal by Tuesday, and added that the Cosatu demonstrators there had been bused in from Durban.

Police added that no serious cases of intimidation had occurred at Golela but that "very vulgar" language had been used between taxi drivers and demonstrators.

South Africa;
Taxi drivers shot execution style


BYLINE: Mzilikazi wa Afrika, African Eye News Service (South Africa).


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Jane Furse - Four taxi drivers who were kidnapped after shoot-outs between the Boseka-bo-eja taxi association and South African Long Distance Taxi Association (Saldta) in Jane Furse were found shot dead execution style in caves near Burgersfort on Thursday.

Northern Province police spokesperson, Supt Phuti Setati, said on Friday that six suspects had been arrested in connection with the murders and that more arrests were imminent. 

"The police are detemined to rid the taxi industry, as well as the community of this menace," he said.

He said the names of the deceased could not be released until their next of kin had been informed.

The shoot-out allegedly erupted at the Jane Furse taxi rank on Monday when a Boseka-bo-eja taxi driver resigned from the association and then attempted to force fellow members to join Saldta.

The taxi driver allegedly also attempted to remove Boseka-bo-eja stickers from the association's taxis and replace them with Saldta stickers.

When Boseka-bo-eja drivers refused to resign, the taxi driver allegedly drew his 9mm pistol, afterwhich the shoot-out erupted between the two taxi associations.

More shooting took place at the rank the following day. * Meanwhile, nine badly beaten men, three of whom were treated in intensive care at the Witbank hospital, were released from protective police custody on Friday after Witbank taxi drivers accused them of stealing car radios.

Provincial police spokesperson, Capt Malcolm Mokameni, said the house of a policeman accused by angry taxi drivers of releasing the men, was also vandalised on Friday.

Three taxi drivers have been arrested in connection with the looting of Sgt Stanley Kgwathe's home. .

Africa News


March 7, 1997


South Africa;
Project to bring government closer to people


BYLINE: John Hammond, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Nelspruit - A R130 000 project aimed at bringing government closer to the people was launched for the first time in Mpumalanga on Thursday. Premier Mathews Phosa welcomed the project, saying it was "a big step" in allowing communities to look into and participate in government activities. 

The project, launched in Nelspruit by the Institute for a Democratic Alternative for South Africa (Idasa) aims to broaden the Government Information Service (GIS) and to equip pupils with marketable life skills while still at school.

"According to the Department of Education all schools will eventually be linked by computers, improving the availability of information," explained Head of Strategic Planning and Development, Joe Magagula.

He said pupils would enter speech contests to discuss government achievements, and then enter provincial finals.

Twelve winners drawn from all Education Department districts would then undergo training at the University of Pretoria's Statomet Division, studying research metho-dologies, and survey and data collection for the GIS, he added.

Magagula said accurate reports were needed for the smooth integration of the Reconstruction and Development process and that pupils and parents would play a key role in the project.

"The introduction of computers will add value to the education system," added Project Manager, Sheriff Molefe.

He said computer training learnt by pupils at school would make them more marketable when seeking jobs. .

South Africa;
Non-paying students won't be kicked out


BYLINE: Benjamin Shabalala, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

Kabokweni - The non-payment of registration fees by certain students at the Elijah Mango College of Higher Education in Mpumalanga was resolved on Tuesday when college management agreed not to lock-out non-paying students.

Acting rector, Mr DL Mkhize, told protesting students on Tuesday that the college would instead negotiate the issue of non-payment with the college's Student Forum. 

On accepting a memorandum from Student Forum president, Migros Khumalo, Mkhize urged all students who could afford to pay registration fees, to do so.

"Those who haven't paid can, however, rest assured that they will not just be kicked out," he added.

In the memorandum, students called for registration fees to be scrapped, explaining that the Mpumalanga Department of Education should continue the bursary scheme of the former Kangwane government.

The memorandum also demanded that students who had paid their registration fees of R500 for second-year and R300 for third-year, be refunded. .

Africa News


March 7, 1997


South Africa;
Pupil acquitted for shooting teacher in penis


BYLINE: Benjamin Shabalala, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Nelspruit - A 19-year-old school pupil was acquitted by the Nelspruit regional court on Monday on charges of shooting a teacher through the penis and thigh, as the teacher was unable to remember his name in the court room.

The teacher, Shadrack Mlimi, said he had confiscated a handgun from a school pupil in January who later returned, saying a certain Dumisane wanted the gun back. 

On February 14, while at the Mahushu bottle store, Mlimi was allegedly approached by someone who, without warning, shot him in the penis.

The bullet also penetrated his thigh.

In court, Mlimi said the shooting took place in a matter of two minutes.

The magistrate later decided the incident lasted only 25 seconds, during which, he said, Mlimi would have been unable to identify his attacker.

Mlimi told the court he had only seen his attacker, identified by the court as Dumisane Mgiba, on two previous occasions.

He said he did not Mgiba's name, and only knew his face.

Mgiba was acquitted on the shooting, as well as on charges of the illegal possessin of a 9mm Taurus pistol and a single round of ammunition on May 9 last year. .

South Africa;
Alleged double-murderer to be transferred to reduce state costs


BYLINE: Mzilikazi wa Afrika & Sharon Hammond, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

Nelspruit - A Nelspruit magistrate has applied to the Attorney-General to transfer double murder suspect, Mark Dewes (40) to Nelspruit prison from Pretoria to reduce state expenses.

Dewes' legal representative, Ike Schwartzberg, explained that transporting his client from Pretoria prison to Nelspruit under police guard for each court appearance was costing the state too much money. 

Dewes is still undergoing psychiatric observation in Pretoria following an alleged shooting spree in Sappi's Weltevreden plantation near the Sudwala Caves which saw two people killed and two injured in November last year.

Dewes was arrested on December 3 last year after allegedly killing Halt Transport manager, Gary Gillbanks and businessman, Koos Roos, after his ex- wife wife drove into the back of Halt Transport forestry truck on November 25.

He also allegedy injured two Halt employees, Solly Phiri (21) and Pat Nkosi (24).

Dewes was able to evade police roadblocks between Nelspruit and Johannesburg for a week before being arrested outside his ex-wife's house in Florida on the West Rand.

Dewes faces two charges of murder and five of attempted murder. The case was postponed on Friday to April 21 for the Attorney-General to set a trial date.

Africa News


March 7, 1997


South Africa;
Taxi drivers threaten to shoot journalist


BYLINE: John Hammond, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Kwaggafontein - A freelance investigative journalist working for African Eye news Service in Mpumalanga has laid intimidation charges against five unidentified taxi operators after they threatened him with physical harm on Monday morning.

Joseph Ngoma (23) was allegedly cornered by two taxi drivers and three taxi owners at the Kwaggafontein Taxi Rank and was told not to report on a court case involving their colleagues. 

The case, currently before the Kwaggafontein Magistrate's Court, involves the assassination of drivers from rival taxi organisations.

"These guys cornered me first and then began screaming that they would shoot me and plant a gun on my body to make it look like self-defense. They warned me very unpleasantly to keep out of their business," said Ngoma afterwards.

"This is not the first time that the press or even normal members of the public have been intimidated by taxi operators in the area."

The men also allegedly warned Ngoma not to attempt to use any local taxis, or come near their rank again.

There is no other form of public transport in the rural areas surrounding Kwaggafontein.

Provincial AENS bureau chief, Justin Arenstein, confirmed that rural reporters in Mpumalanga were often intimidated and had their homes attacked after working on relatively routine stories.

"There is very little understanding of the role of the media in these areas and reports describing court cases or the like are often viewed as personal attacks on those involved," he explained.

"As a result, we often have to rotate our reporters and also have a standing rule that journalists from trust or rural areas don't report on their home territories."

Individual journalists in Mpumalanga have also been subjected to verbal abuse at press conferences, in official government press releases and in the provincial legislature.
