Africa News


March 7, 1997


Ethiopia;
Government and Business Consultation (Editorial)


BYLINE: Tamrat Bekele, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 147 words


 

Addis Ababa - In the Ethiopian market place, we are engaged in a street fight for our existence. Few closer to the family of business people and an increasingly desperate coalition of industrialists seem to recognize the significance of this development.

There are plenty of goods in the shops but there are few buyers. The problems of increasing capacity in basic industry, coupled with diminishing consumption, make a trade crisis inevitable.

Rationalization is essential to the survival of these most basic of Ethiopia's industries, but it will be accomplished only if government, in consultation with business, organizes itself to deal with reality.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


212 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 7, 1997


Ethiopia;
The "Little Rains" Are a Little Late


BYLINE: Our Economic Correspondent, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1294 words


 

Addis Ababa - The "Ferenjis" call them the "little rains". We call them the "Belg" rains.

The "little rains" are so called, because they are much less in quantity than the "big rains" (or the "Kremt") which fall during June, July, August and part of September. The "little rains" typically come during the February- April period. And now it is the first week of March, but the "Little rains" have not yet put in an appearance, at least in Addis Ababa, which receives a great deal of both the "Kremt" and "Belg" rains. 

There is still time for them to arrive as the "Belg" season generally extends to May and officially begins in March. But the omens in the skies of Addis are not particular encouraging at the moment. They are clear and blue and, but for some tempering winds, the heat in the afternoon is quite intense. The dreaded word "drought" is already on the lips of many people. Is 1997/98 going to be another drought year, after two consecutive, good crop years? It is still too early to say, but there have been foreign reports, including those of the BBC, that countries in East Africa may experience drought conditions in the 1997/98 period. With respect to Ethiopia, the BBC mentioned particularly the Ogaden region. Ethiopian officials appear to have recognized the possibility of drought at least in some regions of the country as may be gathered from the following passage which appeared in the "Ethiopian Herald" ( the government-owned English daily newspaper) of February 22, 1997:

"a study aimed at identifying the magnitude of the drought-caused disaster in Afder and Liben Zones of Somali Regional State is being conducted. An assessment team drawn from the regional disaster prevention and preparedness and health bureaus as well as the regional council was deployed to the zones to get first-hand information on the state of the drought disaster to determine the quality of relief food to be dispatched to the areas."

A failure of the "Belg" rains is usually regarded as a harbinger of a similar failure of the "Kremt" rains, although this need not always be the case. A failure of the "Kremt" represents total disaster, as it accounts for about 90 percent of total crop production. The "Belg" rains account for the remainder on average, but they are much more important in some regions, particularly in Bale, Tigray and Wello. If the "little rains"fail to materialize, the country's total crop production may drop by as much as 10 percent; if the "Kremt" fails or the rains prove inadequate, then we will have to contend with yet another drought.

However, should drought strike again, mass starvation as in past years is unlikely, given the officially reported grain, mainly maize, surplus of 5-10 million quintals for the current 1996/97 year. It may nevertheless be necessary to halt the present drive to export maize to neighboring and other countries, which, it appears, have been prompted to import Ethiopian maize by prospects of drought conditions in their own climatic zones. On the other hand, the present policy of persuading donor countries and international organizations to buy surplus maize on the domestic market for distribution to food-insecure people in food-deficit and other regions of the country is commendable and should thus be continued on a more systematic basis. But, of course, there may not be a drought after all, and the current signs of drought conditions may be short-lived. At any rate, concerning the "Belg" rains nothing certain is likely to emerge before the end of March.

In the event of a drought, the assistance to be obtained from international and domestic NGO's becomes particularly important. But the relations between the government and many of these NGO's appear to have soured quite a bit in recent months, leading to outright closure of a sizeable number of them. Apparently, this problem does not seem to have been solved in any satisfactory manner as may be appreciated from the following excerpts from the "Ethiopian Herald" of the same date as quoted above:

"Meanwhile, a statement issued by the commission (i.e. Disaster Prevention and Preparedness Commission -DPPC) indicated that late submission and incompleteness of plan of operation by NGO's continues to be a problem. Out of 240 NGO's expected to submit their annual plans of operation in 1996, 34 have not submitted, it said, and indicated that 96 others have not yet handed in their 1997 plans."

"The Nazareth Children Center and Integrated Development Organization was banned from operating in Tigray Eastern Zone for failure to meet provisions in the agreement it signed, zonal disaster prevention and preparedness department said. The department said the welfare organization's performance through 1985 E.C. in its area of operation in Ganta Afeshumu Woreda of the zone has been proved to be insignificant."

Why it is difficult for some NGO's to submit plans of operation to the DPPC and why the government has taken such harsh measures against such NGO's remain a mystery.

Even if 1997/98 turns out to be a drought year, there are quite a few things going for Ethiopia at present including:

* a still comfortable level of foreign reserves

* rising world prices for its major export commodity, coffee;

* a considerable amount of foreign soft loans and grants in the pipeline;

* the reported nine-fold increases in the country's food security reserves;

* the reported 5-10 million quintals of surplus grain in the 1996/97 harvest.

In any case, in the spirit of "disaster prevention and preparedness" it would be advisable to take the following measures in the face of what appear to be dangerous weather warning signals:

* prepare as soon as possible a comprehensive weather conditions and crop production prospects report covering the whole country, with particular reference to regions likely to be affected by the current weather changes; ( this is to be just a general survey not an in - depth assessment);

* estimate the needs for relief aid in the event of a drought;

* submit estimated relief requirements to donor countries and international organizations in good time;

* prepare preliminary appropriations for the government budget and a action plan to implement it.

* patch up differences between the PPDC and NGO's

We hope we will not need all these reports and relief needs estimated, but it would be wise to err on the side of safely and security. The "little rains" may be only a little late now; however, there is no telling whether they will arrive at all this "Belg" season!


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


213 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 7, 1997


Mozambique;
Mozambican Refugees Thrown Out Of Zambia


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - Zambia has expelled about 300 Mozambicans who sought refuge in that country because of February's devastating floods in the Zambezi River basin, a Mozambican newspaper reported Friday.

The newspaper, Noticias, said the victims were now sheltering in the small town of Malowera, in Mozambique's Tete province, just south of the Zambian border. 

Zambia's ambassador in Maputo, Bellon Chisuta, told the newspaper that he knew nothing about the expulsions and cast doubt on the veracity of the reports.

However, a Mozambican government delegation is due to visit Zambia shortly to find out why Lusaka took this measure. The two countries have had a long history of friendship.

The director of Mozambique's Refugee Support Nucleus, Fernando Fazenda, said the expulsions violated a protocol on refugees signed between the two countries.

Meanwhile, Fazenda said that Malawian authorities, though not resorting to forced repatriation, have said they are unwilling to receive a joint mission from the Mozambique Support Nucleus and the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees to discuss the situation of up to 60,000 Mozambicans who have fled into Nsanje district in southern Malawi, because of the floods. "We wanted to go to Malawi to see at first hand the conditions of our fellow countrymen," Fazenda said. "Together with the Malawian authorities and the UNHCR, we wanted to find ways of helping them. But Malawi is not willing to receive us."


LOAD-DATE: March 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


214 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 7, 1997


Zaire;
Germany Assists Zairian Refugees


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Germany gave 290,000 U.S. dollars Thursday to support Zairian refugees entering Zambia in increasing numbers through Kaputa and Mpulungu, in the north of the country.

The German Embassy in Lusaka said this action followed an appeal for aid, to the international community, by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. 

The contribution, to be transferred to commissioner's headquarters in Geneva, is to be reserved for refugee support programmes to be implemented in Zambia between March 1 and July 31.

"German hopes that its contribution will help to alleviate the plight of the refugees and will make it easier for Zambia to continue its traditional hospitality in this field," the embassy said.

Zambia's home affairs minister, Chitalu Sampa, appealed to donors Tuesday for help in dealing with the influx of Zairian refugees. The refugees have been fleeing a westward rebel advance in eastern Zaire.

Sampa said that there was great human suffering at northern Mpulungu Port, the main refugee entry point into Zambia. He said that due to congestion and exhaustion there have been 29 official deaths recorded among the 2,000 Zairian refugees who have entered Zambia since October 1996.


LOAD-DATE: March 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


215 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 7, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
African Leaders Affirm Democracy Was Here To Stay


BYLINE: Joseph Ngwawi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 947 words


 

GABORONE, Botswana (PANA) - African Commonwealth leaders concluded a key democracy and good governance round-table late February, against the backdrop of a number of destabilizing factors undermining political reforms on the continent.

The leaders, who met in the remote game resort of Kasane on the Botswana border with Namibia, Zambia and Zimbabwe, decried the prevalence of poverty, tribalism and "brain drain" as factors that threaten the continent's young democracies.

While recognizing the importance of political opposition, they expressed reservations about the activities of some unnamed foreign funded non- governmental organizations which promoted activities "detrimental to stable democratic processes."

The roundtable, described by Commonwealth Secretary-General Emeka Anyaoku as unique and ground-breaking, began on Feb. 24 with meetings of ministers and opposition leaders from Africa's 18 Commonwealth states. 

Presidents who attended the retreat were Ketumile Masire of Botswana, Yahya Jammeh of Gambia, Daniel Arap Moi of Kenya, Bakili Muluzi of Malawi, Joaquim Chissano of Mozambique, Nelson Mandela of South Africa, Benjamin Mkapa of Tanzania, Frederick Chiluba of Zambia and Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe.

Other countries represented by prime ministers or deputies were Cameroon, Ghana, Lesotho, Namibia, Seychelles, Swaziland and Uganda.

However, Nigeria, suspended from the commonwealth in 1995 for its human rights record, was not invited to the meeting which sought to assess progress on the implementation of the recommendations of the Commonwealth's Harare Declaration of 1991.

Representatives of ruling and opposition parties who met prior to the leaders' retreat had earlier made various proposals, among them, the need for the Commonwealth to initiate a common code of conduct which would be binding on all African political parties.

The proposed code of conduct, which was not included in a joint statement produced at the end of the leaders' retreat, would have enshrined the right of the victorious party in an election to rule as well as the right of losing parties to oppose the rules by constitutional means.

It would also call for equal access to the media as well as state funding for political parties.

In the joint statement, the leaders underlined that sustainable democracy could only grow within society and could be neither prescribed nor imposed from outside.

"Democracy is not foreign to Africa," Nigerian-born Chief Anyaoku said. " Where I come from there is a saying that a chief is a chief by the will of the people."

The leaders noted that even countries like Swaziland and Nigeria, which banned political activity, were currently working on a timetable for reforms which could see them introduce political pluralism in the near future.

However, despite the commitment expressed by the leaders, Africa still faces a formidable enemy in the form of inter-ethnic conflicts in many parts of the continent.

These conflicts, Moi said, were the major impediments to efforts by Commonwealth Africa to embrace democratic tenets as outlined in the Harare declaration.

He said peace and stability, key ingredients in the democratization process, would never be guaranteed in Commonwealth Africa unless ethnic strife in the region was contained.

Referring to the Great Lakes region, Moi said a lasting solution should be found to problems afflicting Burundi, Rwanda and Zaire if political reforms in other countries in the region were to be cemented.

"My country, for example, may be peaceful and stable, but we cannot live in peace with the turmoil we see all around us in Somalia, the Sudan and in the Great Lakes region," he said.

Kenya is leading regional efforts to bring lasting solution to the crisis in eastern Zaire where anti-government forces have captured large areas in their attempt to topple the regime of President Mobutu Sese Seko.

"It is regrettable that at a time when Africa should be addressing the economic challenges facing her, the scarce resources are being devoted to quelling civil strife and ethnic conflicts," Moi pointed out.

It remains to be seen whether the February round-table could have laid a strong enough foundation that could see Commonwealth Africa becoming a shining example to the rest of the continent or whether it was just another high-level summit that comes to nought as was the fate of similar initiatives in the past.


LOAD-DATE: March 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


216 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 7, 1997


Central Africa;
OAU Donates 40,000 Dollars Toward C.A.R. Peace Efforts


BYLINE: Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - The Organization of African Unity (O.A.U.) announced a donation of 40,000 U.S. dollars Thursday to help offset the allowances of the inter-African Mission for the monitoring of the Bangui Peace Accords for the politically troubled Central African Republic.

The organization said also it would send a senior military officer, Col. Gustav Zoula, from its Addis Ababa headquarters to Bangui, capital of the Central African republic, from March 16. 

The officer will, during his two-weeks stay in the country, help the international follow-up committee on the Bangui Accords to implement disarmament of rebel soldiers.

The agreements provide for an end to the mutiny, disarmament, formation of a government of national unity, and the reintegration of rebels into the army.

Both moves are follow ups to an O.A.U. peace mission to Libreville, capital of Gabon, and Bangui, in February. That mission was headed by the organization's assistant secretary-general, Pascal Gayama.

O.A.U. Secretary-General, Salim Ahmed Salim, has said that the presidents of Chad, Burkina Faso, Gabon and Mali had been instrumental in resolving the crisis.

"Their efforts were a demonstration of Africa's commitment to resolve its own problems," Salim Said.

He said the O.A.U. was ready to help consolidate the Bangui Accords and ensure that unity and cohesion return to the Central African Republic.


LOAD-DATE: March 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


217 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 7, 1997


West Africa;
Nigeria - Sierra Leone Military Accord Renewed


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigeria and Sierra Leone signed in Lagos Friday an accord renewing their military cooperation.

The defence chief, Maj.Gen. Abdulsalam Abubakar, initialled the agreement for Nigeria, while Sierra Leonean deputy minister of defence, Rtd. Capt. Sam Norman, signed for his country.

The pact, known as "Status of Forces Agreement (SOFA), provides for the expansion of the Nigerian Army Training Agreement (NATAG) signed between both countries in 1994. 

While NATAG provided for the training of Sierra Leonean troops only, SOFA covers training for the navy, air force, the police and other security agencies.

Abubakar said the agreement was a reaffirmation of Nigeria's support for Sierra leone.

He said both countries had socio-economic and cultural ties over the years, having trained together as part of the Royal West African Frontier Force and more recently, collaborating under the West African peace monitoring force or Ecomog, in Liberia.

Contemporary developments have proved that no nation could stand alone, Abubakar said, noting that the emphasis in international relations was collective regional security.

He announced that Brig.Gen. Jimi Ojokojo would head the Nigerian training mission to Sierra Leone.

In his response, Norman said with the agreement, both countries had made an undertaking to protect their peoples. He said Sierra Leone always looked up to Nigeria as a bigger brother.

The renewal of the military pact came amid reports by a Lagos newspaper that Sierra Leonean rebel leader, Foday Sankoh, arrived in Lagos early this week at the invitation of an unnamed businessman.

The Concord newspaper reported Friday that Sankoh was arrested Sunday by the Nigerian police for being in possession of arms at the Lagos airport. The daily said he was later handed over to the presidential guards who flew him to Abuja, for further questioning.

But neither the Nigerian authorities nor the Sierra Leonean High Commission in Lagos could confirm or deny the story.

Sankoh is leader of Sierra Leone's Revolutionary Unity Front (RUF), which has been waging a bush war against the Freetown government.

The warring parties recently signed a peace accord brokered by Cote d'Ivoire to end the six-year-old civil strife, which has killed at least 15, 000 people.


LOAD-DATE: March 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


218 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 7, 1997


United States and Africa;
Major Conference On U.S. Trade & Investment In Africa


BYLINE: Felix Njoku, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - The immense opportunities offered by Africa for American businesses will again feature at a major trade and investment conference to be hosted in May by the City of Scottsdale in the state of Arizona, the south-western United States.

The organizers, Phoenix-based AMI Consultants, told PANA that the May 1-2 forum would discuss emerging opportunities for U.S. investment in Africa. It will also deal with the challenges, information, facilitation and support programmes among a host of issues on how to do business in Africa. 

"Few regions of the world offer more untapped opportunity for U.S. businesses than Africa," said Robert Sherman, President of AMI Consultants, in pre-conference papers released to PANA.

"Yet, the companies that have entered that market constitute only 'the tip of the iceberg' compared to the enormous opportunities that exist in this large and resource-endowed continent," Sherman said.

Sub-Sahara Africa is a market of nearly 750 million persons. The annual rate of returns on the U.S. foreign direct investment has been calculated by the Department of Commerce at 28 percent. This is higher than any other part of the World, the document noted.

In this regard, Sherman said the conference would highlight specific opportunities and identify resources that are available to assist U.S. businesses participating in the commercial development of Africa.

It will also present the range and depth of assistance available from a host of U.S. and multilateral funding institutions which, between them, manage some 40 billion U.S. dollars for African projects.

"Additional sessions will highlight private sector experiences focusing on practical realities that underscores success in trading and investment in Africa," Sherman said.

African ambassadors and commercial attaches accredited to the U.S., he said, had been invited to provide country specific reports.

Dignitaries invited to speak at the forum, billed to take place at the Sunburst Resort in Scotsdale, Arizona, include U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan, Arizona governor Fife Symington, Senators John McCain and John Kyl as well as many local officials.

Others are U.S. Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs George Moose, David Miller of the Corporate Council on Africa, the Reverend Leon Sullivan of IFESH, among other ranking officials from the State and Commerce departments which are co-hosts.

AMI Consultants, which in 1996 organized a similar forum tagged "Africa96" in Phoenix, says participation fees range from 95 to 150 dollars payable as from April 10, 1997. (Contacts: Dr. Robert Sherman or Dr. Innocent Abiaka: Phone (606) 279-7278 Fax (602) 279-7703 E-Mail: amicon@goodnet.com


LOAD-DATE: March 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March 8, 1997


Science and Health;
Bats may beat malaria


BYLINE: Sharon Hammond, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

Komatipoort - The misunderstood bat may prove to be an effective means of combatting malaria-carrying mosquitos, says Dr Gary Bronner, a project leader for the Angolan free-tailed bat study.

Bronner, a senior lecturer at the Department of Zoology at Potchefstroom University, said the aim of the study was to determine if the Angolan free- tailed bat and lesser free-tailed bat could effectively control mosquito numbers in specifically the Komatipoort area in Mpumalanga. 

"We want to find out if the bats eat everything they come across or if they are fussy," he says.

"We want to determine how much of the bat's diet is made up of mosquitos, and if we find bats are actually valuable malaria fighters, perhaps they'll lose their bad image," he explains.

Transvaal Sugar Limited (TSB), the largest sugar manufacturer in the area, has proposed sponsoring a Zoology student R10 000 to help

conduct the study.

"The project is looking at a long term approach and not a quick-fix solution to the problem of malaria in this area," explains TSB spokesperson, Riaan Pienaar, on Thursday.

Bronner and his team are searching for a student prepared to live for a certain length of time in Komatipoort, a small farming community along the border of Mozambique, to study the two bat types.

The bats would have to be caught and ringed, and injected with sterilised water for later blood testing to determine the amount of energy the bat consumed.

The student would also have to determine how many mosquitos were eaten by the bat. .

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


March 9, 1997


Science and Health;
Development brings plague of sexually transmitted diseases to villages


BYLINE: Sharon Hammond, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 934 words


 

MALELANE - When the rural villagers of the far eastern Mpumalanga heard that their area had been targeted for multi-million rand development, they rejoiced at the pending economic libera-tion.

Little did they realise that the onslaught of hundreds of cash-flush labourers working on dam and other infrastructure sites, would leave their agriculturally based communities reeling under a 50 to 100 percent increase in HIV infections as well as a litany of other sexually transmitted diseases (STDs).

The reason: single men working on construction sites for months on end and with nothing to really spend their wages on, easily seduced rural women and even young school girls with promises of money, clothing or even food.

Mpumalanga AIDs and STD Programme head, Dr Calvin Billinghurst explains that 19 percent of women living in the rural triangle between Komatipoort, Barberton and the northern border of Swaziland, admit that they are aware their construction worker husbands and lovers regularly practice unsafe sex with other women. 

This brings into question, says Dr Billing-hurst, just how much responsibility the construction industry management should shoulder in the sexual health education of their workers, and how much must be left to the government.

Three of the Mpumalanga Department of Health's major clinics in the area have shown increases of up to 100 percent in HIV and STDs since construction began on the R488 million Driekoppies Dam along the Lomati River in 1993.

"With the construction of the dam, there's been a definite increase in the number of STDs. It will be interesting to see if levels drop after the dam is completed," adds Dr Billinghurst.

Social workers also say that the rapid shift of employment from low paying agricultural jobs to a weekly cash wage system in the construction trade, without any increase in spending outlets has disrupted the traditional social fabric.

Teenage delinquency, teenage pregnancy, increased drinking problems and an alleged decline in respect for traditional authority structures have all accompanied the develop-ment projects.

Driekoppies's site manager, Mike Nietsche, admitted to Reconstruct that his workers were not being educated with regards to safe sex.

"At least 75 percent of the workers live in surrounding villages and we agreed with the Department of Health one year ago that their clinics would be responsible for the necessary education," he explained.

"Their people are trained and paid to do that," he added.

Construction on the dam is expected to continue until at least the beginning of 1988.

Another large industry operating in the area, Transvaal Sugar Limited (TSB) spent two years on the construction of its second regional sugar mill, costing R418 million, north of a tribal village called Naas, but has been praised by health workers for its commitment to primary health care.

"TSB's very good. They have their own clinics and regularly make use of organisations like the AIDs Training Information and Counselling Centre (Aticc) which has a large budget for the free distribution of condoms," says Dr Billinghurst.

TSB nursing sister, Zelda Van Jaarsveld, explains that the company has ten clinics and annually organises a large theatre production about the dangers of unsafe sex.

"We also conduct formal training sessions, as well as informal training sessions where we go into the workplace and discuss the use of condoms with workers," she said.

Dr Billinghurst warns that Mpumalanga has the second highest HIV/AIDs rate in the country with 16 percent of the province's population being infected with HIV.

"In fact, a sample survey of 1 000 women indicate that five percent of babies are being born HIV positive, which means the province could face a negative growth rate within two to three years," he said.

At the moment, Mpumalanga has a population growth rate of 4,5 percent.

"I think only when people feel the enormous impact of full-blown AIDs which should start affecting the population in two to three years time, will it be taken more seriously," Dr Billinghurst warns.

In light of the staggering implications full-blown AIDs will have on the province's economy, industrial and corporate management should perhaps consider shouldering greater responsibility in creating awareness about the killer disease. .


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


221 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 9, 1997


Sports - General;
South Africa's first Black gold Olympic medalist trapped in cliches


BYLINE: Sharon Hammond, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2107 words


 

NELSPUIT - South Africa's sporting hero, Josaya Thugwane is trapped in an almost impenetrable cocoon of cliches created by the country's media.

He's the nation's "golden boy", the "rags to riches" story of everybody's dreams who "overcame all odds".

The first black South African to win an Olympic gold medal, Josaya was photographed as a gargantuan in cool shades crossing the finish line in Atlanta with ease.

In reality, the 45 kilogram megastar is a pintsized 1,55 metre cleaner who is swallowed up by executive chairs like a toddler on dad's lazy-boy.

He's serious, gives only occasional smiles, and genuinely believes that he hasn't won the medal, but that the faceless 40-million of a fledgling Rainbow Nation have won it. 

The fawning of politicians, premiers and mayors who threw him the "mother of all parties" and spun him on a two-week blitz of Mpumalanga, only exhausted the quiet family man, often leaving him in a blinking daze, but he suffered it all with unselfish patriotism.

"What I've done, I haven't done for political organisations," he says simply. "In South Africa there are a lot of organisations and the people who run those organisations are South African and I won this medal for South Africa. I have done this for South Africa," he explains.

Josaya says he wants as many South Africans as possible to see "their" medal and that the only way that could be done, was for him to go to the people.

Through the services of a Zulu translator, it's quite a task to fathom the man. He does not show much emotion, talking in low monotones with only the occasional lift of eyebrows and widening of eyes to stress a point.

Frustrated photographers attempting to capture him on film when he was granted the freedom of Mpumalanga and Nelspruit, referred to him as "dead-pan" and "like a statue'.

"It's just not good, just not good," some muttered in a low-key frenzy, nervously glancing at their watches as their deadlines drew nearer and the pintsized hero remained annoylingly expressionless.

But at the mention of music, the sombre face breaks out into an impish grin and we learn that the wee African has a thang for reggae! If, he says, reggae was played at Premier Mathews Phosa's big bash for him, all exhaustion would melt away. Josaya's into boogieing, you see, despite being a teetotaller (not because of any Christian values - he only attends church when he feels like it) but because it wouldn't do his training any good.

"Oh, yes, I dance!" he says brightly. "I'll only drink coke and stuff, but I'll dance, especially if its reggae," he insists, listing Lucky Dube and the Toots and the Maytals as his favourite reggae bands.

True to ardent reggae fans, Josaya sported funky dreadlocks when he went over to Atlanta, but because of the humidity, he was forced to cut them off.

"In fact, when his mother's employer called her to see him cross the finish line, she didn't recognise him without his dreads and refused to believe it was him," explains Josaya's chaperone during the provincial blitz, Musa Mlombo.

Despite the bit of rebel in him (and, of course, the extraordinary rise to international fame), Josaya insists he is quite ordinary and describes his daily routine as running, bathing, watching the news, and having early nights. Josaya's other interests still involve running.

"If there's a sports game in the township, I go watch it, especially if it's soccer," says the runner, whose interest in running started when he played township soccer himself.

He also attends school sports days in Emzinoni township near Bethal, and helps out with the 1 500m races.

"But even if they don't need my help, I run with the kids for fun," he adds.

Josaya has always been popular in the township, and this has been attributed to his general kindness. For instance, he can't say exactly how many pairs of running shoes he owns because, he explains, besides the 20 pairs at home, there are many that he's given away.

And even though the diminutive star lately has to drive through the dusty township rather than walk so as to avoid happy crowds who want to shake his hand, he does not consider himself a hero.

"I'm not like a movie star, and if I am a hero, it's too early to tell," he says, reverting to his usual modesty.

Asked whether the road show had disturbed his family life, Josaya says he's spent every possible moment with his wife, Zodwa and two of his four children, who have accompanied him since he landed to the glare of camera flashes and TV lights at Johannesburg International Airport.

But it is the violent crime in South Africa that really motivates Josaya to keep his family at his side. After a vicious attempt on his life during a hijacking in March, he's been looking for a safer place to keep Zodwa and the children.

"I was shot in the face and they took my car. I did not know if I would be able to run in the Olympics. Even when I was well, I was afraid to go because there was no-one to look after my family. I tried to move them to Hendrina, where it is safer, but was unable to," he says.

"I really am afraid of the violence and that is one of the reasons I want a house and not a shack - houses are safer."

The importance of his own family makes sense when he describes his childhood, a tale which would make any Hollywood director weep for not thinking up the story-line himself. It is likely to forever cast Josaya as a new folk hero for a new era.

"I was raised differently to other people who had a mother and father," he starts. Josaya was born to a teenage mother on a farm in Mpumalanga on April 15, 1971, and was adopted by his grandparents. He's never known his father and his somewhat estranged mother lives with a boyfriend.

His only taste of education lasted a few months when an uncle took him to a farm school at the age of 13. He was to start Sub A.

"But my uncle died and I had to get a job because we had no food and I had to look after my grandmother," he explains.

Josaya's first job was that of an unpaid cattle herder, while he and his grandmother lived with an uncle and aunt who were farm labourers on a farm outside Bethal.

"Nobody was allowed to stay on the farm without working. I earned nothing, and my uncle earned a bag of mealie meal every month which would have to feed the four of us," he says, using that slight lift of the eyebrows.

At the age of 14, Josaya left home to find work in Kriel, where he worked as a garden boy in the gardens of suburbanites for the nexst three years.

At the age of 17 when, he says, "the spirit of running entered me", Josaya joined Koornfontein mine, as a cleaner of the staff quarters.

Describing his experiences at the mine, it soon becomes clear - Josaya is a no-nonsense man. In fact, he is often accused by management of being cheeky.

When told by mine management to work on weekends, he dug in his heels - he couldn't afford to cut into his training time. His stubborness paid off and he was finally accommodated by being transferred to work in the kitchens as a dishwasher and server.

In 1993, after insisting on three months leave to go to circumcision school, Josaya returned to work to find someone else had taken over his kitchen duties, and was told he was to work underground.

"I refused. They said it would only be for six to twelve months, but the dust is bad for my lungs and after working so long underground during the day, I wouldn't have the strength to train at night," he explains.

This time, mine managment refused to negotiate, and Josaya refused to budge. He resigned.

He began training under the guidance of American-based athletics agent, Tony Longhurst, and won the 1993 South African marathon title. Thereafter, he was trained by one of South Africa's formeost long distance coaches, Bobby McGee, who nurtured Josaya to his penultimate victory at Atlanta in August.

"Josaya is actually uncoachable," says McGee. "He is very much a 'feel' runner who takes what works for him and basically designs his own training programme," says McGee.

Josaya admits to being somewhat of a masochist and does not believe that he's trained properly, unless his legs ache.

"After nine days of training in Atlanta, I told Xolile (Xolile Yawa, the South African runner who withdrew from the Olympic marathon due to injury) I had to train on my own in the mornings because the training was too easy - in South Africa I could feel I was really training, because my feet were sore," Josaya explains.

The three years before Atlanta were spent solely on training and running half-marathons and the mines and business sector took note of the dynamo who ran taxing, hilly routes with ease.

"Koornhof begged me to go back to them, but they still wanted me to work undergound and I couldn't do that," Josaya says.

He says the private sector also approached him, but because he was uneducated, could not employ him.

The management at Koornhof mine eventually found work which Josaya would be prepared to do and he was finally re-employed as a cleaner.

But since his win, sponsorships worth thousands of rands are expected to fall in his lap and Josaya could soon become a millionaire. Will he always be a cleaner?

"I'll still work at the mine, but I'm due to be promoted to a telephone operator," he says, with a pleased smile. Any money his Atlanta win will earn him, would simply be invested to "make more money" he adds.

As for the possible "millions", he says he's not concerned by the implications success would have on him, nor by the possibilities of being exploited.

"Maybe when I have the money, I'll worry. But right now, I don't. So people can ask and ask for money, but I don't have any," he says simply.

What he does want, however, is both houses that have been offered to him by the Mpumalanga govenrment and Koornfontein mine. A bit of a political dispute arose over who would give Josaya a house, but he believes he could put both to good use.

"I have two children from another woman and they need a house. I need a house too, because my blue shack is just too cold," he explains.

Quite soon, he might just be able to buy himself his own house - or two.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


222 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 9, 1997


Science and Health;
Africa's myths may save Africa


BYLINE: Sharon Hammond, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1054 words


 

Nelspruit - For centuries, four pale gods reigned on the prominent rock outcrop which looms over the flat planes of Acornhoek on the border of Northern Province and Mpumalanga.

Today, the majestic rock mountain still dominates the landscape, but the legend of the pale gods has been dead for 30 years, since white businessmen in the area built a hotel on its slope.

"The hotel didn't last long, but the people believed that the power of the gods had been broken, and no longer feared them," explains Petros Ndimande, a Swazi taxi tour operator from Nelspruit.

No longer would people mysteriously disappear when mist enshrouded the mountain at dusk and dawn, and perhaps story tellers will no longer tell the legend since its power was killed by the white man. 

The killing of legends, warns archaeologist, Sidney Miller, is a serious threat to the survival of culture and, ultimately, to economic prosperity brought by tourism.

Mpumalanga MEC for Arts and Culture, Lassy Chiwayo echoes this sentiment.

"We need to promote story-telling methods, and hotel and leisure industries can play a role in this by creating jobs for local comedians and dancers," he said at the recent Satour promotion of Mpumalanga and Northern Province as tourist destinations.

Miller, who hit the headlines when he and his team uncovered the 13th- century stone-walled trading city of Thulamela near Pafuri in the Kruger National Park last year, says instead of carving giraffes and birds, local sculptors should rediscover the craftsmanship of their Thulamela ancestors and replicate the ancient gold bracelets and beads discovered on royal skeletons on site.

"This is what Africa can give tourism - a touch of the mystical, something unique that no other country has," he says.

Supporting a more controversial means of attracting tourism, Miller proposes that more archaeological sites be responsibly reconstructed in terms of the National Monuments Code of Ethics.

"If South America can make millions from the Aztecs, and the Egyptians can make money from stones stacked on one another, then archaeology can make a great contribution to the economy of this country," he explains.

He said France "bragged" about its mere 470 archaeological sites, whereas South Africa had a conservative estimate of 15 000 sites.

"South Africa has the richest history in the world," he says.

"In Mpumalanga, Northern Province and Thulamela, there was a continuous habitation over 1,5 million years," he explains.

He says the difference between South Africa and countries such as South America and Australia, should be that South African archaeologists reconstruct sites with the cooperation of local communities.

"South American Indians and Aborigines have demanded the state return ancestral bones, but at Thulamela, this problem was averted because we worked with the community," he explains.

He says the community around Thulamela had allowed scientists and archaeologists to study royal skeletons, on condition they be reburied with the appropriate reverence.

The community has also, he says, formed a committee to manage funds generated by the site and to ensure all money went back into the community.

"Everyone participates and is proud. This is not a begging community," Miller explains.

He also warns against communities selling original artifacts to overseas collectors and forever losing cultural heritage pieces.

"For R20 000, a piece is lost to someone's house overseas, whereas it could be worth more if 20 000 school children had to see and learn from it," he says.

He says artifacts, such as the Mapungubwe gold which has been locked away for 60 years, should not be hidden in university vaults, but rather displayed and protected in museums.

"After all, to whom do these artifacts belong? We have to look at changing the law," he says.

Although a serious supporter of taking tourists to living cultural sites and tribal villages, Miller also warns against disturbing tribal life where communities may instead pander to tourists, instead of giving them the genuine experience.

"This is a sensitive issue and must be handled delicately," he says.

"We must keep in mind that we are taking tourists into the private lives of people and must not disturb their way of life," he explains.

Today, he says, archaeologists take as little as possible away from sites to leave "something for brighter architects in 200 years time".

In the mean time, sites can be used efficiently to create jobs and spin- offs for tourism.

"But they should not be run by big-operators. They could be constructed in such a way that the money goes into the correct pockets," Miller says.

"We must remember, we are touching the lives of people's ancestors, and must guard against transferring their rights," he says.

"If we lose respect for the ancestors, we may lose everything." .


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


223 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 9, 1997


South Africa;
ANC STATEMENT ON NP INVITATION TO IFP, DP, FREEDOM FRONT


BYLINE: African National Congress of South Africa


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 174 words


 

Johannesburg - The ANC has noted the NP invitation to the IFP, DP and Freedom Front to join it in opposing the ANC. The ANC views the NP invitation to these parties as an invitation to commit mutual political suicide. 

For any political party to be seen to be hugging with the apartheid hyena and the alleged church bombers is to invite sudden political death. The immediate historical task of the NP is to die. Without the death of the NP, the chances of the growth of a vibrant and yet patriotic opposition is frustrated.

The ANC calls upon all political formations to co-operate with it and together roll our sleeves to confront the national catastrophe bequethed to us by the party of apartheid, the National Party.

Issued by the ANC KwaZulu Natal Political Leadership, 8 March 1997.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

224 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 9, 1997


South Africa;
ANC STATEMENT ON IFP VIOLENCE ACCUSATIONS


BYLINE: African National Congress of South Africa


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Johannesburg - The ANC KwaZulu Natal Caucuss has noted the statement of Mr Arthur Konnigkramer, IFP Provincial MP, accusing some members of the ANC Provincial Parliament of being responsible for violence in KwaZulu Natal with dismay and disgust.

The Safety and Security portfolio committee of KwaZulu Natal Legislature set up a sub-committee to investigate allegations of a "no-go" area in Richmond for South African Police Service. The Sub-Committee began its work last year and has heard evidence from a number of people. The Sub-Committee has yet to finalise its report. 

One of the reports submitted to the Committee was an Intelligence Report from the SANDF. The report which appears to be based on the evidence of informers, contains a number of allegations against ANC and IFP members. In the IFP the report points at the highest level.

The ANC will not sink so low as to reveal the names of the most senior IFP leaders mentioned in the Intelligence Report before the full Committee makes its final report.

The Subcommittee is still in the process of discussing the document and has not as yet spoken directly to the SANDF to ascertain the reliability of the information and on what basis it was compiled.

The Subcommittee however agreed that the document is to be treated as privileged to the Sub-Committee until decided otherwise.

Mr Konnigkrammer has by releasing selective details of the report, shown his contempt for the Sub-Committee and his lack of commitment to ensuring that the Sub-Committee completes its task and the problem of no-go areas is effectively addressed. He has virtually jeopardised the the work of the Sub- Committee and that of delivering peace in KwaZulu Natal.

The ANC leadership will raise this problem created by Arthur Konnigkramer to the IFP leadership.

Issued by The ANC KwaZulu Natal Caucus, 8 March 1997.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


225 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 9, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
WFP Emergency Report No. 10 - Africa (03/10)


BYLINE: World Food Programme


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 3627 words


 

Rome - This report includes: A) Burundi, Rwanda, Zaire and Tanzania B) Uganda C) Sahel - Chad, Mauritania and Niger D) Mozambique and Malawi floods.

PART I - HIGHLIGHTS (Details below in Part II)

A. EAST AFRICA: REGIONAL OPERATION FOR BURUNDI, RWANDA, ZAIRE AND TANZANIA

1. Eastern Zaire a) Refugees abandon Tingi Tingi camps on 28 February, and head into the forest; some reported moving towards Kisangani and Ubundu. b) Zaire Government reacts to evacuation of aid agencies from Kisangani and orders expulsion of international UN and non-governmental organization (NGO) staff from the country. c) Refugees of Shabunda and Kalima camps reportedly on their way to Punia. d) WFP makes arrangements with the Catholic mission to continue food distributions to internally displaced persons and newly arriving refugees in Kisangani and to refugees in Punia.

2. Rwanda a) Food deliveries improve; UN aid convoys operate under military escort between Kigali and Cyangugu, Kibuye, Gisenyi and Ruhengeri. b) Some 428,000 persons, mostly returnees, benefit from food distributions in the period 24 February to 2 March. 

3. Burundi a) WFP together with NGOs is undertaking a food and seed distribution operation in many parts of the country. b) Increased security incidents in Bujumbura, attributed to rebels hiding within internally displaced person sites around the city, leads to forced movement of people away from the city.

4. Tanzania a) Kigoma refugee population now at over a quarter of a million and influx continues at steady rate. b) In drought-affected regions, cereal prices are increasing daily, while in some of the worst affected areas, livestock is sharply declining in value to a fraction of usual prices.

B. UGANDA

1. Update a) Numbers of affected Ugandans rapidly increasing at a time when food resourcing situation reaches alarming levels. b) FAO/WFP Crop and Food Supply Assessment Mission preliminary results indicate that rapidly deteriorating security situation in northern and eastern districts of Uganda has resulted in a doubling of food prices. c) Constraints on WFP local purchase of food commodities because of impending shortages affects supply of food to Sudanese refugees in the north of Uganda, which had been based mainly on local purchases. Food stocks will be depleted end-March and resources are urgently required to cover needs of 230,000 refugees.

C. SAHEL - CHAD, MAURITANIA AND NIGER

1. Update a) WFP emergency operation approved for Chad (EMOP 5798) to cover needs resulting from crop failure due to drought. Food requirements are 7,700 metric tons for 356,000 beneficiaries for three months. b) Another drought emergency operation (EMOP 5819) is under preparation to provide 16,560 metric tons food aid for 200,000 beneficiaries in Mauritania for six months. c) Harvest in Niger reported as average, but some areas of the country have been without rain for a second consecutive year. WFP is targeting most vulnerable zones under its existing development projects.

D. MOZAMBIQUE AND MALAWI

1. Impact of floods a) WFP Southern Africa cluster, headquarters Maputo, is assessing the effect of severe flooding in February in Mozambique and Malawi. WFP response will be on a regional basis. b) In Mozambique, immediate food needs are under control. An FAO/WFP crop assessment mission in April will establish the numbers of people affected by the impact on crops and resources required to respond to needs, but it is expected that no food imports will be required. c) DHA situation reports on Malawi and Mozambique available on ReliefWeb at http://www.reliefweb.int/ (click on Emergencies).

PART II - DETAILS

A. EAST AFRICA: REGIONAL OPERATION FOR BURUNDI, RWANDA, ZAIRE AND TANZANIA

1. EASTERN ZAIRE

1.1 General

a) Expatriate staff from aid agencies were evacuated from Kisangani to Kinshasa on 1 March. This precautionary measure was dictated by signs of increased insecurity and operational difficulties related to military activities. The Government of Zaire strongly condemned the temporary withdrawal of aid agencies from Kisangani and retaliated by ordering the expulsion from the country of staff previously based in Kisangani. The UN is adhering to the expulsion order made by the Government, thus leaving the door open for further negotiations. UN expelled staff were expected to go to Brazzaville.

b) WFP has made arrangements with the Catholic mission to continue food distributions to internally displaced persons and newly arriving refugees in Kisangani and to refugees in Punia. WFP local staff will continue to assist this operation.

c) Refugee camps in Tingi Tingi have emptied. On 28 February, fearing that the rebels were fast closing in, the 160,000 refugees hurriedly left the camps. The rebels of the Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire (ADFL) are reported to have taken the camp, its airport and the nearby town of Lubutu, on the following day, 1 March.

d) After deserting the Tingi Tingi camps, refugees started walking in different directions, some towards Kisangani. In an effort to try to prevent the refugees from reaching Kisangani, Zairean authorities tried to divert movement towards Ubundu, a river port on the left bank of the Zaire River, but some refugees have started to arrive in Kisangani, on trucks hired by WFP for food deliveries and returning from the Lubutu area.

e) An average of 4,000 displaced Zaireans a day are arriving in Kisangani, joining some 31,000 already in town. Food distribution by WFP national staff in collaboration with the Catholic Mission is scheduled to continue to the internally displaced persons and arriving refugees. WFP food stocks in Kisangani as of 4 March amounted to 409 metric tons.

f) Refugees who had left the former camps of Shabunda and Kalima are reported to be now on their way to Punia. Some 5,000 refugees were already gathered in Punia and an estimated 10,000 more are heading towards this town, 300 km south-east of Kisangani. The WFP plane was able to deliver 12 metric tons of food to Punia, for distribution by the Catholic mission.

g) Some 8,000 Zairean refugees have arrived in northern Zambia in recent weeks, entering through Mpulungu, via Lake Tanganyika. The refugees are accommodated in Kasama and Mbala. WFP has positioned 400 metric tons of food commodities in Kigoma, Tanzania, for onward transportation by lake barge to Zambia. WFP has also airlifted to Kasama 11 metric tons of non-food items for UNHCR from Mwanza in Tanzania.

h) An Ilyushin 76 is on stand by in Mwanza to resume airlifts into Zaire when circumstances permit. Air capacity in Kisangani for movements inside Zaire includes one Andover, capacity 6 metric tons, one DC3, capacity 3 metric tons and one Aztec with a capacity for 5 passengers.

1.2 Goma

a) UN agencies and NGOs are discussing assistance plans for local affected populations. Assessment exercises will be carried out to determine numbers and locations of people in need, with WFP taking the lead in this process. Aid agencies remaining in Goma include MSF-Holland, the International Committee of the Red Cross, Catholic Relief Services, Save the Children, Oxfam, UNICEF, UNHCR and WFP.

b) WFP has handed over the management of nutritional centres in Goma to UNICEF. There are presently 13 centres with 620 children.

1.3 Bukavu

a) Aid agencies have drafted a plan of activities to be carried out at transit centres and assistance points along the Bukavu/Kingulube road. Responsibilities will be shared among various agencies: SCF for nutrition, MSF/IRC for health and Care International for logistics. Between 24 February and 2 March, distribution of 1.5 metric tons of high protein biscuits at way stations along the Walungu/Bunyakiri axis benefited 1,102 returnees.

2. RWANDA

2.1 Regular UN aid convoys under military escort have started running between Kigali and Cyangugu, Kibuye, Gisenyi and Ruhengeri. Seven UN vehicles have been provided for these escorts. Regular flights to Gisenyi and Cyangugu have also been started by WFP.

2.2 Rwandan refugees continue returning from eastern Zaire. Between 24 February and 2 March 1,392 returnees came back via Cyangugu and 446 via Gisenyi. The recent upsurge in fighting in eastern Zaire is expected to result in increased repatriation. Over the past week 111 returnees came from Tanzania and 13 new refugees arrived from Burundi. In the same period, 1,745 Burundians returned to their country from Kibangira camp in Cyangugu prefecture. Another 2,400 Burundian refugees remain in that camp.

2.3 WFP is continuing efforts to speed up food distributions to returnees and to persons who have had to leave homes and land they were occupying due to the arrival of some of the returnees. Planned beneficiary figures for the months of March and April have been submitted to WFP by the National and Prefecture Food Committees. WFP has set a limit of 1.5 million beneficiaries for logistical and development reasons.

2.4 From 24 February to 2 March WFP distributed 2,678 metric tons of food to 428,000 beneficiaries. This represents a significant increase in deliveries as compared to February averages, when insecurity hampered access of convoys to many areas. Most distributions benefited returnees (65%), but also food-for-work programmes (25%), institutional feeding (5%) and targeted assistance programmes (5%).

3. BURUNDI

3.1 The seed distribution programme coordinated by FAO continues. In total WFP and NGOs will distribute 1,100 metric tons of seeds while the Government of Burundi will distribute 400 metric tons. Following joint assessments by WFP, FAO, NGOs and the Government, seed distributions were undertaken in Cibitoke, Bubanza, and Kayanza. Food distributions by WFP and NGOs are being undertaken simultaneously to minimize the risk that the seeds may be used for consumption, rather than for planting.

3.2 Teams conducting the joint UNICEF/FAO/DHA/WFP study of displaced populations went to sites in the provinces of Kayanza, Gitega, Muramvya, Makomba and Cibitoke during the past week. In addition to assessing food needs, the study examines the living conditions of these populations, including housing, water and sanitation, health, and access to education.

3.3 The security situation in the city of Bujumbura has worsened with recent incidents increasing. Concern is growing over the security risks posed by sites around the city holding internally displaced persons, such as the Johnson Centre, fuelled by accusations that rebels being harboured at these sites. The Minister of the Interior announced that several of the sites will be closed and the residents returned to their hills of origin. Observers who visited the places in question over the weekend confirmed that residents were in fact being moved out of the sites and that there are plans to move out another 4,000 people.

3.4 Mr. Martin Griffiths, UN Humanitarian Coordinator for the Great Lakes Region, has highlighted the concern of the international community in Burundi about the Government of Burundi's policy of regroupment, indicating that possibly up to 500,000 civilians might be affected.

4. TANZANIA

4.1 Refugee situation

a) The refugee influx into Kigoma continues at 1,000 to 1,500 persons per day. The total refugee population in Kigoma has reached 254,000, while the total refugee caseload for Tanzania is now over 350,000. In Kasulu district, the refugee population now equals the local population. The transfer of 15, 000 refugees from holding centres to the new Lugufu camp has temporarily relieved crowding at the three centres in Kigoma. Poor road conditions and inadequate transportation continue to disrupt food deliveries.

b) A mission made up of the Government of Tanzania and senior representatives of UN agencies and donors visited Kigoma region 3-6 March. The visit is to followed in the immediate future by a technical mission which will identify how populations in the areas of the refugee camps may be assisted to alleviate the impact of the presence of the high numbers of refugees.

4.2 Impact of drought

a) In drought-affected regions, cereal prices are increasing daily while livestock prices in some drought affected areas have dramatically dropped. Reports from north-eastern and Lake Victoria regions indicate that pastoralists are now so concerned by the complete lack of grazing and water that they are willing to sell cattle for 5,000 to 10,000 TZ SHS per head - twelve to fifteen times less than the normal prices of 70,000 TO 110,000 TZ SHS per head.

b) Drought assessment teams will visit priority areas between 10 and 25 March. These have been identified as Arusha and Kilimanjaro in the north-east coast area, Lindi in the east/south, Morogoro in the west, Dodoma, Singida, Tabora and Shinyanga in the central area and Mwanza and Mara in the Lake Victoria area.

B. UGANDA

1. UPDATE

1.1 The food resourcing situation for the Uganda programme has reached an alarming level, at a time when the number of affected people in need of immediate food assistance is likely to double.

1.2 An impending shortage of local food crops, due mostly to insecurity, has seriously affected the supply of food to Sudanese refugees in the north of Uganda. This supply was programmed mainly on local purchases. Food stocks for 230,000 Sudanese refugees under the WFP protracted relief operation PRO 5623 will be depleted end-March. The large balance of uncommitted resources for this operation needs to be mobilised and shipped immediately to avoid a prolonged interruption in distribution and increased malnutrition, already prevalent in most refugee settlements.

1.3 At the same time, the number of internally displaced in Kitgum and Gulu in northern Uganda is on the rise due to the continued insurgency, which has also prevented the internally displaced population from planting this season's crop. It is critical that the recently approved emergency operation to assist 110,000 persons (EMOP 5816) gets resourced fully on an urgent basis. The EMOP, currently covering needs for a six-month period, may need to be expanded until the displaced can harvest their next crop in February 1988.

1.4 Preliminary information from the FAO/WFP Crop and Food Supply Assessment Mission indicates that the rapidly deteriorating security situation in northern and eastern districts of Uganda has resulted in food prices doubling, exceeding the purchasing capacity of the average consumer. Food reserves are expected to decrease further in the lean season with the number of affected people rising accordingly. Details of the findings of the Mission will be made available when the Report is finalized and released by FAO and WFP. The Report will be accessible on the Internet at http://www.fao. org (click on Global Watch, then GIEWS, Special Reports).

C. SAHEL - CHAD, MAURITANIA AND NIGER

1. UPDATE

1.1 Poor cereal harvests have resulted from rainfall shortages in the Sahelian regions of Chad, Mauritania and Niger. Under an emergency crop failure assistance project (EMOP 5798) approved on 3 March, WFP will provide 7,700 metric tons of food commodities for 356,000 beneficiaries in Chad. This three-month operation is expected to be implemented immediately. WFP is preparing an emergency operation (EMOP 5819) to provide 16,560 metric tons of food aid for 200,000 beneficiaries in Mauritania through a six-month emergency drought mitigation project.

1.2 While the harvest in Niger was near average, some areas of the country have not received rain for the second consecutive year. WFP has reinforced activities under its existing development projects, which are targeted at the most vulnerable zones and populations, to respond to the situation. WFP is also working in close collaboration with NGOs for the implementation of health projects and vaccination campaigns in vulnerable regions.

1.3 WFP has taken action to establish a regional cluster office in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso. This office will coordinate WFP assistance throughout the Sahel Region. The office is expected to be operational by the beginning of the second semester of 1997.

D. MOZAMBIQUE AND MALAWI

1. IMPACT OF FLOODS

1.1 The WFP Southern Africa cluster, which has its headquarters in Maputo, is assessing the effect of severe flooding in Mozambique and Malawi in February. WFP response will be on a regional basis, to cover both countries.

1.2 The government of Mozambique launched an appeal for assistance on 24 February, to cover short and medium-term needs for repairing structural damages and meeting the requirements of the population living in the flood- affected regions, in the central provinces of Sofala, Manica, Tete and Zambezia.

1.3 Priority areas of food needs in Mozambique are presently covered through joint action by WFP, GTZ and other NGOs; WFP is providing assistance to 51,500 flood-affected beneficiaries within the existing emergency programme. WFP Mozambique considers the food situation presently under control. Although the exact numbers of beneficiaries and resources required will have to wait until an FAO/WFP crop assessment mission in April, food stocks in the country are good. As no food imports are needed, WFP's response will be in the form of local purchase and transport.

1.4 In response to the Malawian Government's appeal for international assistance, DHA's UN Disaster Assessment and Coordination (UNDAC) team arrived in the country on 19 February to assist in assessing flood damage and assistance needs in southern Malawi. Assessment results can be found in the report "Malawi - Floods, DHA Situation Report No. 4 International Appeal for Assistance" Date: 25 Feb 1997.

1.5 Further information on the impact of the recent floods in Malawi and Mozambique, including DHA Situation Reports, can be obtained by going to ReliefWeb at http://www.reliefweb.int/ and clicking on Emergencies.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


226 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 9, 1997


East Africa;
Emergency Update No. 121 on the Great Lakes (03/07)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1867 words


 

Nairobi - The Zairean Ministry of Defence said there had been violent clashes with rebels on Thursday, near Panga, some 80 kilometers northeast of Kisangani. A statement said 114 rebels from the Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire (ADFL) had been killed. The government said its soldiers had repelled another attack in the area, killing seven rebels. It is the first time the defense ministry has acknowledged the presence of rebels close to Kisangani, reports AFP.

* UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan favours a political solution for the Zairean crisis, including a ceasefire, with protection for aid workers and refugees. UN Spokesman Fred Eckhard said the Secretary-General met with Joint OAU/UN Special Representative for the Great Lakes Region Mohamed Sahnoun on Thursday. Sahnoun is expected to attend the briefing of the UN Security Council today, with Martin Griffiths, Humanitarian Coordiator for the Great Lakes Region.

* Punia, eastern Zaire, is reported by Reuters to be under the armed occupation of Hutu soldiers of the former Rwandan army. Half the estimated 100,000 civilian polulation of the town and its surroundings have fled from harassment and stealing by the ex-FAR, says a correspondent in Punia. Rwandans fear the arrival of the ADFL, which has made rapid gains in the area. Rwandan refugees in Punia said they were planning to leave soon, as the rebels "have been killing refugees". Local gendarmarie have disarmed and disappeared, according to the report. 

* Only a few dozen sick and dying Rwandans remain in Tingi-Tingi camps, eastern Zaire, reports AP. Rebels distributed small amounts of food, and said the UN should help repatriate those left in the camp. Journalists were barred from entering the camp by rebel commander Jonathan Ndironsonga, who refused to discuss what happened during the takeover. AP quotes a refugee - whose circumstances are not explained - as saying the camp was empty when rebels arrived, but that fleeing refugees were pursued for four miles to the town of Lubutu "where we were stopped". The refugee alledged "more than 100" were then killed. There was no sign of the bodies of 25,000 refugees the Zairean government says were killed when the ADFL took the camp last Saturday, report AP, and "no stench of death".

* The outgoing UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, Jose Ayala Lasso, appealed to donors on Thursday to fund the deployment of observers to eastern Zaire to investigate reports of alleged massacres of Rwandan refugees by rebels. In a United Nations statement Lasso said he was deeply concerned by reports from human rights groups alleging the existence of mass graves in east Zaire, near former refugee camps for Rwandans and Burundians. Lasso has asked the UN's Special Human Rights Investigator for Zaire, Roberto Garreton, to investigate the massacre allegations.

* The Kenyan government will host a summit on the conflict on eastern Zaire, on March 19, but will not invite rebel leader Laurent-Desire Kabila, the Minstry of Foreign Affairs said yesterday. Spokesman David Kikaya told Reuters that the purpose of the summit was to "advance the search for peace and a lasting solution". He said Kabila had not been invited because it was a head of state summit. Zairean President Mobutu Sese Seko has been invited to attend, with President Mandela and five other heads of state.

Reuters says that Kabila's search for international recognition was " crowned in Johannesburg on February 29 when he had an hour of talks with Mandela", Africa's most respected statesman. On Thursday, President Moi was reported in the local press as expressing concern "over the sincerity of leaders involved in the Great Lakes region conflict talks". He said he would make his position clear at a regional meeting on March 19. Moi's announcement of the March 19 summit is seen to be an attempt to regain the diplomatic initiative in the eastern Zaire crisis.

* French Foreign Minister Herve de Charette on Thursday accused Uganda of supporting Zairean rebels. The Foreign Minister indicated that France would not intervene alone in Zaire, but feels that the key to halting the conflict may lie with the US which has close ties with Uganda and Rwanda. French analysts said the government believed the United States was trying to edge it out of the last region where France still wielded influence from a colonial past, reports Reuters.

* Former Tanzanian president Julius Nyerere says Zaire and its people should be looking to life beyond their sick president Mobutu Sese Seko, saying "the poor man is going". He said that the days of the "big man" in African politics were over. He was giving his views in a television interview, while attending celebrations in Accra, marking 40 years of Ghana's independence.

* Martin Griffiths, Regional Humanitarian Coordinator for the Great Lakes region has said the policy of regroupment in Burundi is one of "deep concern to which the international community should be fundamentally opposed". Regroupment represents a military strategy by the Burundian authorities against rebel insurgency, and will affect up to 500,000 civilians, according to the authorities. 200,000 people are in camps in provinces where there is conflict. Griffiths reported seeing degrees of malnutrition in children he described as "disgraceful".

The policy is not based on voluntary movement by the regrouped, as those who do not comply may be considered as rebels or supporters of rebels. The Burundian authorities, however, say it is voluntary and temporary measure, and that the security of people cannot be otherwise assured by the State in areas of conflict. The authorities say most of the camps are expected to be closed by June, and have requested humanitarian assistance. Griffiths said humanitarian agencies "face the dilema of how to meet the needs of those in the camp without having the effect of encouraging or supporting the military policy". While donors and agencies agree that the policy is to be deplored, there are differing opinions on how to meet the humanitarian needs.

Today, Griffiths called on behalf of aid agencies to exempt humanitarian assistance from sanctions imposed on Burundi by its neighbouring states. Asking that regional and local sanctions committees act expediently on UN requests for fuel and assistance, Griffiths said the supplies "are indispensable simply to continue delivering aid". Despite requests made by the UN on 18 November, no fuel has yet reached agencies in Burundi. A press statement issued by the Regional Humanitarian Coordinator has been circulated through IRIN today.

* Burundi's Radio Umwizero (Radio Hope), which broadcasts a message of ethnic tolerance and reconciliation, has been threatened by extremists. Pierre Pradier, general secretary of the Paris-based Association for Humanitarian Action, said Radio Umwizero had been told to sack the radio's franchise holder for his alleged sympathies with Hutu rebels. The radio station employs about 20 local journalists, and is funded by the European Union. There is a proposal by UNESCO to create a Great Lakes regional radio.

* UNICEF Director Carol Bellamy yesterday condemned the abduction of up to 10,000 children by the Lords Resistance Army in northern Uganda, and called for their immediate release. In a statement issued from New York, Bellamy said that captives were often tortured, and those caught trying escape were killed. Girls are sexually abused by soldiers and are given as "wives" in lieu of other forms of payment. The statement called for concerted international pressure, and said the problem was "neither to big nor too complex to solve".

* Radio Rwanda said yesterday more than 50 people, alledgedly implicated in the murder of five UN Human Rights field officers, had surrendered to the authorities in southwest Rwanda. It said Gahutu - said to have masterminded the murders - and his accomplices were an important factor in insecurity in Bugumya sub-prefecture and Cyangugu Prefecture. They operated from the Nyungwe forest and retreating to Burundi to reorganise. Those who had surrendered had also handed over military equipment.

* The International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda agreed on Thursday to take steps to locate and protect defence witnesses thought to have fled the Tingi- Tingi camps in eastern Zaire last week. The decision follows a request by the lawyer of Georges Rutaganda, former Interahamwe leader, to get "special protection" for 16 defence witnesses. Tirbunal president Laity Kama ordered the court clerk to seek the help of the countries and humanitarian organisations concerned, notably UNHCR, to track down and protect the witnesses. The decision was broadcast by independent Agatashya radio in Arusha, Tanzania, where the Tribunal sits.

* Ethiopia - which has suffered major famines for decades - is for the first time exporting maize for relief purposes. A convoy of 32 lorries carrying 1,246 metric tons has been purchased by the World Food Programme to feed about 40,000 people in Kenya for one month. The majority of relief food under WFP's drought operation for Kenya will go to an estimated 207,000 people in drought-stricken areas of Garissa, Mandera, Wajir, Isiolo and Marsabit in North Eastern and Eastern Provinces.

Nairobi, 7 March 1997, 18:40 GMT

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. UN DHA IRIN Tel: +254 2 622123 Fax: +254 2 622129 e-mail: irin@dha.unon.org for more information. If you re-print, copy, archive or re-post this item, please retain this credit and disclaimer.)


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English
