227 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 10, 1997


Sudan;
Appeal for Sudanes Detainees


BYLINE: The World Organisation Against Torture (Geneva)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 814 words


 

Geneva - Case SDN 050297.1 Follow-up of case SDN 050297

The International Secretariat of OMCT has received new information on the following situation in Sudan.

Brief reminder of the situation: The Sudanese Victims of Torture Group, a member of the network, informed the International Secretariat of the arrests, detentions and fear of torture of sixty-one people in and around Khartoum at the end of January and the beginning of February. The whereabouts of the sixty-one people was unknown. 

New information: According to new information received from the Sudanese Victims of Torture Group, Mohmed Babiker Mukhtar and Dr Mohmed Suliman were released on 21 February.

Case SDN 220197.2 Follow-up of case SDN 220197 and Case SDN 220197.1

The International Secretariat of OMCT has also been informed of the release of, Abdella Malik one of the forty-eight detainees on whose behalf we requested your intervention.

Brief reminder of the situation: The Sudanese Victims of Torture Group, a member of the network, expressed its grave concern over a wave of arrests made within the month of January. Between 7 and 13 January 1997, forty-eight people were arrested by the authorities in Khartoum and were being held without charge. In several cases, families had not been informed of the whereabouts of the detained. On 20 January 1997 Dr. Nageeb Nagmadin Hassan El Toum, one of the arrested persons was moved from an unknown detention centre to the ghost house at Kober Prison.

New information: According to new information received from the Sudanese Victims of Torture Group, Abdella Malik, one of the forty-eight people arrested, was released on 21 February.

Action requested : Please contact the Sudanese authorities urging them to:

i. take immediate measures to guarantee the physical and psychological integrity of all people still detained and immediate locate their whereabouts if still unknown;

ii. immediately release all the detainees if they are being detained without valid charge or, if such charges exist, to bring them before a competent and impartial tribunal and guarantee their procedural rights at all times;

iii. open a full impartial inquiry into the all the events and allegations of violations of fundamental rights, including acts of presumed torture, identify all those responsible and bring them to trial and apply the penal, civil and /or administrative sanctions provided by legislation;

iv. guarantee in all circumstances respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms in accordance with national laws and international standards.

Addresses: His Excellency Lieutenant General Omar Hassan al-Bashir, President of the Republic of Sudan, People's Palace, PO Box Khartoum, Sudan. Telex : 22385 PEPLC SD or 22411 KAID SD - Fax : +249 11 71 724

Brigadier Bakri Hassan Salih, Minister of Interior, People's Palace, PO Box 281, Khartoum, Sudan. Telex : 22842 WZARA SD or 22604 IPOL SD - Fax : +249 11 71724 / 76554 / 77900 / 73946 / 70186

Mr. Abdel Basset Sabdrat, Minister of Justice and attorney-General, Ministry of Justice, Khartoum, Sudan. Telex : 22459 KHRJA SD (via Ministry of Foreign Affairs) - Fax : +249 1174 063

Mr. Ali Osman Mohamad Taha, Minister of Foreign Affairs, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, PO Box 873, Khartoum, Sudan. Telex : 22459 KHRJA SD or 22461 KHRJA SD - Fax : +249 11 74 063 The Diplomatic Representatives of Sudan in your country.

Geneva, 10 March 1997

Kindly inform us of any action undertaken quoting the exact number of this appeal in your reply.

For further information, contact Ben Schonveld, Projects Manager OMCT-SOS- Torture Fax 4122 733 1051 Ph 4122 733 3140. OMCT is l'Organisation Mondiale contre la Torture / The World Organisation Against Torture. OMCT@IPROLINK.CH http://www.omct.org/


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


228 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 10, 1997


East Africa;
Emergency Update No. 123 on the Great Lakes (03/10)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1360 words


 

Nairobi - The leader of the rebel group, the Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire (ADFL), Laurent-Desire Kabila, said on Saturday that he was ready to negotiate a ceasefire along the lines of the proposed UN peace plan, reports AFP, but he refused to stop his westward push on Kisangani.

Kabila told reporters at the weekend that several columns of rebel troops had surrounded Kisangani and that they were meeting fierce resistence, mainly from ex-FAR who are fighting alongside Zairean government troops. Until Saturday, Kabila had refused to discuss a ceasefire. His about-face came after the UN Security Council called on Friday for the rebels to "declare publicly" their acceptance of a truce. The Government of Zaire accepted the peace plan on Wednesday and has called for international observers to be deployed immediately to monitor the withdrawal of foreign troops. The five point plan provides for an immediate ceasefire, the withdrawal of foreign troops and mercenaries, negotations, elections and the protection of refugees. 

* An inter-agency emergency relief programme for Tingi-Tingi camp and Amisi in eastern Zaire is expected to start within the next few days. A UN-NGO inter-agency mission which flew into Tingi-Tingi yesterday reports that the condition of the refugees is extremely poor and that many would probably die within days. Some 600 - 1,000 refugees were seen in Tingi-Tingi and others are trickling in from the surrounding forest. Many had fled the camp on 1 and 2 March just before it was taken by the ADFL. The refugees claim that there are "thousands more refugees" in the forest and that thousands had fled eastwards on the Walikale road. Sources said that the ADLF has given assurances that aid workers can return and assist the refugees.

The mission, led by UNHCR and accompanied by the UN Regional Humanitarian Coordinator, Martin Griffiths, also overflew Amisi and observed some 250 refugees. During the overflight of parts of the road between Walikale and Lubutu, no other significant numbers of people were seen. Filippo Grandi, UNHCR Head of Sub-Office and Field Coordinator for the region - Zone 2 said: " Many of the refugees we saw were elderly or women and children. Most are sick or wounded. All of them are exhausted and want to go home quickly". In addition to emergency assistance, plans are being put in place with the ADLF to reopen road access between Tingi-Tingi and Bukavu and to establish transit centres to facilitate repatriation to Rwanda. Some of the weakest will be flown back to Rwanda. This was the first time rebels have allowed humanitarian officials to approach the front-line to look for refugees. Tingi- Tingi camp housed between 160,000 - 170,000 refugees before being overrun by rebels ten days ago.

* Britain and the United States have effectively "killed off" proposals for a multi-national force to protect refugees in eastern Zaire, reports AFP. UN Secretary-General Kofi Anann had tried to resurrect the proposal after talks in Paris with French leaders, but both the US and British Governments have rejected it.

* The World Food Programme delivered on Saturday some 65 tonnes of food for thousands of Rwandan refugees who have arrived in the town of Ubundu from Tingi-Tingi camp. The food was transported by train from Kisangani. Relief workers who tried to distribute the food were "overwhelmed", AFP reported. Another 120 tonnes of food was expected to be dispatched today. An airlift of high protein biscuits was also planned but the plane was unable to take off because of heavy rain. As many as 20,000 had arrived in the town as of Sunday and a further 20,000 were expected today. Refugees in Ubundu said that many thousands of refugees were fleeing 140 kilometers west of Ubundu to Opala - a perilous journey that covers swampy terrain and dense forest.

* The French Secretary of State for emergency humanitarian affairs, Xavier Emmanuelli visited Ubundu on Sunday and said that the refugees faced death through starvation, illness, or at the hands of rebels if they did not receive aid urgently. Emmanuelli was due to leave for Kinshasa for a meeting with the Zairean Government later today. At the weekend acommunique from the French Foreign Ministry called on "all those who have influence over" the rebels to use it to obtain an end to the fighting.

* According to the Daily Nation newspaper, Uganda claims that it has driven rebels of the Lord's Resistence Army (LRA) back to Sudan but says that it continues to be on the alert against counter-attacks. Uganda's Minister of State for Defence said that Uganda believed that the rebels "would be rearmed by their Sudanese backers", but heavy deployment of government troops in the north of the country would counter any attacks.

* HIV infection is declining in parts of Uganda. A report, compiled by the Ministry of Health's STD/AIDS Control Programme in October, but only recently released, says that researchers monitoring infection amongst pregnant women at six hospitals between 1991 and 1995 report that in two hospitals the average rates dropped from 27.8% and 22% in 1991-1992 to 16.8% and 13% in 1993-1995 respectively. Only at one hospital was the decrease insignificant. In spite of the decrease, overall, statistics for Uganda and Africa remain grim. WHO says that there are about 14 million people with HIV in Africa, some 63% of all cases worldwide. It is estimated that there are 1.5 million infected Ugandans. In addition, while infection rates have dropped in urban areas, they are increasing in villages, particularly in areas plagued by civil war.

* The recent decision by Brussels to halt the construction of a bullet factory in Kenya arose from differences with the Kenyan government over an end-user agreement for munitions, reports the "East African". The decision to suspend the US$ 26.7 million project - partly financed by a Belgium firm - followed concerns that bullets from the factory could reach the Great Lakes region.

* Rwanda's national assembly has elected Joseph Sebarenze of the Liberal Party as speaker to replace Juvenal Nkusi, a Social Democrat who was ousted on 10 February. Jacqueline Muhongayire from the Social Democrat Party was elected deputy speaker. Nkusi was voted out of office when he followed President Pasteur Bizimungu in refusing to sign a bill which would allow the national assembly to exert control over the government.

* Rinderpest, a highly infectious cattle disease, is threatening livestock and wildlife in northern Tanzania, the official Shihata news agency reported on Sunday. The reports says that Tanzania needs US$ 3 million to fight the epidemic. A vaccination campaign is already underway.

Nairobi, 10 March 1997, 19:09 GMT

229 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 10, 1997


Business and Finance;
Micro businesses seek JSE listing in bid for capital boost


BYLINE: Wilhelm Snyman, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

Cape Town - Backed by leading financial institutions, a new micro-business support corporation is to seek a listing on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange.

The Micro Business Development Corporation has been set up as a public company to provide working capital for small entrepreneurs while at the same time providing investors with a sound investment and market-related profits. 

Chairman Tony Davenport said at the weekend this was the first institution of its kind in South Africa.

"Hitherto South Africa has largely ignored the micro-enterprise sector of the economy, but it is now being realised that self-employment in this sector is the only hope for millions of people who cannot find jobs in the formal sector.

"In the past, micro-enterprise development has been regarded as a handout affair, reliant on donor-funding.

"But the time has come for this sector of the economy to expand on a sound business basis - not looking for charity, but instead offering an excellent investment opportunity," he said.

Mr Davenport said experience over several years had shown that large numbers of people were willing and able to be self-employed in micro- enterprises if they had training and access to capital.

"The success of the so-called township MBA programme and the Start-Up Fund has proved this." The corporation is being advised by Boland Financial Services.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


230 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 10, 1997


South Africa;
The return of South African self-belief (Editorial)


BYLINE: Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

Cape Town - A public mood swing from the paralysis of foreboding to joyous optimism is a wonderful thing to behold; a fragile, transient thing too, but a powerful gift to be treasured and used.

We have experienced many such moments in our tumultuous recent past - the pre-election peace day, the election itself, the inauguration, the unlikely sporting triumphs - and this weekend it was the turn of Cape Town to give the lead to the entire country.

On this Monday morning in the late summer of 1997 it is not our problems which are uppermost in the minds of the people of our region, it is our opportunities. 

The full meaning of Cape Town's shortlisting for the Olympic Games of 2004 is beginning to sink in. More than anything else, that meaning is this: the bitter argument over whether we are capable of hosting the Games is over. Cold-eyed experts from other shores have declared that we are and they cannot afford to lie.

The question of the next six months is whether we really want to host them and, as a corollary, whether we deserve them. The auguries were marvellous on Friday as the signs of resurgent South African self-belief burst loudly to the surface. It is true: the mood is swinging.

That the Cape Argus/Pick 'n Pay Cycle Tour took place with spectacular success and in blessed weather directly after the outpouring of delight over the Lausanne announcement was a serendipitous bonus. A wonderfully-organised event with a unique South African flavour - it was a microcosm of the first African Games, and make no mistake that the people felt it.

The Cape Argus stands proud of its longstanding belief in our people's ability to take on the world, even when that view was out of kilter with the general mood. And we hand out some mighty claps on the back for this battle won in preparation for the war. Congratulations to Chris Ball and his team for their effort and forebearance. To the government and sporting figures who supported the Bid so passionately and professionally. And, let us never forget, to Raymond Ackerman the dreamer. Our team starts playing the real Game on a happy high.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


231 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 10, 1997


South Africa;
Josephine Cooke: woman on a mission for the women of the world


BYLINE: Jenny Viall, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 947 words


 

Cape Town - At the age of 65 Josephine Cooke is not about to step into retirement. There's just too much to do.

Right now she's president of a mortgage services company, she's president of Zonta (a women's service organisation with 35 000 members in 68 countries), she sits on the Sex Equity Commission in Los Angeles and sings soprano in her church choir (when at home). This woman is busy. And then there are the " personal missions" she still has to tackle, she says. 

One of these is to get the medical world to take notice of the fact that's she alive. Ms Cooke has sickle cell anaemia, and according to medical science she should be dead at her age. "I was sickly all my life," she says, "I didn't make 100 pounds, and I thought pain was a way of life.

"Doctors gave me blood transfusions and told me not to fly above a certain height. Then a doctor put me on sodium bicarbonate tablets.

"Its a rarity to be 65, and healthy, with sickle cell anaemia. And now I fly halfway around the world! I've tried to get the medical community to listen to me, they just say take it if you want to."

But she's determined not to give up, and has found a doctor willing to do tests on her. "I think I have a mission. That's why I'm still here," she says.

Ms Cooke is in Cape Town to charter the first Zonta club in South Africa. That's her privilege as president. It's also given her a chance to see first- hand the educational projects Zonta supports through its two-year South African girls education programme.

Zonta's mission is to advance the position of women and since its establishment in 1919 its objectives have stayed much the same. There's been some modernising but no compromising, says Ms Cooke.

How far has Zonta's mission been realised?

"I think we've made much progress around the world, in some countries more than others. We have much, much more to do. In my lifetime we've seen major improvements for women. But there are always new walls and ceilings being built.

"We have to have our minds open, and be flexible. For instance, in Holland there have been 20 incidents in the last year of fathers killing their children because they couldn't get custody. That's a new issue in the 90s."

Ms Cooke defends charges of Zonta being an elitist organisation of executive and professional women in business. "It's not," she says. "Our aims are lofty. But our foremothers in 1919 set the tone and we see no reason to change it. If we're going to get something done this is the expertise we need to bring women who are not yet professionals into the field.

"The Zonta net draws in high school girls and members from other areas, such as people active in their community, volunteers and home makers. Visiting schools in South Africa has been an eye opener, says Ms Cooke. Zonta International has pledged $35 000 (R157 000) to improve education in South Africa for the girl child working in partnership with Unicef.

"Of course boys will also benefit. It's really about children. I was very touched, very moved with what I saw and the extent of support needed. And that's more than academic needs, more than curricula needs. There are socio- economic problems that are a deterrent to a good education.

"I left knowing what a tremendous job we have."

Zonta International recognises the enormous problem of violence against women and has started an ongoing, self-administered project to tackle the problem. The first stage of the programme will be a resource centre.

"We want to build a database and organise around the world, exchange information and ideas, have material available. We want to establish an advisory council, look for those people committed to removing this stigma.

"We fully understand that a lot of this violence is considered to be cultural, and we understand you can't go out and fight that with a stick."

Ms Cooke started her working life teaching functionally illiterate adults. In the late 40s, teaching and nursing were the options for black women.

Ill health prevented her from becoming a nurse, so teaching it was until she left Pennsylvania for Los Angeles and found a job in the mortgage banking world.

She has no hesitation in saying that affirmative action got her where she is today. "When I moved I needed a job. In the late 60s affirmative action was introduced. I was in the right place at the right time and I got a job. I applied myself and in two years was vice-president."

Affirmative action is a good thing, she believes. "Maybe we have to change the name of affirmative action, the perception of it. It must continue as it offers an opportunity to open doors to people who have been deprived previously. But once in the door there should be the requirement to perform."

That's a requirement Josie Cooke has more than fulfilled.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


232 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 10, 1997


Sports - General;
Cape Town: On our bike for the games


BYLINE: Ashley Smith, Staff Reporter, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 747 words


 

Cape Town - The hugely successful 20th Cape Argus/Pick 'n Pay Cycle Tour on Sunday showed that Cape Town had the capacity to host major events, said Olympic 2004 bid chief Chris Ball.

About 28 000 starters made it the biggest sporting event of of its kind in the world, just two days after the shortlisting of Cape Town, Rome, Athens, Buenos Aires and Stockholm as potential host cities.

Mr Ball, who flew back from Lausanne to be at the finish, said it was such events as the cycle tour that set Cape Town apart from the other shortlisted cities.

The city's ability to organise huge sporting events would play a key role in the final presentation to the International Olympic Committee in September, he said. 

Straight after his arrival from Switzerland, Mr Ball flew from Cape Town International Airport by helicopter to address the thousands assembled for the tour awards ceremony in Camps Bay.

"Cape Town's inclusion on the Olympic host city shortlist for 2004 is a confirmation that the IOC believes the Mother City can successfully host the greatest sporting spectacle in the world," he said.

The bid company was entering a new phase of its campaign to market the city as the 2004 venue. "The IOC has accepted our plans fully and they certainly would not have put us on the shortlist had they not believed we could host the Olympics, but now the hard work really begins."

He said there had never been a doubt in his mind that Cape Town would be on the shortlist. "It is now up to us to attract more visitors to the city so they can fall in love with it. This is integral to the city's chances of securing the bid."

After the trophies were handed to the tour winners, Mr Ball congratulated the organisers, sponsors and especially the volunteers, whom he called "the silent army".

The tour would be among events featured in the bid company's final presentation to the IOC on September 5, he said.

Metropolitan mayor William Bantom, who also returned from Lausanne yesterday, said he was "extremely excited and relieved" at Cape Town's shortlisting. "As you can imagine ,it was a very tense time while we were in Lausanne but now we realise that the hard work begins.

"Everyone is talking about the chances of Rome and Athens being very good compared to Cape Town.

"I'm of the opinion we are all in the starting-blocks now.

"I believe Cape Town has a very good chance of convincing the IOC to vote for us if you look at what we have got, in the physical sense, the beauty of the city, and the capability of our city to deliver.

"Politically I'm convinced we are in a very good position to persuade the IOC members from Africa they need to vote for Cape Town and Africa."

The success of the cycle tour demonstrated to the world that the people of Cape Town were capable of staging world events, he said.

Michael Morris reports that the bid company went into a strategy meeting first thing today to begin planning the nitty-gritty of the crucial lobbying phase that will continue until September.

The team, some of whose members returned yesterday from Lausanne, is riding a wave of optimism after Cape Town's shortlist selection but is mindful that a huge effort will be required to convince the IOC.

A key target will be raising funds at home for an extensive showcasing programme - the team is hoping to get all 108 voting IOC members to visit the city in the next six months to convince them of Cape Town's capacity to stage the Games.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


233 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 10, 1997


United States and Africa;
U.S. Great Lakes Situation Report No. 25


BYLINE: U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 4440 words


 

Washington DC - U.S. Agency For International Development, Bureau for Humanitarian Response (BHR), Office of U.S. Foreign Disaster Assistance (OFDA) . GREAT LAKES - Complex Emergency Situation Report No. 25 Fiscal Year (FY) 1997, March 7, 1997.

Overview

The Banyamulenge and the Banyarwanda people, who are Tutsi of Rwandan origin, settled in the Mulenge hills of South Kivu, Zaire, and the Masisi region of North Kivu, Zaire, more than 200 years ago. Sporadic ethnic violence in the Masisi region has occurred since 1959, but it again escalated in the fall of 1995 as the former Rwandan army (the ex-FAR) and the Rwandan Hutu militia (the Interahamwe) targeted the Banyarwanda in an apparent attempt to create an area of Hutu control.

In September 1996, the situation in the Uvira region of South Kivu began to resemble that of the Masisi region, as government-sanctioned harassment of Banyamulenge Tutsis intensified. On October 14, fighting broke out between the Banyamulenge rebels and the Zairian Army (FAZ) near Runingo refugee camp, in South Kivu, forcing the roughly 220,000 refugees to flee. 

The Banyamulenge joined forces with other Zairian rebels to form the Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire (Alliance), led by Laurent Kabila. The fighting spread, moving up the eastern border of Zaire from Uvira to Bukavu, and south from Rutshuru (North Kivu) to Goma. As a result of shelling October 26 and November 1, hundreds of thousands of refugees from Kibumba, Katale, and Kahindo camps, near Goma, fled south to Mugunga camp. After Hutu attacks from Mugunga camp on Goma town, the Alliance counter-attacked from the east on November 14, forcing the ex-FAR and Interahamwe to retreat west and compelling hundreds of thousands of refugees to return to Rwanda, while others fled north and west into Zaire.

During the last three months, the Alliance has continued its advances in Eastern Zaire, most recently capturing the towns of Kindu and Manono in the south, and Lubutu and Tingi-Tingi camp in the north. It controls an area about 1,280 km long, and has driven as deep as 400 km westward into Zaire.

USG Humanitarian Assistance for Fiscal Year (FY) 1997 (to date): $125,348, 351

Numbers Affected Rwandan refugees: From November through December 1996, 1, 033,405 Rwandan refugees returned from Eastern Zaire and Tanzania to Rwanda, according to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR). Another 232,000 Rwandans reportedly have returned from Eastern Zaire and Tanzania this year. The UNHCR claims there are up to 376,590 Rwandans stranded in Eastern Zaire, including at least 160,000 who fled last weekend from Tingi-Tingi to Ubundu, 150 km south of Kisangani, and towards Kisangani. There are about 125,000 others dispersed in smaller groups in South Kivu and Maniema provinces, including 40,000 refugees who abandoned Shabunda before it was overrun by the Alliance on February 5.

U.N. officials reported that 25,000 of the Shabunda refugees, some Burundian, fled to Kalima, 145 kmeast of Kindu, and continued west shortly before Kalima fell tothe Alliance on February 23.

The whereabouts of the other 5,000 is unknown.

About 20,000 refugees and internally displacedpersons (IDPs) have gathered in Punia, Maniema province,and more refugees are reportedly headed there from Kalima.

Burundian refugees: Of the 143,000 Burundian refugees originallyin the Uvira area, some 64,000 refugees have returned to Burundi and about 13,500 have arrived in Tanzania.

The UNHCR states that 39,675 refugees are missing, with many believed to between Fizi and Kalemie, in Zaire. There are 272,500 Burundian refugees in Tanzania, and 5,100 in Rwanda. A small number of Burundians are returning daily to Burundi from the Ngara camps in Tanzania.

Zairian refugees and internally displaced: 77,650 Zairians have fled to Tanzania, and in Rwanda there are 13,959 Zairians whofled the Masisi region last year.

About 11,000 Zairians are reported in Uganda, about 4,000 fewer than in the last week of February, the UNHCR reported.

Before Kindu fell to the Alliance, there were about 19,000 IDPs in Kindu and more than 12,000 IDPs in Kisangani.

To date, about 7,500 Zairian refugees have fled to Zambia, most of them arriving in Mpulungu. The Government of Sudan has appealed for UNHCR aid to assist the 10,000 Zairian refugees it reports are in the Bazi area of Western Equatoria. The number of displaced Zairians grows as theAlliance continues its advances and the FAZ retreats, looting everything in its path. Current Situation The Alliance overran the Tingi-Tingi camps on March 1, causing the roughly 160,000 refugees to abandon the area before the rebels arrived.

On March 4, a news report quoted local witnesses who claimed that some of the Tingi-Tingi refugees had walked to the Ubundu region, about 150 km south of Kisangani, while others were seen walking toward Kisangani, 200 km northwest of Tingi- Tingi. On March 2, Alliance leader Laurent Kabila appealed to the U.N. to help the Tingi-Tingi refugees. In Maniema province, the Alliance flew journalists to Kindu, whichit seized on February 28, to prove its control of the city.

On March 5, the Alliance rejected calls for a ceasefire until theGovernment of Zaire (GOZ) agreed to face-to-face negotiations. Earlier that day, the GOZ requested the urgent implementation ofaU.N. peace plan, endorsed by the Security Council on February 18. It calls for an immediate end to hostilities; the withdrawal of all external forces, including mercenaries; the reaffirmation of respect for the national sovereignty and territorial integrity of Zaire and other states of the region; protection and security of all refugees and displaced persons, and the facilitation of access for humanitarian assistance; the rapid settlement of the crisis through dialogue and elections; and the convening of an international conference on peace, security, and development in the region.

The resolution follows a plan advanced by Mohammed Sahnoun, the joint U.N. - Organizationof African States (OAU) special representative for the Great Lakes, and a Security Council statement made on February 7. The U.N. evacuated its 19 workers from Kisangani to Kinshasa on March 1. They were among 57 expatriates, including NGO workers, who were flown to Kinshasa. The GOZ subsequently expelled nine of the 19 U.N. workers, after accusing the U.N. of failing to notify the GOZ of its intention to relocate staff. News reports on March 6 told of hundreds of residents trying to flee Kisangani by boat.

In South Africa, indirect "proximity" talks are in recess, with representatives of the Alliance and the GOZ in consultation with their respective leaders in Zaire. The talks began on February 25, when Kabila met with President Nelson Mandela. There have been no reported meetings between Alliance and GOZ representatives. U.N. - OAU special representative Sahnoun was also in South Africa for discussions with the warring parties.

In Rwanda, ethnic violence continues. The French news service AFP, quoting U.N. and local officials, reported that 20 people died during the weekend of March 1-2. The first attack occurred in Rushashi commune, Kigali Rurale prefecture. Humanitarian workers said 10 people died and 21 were wounded. The second attack took place on March 2 or 3 in Ruhengeri prefecture, according to humanitarian workers. Although Radio Rwanda did not report the attacks, it did broadcast death noticesof the victims.

On February 22, unknown gunmen in Kibungo prefecture killed 21 people, including 16 children. All were Hutu. On February 9, eight Rwandan civilians were killed and three were wounded when suspected ex-FAR/Interahamwe gunmen attacked a convoy of minibuses about 20 km from Kigali. The victims were all Tutsi, their Hutu companions having been left alone by the attackers. A report released by the U.N. Human Rights Field Operation in Rwanda (HRFOR) states that human rights has "drastically deteriorated" since the new year. In January, HRFOR received reports of at least 424 killings in 55 incidents, which was the highest number of killings since early 1996. In January,311 of the 424 killings occurred in the four prefectures bordering Zaire; 228 were in Ruhengeri prefecture alone. The 424 victims included 163 whose deaths were attributed to the GOR, including RPA troops, and 42 to the ex- FAR/Interahamwe. HRFOR reports that insecurity has forced it drastically to curtail its monitoring work.

The killing of foreign humanitarian workers in the past two months in Rwanda has led to the curtailment of most reliefactivities and human rights monitoring. The most recent killings of foreigners occurred on February 4, when two expatriate human rights monitors and three Rwandans working for HRFOR were shot in Karengera commune, Cyangugu prefecture. On February 2, an unidentified assailant shot and killed a Canadian Catholic priest as he was serving communion in Kampanga parish, Kinigi commune, 20 km north of Ruhengeri town. On January 18 in Ruhengeri town, about 100 km northwest of Kigali, three Spaniards were killed and an American was seriouslywounded by gunmen. The Spaniards worked for Medicos del Mundo (MDM) and the American was with Doctors of the World, an affiliate of MDM and operating through a grant funded by USAID/BHR/OFDA. The RPA stated that the killers belonged to the ex- FAR/Interahamwe.

On February 19, the International Committee of the Red Cross(ICRC) stated that it would base most of its 50 remainingdelegates in Kigali and maintain limited operations throughout the country, except for Ruhengeri, where ICRC has suspended its operations. The International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC) has transferred 25 delegates to Kenya, leaving a staff of six in Kigali. In a press conference on February 8, Vice- President Paul Kagame described the GOR's control of the security situation as "sufficient," though he added it would take time before conditions returned to normal. On February 20, Foreign Minister Anastase Gasana announced to foreign diplomats in Kigali the GOR's plan to "re- educate" 5, 000 ex-FAR returnees.

Political/Military Situation

The GOZ's call on March 5 for the implementation of the U.N.peaceplan for Zaire followed an announcement in Paris by Zairian Foreign Minister Gerard Kamanda wa Kamanda that PresidentMobutu Sese Seko had accepted the plan. Mobutu has beenin France since February 21. The announcement followed recent Alliance advances, which included Kindu on February 28, and Lubutu and the Tingi-Tingi camp on March 1.

The Alliance victories came after little or no fighting by the FAZ. Kindu hasa major airport and is a railhead for Shaba province. On February 26, the U.N. fired the chief administrator and deputyprosecutor of the International Criminal Tribunal on Rwanda (ICTR) in Arusha, Tanzania, after the U.N. Inspector General reported waste and mismanagement.

To date, the ICTR has indicted 21 people, of whom 13 are in custody. Among those indicted are Anatole Nsengiyumva and Ferdinand Nahimana, who havepleaded innocent to charges that they participated in planning the 1994 genocide. Nsengiyumva, then an officer in the FAR, allegedly ordered participants at a meeting to murder Tutsis. Nahimana is the former director of Radio des Milles Collines, which urged the population to kill. In the genocide trials in Kigali, Froduald Karamira was sentenced to death on February 14 for helping to plan and undertake the genocide in 1994. He appealed the verdict. On February 18, a court in Gikongoro handed down the first acquittal of a genocide suspect on trial in Rwanda, and convicted six others to life imprisonment.

In Burundi on February 24, gunmen killed seven people and wounded an infant in an attack in Kamenge, an outlying district of Bujumbura. Apparently, the killings were committed as a deterrent to Burundians who wanted to return to Kamenge, which has been largely destroyed.

Relief Efforts Zaire: To date there are no known large concentrations of refugeesin Eastern Zaire. The 40,000 refugees who walked fromAmisi to Tingi- Tingi on February 7 are among the 160,000 Rwandan refugees who are proceeding either to Ubundu or Kisangani. A World Food Program (WFP) plane flew over the Ubundu region on March 6, and reported seeing groups of refugees. The WFP also reported that the landing strip in Ubundu cannot accept a DC-3. Before evacuating to Kinshasa, WFP workers left one week's worth of food stocks in Kisangani and Tingi-Tingi.

UNICEF officials expressed great concern about the 600 children who were on therapeutic feeding and the 2,500 children who were onsupplementary feeding in the Tingi-Tingi camps before the refugees abandoned the camps last week. News pictures of refugees walking from Tingi-Tingi to Kisangani showed them in poor condition.

A BHR/OFDA assessment team, returning from Kinshasa on February 26, reported that the relief effort out of Kisangani had been hampered by expense, danger, and logistical difficulties. With occasional exceptions, the Tingi- Tingi refugees received less than a fifth of the 80 MT of food needed to meet their daily needs. The location of approximately 25,000 Rwandan and Burundian refugees who were fleeing toward Kindu last week is also unknown.

Before Kindu fell on February 28, the refugees were known to be walking from Kalima southwest toward Kindu. In Punia, 170 km south of Tingi-Tingi, the World Food Program(WFP) flew in emergency food supplies on February 25. About 4,000 Rwandan refugees, all malnourished, arrived there two weeks ago. TheCatholic NGO Caritas sent workers there on March 2, and the WFP flew in 9 tons of food.

The Kisangani transit center houses 2,500 IDPs, with 3,000 hoping to gain entry, the BHR/OFDA assessment team reported on February 20. Another 12,000 IDPs are dispersed throughout the city. After a request from the Alliance, the UNHCR, the International Rescue Committee (IRC), Save the Children Fund (SCF/UK), ICRC, Oxfam, and CARE sent a convoy to find refugees in Kingulube, south of Shabunda. The team, amid logistical difficulties, returned to Bukavu on February 20, transporting 40 vulnerable refugees to Rwanda. Three died en route. The relief committee will try to establish way stations to assist refugees in reachingRwanda, but poor road conditions will require all supplies to be portaged. On February 10, the ICRC reopened its office in Uvira. The ICRC is also assisting IDPs in Kalemie, to the south.

Rwanda: The UNHCR reports that 1,300,582 refugees returned to Rwanda in 1996, and so far this year about 232,000 refugees have returned from Zaire and Tanzania. In contrast to the 16,971 refugees who returned to Rwanda from South Kivu between January 20 to 26, only 1,675 refugees returned between January 27 and February 2, the WFP reported. The reduction is widely believed to be related to the renewed fighting in Eastern Zaire.

Burundi: The Government of the Republic of Burundi (GRB) recently announced the establishment of regroupment camps in Bujumbura Rurale and Bururi provinces. The practice of regrouopment is already being enforced in the provinces of Karuzi, Kayanza, Cibitoke, Bubanza, and Muramvya. Local press reports state that military authorities have told Burundians living in particular areas to move to the regroupment sites. If the peasants do not move to the camps, the military will consider them rebels, and they could be killed.

The USAID/BHR/OFDA Emergency Disaster Relief Coordinator (EDRC) travelled on Highway One during February 12-13. The road links the capital to Kayanza province, which borders Rwanda. Although he saw some farmers at work, many fields appeared abandoned. He saw commercial and private traffic on the road, but fewer bicyclists transporting produce than in the past. There were signs of wanton destruction to buildings in Bugarama and Teza. In Kayanza, the EDRC visited three regroupment camps, two of them formed in January. Although the provincial governor told the EDRC that the camps were temporary, he did not say when the army would allow residents to move closer to their homes. At Buraniro camp, children appeared healthy and people were cultivating nearby fields. From February 3 to 9, the WFP distributed 1,234 MT of food to 98,173 people in Burundi. Most of the recipients have lived in regroupment camps since 1996. Kigoma port storage facilities are full; consequently, WFP truck convoys from Ngara, Tanzania, to Ngozi have risen from once to three times weekly.

Tanzania: The GOT has declared that those Rwandan refugees from the Tanzanian camps who did not repatriate, and who are now hiding, will be considered illegal aliens. In early February, the UNHCR began demolishing 47, 000 huts in five camps in Karagwe, where Rwandan refugees had stayed until last December. As of February 28, there were 353,582 refugees in Tanzania, of whom 77,650 were Zairian, and 272,500 were Burundian. In the Ngara camps, there are 105,000 refugees; of the total, 59,000 are in Lukole camp, with the remainder in the former Lumasi camp, now called Lukole C. A Tanzanian newspaper reported that 220 FAZ deserters who arrived in Kigoma in late February had robbed and beaten Tanzanians. The GOT is reportedly growing increasingly impatient with this group.

In the Kigoma region, there are 240,134 refugees: the Nduta camp has 15,614; Nyarugusu has 44,204 Zairians; Lugufu, 90 km east of Kigoma town, opened on February 15 and will have a capacity of 200,000; Muyovosi has 40,788 refugees; Mtabila has 27,319. As of February 28, there were 23,195 refugees in holding areas in Kigoma town. Ninety percent of them are Zairian. Tanzania receives about 1,000 refugees daily.

USG Assistance

On October 26, BHR/OFDA deployed a USAID/DART to Kigali, Rwanda, to conduct assessments, report on the situation, and provide funding to NGOs, U.N. agencies, and international organizations for programs to assist in repatriation efforts. USAID/DART completed operations on February 25. On November 7, 1996, U.S. Ambassador to Rwanda Robert Gribbin declared a disaster, noting that the refugee crisis in eastern Zaire posed a humanitarian emergency for Rwanda.

On November 12, U.S. Ambassador Daniel Simpson declared a disaster in Zaire as a result of the violent break-up of refugee camps in eastern Zaire.On November 18, the USG pledged $140 million in humanitarian and development assistance to address needs in the Great Lakes region. On November 25, Ambassador Morris Hughes declared a disaster in Burundi as a result of continuing civil strife. From February 12 to 26, BHR/OFDA deployed an assessment team to Zaire, to evaluate relief needs in the GOZ-controlled areas of Eastern Zaire. Although insecurity prevented the team from travelling outside Kinshasa, it gathered information by meeting daily with NGOs and U.N. agencies in the capital.

USAID FY 1997 Assistance to date:

BHR/OFDA Assistance Rwanda To date, BHR/OFDA funding has been obligated as follows:

Grant to Action Aid for shelter in Kibuye: $774,700

In FY 1997, BHR's Office of Food for Peace (BHR/FFP) has committed 96,000 MT of P.L. 480 emergency Title II commodities for WFP. These commodities, valued at $72,500,000, will assist refugees and displaced persons in Rwanda, Zaire, Burundi, Uganda, and Tanzania.

Africa News


March 10, 1997


Liberia;
March Briefing Paper on Liberia


BYLINE: African Faith and Justice Network (Washington, DC)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1734 words


 

Washington - This paper outlines major military, economic and political developments in the Liberian peace process and the march towards general and presidential elections in May this year. This briefing covers the period February 24 to March 4, 1997. JUSTICE AND PEACE COMMISSION National Catholic Secretariat, P. O. Box 103569 1000 Monrovia 10 Liberia, West Africa Ph. (231) 227657; 225930 Fax. (231) 227838; 226006, March 4, 1997

MILITARY SITUATION

Though it was said by the West African Peace keeping Force, ECOMOG, that the disarmament process had gained a 91.8% success, there are semblances of huge cache of arms being hidden in certain parts of the country. Recently, a huge quantity of arms were discovered in the Lofa Bridge area in Lofa County. They were hidden there by forces alleged to be of Alhadji Kromah's ULIMO-K. Since ECOMOG dug out and retrieved said arms little over a week ago, there have been no comment from ULIMO-K.

Capt. Andrew Paye, a former fighter of the defunct NPFL has alleged that the front is hiding huge quantities of arms in many parts of the country, especially in Bong and Nimba counties. Such arms, he says include assault riffles and calibres. Only the Press Secretary of former Councilman Charles Taylor, Reginald Goodridge has attempted to deny the allegation. 

Several arms and ammunition have been discovered in the Executive Mansion by ECOMOG. Disclosure has not been made yet as to which of the former factions did store said items at the Mansion.

About 27 fighters of ULIMO-J were rounded up by ECOMOG for being in possession of arms following the disarmament period. 17 of those rounded up were juveniles. They are currently detained at the Monrovia Central Prison in MONROVIA. All of them were severely flogged by ECOMOG, leaving deep scars and wounds on their bodies.

The Deputy Comptroller general of Liberia, Nathaniel Momo Mendemassa was on Saturday morning at 2:00 A.M. killed by armed robbers, numbering 10 at his home behind the T.B. Annex in Congo Town. He was shot twice in the thigh and abdomen. Two of the suspects have been arrested and the newly factional appointee to the Directorship of the Liberia National Police, Charles Deshield, has vowed to launch a massive and vigorous investigation into the murder of Mr. Mendemassa.

POLITICAL SITUATION:

The 28th of February set the pace for resignation of prominent government officials with an expressed commitment to contest the ensuing May 30 Presidential and General Elections. At the level of the State Council, three of the Councilmen have resigned and have nominated proxies as follows:

Charles Taylor -- Victoria Reffell

Alhadji Kromah -- Dr. Vamba Kanneh

Dr. George Boley -- Weade Kobbah-Wureh

Other resignations include Speaker Morris Dukuly, First Deputy Speaker Samuel Dokie and Second Deputy Speaker Assumana Kroma. Others include Associate Justice Laveli Supuwood and 21 TLA members. of the various appointments made thus far, only one person Vivienne Wureh, has rejected her appointment to head the Health Ministry on grounds that she is non-factional and would not accept any factional appointment. Her rejection came on Monday in all of the dailies and the national news.

Lusinee Kamara was on Thursday, February 27 inducted Speaker of the TLA by Ruth Perry, Chairperson of the ruling Council of State. He replaced Morris Dukuly, also of ULIMO-K.

Cletus Wotorson of the Liberian Action Party (LAP) on Friday, February 28 declared his ambition for the Presidency before partisans of LAP in the presence of a record crowd and requested the support of the Alliance of Seven Political Parties to consider him the presidential preferment for the presidency.

The Liberia People's Party (LPP) denies claims by the United People's Party (UPP) that both parties reached a compromise in Banjul in 1990 for the Presidency. The claim by the UPP that they had agreed in 1990 that the Interim President then should be produced by the LPP so that whenever there was any elections the UPP would correspondingly produce the President, the LPP in its Press Statement averred, is untrue.

On Monday march 3, 1997 the UPP held its primaries to elect a Standard Bearer. One of the four contestants, Joseph Boakai, was conspicuously absent, thus leaving the race to Peter Amos George, Jr., Blamoh Nelson, and the veteran G. Baccus Matthews. Of the 137 voters qualified to vote from the various electoral districts, Mr. George polled no vote, Nelson got 7 votes and Matthews 130 votes. Mr. Matthews said he is quite confident that he will emerge as the choice of the Alliance.

The Two-China issue continues to (claim) public attention. Against the acceptance of the other members of the State Council, Mr. Taylor continues to maintain that there is relations between Taiwan and Liberia. He has appointed an Ambassador to Taiwan (John Cummings) and has even paid a private visit there. Upon his return, he told the nation that Taiwan has promised to assist Liberia with about U.S. $500 million for reconstruction and socio-economic development.

Of the amount he has allotted $1 million for ECOM (Electoral Commission) and $1 million to his humanitarian fund. Reports coming in recently say Taiwan has denied ever promising such sum and is in fact recalling its Ambassador for misleading that country about relations between Liberia and Taiwan. Several local institutions and private individuals, including former (Council member) Alhadji Kromah, has called for the rejection of said funds (and stated that) acceptance and usage will represent an outright recognition of Taiwan and the establishment of diplomatic relations therewith. This has now become popular opinion.

However, USAID has offered to assist the ECOM with $6 million to ably conduct the elections which are slated for May 30. This offer has directly or otherwise erased the Taylor bluff about his successful mission to Taiwan.

ECONOMIC SITUATION:

Even though the rate of Liberian dollars to US dollars has reduced to 56 to 1 prices of basic commodities continue to rise. Gasoline, for example costs between 85 to 90 dollars as opposed to the previous cost of 70 to 75 dollars. A 100 pound bag of rice has now risen to 1,600.00 for pussawa (previously 1, 300.00).

On Monday, March 3, 1997 (government) announced that it is prepared to pay civil servants salary arrears up to December . There are however the usual kind of doubts because the government has always reneged on its promises of settling civil servants salary arrears over the years. These payments if effected will extend from mid 1996 to December 1996.

OTHER ISSUES:

Alhaji Kromah, former Council (member) has apologized for whatever his faction and other factions have done during the period of civil crisis against the people of Liberia. He has also offered 4000 scholarships to students of the University of Liberia, where he has resumed lecturing in Mass Communication.

Six ex-fighters of the ULIMO faction have been killed by a group of civilians using cutlasses and traditional spears in Grand Cape Mount County, reports alleged. These incidents took place in Gbeh Town, Gbieh-bor Town, Fan- mila Town, in Cape Mount.

The boycott of courts recently called by the Liberia National Bar Association (LNBA) still holds. The State Council has called on the LNBA to exercise restraint as the Council determines to take appropriate actions in favor of the restructuring of the Supreme Court. The Bar Association has remained stern in its decision to boycott the courts until it is allowed duly participate in or be accorded the mandate of naming judges to the Supreme Court, especially in terms of making it a defactionalized and credible arm of government.

Since the boycott on February 19, only three lawyers have appeared in courts. They include Francis Garlawolo, Arthur Williams and Frederick Jayweh. The Supreme Court bench, as appointed by the State Council includes Hall Badio (Chief Justice); Karmoh Soko Sackor, Laveli Supuwood, Octavius Obey and William Metzgar as Associate justices. Names forwarded to the State Council include: David Kpomarkpor, Harry Reeves Cooper, Wilkins Wright, Frances Johnson Morris, David Hne, Luvenia Ash Thompson, Laveli Supuwood and C. Alexander.

Stephen W. Wreh-Wilson Acting Director

Distributed by Africa Faith & Justice Network; P.O. Box 29378 Washington, D. C. 20017 202 832 3412; Fax 202 832 9051; email afjn@igc.apc.org.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


March 10, 1997


Western Sahara;
Sahara Weekly News Update (03/03 - 03/10)


BYLINE: Western Sahara Referendum Support Association


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 787 words


 

Geneva - Sahrawi National Day (27.02.97) The population of the refugee camps commemorated the 21th anniversary of the proclamation of the SADR with great manifestations, in presence of international delegations. In his speech President Abdelaziz declared the Sahrawi people is able to defend its legitime rights and categorically refuses the occupation of its territory.

He reiterated to be ready for a serious dialog and insisted that future meetings with Morocco should concentrate on the core of the issue and should be held in a neutral country, with the presence of international observers. The Algerian War Veterans Minister Said Abadou declared Algeria is working to help bring about a peaceful solution to the Western Sahara conflict and encourages all direct contact between the Polisario Front and Morocco, and added: "Algeria's attachment and support for the legitimate claims of the Sahrawi people are firmer than ever." 

01.03.97 Freedom for Mohamed Daddach

The European Bureau for Human Rights in Western Sahara based in Geneva starts an International campaign for the liberation of Mohamed Daddach, a Sahrawi jailed since 20 years in Morocco.

03.03.97 Throne Day

In his speech to mark the anniversary of Throne Day, King Hassan II spoke about Western Sahara:

"We also tried over the course of last year to inform you on the efforts to implement the UN plan to hold a referendum in our Saharan territories. These efforts might speed up the process of identification (of Saharan citizens eligible to vote) and thereby the implementation of the UN plan. Regrettably, no matter how much Morocco has tried to show its good intentions, the other side has shown only craftiness, stubbornness and procrastination, in order to delay any progress in this artificial problem.

However, Morocco, as we have repeatedly asserted, will keep its open-door policy. It is fully committed to the UN Security Council's plan and is ready to cooperate faithfully and effectively within its framework. But nothing will deter it from thwarting efforts aimed at jeopardizing its security.

Morocco always listens to all its sons. It is aware of their preoccupations, regardless of whether they live in the north or in the south of the country and aware of their eagerness to build their future with pride in their country - which will know, when the need arises, how to be compassionate and merciful (towards sons who have gone astray)." (BBC)

04.03.97 James Baker U.N. Envoy to Western Sahara?

Mr. Kofi Annan plans to name former secretary of state James A. Baker III as his special envoy to explore possible compromises between Morocco and the Polisario Front, reveals The Washington Post, which adds that "Annan believes he needs a prestigious representative to underscore the importance he attaches to this issue".

05.03.97 Mexico: no change

A Mexican MP in visit at Rabat declared: "The position of the Mexican government will not change". Mexico recognizes SADR since 1979, but recently rumors announced a possible retray of its recognition.

05.03.97 Mr. Kofi Annan meets the Moroccan U. N. ambassador Ahmed Snoussi. He should receive soon the Sahrawi Foreign Affairs Minister Bachir Mustapha Sayed.

06.03.97 Union of the Sahrawi Youth

A protocol of cooperation and friendship between UJSARIO and Youth Council of Castilla y Leon was signed at the occasion of the visit of the international secretary of UJSARIO. The main points of this protocol are the reafirmation of the support and solidarity, the start-up of a programm of exchange between the two organizations, the raise of awareness campaigns on W. S. and material support. UJSARIO participates in the International Coordination Committee for the 14th Festival of Youth and Students (July 25 to Aug. 5th 1997).

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


March 10, 1997


South Africa;
Amnesty Committee to Hear Eastern Cape Cases


BYLINE: Truth and Reconciliation Commission


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Cape Town - Up to 14 amnesty applications from people serving sentences in Eastern Cape jails will be heard when the Amnesty Committee sits in East London next week

The public hearings, to be held in the Robbie de Lange Hall, are scheduled for three days from Monday 17 March to Wednesday 19 March.

The applicants include several members of the ANC Youth League (Ancyl) , one from Azapo and three former Ciskei policemen.

They are:

-- Kwanele Enough Toba, Wakhile Thomson and Jonginkosi Wellington Makom are former Ciskei policemen who were convicted of various assaults and crimen injuria committed in 1987. Makom is held in Middledrift Prison and the other two in Mdantsane. They say they acted on orders to detain certain people regarding anti-Ciskei activities at the time. The assaults took place while these people, including a number of women, were in detention. 

-- Don Johnson Ntsikelelo (26), currently serving a sentence in St. Alban's prison in Port Elizabeth for the February 1991 murder of Mrs Nomsa Hanabe, then mayoress of Klipplaat. He was also convicted of possession of firearms and ammunition. Ntsikelelo says he was a member of the ANC/SACP alliance.

-- Tobani Makrosi (30) and Tyibilika Bonakela (24) have applied for amnesty in connection with two counts of kidnapping from the Inyibaba High School during February 1993. The abductions of which they were convicted took place during fighting at the school between Cosas and Paso. Makrosi says he is a member of the ANC. One of the two women abducted died, but they were acquitted of responsibility. They are currently held in Fort Beaufort Prison.

-- Seven people who declare themselves as members of the Ancyl are applying for amnesty in relation to the murder of Mrs Nohmbile Mphambani in April 1993, of which they were convicted. The seven, held in Mdantsane Prison in East London, are: Mvuyisi Raymond Ngwendu; Mzimhle Elvis Bam; Dumisani Ernest Mbhebe; Ndumiso Mdyogolo; Sikhumbuzo Victor Mphmbane; Sakhumzi Bheqesi; Andile Namathe Gola. They are between 22 and 25 years old.

-- Nwenkwe Alfred Madela (41), who says he is a former Regional Chairperson of Azapo and is serving a sentence in St. Alban's Prison in Port Elizabeth, has applied for amnesty in respect of various offences in December 1993 including arson, malicious damage to property, kidnapping and possession of fire-arms, of which he was convicted.

Notices have been given to victims informing them of their right to attend the hearings and to adduce evidence. The hearings are due to start at 09h00 am.


LOAD-DATE: March 12, 1997

237 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 10, 1997


Zimbabwe;
Urban Folks Till The Land To Survive


BYLINE: Chemist Mafuba, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1448 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Like in many cities of sub-Sahara Africa, urban agriculture has taken root in Zimbabwe with more people, stung by harsh economic reforms, taking to cultivating crops on unused city land to supplement household food needs and income.

Long prohibited by the urban authorities, it was only in 1984 that local authorities allowed organized urban crop-cultivation after President Robert Mugabe directed that the public be allowed to till unused land in the cities.

But even now those caught cultivating in the wrong places, particularly on stream banks, risk having their crops slashed, a measure that has bred controversy in many towns and cities.

However, the clearest signal yet that urban farming is now a fact of life in Zimbabwe has been the allocation of land to individuals and co-operatives in the main cities for crop cultivation by residents. 

While maize is grown mainly to supplement earnings, this year saw an upsurge in the cultivation of sweet potatoes, beans and other nutritious small crops.

This season, Harare Mayor Solomon Tawengwa sourced 6,000 tones of maize seed worth at least 3,000 U.S. dollars for free distribution to urban farmers, many of them poor folks struggling to meet daily survival needs.

In Bulawayo, Zimbabwe's second largest city, the council is working on a comprehensive programme to promote urban agriculture without damaging the environment.

Town Clerk Mike Ndubiwa said part-time farming offered wide economic opportunities for the urban poor who have been hard hit by harsh economic reforms.

"There have been signs of good organization like well demarcated fields used by specific households each year," he said.

Enda-Zimbabwe, a non-governmental organization, discovered in a recent study that the number of people engaged in urban farming doubled during the period 1990-95.

But the situation in Harare, even with plots which were allocated to co- operatives by the council, is somewhat haphazard.

The policy of the city council is to let tenants plough open lands until their housing construction programmes reach the fields.

Sofia Tom, resident of Budiriro low density suburb, cultivated her patch of sweet potatoes for the first time, in 1997..

"The woman from where I stay gave me this piece of land, together with other women, saying she had grown a lot of crops in her rural home," Tom said. "Where I come from I do not have any piece of land."

The idea of sub-letting plots in urban areas is not a new.

Mandivamba Rukuni, the chairman of the 1994 Land Tenure Commission, said similar reports had been received when his team was collecting evidence.

"We were told that one person would own large tracts of land in an urban area which he would sublet to other tenants," he said. "On giving up that piece of land, its ownership would revert back to the original landlord who would relocate it to somebody else."

Fears that urban agriculture could result in environmental degradation have been allayed by Chris Mugadza of the Natural Resources Board.

Urging councils to formalize cultivation in urban areas, he said Zimbabwean law required farmers to cultivate at least 30 meters away from streams and only on suitable soils.

"If councils can identify areas that can be cultivated, people can pay for that. Then Agritex (the Department of Agricultural Technical and Extension Services) can come in and advice on conservation," Mugadza said.

Rukuni said in many industrializing countries, and where their urban populations were growing, developed a sound policy of part-time farming.

"If you have a tradition of small-scale production like most Zimbabweans have, it means that for those people it makes economic sense to have land in small parts and utilize it, " he said.

"There should be a method to lease land. There is need for clarity in managing that land so the municipality will regulate it to conserve water and soil,"he added.

Rukuni said for any form of agriculture to succeed the government should come up with a general land policy, which is lacking in Zimbabwe.


LOAD-DATE: March 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


238 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 10, 1997


Nigeria;
Nigerian Driver Returns Lost Money Worth 60,000 U.S. Dollars


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 840 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - What would you do, if penniless, but happen to bump into a bag stuffed with as much as 60,000 U.S. dollars lying in the middle of the road with nobody watching: walk home quietly to attend to your numerous financial needs or report the find to the police?

A Nigerian commercial driver, Malam Abdulkarim Shehu, shunned the temptation of such questionable instant wealth and chose the latter option: the path of honor, which has brought him national recognition.

On Feb. 23, Shehu, riding in a French designed Peugeot car, was on his way from Jibia, a border town between Nigeria and Niger. He was heading for Kano, Nigeria's northern city, when he spotted an object on the busy road frequented by traders, who transported merchandise between Nigeria and other West African countries such as Burkina Faso, Guinea, Niger and Sierra Leone. " When I saw the bag in the night, I thought an innocent victim of a motor accident was waiting for help and so I stopped," he said in a newspaper interview published in Sunday in the southern city of Lagos. 

But on getting to the spot, he said he discovered it was a big bag containing bundles of money. This was later confirmed by police in Kano State to be 30.05 million francs CFA, about 60,000 U.S. dollars.

Shehu said he took the money home but remained in such shock he was unable to sleep that night. The following day, he took the bag of money to officials of the local branch of the Nigerian Union of Road Transport Workers who took the money to the police.

As it turned out, the money belonged to a group of 30 traders from Burkina Faso, who were on a business trip to Kano. The bag had dropped without their knowledge.

For his honesty Shehu, 34, has appeared on Nigeria's television network programme to receive words of commendation from the Kano deputy commissioner of police, Ade Ajakaiye.

"This is a gallant display of patriotism by an honest Nigerian at a time when economic hardship is pushing people to commit crimes," he said.

Later, Ajakaiye handed the money to the Burkinabe nationals, who he would not identified by name, for what the police said were security reasons.

To show their own appreciation, the traders gave Shehu 30,000 franc, about 60 dollars, in cash.

However, popular opinion is that Shehu deserves more, especially from the Nigerian authorities, if only to encourage similar show of public spirit by the citizenry.

The driver's financial standing also appears pathetic.

Shehu, a father of two children, said one of his two wives had divorced him, apparently over a financial dispute, and his other wife was expecting a new baby.

"I do not have money to buy firewood for her, let alone food," he said.

But despite his precarious state, Shehu, a devout muslim, says he derives joy from his action.

"If I had taken the money I would spend it and my Allah will ask me on the final day," he said.

Still sounding philosophical, he said "no amount of money taken illegally would make one rich unless Allah wishes you so."

Shehu's friend, Garba Faggi, has also attested to his honesty, but insists that "many people would not return the money if faced with similar challenges. "

As an incentive to others, Faggi recommended that Shehu be rewarded adequately by the authorities.

Another commentator suggested the driver be considered for assistance under Nigeria's National Family Support Programme.

A Nigerian police corporal, who turned in one million naira (about 12,000 dollars) he found at an accident scene two years ago was promoted and received car gifts and scholarships for his children.

Conceding that Shehu needs more than a symbolic national recognition, Ajakaiye said bigger rewards could be in the offing for the driver for his exemplary demonstration of public spirit.

But when and in what form this would come, he could not say.


LOAD-DATE: March 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


239 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 10, 1997


Ethiopia;
Attempted Jail Break Foiled In Addis Ababa


BYLINE: Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - At attempted jailbreak by inmates of the Addis Ababa Central Prison was foiled Monday when guards fired shots before capturing three prisoners in the compound of the Organization of African Unity headquarters, the O.A.U.

Witnesses said a number of the prisoners jumped the walled prison fence and dashed across a wide open space before reaching and scaling the O.A.U. perimeter wall.

Witnesses said the shooting lasted about five minutes as guards ran after the prisoners in hot pursuit. Witnesses said they were unsure if the guards fired their guns after the prisoners entered the compound, which is a diplomatic premiss.

The witnesses said that one of three captured escapees was slightly wounded.

Police cordoned off roads close by and leading directly to the O.A.U., after the shooting about 15.30 p.m. (12.30 gmt), as several prisoners made their dash for freedom.

It was not immediately clear how many prisoners escaped and were recaptured. It is also unclear whether or not they were common criminals. However, police and prison officials are expected to issue a statement on the incident later Monday.

Officials of the O.A.U. were not immediately available for comment.


LOAD-DATE: March 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


240 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 10, 1997


Zambia;
Zambian Students Protest Non-Payment Of Allowances


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - Students at the Lusaka campus of the University of Zambia boycotted classes Monday, in protest against the non-payment of their book allowances by the government.

Dozens of riot police kept vigil outside the campus early Monday after students hurled stones at vehicles along the Great East Road in the capital, Lusaka. Police have blocked the main entrance to the campus and arrested eight students. 

The students are demanding the payment of some 280 U.S. dollars as book allowance for returning students and about 150 dollars for freshmen, promised by government in 1996.

Students claim the government has failed to provide a convincing explanation for the delayed payments since the institution opened February.

The university's public relations officer, Mulise Malambo, said an official statement would be issued later. The official would not comment further.

But the Zambian Minister of Education, Syamukayumbu Syamujaye, told journalists that police would deal expeditiously with the arrested students.

The Zambian News Agency reported that nine student had been expelled with immediate effect. One other has been suspended for one academic year for riotious behaviour.

The agency said that the university authorities had ordered students to report for classes Tuesday or face disciplinary action.

The entire student body is to a punitive levy for wilful damage to university property. No student will be allowed to register for the second semester until the levy is paid.

University students at the northern copperbelt town of Kitwe are also demanding immediate payment of their meal and book allowances.

The Zambian media reported that students had not been paid allowances since they opened two weeks ago and most of them were very hungry.

The Copperbelt University Students' Union acting president, Harry Mafuta, said tension was mounting among students over the delayed payments.

"Normally, we are paid four days after opening but this has now been two weeks and we have not received a proper reason for the delay," he said.


LOAD-DATE: March 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


241 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 10, 1997


East Africa;
Sudan Threatens To Attack Uganda


BYLINE: Yahya El Hassan, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan (PANA) - Sudan said Monday it reserved "the right to respond" to the reported aggression by Ugandan troops on the border towns of Kaya and Bazi, southwest of Juba, the capital of Sudan's Equatoria region.

The official Sudan News Agency quoted government spokesman Tayeb Ibrahim Mohamed Khair as saying that a "large number of tanks and heavy artillery were used by the aggressors."

Khair, who is also information and culture minister, said that Khartoum might respond to this "heinous aggression by all means available." 

He alleged the attack was in fulfillment of threats by Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni who was quoted a few weeks ago as saying he was looking for a way to settle differences with the Sudan in the battlefield.

The attack on Kaya and Bazi, located a few hundred meters from the Uganda border, was first announced by the Sudanese army spokesman, Gen. Mohamed Sanousi Ahmed. He said the attack occurred at 5.00 A.M. Sunday (0200 GMT).

In a terse military communique, Ahmed had said that the attack was launched by " Ugandan forces moving from the Ugandan Koboko and Kiro areas." on the town of Kaya.

He added that the assault on Bazi was launched from Zairian border areas of Aliwara and Ambakalo. He said both areas were under what he termed the control of Uganda-backed Tutsi anti-government forces in Zaire.

However, Ahmed did not give any casualties but said Sudanese troops were " courageously fighting the aggressors on all the battle fronts."

He claimed that "inlets were opened (by the Ugandan attackers) for the rebels to move towards the town of Yei" in Equatoria state, southwestern Sudan.

About two months ago, Sudan accused Ethiopia of opening similar corridors for rebels to seize border towns in the Blue Nile region. Addis Ababa denied the allegation.

Ahmed also claimed Monday that Israeli, Eritrean and Ethiopian military experts had joined Uganda in the attacks Sunday.

"We are sure about the involvement of 30 Israeli experts in the Ugandan attacks on the border localities of Bazi and Kaya," he said at a news conference.

There has been no independent confirmation of the latest Sudanese claim against these three countries.

Admed declined to confirm claims by the Sudanese opposition fighting the government that that the two localities had fallen to them.

"Fierce fighting is still going on. Our defence is not an inflexible one," Ahmed said.


LOAD-DATE: March 10, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


242 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 11, 1997


Business and Finance;
Campaign To Save The Nigerian Leather Industry


BYLINE: Goddy Ikeh, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1134 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Statistics of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) show that Africa loses about 850 million U.S. dollars annually due to poor collection of animal hides and skins.

African livestock owners also hardly receive added value for "a good quality skin from any animal sold alive."

Spore, a publication on information for agricultural development in Africa, the Caribbean and Pacific countries, which highlights the FAO's views, says that skins are not collected for markets in sub-Sahara Africa.

For instance, it says Guinea collects only 20 percent of its skins for markets. 

In Nigeria, Africa's most populous country with some 100 million people, the problem is different.

Most hides and skin produced in the country are cooked and consumed as a local delicacy nicknamed "Ponmo," in southwestern Nigeria, where it is mostly eaten.

Ponmo is extracted from at least 1.3 million cows slaughtered annually in the country.

While Nigeria accounts for some 70 percent of these animals, imports from neighbouring Niger and Mali make up the shortfall.

No particular attention was paid to these statistics in the Nigeria's heady days of abundant petro-dollars.

But given the current economic depression, beef, a body-building protein, has been priced beyond the reach of the average Nigerian family.

A kilogram of beef is now sells for 180 naira (2.25 U.S. dollars), while ponmo of the same weight goes for less than 60 naira (75 U.S. cents). All this in a country where the minimum wage is under 2,000 naira (25 dollars) a month.

Many Nigerian families now try to cut corners. And even against the warning from health experts that ponmo has no nutritional value, consumers have stuck adamantly to the product, which is even far cheaper than fish.

While its origin remains a mystery, the consumption of ponmo has gained popularity as appetite for it has spread to the rest of the country.

Ponmo does not require much work. It is prepared, first, by removing the hairs on the cow hide by shaving or burning. Then, the skin is soaked in water for about 24 hours. It is par-boiled with potash and is ready for the soup pot.

Trade in ponmo is popular among women, with civil servants and middle income earners, constituting the largest clientele.

But the Nigerian government is worried that the high rate of ponmo consumption poses a great threat to the country's otherwise lucrative leather industry.

Consequently, officials launched a campaign in 1996 to dissuade consumption of ponmo.

As part of the national drive, Science and Technology Minister Sam Momah has said the practice of cooking hides and skin should be outlawed.

He says the country is losing about one billion U.S. dollars annually in potential foreign exchange earnings from the local consumption of hides and skin that could have been transformed into exportable leather and its products.

Momah says Nigeria could gain more by exporting its processed hides and that "only a controlling legislation can save the situation."

The secretary to the Nigerian government, Gidado Idris, has also joined in the crusade warning that the country could not afford to kill its leather industry.

But from all indications, the campaign has achieved very little.

In their reaction to appeals and threats from government officials on ponmo consumption, consumers interviewed on Nigerian national television threatened recently to start a "ponmo riot."

They said instead of quarrelling over consumption of ponmo, government should do something to improve the living conditions of the people.

For his part, the provost of the Federal College of Chemical and Leather Technology, Zaria in northern Nigeria, Benedict Dashe, says persuasion rather then threat should be the solution.

Illustrating with statistics the danger posed to the leather industry by indiscriminate ponmo consumption, Dashe says tanneries in Lagos, where the bulk of the cows in the country are slaughtered, depend on other parts of the country for the supply of hides and skin. Those in Lagos are consumed.

In the 1960s and 1970s, he says, some 90 percent of hides in Britain were supplied by Nigeria.

Still on the economic implications of local consumption of hides and skin, Dashe says, "a pair of imported shoes for which Nigerians pay about 7,000 naira (87.5 dollars) now, could have been produced locally for less than half that price."

But to stem the controversy, he says "there should be adequate public enlightenment on the wastage which should appeal to the patriotic instinct of us all."

However, ponmo sellers are worried a ban on the item would affect their livelihood, adversely.

One ponmo seller, Olufunke Daisi, says she makes between 150 and 300 naira (1.88 and 3.75 dollars) a day selling ponmo.

She says a ban would throw her and an estimated 1,000 ponmo traders in various Lagos markets, out of business.

But while the national debate rages, ponmo addicts continue to munch the zero-nutrient "delicacy".


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.
