March 11, 1997


Cote d'Ivoire;
Ivorian Leader Pardons Teenage Killer


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 120 words


 

ABIDJAN, Cote d'Ivoire (PANA) - A 14-year old Guinean girl, Fanta Keita, serving time for the murder of her husband has been pardoned by President Henri Konan Bedie and released. 

Keita's parents forced her into marrying her 29-year old cousin. After repeated beatings and rape she ran away frequently, eventually stabbing her husband to death on April 21, 1996. She was imprisoned May 30 that year.

Women's rights groups commended Bedie for releasing Keita on Monday, saying it was a victory for women.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


244 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 11, 1997


Business and Finance;
Nigeria Airways Gets New Managing Director


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 267 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigeria's Federation Aviation Ministry said Tuesday Jani Ibrahim had been named the new managing director of the financially- troubled state carrier, Nigeria Airways.

The ministry gave no reason for the measure but said the change took effect Friday. Ibrahim takes over from Air Force Group Capt. Peter Gana, who was appointed to the post in March 1995.

Gana, who has been serving as the President of the African Civil Aviation Association, is reassigned to the Nigerian Air force.

The ministry also announced the retirement of seven directors in the airline's operations, engineering and administration departments.

The carrier has been in financial crisis for several years now and aviation officials says it owes creditors at least 11 billion U.S. dollars.

Creditor seizures of some of the airline's planes has left it with four operational aircraft from a jet fleet of 20 some 10 years ago.

At the moment, Nigeria Airways' planes are banned from the United States following Washington's suspension of flights to and from Nigeria since 1993 over alleged airport insecurity.

Last week, the British aviation authorities banned Nigeria Airways flights into London because the carrier's plane were not insured.

LANGUAGE: English

245 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 11, 1997


Business and Finance;
Libya Earned Nine Billion Dollars in 1996


BYLINE: Ali Delali, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya (PANA) - Libya earned at least nine billion U.S. dollars in 1996, the country's Central Bank Governor, Taher Jehmi, has said.

In a report to the People's General Congress, the country's highest legislative body which ended a six-day session Sunday in Syrte, he said that 95 percent of the earnings were from petroleum sales. 

In the same year, Libya realized a trade surplus of 670 million dollars.

Libya, a member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, produces 1.2 million barrels of oil a day.

However, Jehmi said that the fall in crude oil prices on the world market, toward the second half of the 1980s, prompted Libya to suspend several industrial and agricultural development projects.

Libya's economic crisis aggravated in 1992, following the economic sanctions imposed on it by the United Nations Security Council at the request of Britain, France and the United States.

Two of these countries are demanding that Libya extradite two of its nationals accused of involvement in the explosion of a PanAm jetliner over Lockerbie, Scotland, in 1988.

France wants the men tried for their alleged involvement in downing a French jetliner, belonging to the private company, UTA. That plane crashed into Niger's Tenere desert in 1989.

After Libya's repeated refusal to send the suspects for trial in Britain or the United States, the U.N. tighten sanctions by freezing Libya's foreign assets and putting an embargo on equipment for its oil industry, the mainstay of the country's economy.

During the recent O.A.U. Ministerial Council meeting in Tripoli, Libyan Foreign Affairs Minister Omar Montassir told the Pan African News Agency that sanctions had led to an increase in the cost of oil production and that operations could stop at any moment.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


246 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 11, 1997


Zimbabwe;
Panic As Mugabe's Plane Develops Engine Trouble


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

SHANNON, Ireland (PANA) - Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe's VIP charter flight from Ireland had to be aborted Monday soon after take off from Shannon Airport, about 200 kilometres west of Dublin, after one of the engines developed a fault.

The reconditioned Boeing 707, which is more than 30 year old, had stopped in Shannon for refuelling after a 20-minute flight from Dublin, and took about 75 minutes to land as it had to jettison fuel for safe landing.

But even after releasing the fuel, the plane could not land immediately because its nose wheel would not lower automatically. It had to be released manually. 

Mugabe, accompanied by his wife Grace, Foreign Minister Stan Mudenge and other government officials and reporters, had completed a two-day official visit to Ireland and was returning home.

First there was the smell of fuel on take off, followed by sparks of fire from one of the four engines.

Then, Capt. Christopher Szechenyi announced over the public address system that engine number three had developed a problem, the fire indicator was on, and the aircraft had to return to Shannon.

While most passengers in the economy class put on a brave face as the captain reassured them, the mood changed when he said the nose wheel could not be released, especially after explaining that the aircraft was taking time to land "as we are trying to burn as much fuel as we can."

Szechenyi said, "We have a problem, the nose wheel will not come down. We are now in a situation where we have to put down the nose wheel manually."

By this time all the passengers had their seat belts tightly fastened as one of the cabin crew had elaborately read out the emergency evacuation instructions.

The green safety instruction sheets, which most passengers usually ignore, suddenly became prime reading material as everyone prepared for the worst.

The Chief of Protocol, Munyaradzi Kajese, who at a point appeared a bit restless, tried to cheer up passengers by dancing funnily along the aisle but quite a number of passengers were still trying to absorb the safety instructions.

"I think we are gone," quipped one journalist, feigning a smile while another government official immediately behind him also, pretending to be unperturbed chipped in: "When your day has come there is no running away."

Finally, the plane landed, at an unusually high speed, trailed well over 20 fire engines, police car and ambulances that had been summoned by the airport authorities.

The president and his delegations were later taken to hotels in the small Irish town, to await alternative arrangements for their flight home.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


247 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 11, 1997


Zimbabwe;
Mugabe's Vision of New Africa


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 947 words


 

DUBLIN (PANA) - Africa is poised to become the world's new region of opportunity and the continent's major priority is to create durable democratic systems in which pluralism is fully entrenched, Zimbabwe President Robert Mugabe said Monday.

Addressing academics, politicians, journalists and leading personalities at a colloquium organized by Harvard University and the Irish Times newspaper, Mugabe said despite negative international media reports, Africa was taking measures to create peace, stability and economic prosperity on the continent.

Africa's Recognition of its Past and Remedies for Its Future was the focus of Mugabe's lengthy address which traced Africa's history and present realities of the continent.

"Africa has been dubbed the dark continent in spite of the fact that there is probably more light and sunshine on the African continent than on any other landmass on this planet," he said. "Africa is much more than a story of tragedies." 

While conceding that post-independent African leaders had made mistakes, it was folly to blame Africa's backwardness on bad government.

"Today Africa is indeed pulling out of the dark age, an age of unreason, cruelty and irrationality. But it is a dark age into which it was plunged by others, not by itself.

"We go into history to learn and not necessarily to apportion blame. A proper appreciation of what happened will instruct our steps today and so help us avoid the pitfalls of the past."

Mugabe said Africa was now determined to resolve conflicts afflicting the continent, most of which he blamed on colonialism and the cold war.

Under colonialism, he said, ethnic African groups were kept apart and made liable to be suspicions of each other. During the cold war, leaders of independent African countries were either rewarded or punished by the two super-powers for their ideological preferences.

"The shift was costly for Africa because its most principled leaders, those who sought to retain the people as their constituency in defiance of outside powers, became the targets of deliberate destabilization policies, while those who collaborated as pliant clients often became blatantly corrupt dictators, now dependent on the might of their foreign masters to remain in power," he said.

"Given what African leaders had to contend with, that the continent has held up the way it has, is itself a source of both wonder and satisfaction," he added.

If Africa took measures to ensure peace and stability through the Organization of African Unity and regional organizations, he said, the environment for investment and economic development would improve.

He cited the lack of major industries in most countries as being the major obstacle to development and the main reason for Africa's rising indebtedness. He added that international terms of trade, despite the successful Uruguay Round negotiations which led to the establishment of the Wold Trade Organization, remained biased against Africa.

He said by stressing the opening up of all markets while seeking to protect information and knowledge, particularly intellectual property rights and technology, the WTO exposed Africa to exploitation.

"Just as I believe inequality and unfairness can engender political instability at the domestic level, so do we view inequality and unfairness at the international level as making for instability and injustice in international relations," he said.

It was for that reason Africa was pushing for the democratization of the United Nations by including African and Latin American countries in the Security Council.

Mugabe said Africa, with a few exceptions, had embraced democracy and that the genius of its people was once again being unleashed.

"Most of its governments are becoming more and more accountable to the people. It can already see an era of peace in the horizon and with it the flourishing human spirit," he said.

The African people, he said, had "resolved never again to remain the object of history but to transform themselves into its subject."

As Africa sought more socio-economic ties, he said, it was also looking at other developing countries in such regions as Asia and South America in the spirit of South-South cooperation.

Africans, he said, would determine the destiny of their continent and cooperate with others as equal partners.

"They were their own political liberators, they are sure to become their own economic liberators," he said.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


248 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 11, 1997


Malawi;
Malawi News Roundup


BYLINE: Malawi News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1414 words


 

Blantyre - The Japanese government announced on February 22 it had donated US$266,00 to the Malawi government for victims of floods in the Shire valley, south Malawi. The donation will be channeled through the Japanese International Cooperation Agency (JICA).

Some US$100,000 of the donation is in cash while the rest will be given in blankets, food, clothing and tents.

DOCTORS PROPOSE WARD CLOSURES AT BLANTYRE HOSPITAL

Medical staff at the Queen Elizabeth referral hospital in Blantyre have said, that unless the administration at the hospital is able to get more staff for fee paying wards, the best solution would be to close them. 

Head of Department of Medicine at the College of Medicine, Professor John Murray, said Wards 2A and 2B face a critical shortage of staff. Professor Murray said that the staffing situation was so bad that this was resulting in inadequate patient care and if it did not improve the wards would have to close.

QECH is a teaching hospital for the Malawi College of Medicine.

LOCAL GOVERNMENT ELECTION FOR AUGUST

The government has announced that the long-awaited local government elections will be held in August this year.

Local Government and Rula Development Minister Dr Matembo Nzunda said he had been assured by the Electoral Commission that the long overdue elections will take place this year.

The Public Affairs Committee had accused government of delaying the elections for political interests. They had called on NGOs to pressure government saying the failure to hold elections two years ago had contributed to the stagnation of democratic structures in the country.

The government had countered saying the main hindrance had been finding the K350 million (US$23.34 million) needed to hold the elections.

HIGH COURT BAN ON NEWSPAPERS</bold>

The High Court in Blantyre has banned Blantyre Newspapers, Daily Times and Malawi News, and their printers, Blantyre Print and Packaging Limited, from publishing and printing any stories mentioning Information, Broadcasting, Posts and Telecom's Minister, Brown Mpinganjira in connection with the Employment Bureau of Africa (Teba).

Mpinganjira had last year sued owners of the two papers for defamation. This followed the publishing of statements by opposition MCP Vice President Gwanda Chakuamba alleging that he had misappropriated Teba funds from the South African government to the government of Malawi. The funds were meant to be paid to former mine workers. The minister also applied to the High Court to order the newspapers to stop publishing the stories until the matter was resolved in open court.

In his ruling, Justice William Hanjahanja said that since an audit report alleging the Teba money had been misappropriated mentioned the involvement of many other public figures and government departments in the misuse of the money, it was unfair to single out only one individual.

Hanjahanja also said the copy of the report, presented in court together with the affidavit from the lawyer representing BP&P, was not an original one. It was a photocopy and there were no signatures, raising serious doubts about its authenticity.

NO LIGHT ON SAGA OF DEPORTED ZAMBIANS

There would appear to be no light spread as yet on the saga of two Zambians deported to Malawi in August 1994.

James Chinula and William Banda were deported to Malawi by order of the Zambian government. The Zambian government said the two men were Malawians who had been embroiled in Zambian politics. However, the High Court in Malawi ruled March 13, 1995, that the two were Zambians, were wrongfully deported to Malawi and were free to return to Zambia.

When asked if the two men were welcome in Zambia following the High Court's ruling, Zambia High Commissioner to Malawi, Colonel Lawrence Haamaundu said his government had not even been advised by Malawi that Chinula and Banda were free to return to Zambia. He said if the Malawi government had ruled them to be Zambians, it should have given them 90 days to prepare for their return to Zambia. He said the fact that they had managed to stay in Malawi for such a long time meant to him that they were where they belong.

Centre for Human Rights and Rehabilitation tried but failed to make an appointment with Zambian President Frederick Chiluba to discuss the issue when he paid a four-day visit to Malawi recently.

Chinula and Banda who left their families and property in Zambia say they are suffering in Malawi because they have no proper means of earning a living. They said that they now depend on well-wishers and relatives for their survival.

MALAWI-MOZAMBIQUE LAKE TRANSPORT ON THE CARDS

Malawi wants to introduce lake services on Lake Malawi between its ports and those on the Mozambican side.

If an agreement is signed between Malawi Lake Services Limited and its Mozambican counterpart, vessels owned by the two companies will be able to call at the other country's ports on a reciprocal basis. MLS Director, Austin Msowoya, said the move to introduce the service was first mooted by the Malawi government about three years ago when Malawi signed a similar agreement with Tanzania Lake Service Corporation.

The same idea was suggested to the Mozambican government and their Minister of Transport expressed interest. Mozambique has, however, not provided feedback as to its latest position on the issue.

Msowoya said Mozambique does not presently have a single ship on the lake so, should the deal be signed, it will initially be to Malawi's advantage.

BOY INJURED BY GRENADE

An eight year old boy from Makheta, a poor neighbourhood in Blantyre, escaped death on March 5 when a hand grenade he was playing with exploded in his hands, severely injuring him. Lamison Gama, who was later admitted to Queen Elizabeth Central Hospital is being treated for multiple injuries.

Relatives said the boy had found the grenade and was playing with it with friends. They said the grenade exploded when he pulled the safety pin. Fortunately for the others, they were some distance from Gama when the accident took place and were not injured.

It is not known from where the grenade came.

MALAWI BEATS BOTSWANA

Malawi national soccer team has beaten Botswana 4-1 in their Africa Cup Group Seven encounter in Gaborone. With this win, Malawi now has 6 points, one point behind Zambia who are leading in the group.

Both Malawi and Zambia have three games on hand. Malawi has one away game against Zambia while the other two will be played in Blantyre. Zambia was recently held to a barren draw with unfancied Mauritius in the latter's backyard.

To contact or subscribe to Malawi News Online, email: AfricaNN@inform-bbs. dk.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


249 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 11, 1997


Malawi;
Devastation in the Shire Valley


BYLINE: Malawi News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 960 words


 

Blantyre - The story of Joseni Alufazema, 56, and his family of seven seemed like a fairy tale.

The last growing season was among the best for the Alufazemas. They realised a bumper harvest from almost all their cash and food crops. "Cotton was the most rewarding, followed by sorghum, then rice. From all my farming activities, I managed to raise in excess of K50 000 (US$3,340)," said Alufazema. Spurred on by last year's successes, he re-invested about K30 000 into his farming business in the hope that this year, he would get even more. 

Today, each passing day is less of a fairy tale and more of a nightmare as he now agonises over how he is going to fend for his family up to the next harvest.

The Alufazemas have lost all their cotton, sorghum and rice fields following heavy flooding that occurred in their area. "What is more painful is that the floods have also left us homeless after damaging our two beautiful houses and all our property," he lamented.

The Alufazemas are among the 80,000 people who have been rendered destitute due to heavy flooding following the incessant rains in February. This affected the Shire valley area in Nsanje and Chikwawa districts, south Malawi. In addition to the 80,000, the floods have also affected some 20,000 Mozambicans who crossed over into Malawi in search of immediate assistance.

Before the government moved in with tents, the victims were crammed in classrooms and church buildings in upland areas that had survived the floods. The Ministry of Health has reported a serious diarrhoea outbreak in the two districts due to the lack of sanitation. The victims' immediate needs are food, drinking water, shelter and health facilities.

Commissioner for Disaster and Relief, Lucius Chikuni, told a delegation of the United Nations System in Malawi that the government needs K199 million (US$14 million) to cater for the flood victims. President Bakili Muluzi, who visited the area soon after the flooding took place, has since declared the two districts disaster areas. Also, in the wake of the flooding, the government has appealed to the donor community and other well-wishers for urgent assistance. Several donor organisations and countries, as well as local well-wishers, have already started responding to this call for assistance. Government and non-governmental organisations have been airlifting food and other relief items to the victims by helicopter from Blantyre, some 80 to 100 kilometres away.

The UN Systems in Malawi, however, has demanded that the government should furnish them with exact statistics, as to the victims and their requirements, as a condition for their assistance. Chikuni insisted that their working figure was 80,000 people, adding that there was a possibility that more people could become affected by the floods since the rainy season was not over.

For what they consider would be a permanent solution to the problem, government has announced that it would be setting aside land upstream for people willing to settle in less flood-prone areas. The government says flooding along the Shire River had become a perennial phenomenon and the best solution was to look elsewhere for land for the victims. Minister of Lands and Evaluation, Peter Fachi, said the government had decided to resettle the victims upstream where they would not be affected by the periodic flooding. He said, however, that the resettlement exercise would be voluntary.

While welcoming the suggestion, the majority of the people have said they would not leave their ancestral lands. Estere Ofesi, 44, who said she owns two hectares of fertile land along the Shire River, has vowed never to abandon the land where her mother and father are buried. "When I die, I want to be buried next to my mother," she said. Most of the people cite economic reasons. They say the river, which is the outlet from Lake Malawi and Malawi's largest and longest river, was their source of income from the fish it provides.

Fostino, Estere's husband, speaking for many said, "Our life has been good here, along the Shire."

<bold>1. FROZEN BANDA BANK ACCOUNTS CONDEMNED BY MCP

The Malawi Congress Party has condemned the government's move of 21 February to freeze the foreign bank accounts of former president Kamuzu Banda Cecilia and Mary Kadzamira.

A statement released February 21 by the MCP said the move "gives the impression these accounts were opened with stolen money ". The statement said Dr Banda had never made a secret of his UK bank accounts that included accounts for all his closest relatives, including the late Nelson Mwale, Mrs Kumangirana and Ms Chendawaka Mwale. All were opened in the 70s.

To contact or subscribe to Malawi News Online, email: AfricaNN@inform-bbs. dk.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

250 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 11, 1997


South Africa;
NGOs continue to oppose R12,2-billion Dolphin deal


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 800 words


 

NELSPRUIT - The Environmental Justice Networking Forum (EJNF) and rural communities from the Blyde River Canyon in Mpumalanga who are directly affected by the province's controversial Dolphin Deal sent delegates to Parliament on Tuesday to brief the Standing Select Committee on Environmental Affairs about their concerns.

EJNF earlier this week rejected a list of amendments to the secret R12,2- billion deal with the Dubai-based Dolphin Group, saying that the government had still not "bothered" consulting with affected communities and appeared to be intentionally sidelining them instead.

The Dolphin deal, which was sighed by the Mpumalanga Parks Board (MPB) and Dolphin without any public consultation last year November, gives Dolphin exclusive commercial development and transverse rights to six State-owned game reserves, Blyde River Canyon and Loskop Dam.

Rural communities living in the target areas protested vigorously to the deal, pointing out that they had gazetted land claims on at least three of the core development areas. 

Land claims are only gazetted by the Land Commissioner if they are found to be justified.

In return for its 25-year monopoly on all of Mpumalanga's key tourism attractions, Dolphin last week offered to pay MPB 25 percent of its revenue from operations in the various parks, as well as an additional 7 percent of its turnover to assist the MPB with its projected budget deficit over the 25- year period.

Mpumalanga's legislature originally approved deal's such as the Dolphin one with the sole aim of finding private sector funders to pay both MPB's deficit and its normal running budget.

The government says that it was forced to do this because it simply didn't have the money to fund the MP.SOURCE&DATE

The MPB asked for R54-million for salaries and other personnel expenses for 1997/ 98, while the province can only afford to give it R11-million.

Legislative members also expressed concern this week that the 7 percent offer by Dolphin was not "good enough".

Because of community outrage, Dolphin also proposed reserving at least 20 percent equity ownership in various joint venture companies which will run the reserve's commercial operations for surrounding communities.

"Everyone is hailing the new concessions as a victory for Mpumalanga, but again no-one has bothered to actually ask the people living in these areas what they want," explained EJNF provincial co-ordinator, Thabo Mabihlaba.

"Sure, it's a lot of money for the government and the MPB, but this is 25- years of various community's lives which have just been signed away without once consulting with those affected."

Insisting that the amendments, including the scrapping of a 50-year secrecy clause in the agreement, were purely symbolic, Mabihlaba said on Tuesday that Mpumalanga's environmental affairs MEC, David Mkhwanazi, was still refusing to meet with either the EJNF or with community delegates.

"We have to express our deepest disappointment at the way the MEC and MPB have handled this issue. We've written to both on a number of occasions, but they've chosen to ignore us," he said.

Stressing that communities were "feeling more and more sidelined and marginalised by the very people they voted in to listen to their concerns," Mabihlaba said that their only option now appeared to be to appeal directly to the relevant national leaders.

"Regardless of the terms or benefits of any contract, any agreement which is not first negotiated with affected communities is seriously undermining the aspirations of communities to get full control of their land and their future," he added.

"Let's not see a repeat of the Apartheid era where the State took the freedom of choice away from 'ignorant rurals' and unilaterally decided what was in their 'best interests'."


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


March 11, 1997


South Africa;
Student organisations clash over boycott


BYLINE: George Mthethwa, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

EMPANGENI - The Azanian Student's Congress (Azasco) in KwaZulu/ Natal lashed out at the South African Student's Congress (Sasco) on Monday afternoon for allegedly misleading students on the campus of the University of Zululand.

Charging that Sasco had blatantly lied to students about registration requirements and about its campaign to have unregistered students formally registered by the University, Azasco said at a mass meeting on Monday that Sasco was "callously" using student's fears to further its own political objectives. 

Sasco organised boycotts and protest marches at the university last week in protest against the university's decision not to allow more than 800 unregistered students back into classes.

"These selfish boycotts which were simply a point scoring exercise have done nothing but bring the university into disrepute. And they have also made the authorities less inclined to listen to us next time there is a genuine problem," said Azasco campus leader and Student Representation Council president, Mbongiseni Ndlela.

"If they had really been concerned about the unregistered students, they would have instead had constructive negotiations with management."

Sasco spokesperson, Vusi Mahaye, denied that Sasco had attempted to play on student's fears and insisted on Tuesday that demands for the unconditional registration of all unregistered students was "a genuine clause worth fighting".

"Why should economic and past educational problems stand in the way of those who want education from getting it," he added.

The Azasco controlled SRC meanwhile announced a further two week extension for registration at the university.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

252 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 11, 1997


South Africa;
Sole survivor of flash flood speaks from hospital bed


BYLINE: Mzilikazi wa Afrika, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

SABIE - The South African National Defence Force (SANDF) sent six special force trackers to Sabie on Tuesday morning to assist with the search for two missing people who were swept off a bridge near Sabie on Monday by a flash flood.

Police helicopters, divers and sniffer dogs are already on the scene but have been hampered in their search by muddy waters and strong currents.

Provincial police spokesman Sergeant Thabisile Gama told African Eye News Service that earlier reports indicating that five people were missing were incorrect. 

"Only three people were in the bakkie that was swept off a bridge. A 13- year-old boy managed to swim to shore, but his mother and the vehicle's driver are still missing and we are beginning to lose hope of finding them alive," explained Gama.

Both George Sekatane (54) and Paulinah Kwiane (32) could not swim.

The survivor, Collen Khwiane, spoke from his Sabie Hospital bed about his ordeal for the first time on Tuesday afternoon.

"My mother was taking me to this very hospital for eye tests on Monday when we were offered a lift in the bakkie. We jumped at the offer but when the bakkie tried to cross the swollen river, we got stuck half-way across," explained the still tearful Collen.

"Mr Sekatane tried revving his way over the bridge but the wheels just turned and we did not move. The water was rising and then he tried to reverse. The next thing I knew, the bakkie was upside down in the water and was sinking."

Collen says that he managed to push himself free from the vehicle, but was unable to see what happened to either his mother or Sekatane because of the muddy water.

"I saw a branch near me when I surfaced and managed to swim to it. After crawling to shore, I screamed for my mother but she was no-where to be seen. I then ran home and reported the accident," added Collen.

Police searchers have combed the banks of the Blyde River from the scene of the accident to the Sybrandt van Niekerk Dam but have found no trace of either missing person.

"The army trackers are our last real hope at the moment, so lets just wish for the best," added Sergeant Gama.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


253 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 11, 1997


South Africa;
50 farm labourers forced to sleep in ditch after eviction


BYLINE: Sylvestor Lukhele & Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 614 words


 

NELSPRUIT - Fifty farm labourers and their families were forced to sleep in ditches next to the N4 highway outside Nelspruit on Monday night, after police evicted them from the Cairn Trust Farm.

The angry labourers, who walked into town and protested outside Premier Mathews Phosa's offices on Tuesday, said that police had smashed their doors down when residents refused to open for them and had "violently" thrown their furniture onto the back of police trucks.

"They just told us that the farmer no longer wanted us on his land. Then they took our furniture and dumped it next to the highway, damaging stuff that is precious to us poor people but which obviously means nothing to them," said community spokesperson, Wilburforce Dotyeni. 

"When the furniture was taken away but we still refused to move, the police told us that unless we ran off the farm very quickly, there would be more trouble than what we could handle."

Insisting that the only reason farmer Mike Perera had evicted them was because all the farm labourers had recently joined a farm labour union, Dotyeni said that many of the labourers had lived and worked on Cairn Trust for 30 to 40-years.

"And now, overnight, we are without homes or any means to protect our wives and children," he added.

Perera was unavailable for comment on Tuesday but the Department of Land Affairs in Nelspruit confirmed that it was aware of the situation.

"We are aware of the situation, but cannot unfortunately get directly involved because these people are not labour tenants and are therefore not protected by the Labour Tenant Act," explained Lowveld departmental deputy- director, David Mabunda.

Only labourers who are given shelter and land to farm on are protected by the Act, while those that receive normal salaries are not.

"From the information at our disposal, this thing started as a labour relations dispute. Apparently the farmer became very upset that his labourers insisted on voting in the historic 1994 democratic elections and threatened to fire them" adds Mabunda.

"They joined a union to protect themselves and have been in dispute since then."

Stressing that Land Affairs doesn't condone any eviction for any reason and that the department always attempts to facilitate negotiations, Mabunda also said on Tuesday that the labourers in this instance had "difficult".

"This eviction could have been avoided if the workers had been a little more co-operative. Instead they made demands they knew the farmer would not accept. But it also appears that the police were heavy-handed during the eviction," Mabunda said.

The head of Strategic Planning in the Premier's Office, Joe Magagula told the angry labourers on Tuesday that the government could do nothing immediately for them and that they should report the matter to the Nelspruit Police Station.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

254 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 11, 1997


South Africa;
Mozambican dies after Mpumalanga hospitals refuse to admit her


BYLINE: Mzilikazi wa Afrika, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

NELSPRUIT - The financial director of the Mozambican company, Brithol Michoma, died of serious head injuries in Mpumalanga on Saturday, after two provincial hospitals allegedly refused to admit her because "she was a foreigner with a medical aid".

Police confirmed on Tuesday that Anna-Maria Mendez (29) and two companions were seriously injured in a head-on collision while on their way to Johannesburg from Maputo on Friday night.

One of the companions, Christo Todorob (26), died immediately after their vehicle collided with a heavily loaded truck just outside of Malelane. The truck was also a Mozambican registered vehicle which was returning to Maputo from Johannesburg. 

Mendez, who sustained severe injuries to her head, and Rui Alegri were rushed to the nearby Shongwe Hospital, which reportedly refused to treat them and instead referred the two to the Themba Hospital in Kabokweni township.

However, after arriving at Themba, medical staff allegedly discovered that the two Mozambicans had medical aid and referred them to the Rob Ferreira Hospital 50km away in Nelspruit for "better treatment".

Police say that doctors at Rob Ferreira then decided the injuries would be better treated at Nelspruit's Private Hospital, "especially since they had medical aid".

Mendez and Alegri were finally admitted to the Private Hospital at 05h00 on Saturday morning - ten hours after the accident on Friday night.

Mendez died of her injuries shortly after being admitted after doctors were unable to stabilise her condition. Alegri is still in the hospital's intensive care unit and is reported to be critical but stable.

Shongwe Hospital spokesperson, Obert Ntimane, confirmed on Tuesday that Mendez and Alegri had been turned away because staff had thought that 'they will get better help' at Themba. Ntimane refused to say whether either patient had received any medication from hospital staff before being transferred to Themba.

"The two patients were unknown and unconscious - in coma - when they arrived here. We have no specialists and so we decided it would be best to send them to Themba," he added.

Alegri's doctor, Dr Eric Der Wael, said on Tuesday that both Mendez and Alegri should have been sent directly to Nelspruit's Private Hospital for immediate treatment. "The transfers were badly handled. With more time, we could perhaps have been able to do something for Mendez. The Private Hospital is the only medical institute in this part of Mpumalanga with a Computerised Tomogramme Machine which we need to revive the patient's brain," he explained.

"But unfortunately there just wasn't anything we could do at the time."

Mendez's family arrived in Nelspruit on Tuesday, while Alegri's family have been keeping a vigil beside their father's bed since Sunday.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


255 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 11, 1997


South Africa;
14 taxi drivers accused of execution killings


BYLINE: Mzilikazi wa Afrika, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

LYDENBURG - Fourteen taxi drivers were refused bail by the Lydenburg Magistrate's Court in Mpumalanga on Tuesday after allegedly kidnapping four members of a competing taxi organisation and executing them in a cave near Burgersfort.

According to the State, the 14 South African Long Distance Taxi Association (Saldta) drivers kidnapped Titus Molepo, Silas Nkoeng, Paul Letsoalo and Michael Mathenya from the Jane Furse Taxi Rank after a meeting set up to resolve disputes about routes broke down.

Police report that representatives from Saldta and the independent Boseka- bo-eja Taxi Association (BTA) began arguing violently after Saldta attempted to force BTA to merge with it. Members from both side allegedly drew pistols and began shooting at each other, but the outnumbered BTA delegation scattered soon after the shooting started. 

The 14 accused allegedly cornered the four BTA taxi owners in their vehicles and kidnapped them. Their bodies were found in a cave in heavy bush near Burgersfort by police four days later.

All four men had had their hands tied behind their backs and had been shot numerous times in the head.

Another BTA taxi driver was also robbed of R1500 cash, which he used as a diversion to escape during the clash on Monday, while BTA treasurer, Abraham Mokgoadi (39) was shot in the leg while escaping out of an office window.

Both men will testify for the State against Lucas Morena, Andries Mmaru, Petros Mosotho, Steven Mhlala, Mathews Magoale, Petro Makanyane, James and John Maopane, April Kgole, Johannes Mashigoane, David Mafiri, Samuel Mathaba and Samson Makofane.

The accused were not asked to plead and were remanded in custody until their case is heard on March 17.

A provincial police spokesperson, Senior Superintendent Phuti Setati, said on Tuesday that the arrests and large police presence in the affected areas was a clear message to the taxi industry that the government was not prepared to tolerate any further violence.

"This shooting and killing of competing drivers is like something out of a gangster movie and we will not tolerate it. Innocent people, attempting to use the taxi's are usually the victims in these Taxi Wars and we cannot allow more death," he said.

Jane Furse taxi rank was clam but tense on Tuesday with police armoured vehicles patrolling the area.

Africa News


March 11, 1997


South Africa;
Elderly labourer suffocates in grain bin


BYLINE: Mzilikazi wa Afrika, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

POTGIETERSRUS - Police announced on Tuesday that they are investigating the possibility of foul play after discovering the body of a 60-year-old labourer at the bottom of a grain tank.

Joel Maphoto's body was discovered under tonnes of grain by a colleague late on Monday night after a week-long intensive search of the area by police and his employer's, NTK Mielies. 

"Maphoto went missing last week and we combed all nearby velds and other open areas but found nothing. Then, apparently by chance, one of his colleagues discovered his body on Monday night when he opened a grain chute," explained Sergeant Ronel Otto.

"The company suspects that he may have climbed up a ladder to the top of the 10-metre high tank to check something and then he may have slipped and fallen in. We are not happy with this explanation and will be investigating further."

Maphoto's body had to be recovered from the grain tank by the Potgietersrus Fire Brigade. No arrests have been made and no charges have been laid.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


257 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 11, 1997


Togo;
CPJ Protests Ban on Togolese Independent Weekly


BYLINE: Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

New York - Text of a letter from William A. Orme, Jr., executive director, Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ), to Prime Minister Edem Kodjo of Togo. March 10, 1997. 

The Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) writes to strongly protest the February 19, 1997 six-month ban of the independent weekly, "Forum Hebdo" and the sentencing in absentia of publisher Gabriel Agah to a one-year prison term and a 1 million francs CFA (US$1,900) fine. To date, Forum Hebdo has not received official word of the publication ban.

As a nonpartisan organization of journalists committed to the defense of our colleagues' rights worldwide, CPJ condemns the ban of Forum Hebdo and the sentencing of Agah as serious violations of press freedom. Furthermore, CPJ believes that imprisonment in no instance constitutes an appropriate response to journalists doing their jobs. These rights are guaranteed by Article 19 of the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights, Article 19 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, and Article 9 of the African Charter on Human and Peoples' Rights, all to which we respectfully remind Your Excellency, Togo is a signatory.

Your Excellency, we urge you to do everything within your power to ensure that the ban on "Forum Hebdo" is immediately and unconditionally removed and that Agah is granted a fair trial. We also urge you to guarantee the protection of journalists' sources and the media's right to practice their profession freely and safely.

Thank you for your attention. We welcome your comments.

For information, contact Committee to Protect Journalists, 330 Seventh Avenue, New York NY 10001, U.S.A. Tel:+1 212 465 1004, Fax:+1 212 465 9568. Kakuna Kerina (x 103), kkerina@cpj.org, or Selam Demeke (x 118), demeke@cpj. org. Internet: http://www.cpj.org/.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

258 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 11, 1997


East Africa;
Emergency Update No. 124 on the Great Lakes (03/11)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2107 words


 

Nairobi - Zairean rebels said today that they were within ten kilometers of Kisangani - the last government stronghold in northeastern Zaire - and that the fall of the city is imminent.

The rebels say that they have closed in on three fronts and will not stop their push until President Mobutu Sese Seko agrees to face-to-face negotiations. The radio station of the rebel Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire (ADFL) said that a corridor had been left open to the west so that civilians and Zairean soldiers from Kisangani could flee.

Leader of the ADFL, Laurent-Desire Kabila told AFP yesterday that his troops had been involved in heavy clashes during their advance on Kisangani. Kabila said that some of his men had infiltrated into Kisangani, the base for the government's counter-offensive. 

The Zairean Ministry of Defence denies rebel claims and said yesterday that the rebels were at least 50 kilometers away from the city. No independent account of the situation around Kisangani was available, but sources say that the area surrounding Kisangani is heavily mined and that the three main approach roads are manned by government forces and mercenaries. The Belgrade daily "Dnevni Telegraf" alledged yesterday that 5,000 Serb mercenaries were fighting alongside the Zairean Army. Many Kisangani civilians, meanwhile, have fled Kisangani at night by road, in dug out canoes or via chartered flights. In spite of rebel claims that the battle for Kisangani is imminent, Belgium's Secretary of State for International Cooperation, Reginald Moreels, arrived today in Kisangani, bringing medical supplies to the city. Zaire Airlines also said it would go ahead with its scheduled flights to Kisangani on Thursday and Saturday.

* Rwandan sources told Reuters that the two top commanders of the ex-FAR, who have been fighting alongside the Zairean Army, fled Kisangani for Kinshasa last week. Major-General Augustine Bizimungu, commander of Rwanda's ousted 40,000 strong army and his deputy and director of combat operations, Brigadier-General Gratien Kabiligi reportedly left Kisangani to restock supplies for their troops, but did not return.

* France's President Jacques Chirac today urged the international community to press for a ceasefire in Zaire and to help the thousands of refugees standed in the fighting. AFP says that diplomatic sources believe France wants the United States, in particular, to apply pressure on Kabila to halt his offensive. Kabila agreed in principle at the weekend to a five point UN peace plan which calls for a ceasefire and the immediate withdrawal of foreign troops, including mercenaries. Kabila has not agreed to a ceasefire but said he would not attack the town of Ubundu, 100 kilometers south of Kisangani, where tens of thousands of Rwandan refugees have arrived. Most of the refugees are from Tingi-Tingi camp which housed 160,000 - 170,000 refugees before it was overrun by rebels last month.

* Heavy rains have begun to fall in eastern Zaire, a factor which western military experts believe may slow down the rebel advance, but will ultimately affect government troops more than the rebels, reports AFP. At the same time, many roads will be impassable and there are concerns that this will hamper plans to set up corridors through rebel-held terriority to facilitate repatriation of Rwandan refugees. Relief agencies said yesterday that they were mounting a relief operation within the next few days in Tingi-Tingi following an inter-agency UN/NGO mission on Sunday. The condition of refugees in Tingi-Tingi is reported to be very poor. Some 400,000 refugees are estimated to be in eastern Zaire: many of them are unaccounted for and are believed to be hiding in the forests. An unknown, but large number, of Zaireans have also been displaced by the fighting and are in need of assistance.

As part of efforts to assist refugees emerging from the jungle, a way station has been set up by UNHCR in Kinguluba town further to the east towards Rwanda. The station is manned by 10 relief workers, including two UNHCR staff. Stocks of high protein biscuits and medicines have been pre- positioned at the station. A team is also being sent north of Kinguluba to investigate reports of a large number of refugees gathering in Nzofu.

* President Mobutu will return to Zaire from southern France before the end of the week for talks on the crisis, said an aide. Mobutu returned to France on 21 February - his third visit since undergoing surgery for prostate cancer last August.

* AFP reports that Kabila was hailed as a saviour when he visited Kindu yesterday in what was his furthest visit into the interior since his rebel forces seized swathes of Zaire. Kindu fell to the ADLF on 2 March. In Kindu, Kabila said that his troops had taken Moba in southeast Zaire on Sunday - the last government-held port on Lake Tanganyika. Moise Nyarugabo, a senior official in the rebel leadership, told AFP that Moba had been defended mainly by Burundian rebels loyal to CNDD/FDD leader, Leonard Nyangoma. There has been no independent confirmation that Moba had fallen.

The Zairean currency, the new Zaire (NZ), is reported to have appreciated sharply against the US dollar in Kindu since the rebel take-over. Residents dealing in the black market told AFP that the dollar was going for around 80, 000 NZ against 150,000 NZ - the level before the city fell. The NZ is running at same rate (80,000 NZ per US dollar) in Goma, the centre of the rebellion.

* Emma Bonino, EU Commissioner for Humanitarian Affairs, is reported to have said that humanitarian aid in eastern Zaire should not discriminate between the refugees and members of the armed militia. Bonino is quoted as saying at a press conference in Geneva that it was "not our job to be judges" and that assistance should be provided to those who are suffering " whether or not they are criminals or perpetrators of genocide".

* The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees said yesterday that allegations by the Zairean Government that the agency's withdrawal from Kisangani had led to thousands of deaths were "simply groundless". In a communique issued 4 March, the Zairean Government alledged that the departure of humanitarian workers from Tingi-Tingi and Kisangani led to the deaths of 25,000 people. On the same day an expulsion order was issued to those UN and NGO workers who had left.

UNHCR said that the expulsion was "unfair and unjustified" and rejected Zaire's allegations that it had left Kisangani for no good reason. In a statement issued in Geneva yesterday the High Commissioner, Sadako Ogata, said UNHCR staff "have always taken risks, often substantial risks but they have to remain within reason." Two UNHCR local staff returned to Kisangani at the weekend to assist in relief distributions to refugees gathering in Ubundu and international staff will be fielded in Punia/Ubundu. UNHCR is also planning to return to the now rebel contolled area of Tingi-Tingi.

* The Kenya government is probing the airlifting last week of more than 100 Burundian and Zairean refugees to Kenya. UNHCR has screened the group to determine refugee status. The Daily Nation reported today that sources said another 100 arrived at Wilson airport yesterday, but that this was denied by the government. Amnesty International, meanwhile, has urged the Kenya Government not to return the refugees to Zaire or to their countries of origin.

* Zambian authorities say that Zairean soldiers who have crossed into Zambia with refugees are causing security problems in the country. " Disillusioned" soldiers are reportedly looting villages and selling arms to survive. The soldiers are said to be heading towards Zambia's Copperbelt province - the hub of Zambia's economy. Some 700 refugees who have entered the country are also unaccounted for, further fuelling concerns that the situation is beyond the government's control. Some 2,200 refugees are reported by local authorities to have arrived in Zambia between October and February. News sources say that relations between Zambia and Zaire, which have been shaky, could plummet further unless the refugee situation is contained. Zambia has complained to Kinshasa on numerous occasions about acts of banditry committed by Zairean nationals. Zairean diplomats have also been accused of giving refuge to the refugees and smuggling.

* The Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA) claims to have taken control of the towns of Kaya and Gumuli in southern Sudan and to be advancing towards Juba, the regional capital. Army spokesman, Major General Mohammed al Sanousi Ahmed claimed on state-run radio that Kaya was first attacked on Sunday by the Ugandan Army who then handed over the town to the SPLA. Uganda's Foreign Minister, Eriya Kategaya denied the claim. The town of Kaya is reported to have been a base for the West Nile Bank Front (WNBF) rebels destablising western Uganda. Uganda's Government-owned daily newspaper, the New Vision reported today that the SPLA claimed to have killed 200 Sudanese troops, rebels from the WNBF and the Uganda National Rescue Front II - a splinter group of the WNBF -in their offensive. The New Vision reported yesterday that the SPLA had also taken control of Foki, Kimba, and Bazi along Sudan's border with Zaire.

* The typhus epidemic first signalled by WHO authorities in Burundi in early February is reported to be spreading. The government regroupment villages are said to be hardest hit because of overcrowding and poor sanitation and health structures. In some villages, as many as 500 to 1,000 new cases are reported daily. Worst hit areas are the provinces of Kayanza, Muramvua and Karuzi. WHO believes some 340,000 people are at risk and that if the epidemic is unchecked it could evolve into the largest typhus outbreak since World War II. WHO has flown in 150,000 tablets to treat typhus cases; however the related issues of sanitation and health conditions will have to be addressed immediately in order to contain the epidemic.

* Female circumcision is performed in more than half of the 46 African countries that are members of WHO, says a WHO report released in Brazzaville yesterday. The report says that more than 100 million women in sub-Saharan Africa are currently affected by sexual mutilation in the form of circumcision. Those affected include young girls between the ages of five and ten. In the Great Lakes region, circumcision is practised in Kenya, Tanzania, Uganda and Zaire. WHO will be launching on 17 March a regional plan to accelerate the elimination of female circumcision.

Nairobi, 11 March 1997, 19:03 GMT

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. UN DHA IRIN Tel: +254 2 622123 Fax: +254 2 622129 e-mail: irin@dha.unon.org for more information. If you re-print, copy, archive or re-post this item, please retain this credit and disclaimer.)


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


259 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 11, 1997


South Africa;
Labour's Approach To The 1997/8 Budget


BYLINE: Congress of South African Trade Unions (COSATU)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2347 words


 

Johannesburg - Statement by Mbhazima Shilowa, COSATU General Secretary, March 11 1997.

The test to be applied to tomorrows budget, and indeed future budgets, is the extent to which it is being used as an instrument for transformation. The budget is not an event, nor a technical accounting exercise, but part of an ongoing attempt to shift the social and economic priorities in our country.

It is in this context that the budget will be assessed, not through a narrow examination of statistics and figures. It is not only the issue of 'how much', but the real question is 'for what', and 'how effectively' the resources are being deployed. 

On 23 March 1995 in a submission to the Parliamentary Joint Standing Committee on finance, COSATU had this to say about the 1995/6 budget: "When compared to previous apartheid budgets, the 1995/6 budget does have a number of positive features. Judged in terms of the fundamental shift required by the RDP, however, the budget fails to deliver. At best the budget can be described as a transitional budget. We have yet to see our first RDP budget".

The previous budgets as presented by Derek Keys and Chris Liebenberg had one thing in common. Their credentials while acceptable to the business community, were questionable within the broad progressive movement. While they took their mandate from the cabinet, they had very little or no political authority.

In that sense, the 1997/8 budget is different. The Finance Minister is part of the majority party in the GNU. Labour and the majority of people expect a different budget from him which should underpin the government's commitment to RDP goals and objectives, taking into account the prevailing situation.

Previous budgets particularly prior to 1990, were characterised by mismanagement by the National Party. Of course that is my view. They would argue otherwise. What is the evidence? The experience of our people are:

- Huge inequalities in society: in wealth, income, basic services, infrastructure.

- Expenditure was used to entrench minority rule.

- Public utilities and parastatals provided services and jobs primarily for whites.

- The army and police budgets grew. Not for real law and order situations, but to deny basic political, social and economic rights to the majority, and hence maintain apartheid.

- The tax burden was consistently shifted from the rich to the poor.

While I do not agree with the National Party philosophy, one thing is clear: They demonstrated beyond any reasonable doubt that the budget is an important instrument for policy implementation at various levels. That is what we would want to see this Government demonstrate rather than merely perform an accounting exercise.

The current debate on the budget, have tended to focus on the size of the budget deficit. Targets which were arbitrarily set are then used as yard sticks of success or otherwise of the budget. Constraints on the new government are then used to define our new approach. In my view, while not dismissing the constraints as inherited, I believe that we can develop a different approach. This approach seeks to redefine the debates as focusing on challenges, possibilities and opportunities. In other words, we should acknowledge the existing constraints, but should not allow them to paralyse our approach.

What therefore is our approach to this year's budget? We need to set out clear yard sticks to measure the progressiveness or otherwise of the budget. These should include its approach to:

- Employment creation

- Allocation of resources to social needs

- Elimination of inequalities within society

- Housing

- Land Reform

- Redistribution of wealth and income

- Developing Human Capital

More important, we should judge the relationship between revenue and expenditure. The government can choose to move forward in a progressive way, retain the status quo or regress. Some points on Revenue and Expenditure:

Revenue

Progressiveness would entail a relook at the taxation regime.

- More zero rating for basic goods including water, medicines and foodstuffs

- Multiple VAT rating

- Introduce capital gains tax

- Shift the tax burden away from the poor to the rich and corporations We all know what the consequences of retaining the status quo and regressive taxation will be since this is what we are already sitting with. Inequalities will continue and even widen. The poor will continue to bear the brunt of transformation and subsidise the rich. This is something we should avoid.

Expenditure

In this area, progressiveness would entail an increase in social spending, public works, projects for employment creation rather than a cut. Furthermore there needs to be redistribution and reallocation across provinces particularly the rural areas.

Let me now give two of the critical tests we will apply on the budget, to determine whether it is appropriate for our times and our society's needs or not.

Employment Creation

There is a view that budgets or governments don't create jobs.

- We challenge that view. We accept that Governments are not the only player in the job creation process but it is a very critical player in employment creation. Not only are Government the largest employer, but the way in which they allocate resources can determine whether or not we boost the economy and thereby create jobs.

There are two elements to this, which we will test:

a) Firstly does the budget create new jobs - we have put forward proposals on housing and public works programmes, which in our view will stimulate the creation of more than 500 000 jobs. This requires that money be made available though a new housing parastatal. We will look at whether the rolled over funds, and additional funds set aside for 1997/8 starts to address both the quality of public resources, and also the institutional arrangement. We will look at whether a special 3 year levy on the profits of corporations set at say 5% will be introduced, to help finance the housing / public works programme. We are willing to look at a set timespan of say 2-3 years for its implementation. This should include a prescribed asset investment commitment by workers using pension and provident funds.

b) Secondly, does the budget destroy current jobs - the budget's impact on current employment is through the allocation of spending in health, education, etc. It is affected by budget deficit targets - smaller government spending on non-debt categories generally imply fewer jobs. Some restructuring of the public sector on the lines supported by labour, may result in redundancies in the old beuracracy, but equally, our proposals for improvement in social services will permit a major increase in new jobs, which will offset this. We will carefully evaluate what balance the budget produces in this area of job creation and job security.

This implies that we should combine employment creation for new entrants and the unemployed as well as employment security for those provviding a public service.

2. Social Equity

One of the features of apartheid was the production of major income inequalities in society. On the measure of the gini-co-efficient, South Africa is one of the most unequal societies in the world.

This is the legacy of National Party rule, which we expect current government to address. This year's budget can either.

- reduce these inequalities

- maintain them at current levels

- increase the inequalities

Tools available to the government are both in the area of revenue and expenditure. I am sure that they will want to remove inequalities. If they do want to reduce inequalities, they would need to do the following:.

* introduce a capital gains tax - something which will not be unique to South Africa.

* set a 55% tax rate on "the super rich"

* tax luxury goods at a higher VAT rate

* increase levels of corporate tax, which have been systematically reduced in recent years

* close loopholes used by the wealthy in South Africa to reduce their tax liabilities

* introduce a levy on the profits of companies to finance housing and public works

* increase spending on housing, health - care and education (since these are public services and goods which are of disproportional benefit to the poor)

On the other hand, a failure to implement the above will retain or increase the current inequalities.

Further, proposals which:

* increase the VAT on basic goods

* decrease corporate tax

* decrease the effective tax of wealthy citizen

* removes exchange controls and hence allow domestic holders of wealth to move it off-shore (beyond the effective reach of government)

* cuts the levels of social spending, Will have the effect of increasing the levels of social inequalities.

Budget Deficit

We remain opposed to the current way in which budget deficit management is being approached. They have committed themselves to a reduction of 5,1%; 4% etc. We should mobilise the public to understand that budget deficit management is not a mathematical equation. It will result in a cut in social spending, choke the economy, destroy jobs etc. It should be clear on the other hand that we are not opposed to debt management, if it doesn't 'kill the goose that lays the golden egg', ie stifle economic development and narrow the tax base.

Process

In this year's budget, while there was better participation in NEDLAC by labour on broad parameters, there was very little or no participation on the specific issues of the budget. For the 1998/9 budget we need to ensure involvement from the beginning right to the end. From the time when national priorities are set to when Provinces make their allocation. We also need to encourage our Regions to engage with Provincial governments to ensure that they remain focused to national priorities. If multi-year budgeting is finally introduced, the participation of workers in the process will be even more critical, as budgets will be set, not for one, but several years.

This is the challenge we face. It is the challenge that the government can rise to or fail, and thereby address or shatter the hopes of the majority of citizens.

Issued by Nowetu Mpati, COSATU Head of Communications, Tel: + 27 + 11 + 339- 4911 Fax: + 27 + 11 + 339-2281 E-mail: nowetu@cosatu.org.za.

Africa News


March 11, 1997


South Africa;
Bid battle triggers crime blitz


BYLINE: Michael Morris, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Cape Town - Crime-busting is about to get going in Cape Town in a big way as the city moves to overturn international perceptions about the crime threat ahead of the September election of the host city for the 2004 Olympic Games.

Concerns about the implications of South Africa's high crime rate have emerged as a threat to the city's chances.

In fact the bid has turned out to be the catalyst of a range of practical initiatives to be launched in the next few weeks, not just to boost policing but to deal with the roots of crime to ensure steady, long-term gains. 

These include:

* Establishing, by the end of the month, a Business Against Crime unit, under a board of 15 to 20 top city executives and a full-time chief executive officer, to channel private-sector expertise and resources into the anti- crime drive.

* Launching the first projects under the Integrated Planning Group, formed last year, aimed chiefly at the roots of crime.

The group - comprising "accountable deciders" from the police, army, intelligence, courts, prisons, the city and province, and business - is to meet for a summit next month.

Projects under this initiative include a programme for rehabilitation of street children; installation of closed-circuit TV in the city centre as a deterrent and policing aid; and the deployment of extra police in the city centre, paid for by business.

And a UN "Safe Cities" pilot project to be launched in Cape Town is expected to invest significant international expertise in crime prevention. All these initiatives fall under the National Crime Prevention Strategy of the Department of Safety and Security.

Additional, related initiatives are:

* Establishing a metropolitan operations centre to manage and co-ordinate the responses of police, traffic officials, ambulance and fire services, hospitals, transport authorities and city officials to every incident in the course of mass events - anything from a hurricane to the Games.

* Formulating a "quality assurance checklist" - essentially a tool to provide a comprehensive risk analysis for any big event.

* Formulating an "operational manual" on the integrated management of big sports or other events. This deals with everything from security to protocol.

Cape Town's Olympic bid is the catalyst for most of the initiatives, and is likely to enhance their impact.

Africa News


March 11, 1997


Sports - General;
Desmond Haynes: 26 000 runs on the opener closes his innings


BYLINE: John Freudenberg, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1027 words


 

Cape Town - Cricket has a habit of saying farewell to its legends in often incongruous fashion. Here was Desmond Haynes, a veteran of 116 test matches and the scorer of about 26 000 first-class runs, bowing out of the game at a sparse Newlands on Sunday after making a duck in his farewell innings.

As he left the field, Haynes acknowledged the warm response from a small but loyal crowd of Western Province supporters, ripped off his headband and hurled it into a throng of eager children in the Oaks area, and trotted up the steps to the dressing room.

That was it - the end of a 20-year career which began in Montego Bay in the Caribbean and ended on the other side of the world in Cape Town. 

A day earlier in East London, Peter Kirsten had closed an illustrious chapter before a few hundred people at Buffalo Park after his Border team were whipped by the touring Australians.

A majestic century before a packed stadium would have been a more appropriate exit for both, but cricket makes no allowance for reputation. Haynes at least made a curtain call. Flashing his ever-engaging smile, the 41- year-old emerged on to the balcony outside the Province dressing room and began dispensing with more items of his kit - gloves, T-shirts, even a jock- strap - to a swelling young crowd below.

"It's nice to think that somebody will be keeping a part of me here after I've left," chuckled 41-year-old Haynes afterwards.

Twenty years ago he began his first-class career with Barbados in a match against Jamaica, making nine after being dismissed lbw by Michael Holding, one of the game's greatest pacemen.

At Newlands against Natal on Sunday, Haynes lasted three balls before edging a ball from Gary Gilder, one of South Africa's most promising pacemen, to slip.

It summed up how his career had spanned a generation and many countries. " Not in my wildest dreams would I have imagined that my career would end in South Africa," he said.

Haynes has spent three seasons in Cape Town as overseas professional with Western Province where he opened the batting, adding stability to what was once an often brittle top-order and leaving it as arguably the strongest on the provincial scene.

He leaves for England this weekend to fulfil coaching commitments with English county side Sussex, where he also coached last year. But his playing days are over and Haynes admitted it hadn't quite yet sunk in.

He almost had to be reminded that he had played 376 first-class games. " That's a lot of games isn't it?" he remarked.

"You know, cricket has been very good to me, so it will be hard to just stay away from it after playing for so long and enjoying so many benefits," Haynes said.

"I'd like to get involved in encouraging young people to let them know that if you are successful you can make a living from this game."

But if cricket has been a living for Haynes, golf is his passion and will help fill the void now that he has packed his pads and bats away.

Whatever lies in store on the golf course, it will be hard for him to match his achievements on the cricket fields of the world. Haynes was as much a reason for the success of the all-conquering West Indian team of the 1980s and early 1990s as their fearsome quartet of fast bowlers.

His opening batting combination with fellow Barbadian Gordon Greenidge was the most enduring in the history of test cricket, the pair having faced the new ball together in 89 tests for an average first-wicket stand of 47,3.

In limited-overs internationals, Haynes remains the highest run-scorer ever with 8 648 runs from 238 matches, including 17 hundreds.

In his three seasons with Western Province, he took a while to crack a first-class hundred for his adopted team, until he finally passed the three- figure mark with an unbeaten 202 against Eastern Province in Port Elizabeth in January. But he's never had so many dismissals in the nineties as he has had during his time with Province.

What has given Haynes the most satisfaction, though, is to see the progress of some of the young Province batsmen who have graduated from rookies into genuine match-winners - and in some case, into test players - during his time here.

"It's been very pleasing to see the progress of batsmen such as Jacques Kallis, H D Ackerman, Sven Koenig and Herschelle Gibbs," said Haynes, who is modest about his own input into their development. "I've given a little advice and encouragement."

Just for these young players to share a partnership with Haynes must be an education in itself. He also made special mention of wicketkeeper Paul Kirsten.

Haynes has no regrets. He's had a good innings and although he would have liked to have scored at least nine runs on Sunday- he made nine on his debut for Barbados - he had made 83 against Natal in the first innings.

And, after all, the greatest batsman of all time - Sir Don Bradman - also bowed out with a duck.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


March 11, 1997


Business and Finance;
Duty evasion, smuggling costs South Africa


BYLINE: Llewelly Jones, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Cape Town - Customs duty evasion and poor policing of consumer electronic imports is costing the state at least R2,5 billion in lost customs revenue each year, says Chris de Bruin, the chief executive of Seartec.

"It is difficult to put an exact number on the lost revenue, but it is certainly considerable," Mr De Bruin said.

"I would say the country loses at least R2,5 billion to evasion of duties and straight smuggling." 

Seartec, a subsidiary of Seardel, imports Sharp electronic goods.

Duty evasion occurs mainly on audio and video products because they attract the highest import duties of all electronic goods.

One of the biggest scams of unscrupulous importers is the manipulation of values of goods to avoid paying duties. They do this by declaring major items which carry higher duties at under cost price while inflating the value of lower duty items.

The problem has become so bad that some legitimate distributors of electronic brands are said to be resorting to buying their own products from third party importers.

Mr De Bruin said Seartec had not and would not do this.

"I venture to say we are one of the few companies left doing business legitimately," he said.

Last week, 16 of the 18 members of the Consumer Electronics Association signed a minimum values agreement with the Customs Department in an effort to stamp out duty evasion through misrepresenting the value of imported goods. The agreement details the minimum possible prices for imported electronic goods.

Renier van Rooyen, the managing director of Hicor, said he could not see how goods could be imported for less than these minimum values.

Hicor retails electronic goods through Audiovision, Audiolens and Hitronix, and wholesales audio and video products through Hi-Fi Specialists.

But it is the build-up of confiscated goods that most worries Mr Van Rooyen.

While it was nowhere near that found in the clothing and textile industry where the build-up of confiscated goods was threatening the entire industry, the theft of electronic goods from Government warehouses was making business very difficult for some wholesalers.

"As a retailer, we have been offered goods at 40 percent to 50 percent of their value ," Mr Van Rooyen said.

Both Mr De Bruin and Mr Van Rooyen agree that the only way to stop the evasion and smuggling is to scrap the duties, or to reduce it to a level that would make it more profitable to pay them than evade them.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

March 11, 1997


South Africa;
Long jail terms for killers


BYLINE: Dennis Cavernelis, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Cape Town - A man and a teenager who murdered three black Hermanus residents in a drunken killing orgy were today given heavy jail sentences.

Mr Justice J H Conradie jailed former bank teller Wilfred Jordaan, 26, of Panorama for an effective 25 years and six months, and a 17-year-old former security guard from Hermanus for 22 years. 

Evidence in their Cape High Court trial was that on September 2 1995, the pair went on a "jol" to "donder a few kaffirs".

They murdered Catherine de Wet, Eric Mjikiliso and Nkosana Bushula by bludgeoning them and crushing their skulls with a steering wheel lock.

After assaulting Ms De Wet, Jordaan drove over her and after Mr Bushula was beaten, Jordaan stabbed him six times and drove over his body.

The pair were also convicted of assaulting Richmond Qwathikazi with intent to do grievous bodily harm.

Jordaan was sentenced to 24 years' imprisonment on each of the murder charges and 18 months on the assault charge. The teenager received 21 years for each of the murders and was sentenced to a further year for assault. The murder sentences are to run concurrently.

Mr Justice Conradie said there was no doubt the teenager had been the instigator of the attacks - he had suggested that they "donder a few kaffirs" - but Jordaan had not needed much persuasion to join him.

"Crime destabilises society ... the accused are a danger to society," said Judge Conradie. "These are young people before me, their lives lie ahead of them.

"In spite of their gruesome deeds I cannot say that they do not deserve a chance to be a part of society one day."
