March 11, 1997


South Africa;
Manuel's first Budget (Editorial)


BYLINE: Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

Cape Town - With little room for manoeuvre, and with many competing interests to satisfy, Finance Minister Trevor Manuel is to deliver his first budget in parliament tomorrow.

When Finance Minister Trevor Manuel was appointed last year, some feared that this signalled the end of fiscal prudence. But he has consistently promised to gradually reduce the huge deficits he inherited from the apartheid years and there is no reason to doubt that he will maintain this position when he delivers his first budget in Parliament tomorrow.

At the same time, though, he faces increasingly urgent demands from an electorate which needs convincing that the new government can really offer a better life for all. Can he improve social welfare without increasing the mass of taxes and without deepening government's indebtedness?

It is a tall order by an standard and the business lobby, as vocal in its call for fiscal prudence as it is for tougher measures against crime, would do well to understand the conflicting pressures Mr Manuel is up against.

These conflicting pressures are reflected sharply in the argument between business and the unions over over the vexed issue of VAT.

Business would like Mr Manuel to raise VAT and to do away with exemptions on essential items to finance necessary government spending.

But the trade unions, conscious of the effects this would have on their poorest members, are hostile to the idea.

Clearly Mr Manuel cannot please all sides tomorrow and rather than pull any rabbits out of his hat, he is likely to steer a course between the economy's many competing interests and maintain the cautious approach which has slowly won him the confidence of the financial markets and the respect of his colleagues.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


265 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 11, 1997


South Africa;
Cops hold city gang


BYLINE: Johan Schronen and Joseph Aranes, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 800 words


 

Cape Town - Police believe they have broken the back of attacks on tourists in central Cape Town with the arrest of a gang of young "habitual criminals".

The gang of children and teenagers between 12 and 18 allegedly operated a syndicate that has been linked to a wide range of crime, including street muggings.

Their arrests have coincided with a marked drop in attacks on tourists and others in the city, especially after dark.

Police also say the number of attacks on tourists has steadily declined over the past two years as they and business communities in tourist centres have increased their vigilance . 

Recent statistics of reported robberies and assaults on overseas visitors in the Cape Town central business district, the riskiest zone for tourists, showed only 0,02 percent of all foreigners visiting the city - one in 5 000 - were affected.

Western Cape police commissioner Leon Wessels has reported a significant reduction in tourist muggings.

Given a 28 percent increase in the numbers of foreign visitors to Cape Town between 1995 and last year, the 16 percent decrease in attacks was even more significant.

Records of attacks on tourists over the recent holiday period have also shown a marked drop.

Cape Town detective George Cook said the arrested gang was made up of " habitual criminals", some as young as 12. Some had as many as 20 allegations of robbery and theft against them.

Sergeant Cook said that until recently it had been difficult to keep the suspects behind bars, but thorough research into their criminal backgrounds had helped him prove in court they were habitual criminals, leading to their detention.

Although they were young, "the community needs to be protected against them and they need to face up to their deeds, the sooner the better, so that they can be rehabilitated and a get a chance of a new life before they get too old, " he said.

"Today's petty thief who rips a gold chain from a tourist's neck and sells it for R5 is tomorrow's burglar and next year's armed robber.

"For the first time we are able to keep them inside. Up to now they were in and out of places of safety, but now their long lists of crimes have caught up with them," said Sergeant Cook. He cautioned that the streets were "by no means free of crime" and there were still elements, mostly homeless children, who were not put off by the fate of the arrested gang.

Another gang of marauding street children has struck since the arrests, their victims an elderly German couple.

Alexander Freywald of D/sseldorf and his wife were window-shopping in St George's Mall this week when they were approached by a child of "no older than nine".

"He asked us for money and we refused. The next thing I heard my wife shouting and the young scoundrel made off with her gold necklace," Mr Freywald said.

He gave chase and with the help of a passerby apprehended the boy, only to find that he no longer had the necklace.

They decided to march him to the police depot in Adderley Street, but as they rounded the corner in Darling Street they were confronted by about 20 of the thief's friends, who demanded they free him.

Fearing for their lives, they reluctantly released the boy.

Captour head Gordon Oliver said the tourism industry acknowledged the problem of attacks on holidaymakers but criticised the negative picture being presented.

Mr Oliver urged the community to be partners with the police against crime.

"We must do something about the crime threat to our visitors and then go on spending our energy promoting our city to the outside world."


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March 12, 1997


Science and Health;
Scientists Seek Wines In The Zimbabwean Wild


BYLINE: Takesure Matarise, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1120 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - A wild fruit popular in Zimbabwe for - among other things - making an illicit, highly potent brew called Kachasu, has been found by scientists to have biological qualities useful to the economy.

The fruits, locally known as Masawu and whose scientific name is Ziziphus Mauritania, are the main element in the making of Kachasu or Nubian gin, often brewed locally in uncontrolled conditions for liquor with alcohol content as high as 100 percent.

Police often battle with the illicit gin brewers and drinkers. Often they are rounded up and have to pay fines for either purveying or taking the highly toxic beverage, whose final brew is mostly said to contain hazardous heavy metals. 

But now the Scientific and Industrial Research and Development Center (SIRDC) says the Masawu fruits contain strong micro-organisms, which can be widely used in food fermentation technologies, as they yield the necessary yeasts.

"We might presently be using very mild yeast in making bread and brewing beer, while there is abundant Masawu, with very high alcohol levels," says Joseph Gopo, a SIRDC director.

Gopo told the Zimbabwe Inter Africa News Agency, ZIANA, that at least six micro-organisms constituting lactic bacteria and yeasts, used in fermentation, had been identified in masawu, freely found in abundance in Zimbabwe's forests.

Two other wild fruits, Mazhanje (Uapacha Kirkiana) and Mahacha (Parinari Curatellifolia) have also been found to have useful micro-organisms.

"Micro-organisms from Mazhanje and Mahacha can produce very nice wine, but at the moment why can't we go into a shop and buy such wine?" said Gopo.

These fruits are only a few of those included in a study by the World Association of Industrial and Technological Research Organization (WAITRO), which intends to promote technology for traditional African fermented foods.

WAITRO and SIRDC scientists are making efforts to produce a set of guidelines to monitor, evaluate, and control the fermentation process for basic staple foods in selected countries, as well as good codes of hygienic conduct for local processors.

The scientists believe that such fruits as Masawu could have their yeast put to good use with the products made under control.

"You can have a controlled level of toxicity and have a product which your blood can tolerate," said Gopo.

Zimbabwe's minister of state in the president's office responsible for indigenization, Cephas Msipa, apparently agrees that such measures could be useful.

"We could, for instance, find ways of improving the brewing of Kachasu to make it a safe, and good quality product for export," Msipa said recently at a seminar in Harare on food fermentation technologies.

He also encouraged the use of scientific technology in the production, at a commercial level, of other traditional Zimbabwe foods, using fermentation.

Deputy secretary general of WITRO, Moses Mengu, backed Msipa's view, saying fermented foods constitute a very important and dominant part of the diet for many Africans.

"Processing is still predominantly based on traditional methods which increasingly have to meet the needs of an expanding food market especially in urban centers," said Mengu, who is based in Copenhagen, Denmark

Thus, he said, the risks for contamination, poor quality, and food-borne infections had also increased.

The SIRDC director-general who is also WAITRO's representative in Africa, Christopher Chetsanga, said the biotechnology research institute of SIRDC has taken upon itself to do a study of some of the traditional fermented foods in Zimbabwe, especially those that are almost forgotten.

According to him, African food is "conspicuous by its absence" internationally.

"Is it not a pity that one can purchase from virtually any supermarket in Zimbabwe - both urban and remotest rural - European and Asian traditional foods like spaghetti, macaroni and rice, whilst most of our own typical African foods are not available in our local shops, let alone in international markets?

"In spite of that, there are many benefits that can be derived from fermented foods. Fermentation forms an important technique for preserving several types of foods, like vegetables, milk, fish, sausages, tea, coffee, cocoa, beans and cereals, in most parts of the world," Chetsanga said.

The biotechnology research institute's study, he said, was in line with developing expertise and providing services in food processing to enable community enterprises and the food industry to improve zimbabwe's agricultural commodities.

Zimbabwe is one of the countries participating in a three-year WAITRO/SIRDC project started in 1994, which aims at establishing research into traditional fermentation methods and to introduce quality systems into the traditional African food industry.

The project, which is being funded by the European Commission, is in its final year and also involves scientists from institutions in Denmark, Germany, Burkina Faso, Ghana, Kenya, Nigeria and Tanzania.

The scientists intend to encourage small-scale producers of traditional fermented foods to introduce the concept of quality in their production.

Their ultimate goal is to see small-scale producers commercializing traditional fermented foods of good quality.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


267 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 12, 1997


Sierra Leone;
Nigerian Army Confirms Sankoh's Presence In The Country


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - The Nigerian defence headquarters confirmed Tuesday in Lagos the presence in the country of Foday Sankoh, leader of Sierra Leone's rebel Revolutionary United Front (RUF).

The acting defence spokesman, Col. Godwin Ugbo, told journalists that Sankoh arrived in the country last week. 

But he dismissed a newspaper report that Sankoh entered the country with ammunition and that he had been taken into custody.

Ugbo explained that Sankoh had passed through airport formalities hitch- free.

"He's not in detention and he's not a threat to our security," Ugbo said, adding that Sankoh was staying at a federal government guest house.

"The RUF leader is free to enter into the country as a West African national," Ugbo added.

He said Sankoh had recognized the government in Sierra Leone and could not be regarded as a rebel leader anymore.

Ugbo did not say how long Sankoh would be staying in Nigeria.

The RUF has been waging a bush war against the Freetown government over the past six years.

Both sides signed a peace agreement in Cote d'Ivoire in November 199 to end the war, in which at least 15,000 people died.

Nigeria and Sierra Leone signed a military pact in Lagos last week for the training of that country's military personnel.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


268 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 12, 1997


Nigeria;
Nobel Laureate, 15 Others Charged With Treason


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 547 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Sixteen Nigerians, among them exiled nobel literature laureate Wole Soyinka, were charged with treason Wednesday before a chief magistrate's court in Lagos.

They are accused of conspiracy and bomb explosions, between May 1995 and Feb. 10 1997, to overthrow Nigeria's military government of Gen. Sani Abacha.

Nigeria has witnessed a series of bomb explosions, including three in recent months in Lagos, which killed at least three soldiers and injured scores more. 

The treason charge sheet alleged that the men conspired "to cause explosion in various parts of Nigeria in order to intimidate and over-awe the head of state of the Federal Republic of Nigeria."

Soyinka, who fled the country in 1994, was charged in absentia, along with Amos Arogundade, and two officials of NADECO, the opposition National Democratic Coalition. So too were Alani Akinrinade, a retired army general, and Anthony Enahoro.

The 12 other accused were in court to hear the charge. They included NADECO leaders Olu Falae and Fredrick Fasheun.

Treason carries the death sentence in Nigeria.

Nigerian authorities have accused NADECO and the National Liberation Council of Nigeria, led by Soyinka, of being behind acts of terrorism, including the recent bomb blasts.

The groups, which are waging a campaign to end military rule in Nigeria, are also accused of being behind a pirate radio station which transmits anti- government messages and programes to Nigeria on a shortwave frequency.

Lagos human rights campaigner Gani Fewehinmi is leading a team of nine lawyers in defence of the accused.

One of the lawyers, Femi Falana, told the court it lacked jurisdiction to hear the case.

He also claimed that the alleged offenses were being made known in court for the first time to his clients.

Arguing for bail on behalf of his clients, Falana asked the court to note that while the suspects were in detention, there had been a series of bomb blasts in the country.

Prosecuting Police Superintendent Nuhu Ribadu objected to bail. He said the accused would jump bail.

Chief Magistrate Betty Lufadeju said even though a section of Nigeria's criminal procedure law permitted the court to grant bail, "this is not applicable in this case because it is a capital offence."

Therefore, she dismissed the bail application and ordered the accused to be remanded in police custody. The case adjourned till May 9.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


269 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 12, 1997


United States and Africa;
Hillary Clinton Begins Africa Tour Saturday


BYLINE: Olu Sarr, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - United States first lady Hillary Clinton begins a six-nation Africa tour Saturday aimed at highlighting the progress these countries have made in consolidating democracy, the Press Attache at U.S. Cultural Center said Wednesday.

The official, Karen Sullivan, said Clinton had been asked by her husband, President Bill Clinton, and by the Department of State to make the trip.

By undertaking this tour, Sullivan said, Clinton will also be restating " her commitment to the well-being of children," the empowerment of women, children's programmes, human rights, and to social investment such as in education, health care, and micro-enterprises. 

She begins her visit with Senegal where, as in the other countries on her itinerary, she will inspect projects funded by local and international non- governmental organizations such as Tostaan, Unicef, the American Jewish Worlds Service, and by the United States Agency for International Development.

Clinton is due to meet Senegalese President Abdou Diouf, visit a former slave holding station on the Island of Goree, three kilometers West of Dakar, in the Atlantic Ocean.

In the town of Thies, 70 kilometers east of Dakar, she will Monday visit a women's literacy program run by the American non-governmental agency, Tostaan. Then, visit the Peace Corps training center in the same town.

After her two-day visit to Senegal, she leaves Monday for Johannesburg, South Africa; Zimbabwe, Tanzania, Uganda and Eritrea, in that order.

She is accompanied by a strong delegation comprising members of her office, White House officials -- among them George Moose. He was the former U.S. ambassador to Senegal and is now the assistant secretary of state for African affairs. Another member of the delegation will be Carol Peasley, the assistant director for Africa of USAID.

The state-owned Ugandan newspaper, New Vision, reported Wednesday that Clinton was due in Kampala late March.

"I don't have the itinerary yet but I know that the First Lady will be in Kampala on March 28," said Judy Butterman, the U.S. Embassy spokesperson in Kampala, on Tuesday.

The newspaper quoted foreign ministry sources as saying that Clinton would also meet Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni and address women leaders in the country.

She will visit women projects run by NGOs, one of them the American Foundation for International Community Assistance, FINCA. This is a microcredit agency assisting women in 10 districts including Kampala, Mukono, Jinja, and Mpigi.

"According to sources, Mrs Clinton will visit FINCA because it is one of the most successful non-governmental initiatives funded by the USA government in Uganda," the newspaper said.

The NGO has a loan recovery rate exceeding 90%. It targets poor women.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


270 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 12, 1997


Arts and Entertainment;
Ethiopian symposium examines draft culture policy


BYLINE: Alemshet Kebede, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

ADDIS ABABA - A four-day national symposium on the draft policy of culture opened here yesterday at the Yared Music School.

According to Ato Worku Nida, head of the Department of culture in the Ministry of Information and Culture, over 200 professionals, elders members of religious institutions, renowned individuals, representatives from women's affairs bureaux and governmental and non-governmental organizations drawn from 10 regional states and the Administration of Dire Dawa are attending the symposium.

Opening the symposium, Ato Wolde-Michael Chemu, Minister of Information and Culture noted that Ethiopia was one of the forefront countries renowned for its long history and diverse cultures the source of which was the existence of ore than 80 nations and nationalities. 

The minister recalled that absence of constitutional guarantee and unequal treatment of cultures in the past were the impediments in the way of promoting such cultures.

In the past the Ethiopian nationalities had fought against these negative influences which now enabled them to exercise their cultural rights.

As neglecting ones culture can only mean disregarding one's identity and the well-being of the culture itself, the minister noted that the government, would pay due attention to the development of culture and to this end having a defined policy on culture was necessary.

He added that the absence of such a policy in the past proved the then governments' negligence to respect the culture of the Ethiopian people.

He finally admonished participants to pay attention to five basic points - that the policy should not be against the basic rights of the peoples of all nations and nationalities should not include points that militate against the peaceful relations and coexistence of all peoples, should reflect that cultural activity is the basis for all other developmental activities, that it(the policy) should not make gender discrimination and that it should be reliable.

A number of research papers such as, what is the Necessity for the Study of What Culture Is and Its Development, Activities of Art in Ethiopia-short survey, Women and Culture. The Foundation of the Academy of Ethiopian Languages and its Activities and other will be presented at the symposium it was learned.

LANGUAGE: English

271 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 12, 1997


Ethiopia;
Witnesses testify against Derg Officials


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 614 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - A prosecution witness told the Federal High Court yesterday that he was tortured and ill-treated in different prisons and investigation centres only because he was brother-in-law of the later combatant Hayelom Araya.

The prosecution witness who appeared before the court of law to give evidence against the Derg officials said he served a five year prison term at the Central Investigation Centre and the special prison called "Bermuda" since July 1984.

According to the witness, he was tortured during interrogations on the whereabouts of the parents of the late Hayelom and his brothers and sisters in particular. he said, "I told them to write down anything they like and promised to sign because I could not bear the torture anymore." 

The witness, 56, said he was ill-treated at various prisons and was not allowed to meet his family for four solid years.

Another prosecution witness said even when he was suffering from an infected wound, there was no change for him to escape inhuman tortures.

The 157th witness said his hands were chained for more than five months. The witness showed the court the scars he sustained on his sole and back.

He said while he was in jail, the government was running his garage which lost about 300,000 birr with some of the heavy duty trucks made to serve government agencies as source of spare parts incurring him a loss of over 1.6 million birr.

the 154th witness said he had been placed under arrest in the Central Investigation and Addis Ababa prisons between July 1984 and May 1991 for allegedly being member of the Tigray People's Liberation Front(TPLF).

another witness also testified that he was captured in 1984 for allegedly being member of the Ethiopian People's Democratic Unity Organization and spent long years in prison under appalling conditions.

All the five witnesses said they were driven in a truck to a prison they said was called "Bermuda" with their eyes blindfolded, arms tied together behind the back and the shoes of the guards on the backs.

"Bermuda is a villa with a spacious compound into which inmates were thrown and flogged. The prisoners were often heard bursting into loud wails," the witnesses said.

The said they were subjected to electric shock and dumped heads down into a barrel filled with dirty water.

The witness said they are now suffering from sight problem and are unable to take long walks as a result of the flogging they were subjected to in " Bermuda".

another witness testified that his relative, Lieutenant Mulugeta Aberha, had been imprisoned for five years during the Haile-Sellasie regime.

The witness said, Mulugeta was also in detention in Debre Markos prison and Addis Ababa Central Investigation in 1980 since when he has not been able to trace his whereabouts.

The trial was adjourned until tomorrow, 13 March 1997.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

272 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 12, 1997


Ethiopia;
House registers significant achievements, speaker says


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - House Speaker Dawit Yohannes said the House had registered significant achievements over the past 18 months.

He told journalists that the House, besides issuing proclamations to implement the five-year development programme and provisions enshrined in the constitution, is closely assessing and following up the activities of the executive bodies. 

The House has reviewed the performance of the executive body with an objective to look into constraints, he said, adding despite capacity limitation in some sections the overall endeavour was satisfactory and commensurate to the constitution.

Ato Dawit said the Police College, Prison Administration, Awash Arba Training Centre and the Air Force inspected by the Defence and Security Committee of the House despite existing financial constraints have scored significant achievements adding the House would see to it that priority is given to support them.

Participation of members in discussions held in the House has shown significant improvement, he said and indicated that the major problem was inability to devise a means for close contact and communication between MPs and their constituencies.

In a bid to overcome such a problem, members are expected to return with demands from their respective constituencies after the summer recesses, Ato Dawit said.

According to the house Speaker there is also a long term plan to open offices at constituency level where the MPs could work.

273 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 12, 1997


Ethiopia;
Shinile Zone appeals for relief aid


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

DIRE DAWA (ENA) - The resultant problem from persistent failure of rains in the six woredas of the Shinile Zone has been aggravated due to failure on the part of concerned bodies to take prompt measures, the council said. the Somali Region Disaster Prevention and Preparedness Bureau on the other hand said it is making preparations to help victims in the area.

about 60 per cent of the inhabitants are now exposed to famine as there was acute shortage of water and food, according to zonal council chairman Mahmud Haji Diale.

Diarrhoea epidemic and measles have surfaced in the area following the long dry spell he said, adding people are dying in peasant associations in Shinile and Er woredas. 

The attempt to ferry water from an area as far as 80 km. has proved to be a futile endeavour when compared to the magnitude of the problem, he said and called on pertinent bodies to look for ways of supplying adequate water to the victims.

The regional DPP bureau head Ato Ahmed Nur said preparation have been finalized to dispatch 9000 quintals of relief food to drought victims in 37 centres.

A water tank truck has been deployed to the area with a view to alleviating scarcity of water in the area. he added.

Meanwhile, the Somali regional disaster prevention and preparedness commission announced that it will soon begin dispatching 90,000 quintals of relief grain in addition to the 110,000 quintals so far distributed in the area.

It said in the coming two days relief grain would be distributed to drought victims in Bedowoyn and Shilabo woredas of the region.

According to the Korahe zone disaster prevention and preparedness commission, drought affected people in six camps in Kebri Dehar Woreda Monday received 1,300 quintals of grain.

A total of 540,000 quintals of relief grain is needed to feed drought victims in the region according to reports.

In a related development, civil servants working in various governmental offices in the region have decided to raise money to assist the effort to feed the hungry people.

The regional council executives, head of nine bureaux as well as department and service heads decided at a joint meeting Monday to contribute half and full of their one-month salary in a one year instalment.

Similarly, workers of the regional trade, tourism, industry, transport and communication bureaux have pledged to contribute half of their one month salary within a year.

Bureau head Abdulkerim Kenle Kahin said the workers in the bureau have pledged to raise 15,285 birr.

Africa News


March 12, 1997


East Africa;
Statement by the President of the UNSC


BYLINE: United Nations


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 854 words


 

United Nations - At the 3748th meeting of the Security Council, held on 7 March 1997 in connection with the Council's consideration of the item entitled "The situation in the Great Lakes region", the President of the Security Council made the following statement on behalf of the Council:

"The Security Council expresses its grave concern at the deteriorating situation in the Great Lakes region, in particular in eastern Zaire. It underlines the urgent need for a comprehensive and coordinated response by the international community in support of the efforts of the joint United Nations/Organization of African Unity Special Representative for the Great Lakes region to prevent any further escalation of the crisis there.

"The Security Council reiterates, in that respect, its full support for the five-point peace plan for eastern Zaire contained in its resolution 1097 (1997) of 18 February 1997 and welcomes the endorsement of that plan by the Organization of African Unity (OAU) at its 65th ordinary session of the Council of Ministers held in Tripoli from 24 to 28 February 1997.

"The Security Council welcomes the declaration of the Government of Zaire of 5 March 1997 (S/1997/197, annex) regarding its acceptance of the United Nations peace plan endorsed by the Security Council in its resolution 1097 (1997). 

"The Security Council calls upon the Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo/Zaire to declare publicly their acceptance of resolution 1097 (1997) in all its provisions, in particular an immediate cessation of hostilities, and calls on all parties to implement its provisions without delay.

"The Security Council is concerned about the effect which the continued fighting is having on the refugees and inhabitants of the region and calls upon all parties to allow access by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and humanitarian agencies to refugees and displaced persons and to guarantee the safety of refugees and displaced persons as well as United Nations and humanitarian aid workers. It also takes note with concern of allegations of violations of international humanitarian law in the conflict zone and welcomes the sending of a United Nations fact finding mission to the area.

"The Security Council reiterates its full support for the joint United Nations/OAU Special Representative for the Great Lakes region and urges all Governments in the region and all the parties concerned to cooperate with him fully. It also urges the parties to the conflict to begin, under his auspices, a dialogue in order to achieve a lasting political settlement.

"The Security Council welcomes all efforts, including those of the Organizations and States of the region, aimed at resolving the crisis, including the initiative of President Daniel Arap Moi of Kenya to convene another regional meeting in Nairobi on 19 March 1997 and the initiative of the OAU to organize a summit of the members of the Central Organ of the OAU Mechanism for Conflict Prevention, Management and Resolution on the Great Lakes region in Lome before the end of March 1997. The Council encourages other facilitators and representatives of the regional organizations, including the European Union and the States concerned, to coordinate closely their efforts with those of the Special Representative.

"The Security Council reaffirms the importance of holding an international conference on peace, security and development in the Great Lakes region under the auspices of the United Nations and the OAU.

"The Security Council expresses its gratitude to the Secretary-General for keeping it informed of developments in the Great Lakes region and requests him to continue to do so on a regular basis.

"The Security Council will remain actively seized of the matter."

March 7, 1997

(ENDS) (Transcribed by UN DHA IRIN Nairobi.)

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network "Wire" mailing list. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. 275 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 12, 1997


South Africa;
IFP March In Johannesburg 12 March


BYLINE: African National Congress of South Africa


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 600 words


 

Johannesburg - The demonstration in Johannesburg today, Wednesday 12 March has left a trail of blood in and around Johannesburg. The demonstration indicates a similar pattern to the march before the April 1994 elections when a group of marchers attempted an assault on the ANC headquarters.

Although the march had been advertised as a "Zulu March", nothing is further from the truth. It is instructive to note that many of the marchers were wearing IFP T-shirts and included members of the Self Protection Units (SPU's). 

In 1994 permission was sought for a march allegedly organised by "Zulus" but the application was on an IFP letterhead. It would be unfortunate if a perception were to develop that the march was an attempt by the IFP to misuse the name of Zulu speaking people to perpetuate their own party political objectives. We call on the IFP to clarify its standpoint on this matter.

Long before the scheduled time of the march, demonstrators were spreading panic by assaulting, wounding scores of innocent people in Soweto, Johannesburg and Ikwezi Station, Merafe, Dube, Nancefield, Mzimhlophe, Diepkloof and George Goch hostels. Two people are reported to have been killed by the demonstrators on their way to the march. Events leading to the march were reported as follows:

Soweto -shots fired in the air on Tuesday night from Merafe and Diepkloof hostels - roads barricaded at Nancefield and Jabulani hostels - a man seriously wounded near Merafe hostel - shots fired and stones thrown at a bus driving past Jabulani hostel - a bus set alight near Nancefield hostel - two dead bodies found near Merafe hostel - a person wounded from a bullet fired from a taxi driving past Dube hostel - commuters assaulted on a train from Vereeniging - a man seriously wounded when he was shot in the back at Mzimhlophe hostel

East Rand - intimidation of the general public reported - roads barricaded in Vosloorus and Wattville

Johannesburg - a man seriously wounded when marchers hacked him with a panga in the city - a bystander shot in the leg in Jeppestown at corner Maddison and Page streets - a woman shot at in an office in Maddison street when shots were fired - a man shot in the head at the George Goch railway station - a man wounded in the head at the Carlton Hotel - hawkers in the city centre forced to flee when the marchers scattered their goods

Whereas the ANC respects the rights of political parties and sectors of society to embark on different forms of protest, we insist that those who organised today's events also had a responsibility to ensure it did not degenerate into chaos, lawlessness and public disorder.

The events leading up to the march indicate that the organisers have dismally failed to ensure the demonstration was conducted within the parameters of public order. Consequently, the organisers bear the primary responsibility for the death of the two people near Merafe hostel, injury to scores of other people in Soweto and the Johannesburg city centre.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


276 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 12, 1997


United States and Africa;
Law Group Wants U.S. to Bar Algerians


BYLINE: Africa Policy Information Center (Washington, DC)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 947 words


 

Washington - Action Alert on Algeria from the International Women's Human Rights Law Clinic at the City University of New York

This is an urgent request for your assistance in demanding that the United States government deny political asylum or withholding of deporataion to Anwar Haddam, a key leader, policy maker and spokesperson for the Islamic Salvation Front (FIS) and Armed Islamic Group (GIA), two of the most extreme and significant terrorist groups in Algeria today.

Anwar Haddam is in the custody of the INS and has made a claim for political asylum. Under U.S. law, Anwar Haddam is not entitled to asylum or withholding of deportation because he has "ordered, inited, assisted of otherwise participated in the persecution" of others. It is the obligation of the federal government, and particularly of the Immigration and Naturalization Service (INS), to enforce this law. 

Now there is concern that the United States government may make a deal with Haddam, either giving him political asylum or withholding deportation and thereby allowing him to remain in the country. Either result would be abhorrent and provide him a cloak of legal, moral and political legitimacy.

In his official capacity as a leader and representative of FIS and GIA, Anwar Haddam has assisted and participated in a criminal campaign of terror against civil society in Algeria, targeting indepedent democrats, intellectuals, feminists and women who do not conform to Islamist dictates, as well as journalists and foreigners. The acts of terror include assassination and summary execution; beheading and mutilation; hijacking and hostage-taking; and the burning of schools.

The stated goal of this campaign-- which FIS/GIA call a jihad or holy war-- is to establish a theocratic state that would function according to tenets comparable to those enunciated by the Taliban in Afghanistan. Like the Taliban, the FIS/GIA call for and enforce through violence and terror, the complete segregation of men and women in public life and the obedience of women to their version of Islam. Particularly vicious acts of violence against women in Algeria have included the beheading of a young girl who appeared in public without a veil; and the kidnapping, rape and murder of young wmen who have been forced into "temporary mariages" and held in sexual slavery at the secret bases of militant terrorist groups.

Anwar Haddam has played a significant role in the planning and conduct of these terror campaigns, and has also claimed the power to stop it if the FIS/GIA demands are met. As spokesman for FIS/GIA, he has publicly justified and applauded brutal assassinations and bombings. He is currently the target of an investigation by the French government into bombings in France; it is believed that there is a sealed indictment and strong evidence against him in this connection.

As detailed in the attached press release issued by the Center for Constitutional Rights in New York City, on December 17, 1996 a group of women's rights advocates, intellectuals, journalists and poitical democrats from Algeria filed suit in the federal district court in Washington, D.C. charging Haddam and FIS with crimes against humanity and other egregious violations of human rights.

Anwar Haddam has resided in the U.S. acting as representative of the FIS, since 1993. In the fall of 1996, his initial claim for asylum was denied and he was subsequently arrested by the INS. Once in custody, he renewed his request for political asylum.

Women's groups and advocates of religious tolerance and democratic ideals around the world are outraged that the United States would consider providing this kind of protection to Anwar Haddam and his terrorist organizations. Not only would such an action by the U.S. government provide a veneer of legitimacy to Haddam and FIS/GIA, it would send a message to terrorists in many parts of the world that the United States is prepared to give them explicit or tacit protection. It would also communicate to all who struggle against such terror that gross violations of their human rights do not matter.

We therefore call on the United States government to firmly oppose Anwar Haddam's claim for political asylum and to pursue his involuntary deportation.

Please fax letters stating your concern to: President Clinton (202) 456- 2461, Attorney General Janet Reno (202) 514-4371, Secretary of State Madeline Albright (202) 647-7120, Director of INS Doris Meisner (202) 514-3296.

IWHR URGENT ALERT issued February 26, 1997. For further information, contact IWHR, e-mail: iwhr@maclaw.law.cuny.edu).

Distributed by the Africa Policy Information Center (APIC), the educational affiliate of the Washington Office on Africa, 110 Maryland Ave. NE, No. 509, Washington, DC 20002. Phone: 202-546-7961. Fax: 202-546-1545. E-mail: apic@igc.apc.org.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


277 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 12, 1997


East Africa;
Emergency Update No. 125 on the Great Lakes (03/12)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1480 words


 

Nairobi - Contacts between Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire (ADFL) rebels and the Zairean opposition are increasing. Jacques Matanda, a key member of Tshisekedi's entourage arrived in Kampala a week and a half ago, according to well-placed sources in Uganda.

Since his arrival, he has allegedly had regular meetings with representatives of the ADFL stationed in Kampala. According to a Zairean opposition paper Umoja, Joseph Olenghankoy, leader of the opposition group in the HCR-PT parliament and the national leader of the FONUS party, is out of Zaire and is reportedly meeting with ADFL representatives. Olenghankoy is also considered to be a key member of Tshisekedi's entourage. At a press conference last Saturday, FONUS called for tripartite negotiations between Mobutu, Kabila and Tshisekedi to end the current crisis. The UDPS opposition paper, Tempete Des Tropiques, reported that the national secretary of Tshisekedi's UDPS party, Ms Justine Mpoyo Kasavubu recently meet with rebel leader Laurent Kabila in Goma. Ms Kasavubu is the daughter of Zaire's first President Joseph Kasavubu and has not returned to Zaire since the death of her father. She represents the UDPS in Europe. Her arrival in Goma apparently occasioned the "red carpet treatment" from the ADFL. UDPS claims this visit is part of their peace initiative aimed at solving the current crisis. 

* As the siege of Kisangani continues, Zairean rebels allegedly associated with the ADFL have been reported on other fronts. Recently, members of the Gendarmes Katanganist have allegedly been spotted in Bukavu with the ADFL forces, according to Zairean press and other sources. They are members of the former Shaba seccessist forces who were defeated by Mobutu in the 1977 and 1978 Shaba wars. Following their defeat, the Gendarmes joined forces with the Angolan government. Their numbers, according to Zairean newspaper Le Palmares, between 1,500 to 4,000 strong, have since been reinforced by new recruits from Zaire.

Military forces have also been spotted in Cabinda, an enclave annexed to Angola and located on the Atlantic coast sandwiched between Congo and Zaire. According to the Zairean paper La Reference le Plus, General Estanislau Miguel Boma, the commander-in-chief of the Cabinda army (Force Armee Cabindist-FAC), claimed that there is a large concentration of well armed military personnel in Cabinda. These soldiers are reportedly Swahili speakers who do not speak a word of Portuguese. He claimed that they appear to be waiting for orders to move on Zaire.

* AFP reported today that the US State Department has authorised the voluntary departure of dependents of US Embassy employees in Zaire and has urged US citizens in Zaire to consider carefully their personal security. It has also advised US citizens to defer travel to Zaire.

* French President Jacques Chirac, denounced a "conspiracy of silence" on Zaire yesterday and appealed to the international community to force a ceasefire and undertake urgent humanitarian action. A spokesman for Chirac said that the humanitarian situation in eastern Zaire was tragic and that no- one can ignore it any longer. France has favoured the deployment of a multi- national force to restore order in eastern Zaire, a call which has been not well-received by both the US and Britain. The US State Department told correspondents yesterday that it shared France's sense of frustration with the situation in Zaire, but favoured "political persuasion" over the deployment of a multi-national force. Nicholas Burns, a spokesman for the Department said that the US is urging Kabila to accept a ceasefire and speed up the delivery of relief assistance. Canada, which took the initative in putting together the multi-national force last year is adopting a wait and see attitude. A spokesperson for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said that Canada would consider the request if it were made by the Security Council.

The President of Madagascar, Didier Ratsiraka warned yesterday that if Zaire were to break up, Nigeria and other African countries could follow suit. Following a meeting with President Chirac he said: "We must settle things as soon as possible to prevent (the troubles) spreading".

* South African President Nelson Mandela will probably attend a summit with Zaire's President Mobutu Sese Seko and other African leaders, a presidential spokesman said. The summit which is tentatively planned for Wednesday or Thursday is scheduled to take place in Nairobi. South Africa, meanwhile, says it is pressing ahead with its efforts to bring peace to Zaire but says that " has no magic formula". Deputy Foreign Miniuster Aziz Pahad said that South Africa was in constant touch with the Joint OAU/UN Special Representative, Mohamed Sahnoun and its next course of action would be based on his advice.

* The first Rwandan minors accused of involvement in the 1994 genocide in Rwanda may go on trial in Kigali at the end of April, UNICEF reported yesterday. Special courts have been set up to hear the cases and members of the NGO Lawyers Without Borders have received special training in prosecuting and defending the cases. A UNICEF fact sheet said that some 2,000 minors were waiting to go on trial for offences connected with the 1994 genocide. None of the children will be tried under the first category of genocide crimes, which carries an automatic death sentence. According to the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, as of December 31 1996, some 2,137 children, including 72 girls, were being held in Rwandan prisons. An additional 568 children are accompanying their mothers, who are in prison under charges of genocide. The figure also does not take into account 197 boys who were under the age of 14 at the time of the crime and are not considered criminally responsible, but are being detained nevertheless. Many are being held in a special wing of Kabuga prison and a number of detention centres, most of which have been rehabilitated by UNICEF.

* There are some 254,000 refugees in Tanzania. Since 1993, Kasulu district alone has seen a large influx of refugees from Burundi and now Zaire. Some 113,000 refugees are sheltered in 3 camps: Mtabila (27,000 Burundians), Moyovosi (40,000 Burundians) and Nyarugusu (45,000 Zaireans). Following the ADFL offensive in late 1996, some 1,000 to 1,500 refugees have arrived in the area daily. The Burundian refugees have been crossing directly from Burundi into Kasulu. However, around 80% of the new arrivals are Zaireans. They arrive along the shore of lake Tanganika from where UNHCR collects them by boat and transfers them to Kigoma transit centres. Many believe that there are an even greater number of Zaireans who have not made it to the refugee centres. Refugees from Zaire are thought to be still crossing the lake, although agencies believe that the numbers are declining. ADFL rebels now control almost all of the western shore of lake Tanganyika. Aid workers in the area have said that the opening of new camps has not kept up with the demand. Many of the new camps have only a limited capacity, which fill up quickly. Many of the transit centres in Kigoma town are overcrowded, some containing 2 to 3 times their normal capacity. The logistic capacity to transfer the refugees from the transit centres to the camps is also said to be inadequate to the need.

Nairobi, 12 March 1997, 15:30 gmt (ENDS)

Africa News


March 12, 1997


Business and Finance;
Life Offices Association won't collapse - Director


BYLINE: Llewellyn Jones, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

Cape Town - The powerful Life Offices Association, which represents the multi-billion life assurance industry, is not under threat of collapse because of a dispute with Liberty Life, says executive director Jurie Wessels.

"I honestly don't think there is a chance of the Life Offices Association (LOA) breaking up," Mr Wessels told the Cape Argus.

The LOA is the self-regulatory body of the life insurance industry. It is also the representative body of the industry in its dealings with the Government. 

Mr Wessels said if it disappeared Government would have to step in with "a lot of legislation" to take the place of the self-regulation or the man in the street would be in a very vulnerable position.

The association was a very useful instrument for its members to try and influence their operating environment, but Mr Wessels conceded that the circumstances surrounding the dispute with Liberty could force the LOA to change some aspects of its code of conduct.

The battle with Liberty revolves around its decision to award payments to brokers using its new Blue Print system. The Financial Services Board has construed the payments as a transgression of the Insurance Act in that brokers' commissions would then exceed the maximum commission provided for in the Act.

"In this particular case, Liberty is doing something which is not specifically addressed in the law and there is a difference of interpretation, " Mr Wessels said.

"Some members say what Liberty is doing definitely a contravention of the law, and Liberty disagrees."

Liberty, however, has said that the Blue Print system allows brokers to do the administration themselves, and they are simply being paid for that.

But Mr Wessels said the fundamental question was not really how to deal with Liberty, but rather about having commissions regulated in law.

"We are the only industry that has commissions regulated by law - it's a good consumer protection measure - but it does put us at a competitive disadvantage," he said.

"For instance, the mutual fund industry (unit trusts) can pay higher commissions than we can for competing investments - that is really what is behind the dispute."

Mr Wessels said the industry would now have to take a fundamental view on whether or not commissions should continue to be regulated in law.

"It may happen that the LOA will have to concede that there are certain things which are so competitive in nature that the association does not have the power to regulate them...and pass the ball back to the Government to clarify the law or make new law. The LOA's role would be diminished, but it certainly won't break up."

Africa News


March 12, 1997


Arts and Entertainment;
Frank Brown: Love of art helped conquer lost years of apartheid


BYLINE: Sharkey Isaacs, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 947 words


 

Cape Town - Although internationally-recognised artist Frank Brown has been living for 25 years on the east coast of America in the harbour city of Baltimore, his heart still lies in the seaport of his birth at the tip of Africa - Simon's Town.

Looking like a top basketball player of yesteryear (he's 2,4m tall), Frank, 61, greets you with an American accent, putting you at ease with a few words of warm welcome.

Then, without further ado, he dispenses with formalities and ushers you into his holiday bungalow behind his sister's home in Ocean View, near Kommetjie.

He says he was filled with emotion on arriving here recently for a two- month holiday because the house is the same one in which he, his parents, sisters and brothers were relocated after being uprooted under apartheid's Group Areas Act from Dido Valley Road in Simon's Town. 

Frank recalls vividly how he started from humble beginnings as an artist and was propelled almost overnight into international newspaper headlines. It happened through a chance encounter with a beach photographer, who filmed him collecting chunks of driftwood and fashioning them into pieces of polished sculpture.

His career took off after the publication of several magazine features about him and, with the extra money he earned, he was able to improve his artistic skills by taking a two-year course at UCT's Michaelis School of Art.

Today his works appear in private collections in many parts of the world and famous personalities who have examples of his sculptures include Helen Suzman, Senator Edward Kennedy and Bill Cosby.

Meanwhile Frank also underwent a metamorphosis and wanted to improve his educational qualifications to become a teacher.

At the time he believed that matriculating and entering Hewat Teacher's Training College was not enough.

Bombay University offered him a scholarship, but he was repeatedly denied a passport to India over a period of 13 years by the apartheid government. He says his life during that period was a "void".

Undaunted he continued to apply for other scholarships.

By the time he was 30 he had received offers of four scholarships, and he was eventually granted a passport to study in the United States.

After gaining a BSc degree in Art Education, he obtained a Masters Degree in Art History at the Maryland Institute College of Art, at Morgan State University.

He was 37 when he finally qualified and started teaching at American high schools.

He says: "Although it's been a long, hard road to success I am still brimming with zest and creativity. But I won't forgive or forget those missing years." Frank, the eldest of 11 children in a poor family, rose above the strictures of his environment in a disadvantaged community.

He discovered he had had a flair for art and sculpture at an early age. He also had a driving ambition to better himself through education.

He recalls how he helped his parents make ends meet by working as a newspaper vendor selling the Cape Argus at Simon's Town station.

This led him to becoming an avid reader and it also sparked off his desire to explore the world and to be a lecturer and scholar.

Frank now teaches social studies, geography and English at the Joseph C Briscoe High School in Baltimore, and he says: "Today art is mostly a secondary subject for me."

In a bid to gain some sort of compensation for his lost years Frank and his wife, Sylvia, wrote to the Truth and Reconciliation Commission and volunteered to testify about the scars left by apartheid on their lives. They were dismayed to learn they did not qualify.

Alex Boraine, TRC vice-chairperson, told them in a letter that the TRC was listening daily to the stories of people whose families had been murdered and of people who had been assassinated, who had disappeared and who had been tortured.

"We think these are the priorities, because these priorities are laid down in the Act," Dr Boraine wrote.

The reply continued: "Of course many, many people, including yourselves, were deeply hurt and scarred by the crimes of apartheid.

"You may wish to raise this matter directly with the Minister of Justice so that your request for compensation can be looked at by another commission, committee or department.

"The Act that governs our work simply doesn't allow us to give you the consideration you are demanding."


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997

March 12, 1997


South Africa;
W Cape policemen linked to gangs and drug rings


BYLINE: Joseph Aranes, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Cape Town - Western Cape police allegedly treat gangsters and drug dealers with kid gloves, close gang-related dockets before investigations are complete and downgrade drug-dealing charges.

These and other allegations of "widespread and systematic" police corruption were made to Minister of Safety and Security Sydney Mufamadi in a confidential briefing by University of Cape Town criminologist Wilfried Schd rf.

The report was leaked to the Cape Argus this week. Professor Schdrf said the report was a confidential matter between himself and Mr Mufamadi and that he was not prepared to comment further. 

Professor Schdrf was appointed two years ago as a civilian investigator to probe allegations of police corruption and complicity with gangsters, but gave up last August because of lack of co-operation.

A team of top police detectives was appointed to continue the investigation.

At the briefing, Professor Schdrf told Mr Mufamadi a number of policemen had confided in him about their own experiences and what they had heard about alleged wrongdoing of colleagues. "Based on what the policemen told me and what respected community leaders were saying at the time, I made public statements to the effect that there was widespread and systematic corruption in the Western Cape police," he told Mr Mufamadi.

Drug syndicates and gangs were involved in big business operations and there were vast amounts of money at stake.

"Dirty" senior officers had a lot to lose financially and professionally by being exposed and did everything in their power to conceal their activities.

"If the police involved in such activities suspect they are being investigated, they will conceal their activities by more skilful means. They know police investigative methods, can think one step ahead and have friends in places where they can monitor the progress of the probe against them.

"Every docket that is opened has to be registered on the computer. Any suspect within the agency who has access to a computer can look up whether there is a case under investigation against him.

"Another problem is that it is extremely dangerous for police personnel to squeal on their colleagues, as they fear for their jobs should they make a formal complaint, as often the allegations will be investigated by friends of those accused."

Professor Schdrf said it was wrong that police who knew of wrongdoing by colleagues and superiors could find no trustworthy authority to which to report them.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


March 12, 1997


South Africa;
We 'necklaced' ANC activist, police admit


BYLINE: John Yeld, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Cape Town - Security police strangled an "unknown" activist with a piece of wire during interrogation and "necklaced" his body to disguise their involvement in his death, the amnesty committee has heard.

It also heard that the security police bound at least one other "unknown" activist to a telephone pole and blew him up with a limpet mine to make it look as though he had died by mistake while on sabotage mission. He was already dead when blown up. 

It was possible a second activist had been disposed of similarly, the amnesty committee was told during its hearing in Cape Town yesterday.

This was testimony by two of five former Northern Transvaal security policemen seeking amnesty for more than 40 state-sponsored murders, bombings and assassinations.

Paul van Vuuren, a warrant officer, said he and Vlakplaas "askari" (turned African National Congress guerrilla) Joe Mamasela had abducted the "necklaced" activist in Mamelodi, Pretoria, in 1986 or 1987.

The unnamed man had been identified as an ANC activist or "terrorist" by Harold Sefola, leader of an ANC cell, during a torture session in which Mr Sefola had been given shocks with a portable generator.

Mr Sefola had later been electrocuted with the generator after being allowed to sing Nkosi Sikelel' iAfrika, the amnesty committee had heard in Johannesburg last year.

Yesterday, Warrant Officer Van Vuuren said that while they were driving with their captive in a minibus, his superior officer, Jacques Hechter - one of the five applying for amnesty - throttled the captive with a length of wire "to get information out of him".

"He was throttled to death during the interrogation, whereafter we drove to a deserted road in Bophuthatswana. We unloaded him, poured petrol over him, put a tyre on him and set him alight so that it should look as though he died as a result of 'necklacing'."

Captain Hechter testified that he tied a dead activist to a telephone pole and blew him up with a limpet mine.

"I cannot remember at all how he died ... I cannot remember where it happened. I am not dead sure, but I imagine a second activist was eliminated in the same way."

He has told the amnesty committee he had serious memory problems and could not remember most of the incidents for which he was applying for amnesty, although he did not deny being involved.

LANGUAGE: English

March 12, 1997


Business and Finance;
New Table Bay Hotel 'in a class of its own'


BYLINE: Jermaine Craig, Staff Reporter, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Cape Town - Just days before the official opening, construction workers are burning the midnight oil to put the finishing touches to the majestic R250- million Table Bay Hotel at the Waterfront.

In a prime position at Quay 6 with views of the mountain or sea from every room, the super-luxury establishment is destined to become one of the world's premier hotels.

Sun International's first South African in-city hotel, it is an impressive blend of modern sophistication and old-style elegance. 

It is one of several new hotels in the works, including a 400-room Hilton and a 300-room Marriott, which will dramatically change the face of accommodation in the Mother City and enhance its standing as a premier tourist destination.

Ian Douglas, Sun International regional director of development in the Western Cape, said the hotel group wanted to provide services and design which would enhance the beauty of the region.

"Tourism is a competitive environment and we are carefully examining the market, the demographics and desires of the people of Cape Town. We regard the operation of a world-class, relatively small hotel as the beginning of increasingly impressive developments in the Western Cape - an area which is attracting a growing, discerning international tourist market."

From the moment you turn into the palm-tree lined entrance to the Table Bay, you are struck by the beauty of the building. Every bedroom has a view of Table Mountain or the sea to Robben Island and beyond and there are spectacular views of Cape Town from all the public rooms, walkways and outdoor areas.

Guests will have direct access to the wide variety of entertainment, shopping and business facilities at the Waterfront.

Only 16 months ago, not a single brick had been laid and today, the hotel's 400-odd staff members are rushing around frantically in preparation for the arrival of the first guests on April 2.

The new Sun International Cape flagship boasts spectacular floor, wall and ceiling finishes - with giant murals, friezes, fountains and pillars sculpted in the minutest detail.

The hotel has 329 rooms and a number of public rooms, bars and restaurants. Facilities include the 188-seat Atlantic Grill restaurant, a 94-seat conservatory, a 66-seat lounge, a ballroom and a business centre with boardrooms.

Hotel general manager Jean Mestriner is clearly eagerly anticipating its opening.

"In a city famed for its natural beauty and superior hotels, the Table Bay will be in a class of its own," he said.

* The popular Changing City series run by the Cape Argus is also available on our Internet site. The site is updated daily from Monday to Friday. Access the site through a hyperlink on our main page at http://www.inc.co. za/online/cape_argus, or directly on http://www.inc.co.za/ online/cape_argus/changing_city

Africa News


March 12, 1997


South Africa;
A budget for the Poor


BYLINE: Clive Sawyer, Alide Dasnois and William-Mervin Gumede, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 840 words


 

Cape Town - Finance Minister Trevor Manuel today handed out billions of rands in poverty relief and lightened the load on low-income taxpayers in his debut Budget.

He also kept his promise to cut the Government's deficit.

Sobering news for drinkers and smokers, though, is that "sin taxes" are up sharply again.

A pack of 20 cigarettes will cost 54c more, while beer goes up 3c a can. 

Exchange controls are to be significantly relaxed.

A hallmark of the R186,7-billion Budget is a tight rein on government spending, with a significant shift of emphasis to spending on social development.

"This is a tough Budget - it demands substantially more austerity from government than many of its forerunners have," he told Parliament.

"This Budget tells the story of a government determined to effect deep transformation and to live within its means."

Mr Manuel said the cut in the deficit, from 5,1 percent of gross domestic product last year to 4 percent, had been achieved without new taxes or net tax increases.

"For the first year in many we have been able to provide tax relief to working people," he said, referring to the R2,8-billion tax saving for people at the bottom end of the scale.

Presenting the Budget, Mr Manuel said: "In this Budget we make a substantial allocation to poverty relief; we invest in people through a significant reprioritisation of expenditures in favour of social development.

"We are bold in the further integration of South Africa into the global economy by the freeing up of exchange controls; we provide tax relief for those on incomes up to R60 000."

He said a budgeted cut in the marketable securities tax would boost the competitiveness of South Africa's financial markets.

About 60 percent of national and provincial spending will go to social services.

This includes big boosts for education and health spending.

Tackling the vexed issue of crime, the Government has dedicated R406- million to the National Crime Prevention Strategy, which will cost R902- million and run for three years.

Spending on police, justice and correctional services will go up by about 15 percent, taking into account improvements in conditions of service.

"This provides a clear indication of the seriousness with which the Government is approaching the issue of crime," Mr Manuel said.

In all these departments, particularly the police, steps were being taken to improve management of resources, including extensive training initiatives.

Announcing revenue measures, Mr Manuel committed the Government to further tougher measures against people evading and failing to pay tax.

"The Government will more vigorously enforce the tax legislation.

"We shall actively pursue anyone who breaks the law."

Steps announced today include requiring people who want government contracts to prove they are registered taxpayers and sign a certificate that their tax affairs are in good order.

Similar steps will have to be taken by people wanting foreign currency.

Tax relief for low-income earners will be partly offset by better tax collection, expected to yield R800-million this year.

As expected, Mr Manuel stopped short of a VAT increase. But improved VAT collections should put an extra R400-million in the state's coffers this year.

Budgeted revenue of R161,98-billion will leave the Government short of some R24,77-million this year.

The deficit will be financed mostly from foreign and domestic borrowing, as well as from the proceeds of privatisation.

The sale of a 30 percent stake in Telkom is expected to yield R516-million.

Mr Manuel's long-awaited announcement on the phasing out of exchange controls included what he called "profound" changes. As expected, the new measures benefit indidivuals.

Overall, he predicted a 2 percent growth in the economy this year.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


284 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 13, 1997


Uganda;
Uganda Moves To Stamp Out Corruption


BYLINE: David Musoke, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1438 words


 

KAMPALA, Uganda (PANA) - A wait-and-see attitude prevails in Uganda ahead of the expiry Friday of the deadline requiring Ugandans holding high public office to declare their assets, as a measure to stamp out widespread corruption.

Although in recent years Uganda has often been cited as a model in efficient economic management, corruption is so widespread that an international anti-corruption organization, Transparency International, said the East African country was a leader in this vice.

Recently, Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni set the anti-corruption tune when he announced that he had declared his assets before standing for the May 1996 polls, and as commander-in-chief of the armed forces.

The Inspector General of Government, Jotham Tumwesigye, whose post is the equivalent of an Ombudsman, said recently that 40 members of parliament were yet to fulfill the terms under the country's Leadership Code. 

He told journalists that all ministers, except one, had declared their assets. However, Tumwesigye declined to divulge their names, their wealth, let alone that of the president.

Under the code, political leaders are required to declare their assets, liabilities and earnings. They are also expected to declare loans and whether they had ever been charged for criminal offence or employed by foreign firms.

What is evident is that the Leadership Code, which was enacted five years ago and assented to by Museveni, has remained a dead letter.

Abu Mayanja, a former deputy prime minister and justice minister, attributed the situation to lack of budgetary allocations. This has meant tht the Leadership Code Commission, set up to curb top level corruption, has been unable to enforce the law.

The code also requires ranking officials in 21 districts and those in state- owned firms to declare their assets by March 15 and 30, respectively.

In keeping with his election manifesto, Museveni has pledged that his government would continue its battle against corruption and abuse of office in high places of government.

Consequently, he appointed Vice-President Specioza Kazibwe to lead the anti- corruption crusade, prompted by a public outcry that many leaders had corruptly enriched themselves.

According to the former Ombudsman, Augustine Ruzindana, who is now a member of the legislature, he had intercepted several cheques amounting to billions of shillings, which were supposed to pay for what is jokingly termed as "air supply" or imaginary items.

The powerful Parliamentary Accounts Committee has also unearthed cases of misappropriation and embezzlement of public funds and some of the culprits have gone to jail.

Taking advantage of liberal press laws, the media has also exposed corruption and abuse of power. A weekly, Uganda Confidential, specializes in publishing corruption scandals involving top leaders.

But, according to the Speaker of parliament, James Wapakhabulo, the election of an inspector general of government and the revival of the Parliamentary Accounts Committee were steps in the right direction.

However, he said at a recent anti-corruption seminar that the long-term solution lay in the modernization of society, to enable people know their rights and "stop glorifying thieves."

Meanwhile, the director of special projects in Museveni's office, Amos Twinomujuni, said: "We must start from the top. That is how the small fish at the bottom can fear. The moment you keep quiet, then if I have access to corruption, I will double my efforts."

The Uganda government has been at pains in its efforts to deal with corruption. In November 1996, it even signed a contract with the Swiss Procurement Company, which is expected to plug the existing loopholes in government purchasing.

But, according to observers in Kampala, the success of the anti-corruption drive would greatly depend on the action taken by the inspector general of government against leaders found to have made fraudulent declarations of assets.


LOAD-DATE: April 1, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

March 13, 1997


Mali;
Canadian Company Wins Mali Gold Exploration Concession


BYLINE: Abdoulaye Traore, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 174 words


 

BAMAKO, Mali (PANA) - Canadian mining company Echo Bay Mines Ltd has won a gold exploration concession in Mali's western region of Kayes.

Under an agreement, signed Wednesday with the government, the company will explore an area of 220 square Kilometres in an area called Dag Dag. 

Echo Bay Mines, with headquarters in Englewood, Canada, plans to invest 975 million francs cfa (about 1.87 million U.S. dollars) in the area during the three-year period of its exploration permit.

The company will give the Mali government a 20-percent stake in the exploration company that would be created if gold is found in sufficiently economical quantities.

Echo Bay has four active gold mines in the Americas and is active in the African states of Burkina Faso, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Ghana and Niger.
