297 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 13, 1997


South Africa;
Truth Panel Seeks to Clarify Stance on Informers


BYLINE: Truth and Reconciliation Commission


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Cape Town - Statement by Dr Alex Boraine, vice-chairperson, Truth and Reconciliation Commission, March 13, 1997.

The Truth and Reconciliation Commission is concerned at the widespread confusion reflected in the media over the Commission's role in dealing with allegations about people alleged to have been informers for the government in the apartheid era.

We believe it is necessary to set the record straight by placing on record developments so far:

Last Monday the TRC's Amnesty Committee decided that it did not consider it appropriate for the Committee's present purposes that a former Security policeman applying for amnesty should be forced to name people whom he alleged had been police informers. 

On Tuesday the Human Rights Violations Committee, at a regular meeting, discussed the matter thoroughly. It decided that while it may not be necessary for the work of the Amnesty Committee for the alleged informers to be named, in view of the Commission's commitment to openness an attempt should be made to ascertain their identities.

On Wednesday, Archbishop Desmond Tutu, the Chairperson of the TRC, announced our intentions, noting the following:

"I shall be discussing the matter fully with the Amnesty Committee. However, I do not understand that their decision necessarily precludes other sections of the Commission from conducting an investigation, at least for purposes other than those of the amnesty process."

On Friday the matter was raised by a delegation from the ANC at a meeting with the Commission in Cape Town. We informed the ANC that we had already set in motion procedures to obtain the identity of alleged informers.

We have written to the attorneys for the applicants whose case is before the Amnesty Committee, asking that their clients provide names or face subpoenas requiring them to do so. In terms of a recent Appeal Court decision those named would be given 21 days' notice before being asked to appear before the Commission.

It is of critical importance that at every stage of this process it is kept in mind that we are dealing with allegations which will need to be corroborated before any public announcement is made. The fact that these are so far untested allegations is being largely ignored.

It is also important to make it clear that the Commission does not intend to launch a large-scale sniffing out of alleged informers. We have neither the resources, the time nor the inclination to do this. Where we will have to take action is when specific evidence is placed before a hearing alleging that an informer was party to a gross violation of human rights, either before, during or after the fact. In these cases, we are bound to investigate the allegation, just as we would any other allegation of direct involvement in a gross violation.

We are determined not to allow this issue to become a political football. Our handling of the matter will governed by the specific and carefully- defined objectives of the Commission laid down in an Act of Parliament.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


298 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 14, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Weekly Press Review


BYLINE: Olu Sarr, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1067 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - Nigeria regained the international spotlight for its treason charge Wednesday, on 15 opponents of the military regime. Briefly, that pushed aside but did not submerge comments on the war in Zaire, and a diplomatic entente between Tripoli and the Vatican.

On the regime in Nigeria a Dakar newspaper, Sud Quotidien, said that once one became despotic it was impossible to shake off that behavior.

"Does Sani Abacba not fit this profile?" it said. "We are increasingly inclined to think so, as a result of the treason charge against Wole Soyinka and 14 others." 

It added: "By this act, it appears that the Nigerian government is paranoid, a condition that can lead to suicide." It asked whether the treason charge was not a way of using the country's judiciary "to insult the international community," and all this at a time when a delegation the Human Rights Commission of the Organization of African Unity (O.A.U.) was visiting the country.

It concluded saying that the appearance that Nigeria was faltering was, in fact, "a strategy to take advantage of the international community's failure in reaching a consensus on sanction against Nigeria."

Turning to the commission's tour, it said as those of other organizations, this occasion was being used by the regime to project a positive image of itself and prolong its rule.

"The Nigerian government is talking about wanting to institute democracy yet it is doing the opposite on the ground," it said.

For example, it said when the invited commission arrived in Nigeria, it had still not been authorized to meet political prisoners.

"All this (invitation of international bodies) has been used as delaying tactics to tone down the criticism against the government following the execution of Ken Saro Wiwa, and the Abiola case," it said.

But it warned, although the government had been given room to breathe, "it is obvious that such a manoeuvre cannot continue to succeed indefinitely."

As the westward rebel advance continues in Zaire, so do the comments of African newspapers become more intense and frequent.

The Addis Ababa English language daily, The Ethiopian Herald, said it was time the international community acted jointly to halt the civil war in eastern Zaire "before it engulfs the rest of greater lakes region."

It said that the war was "so depressing" that it appeared to be "yet another vindication of the sordid assertion by the prophets of doom that Africans are inherently incapable of putting their houses in order."

There have been other wars in Zaire, it noted but "the present one may, however, top the list of human tragedies in its Bosnia/Somalia level of ferocity. Time, then, for the international community to join forces in stopping the craze."

The Cameroon Tribune called for immediate intervention in Zaire, for humanitarian reasons.

Supporting what it said was a suggestion by United Nations Secretary- General Kofi Annan that an O.A.U peacekeeping force be sent to the country, the Tribune added: "It is time the O.A.U. is provided the tools with which to make operational its Organ for Conflict Prevention and Management in Africa."

The Cameroonian weekly, Galaxie, said Zaire's uprising sprung from a ground swell of "popular discontent, a crisis of confidence, political deadlock, economic failure and a blind dictatorship."

It said: Laurent-Desire Kabila's alleged liberation struggle could be analyzed as part of a set of solutions to the crisis and to stop Zaire from falling apart."

Partly in agreement with the Galaxie, the Times of Zambia said "the deepening crisis" had "cast a dark pall" over Zaire, which was already in ruin "caused chiefly by gross mismanagement."

Even before the recent fighting erupted in eastern Zaire, it said, "the Zairian economy was in shambles. There was virtually nothing to be salvaged."

Clearly, it said, with or without war, Zairians "would continue trekking across the frontiers" in search of food and other basic essentials.

"What President Mobutu Sese Seko has bequeathed to his country is a legacy which is now all too familiar in Africa: ruin and deprivation," it said.

Extrapolating from the Zaire situation to the larger African scene it said: "Zaire is a symptom of a larger problem which Africa is still encumbered in, namely crass incompetence by despots reluctant to stand down, ethnic divisions and largely useless conflicts that have persisted in the post cold war."

Therefore, it said: "The process of democratization on the African continent will be derailed unless the remaining despots are shown the door."

It added: "The crisis now facing Africa will never be overcome until its leaders learn to call a spade, a spade."

For their part, Libyan newspapers welcomed ambassadorial level diplomatic ties Monday between Tripoli and the Vatican.

Al-Chams saw the move as another diplomatic success for Libya, coming on the heels of the Tripoli meeting of the O.A.U. Council of Ministers.

Al Zahf al Akhdar, said Libya's ties with the Holy See were "a clear and complete rejection of the view propagated by Washington that Libya is isolated".


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


299 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 14, 1997


Swaziland;
Swaziland Frowns At Homosexuals


BYLINE: Tom Holloway, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

MBABANE, Swaziland (PANA) - Unlike their western mates, homosexuals in Swaziland will be having it rough coming out of the closet, since government has said it will not tolerate this behavior in this traditional kingdom of some one million people.

On Thursday, Swazi Prime Minister Sibusiu Dlamini said government would not recognize the newly formed Homosexuals Association, the first of its kind in the kingdom where the King has -- wifes. 

However, Dlamini said at the news conference in Mbabane that the country lacked a law and government policy concerning homosexuals because the phenomenon was new to the society.

In Swazi culture, he said, such sexual behavior was considered abnormal and unacceptable by the larger public.

He said Swazis would have the opportunity, during the forthcoming constitutional review, to express their views on homosexuality.

Until majority opinion on the issue was known, he said, Swaziland would continue to reject the practice.

Swaziland's anti-gay stance came just days after President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe said in Dublin, Ireland, that he had no apology for his persistent attacks on homosexuals in his country.

Mugabe's remark came on the heals of a court revelation late February that country's former non-executive president, the Reverend Canaan Banana, had committed homosexual rape.

The existence of the new association in Mbabane, Gays and Lesbians Association of Swaziland or Galeswa, was announced in a recent statement.

The association's president, Mangosuthu Dlamini, said its objective was to give homosexuals recognition as members of society, as Swaziland moves from a traditional to a modern democracy.

Dlamini said until now, homosexuals in the Kingdom had no voice to demand their right of choice of their sexual orientation "and have been mentally and physically abused by people opposed to homosexuality."


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


300 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 14, 1997


Business and Finance;
Air Zimbabwe Pilots, Engineers Strike, Passengers Stranded


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 707 words


 

HARARE, (PANA) - Air Zimbabwe pilots and flight engineers went on strike Friday demanding better salaries, causing flight delays, cancellations affecting hundreds of passengers.

The action, which took airline authorities by surprise, comes after months of negotiations between the pilots and management for more pay and better packages, in line with other airlines.

"We think it's total disregard of customers. I think we have inconvenienced passengers and over-stretched their patience," said acting managing director, Peter Chikumba. 

By Friday afternoon passengers were seen mingling in the foyer of Harare International Airport, the country's leading gateway, trying to get information about cancelled flights.

Chikumba, while admitting the pilots and flight engineers had a genuine grievance, said their action was misjudged.

He told reporters he hoped that the pilots and engineers would "see sense" and go back to work while negotiations continued.

He would not say how much the pilots and engineers were being paid and how much they were demanding, describing such information as a company secret.

Flight deck crews, who were said to be "resting" in their crew rooms, could not be contacted for comment.

As a result of the strike, Air Zimbabwe has had to lease aircraft from Nationwide of South Africa for its domestic and regional routes. Air Zimbabwe is hiring these aircraft for between 1,500 rand (340 U.S. dollars) and 3,000 rand (681 U.S. dollars), while passengers are being booked on Zimbabwe Express Airlines, a private carrier.

The leased aircraft are Boeing 727 with a capacity of 110 seats, two BAC- 111 with 90 seats and one HS.748 with a capacity of 30 passengers.

While the leased aircraft managed to clear passengers to Bulawayo, the country's second city, and Johannesburg in South Africa, some flights to Zimbabwe's Victoria Falls, Bulawayo and Windhoek, in Namibia, were cancelled.

Passengers to the Kariba resort town were ferried by bus.

By Friday afternoon, no alternative arrangements had been made for international flights to Frankfurt, Lanarka, in Cyprus, and London scheduled for later in the evening.

Chikumba said it was too early to determine the cost of the strike to the airline.

Commenting on an article published Friday by the Zimbabwe Independent, that Air Zimbabwe had "gone bust" Chikumba, who denied ever talking to the paper, said he was worried about the newspaper's intentions. He added that the article had done a lot of damage as some concerned business partners were calling the airline to know its financial position.

"Air Zimbabwe is not broke, it's not bankrupt," he said.

He said he was aware the airline was operating in a competitive environment and there was need for it to tighten its belt.

The Zimbabwe Independent, quoting Chikumba's report on the national carrier's financial situation, said the airline was bankrupt and could not meet all its obligations.

It also said the airline's poor performance meant it was unable to meet salary increments demanded by pilots, engineers and technicians.

Air Zimbabwe, with about 2,000 employees, has a fleet of nine aircraft: two Boeing 767, three Boeing 737, one Boeing 707, one BAE.146 and two Fokkers which are being phased out.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


301 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 14, 1997


Nigeria;
Offical Says 55.7 Million Voters Registered In Nigeria


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - The National Electoral Commission of Nigeria, or Necon, has said that 55.7 million people have registered for Saturday's local council election in Nigeria, in yet another step to returning the country to civil rule in 1998.

Commission Chairman Sumner Dagogo-Jack said Thursday, at a briefing in Lagos, that this figure was almost six million more than the commission had projected during the recent nationwide updating of the voters' register.

Dagogo-Jack said turnout for the March 10-19 voter-registration represented some 54.3 percent of the country's population, which he put at 102.5 million. 

Nigerians go to the polls Saturday to elect some 44,000 councilors and chairpersons from the 776 local councils in the federation of 36 states.

The council polls are part of a series under transitional program to democracy, organized by the military regime of Gen. Sani Abacha. He has promised to hand power to an elected civilian government in October 1998.

Five parties are fielding candidates for the council polls, with balloting in the 104,000 registration/polling stations nationwide.

Dagogo-Jack, whose commission is in charge of all the transition polls, said 58.8 million voter-registration cards were distributed to the 36 states and the federal capital territory, Abuja.

About three million of the cards were unused, as well as at least five million copy cards intended for persons "who might have lost their cards," he added.

He said all 36 states except Jigawa, Kano, and Sokoto -- all in the north, and Lagos -- registered up to 100 percent of their eligible voters.

He attributed the result in the four states to the "poor turnout of women."

Reacting to allegations that registration was marked by some irregularities, he said: "Even these lapses do not seem to explain the fact that in almost all the states, the registered figures overshot the registerable figures."

Some states had complained of inadequate supply of electoral materials, but Dagogo-Jack said the result of the registration and the return of at least three million unused cards had confirmed the commission's argument that enough cards were produced.

On security during Saturday's election, he said the commission had asked police and other security agencies for help.

"As far as Necon is concerned, they would cover as many centers as possible, " he said.

Saturday's poll will be the first national election on a party basis since the controversial June 12, 1993 presidential elections. That election was cancelled by the military regime of the retired General, Ibrahim Babangida.

The annulment of that poll plunged Nigerian into a political crisis from which it is yet to recover.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


302 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 14, 1997


Nigeria;
Nigeria Says No Foreigner Involved In Seized Oil Barge


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigerian authorities said Friday that no foreigners were being held hostage following a reported seizure of an oil barge off the coast of Warri, a town in the country's midwestern state of Delta.

"No oil rig or foreign nationals were involved in the incident," Chika Onwudiegwu, press secretary to Nigeria's chief of general staff, said. 

He was reacting to foreign broadcast media reports that some foreign nationals were being held hostage since Tuesday, when an oil rig was allegedly impounded.

"A group of unemployed youths, who has been protesting marginalization by the oil industry service company, Globe Star, in its employment policy went on rampage and seized the company's barge," he said.

Since the incident, he said, the barge had been released following the intervention of Nigerian security agents.

Speaking from Paris, France, Anith Lear, a spokesperson of the French owners of the barge, said the vessel was neither hijacked nor the workers on board held hostage.

"No one was being kept on board against his own will," she said. "No one is being kept hostage."

Occasional friction occurs between foreign oil companies and Nigerian communities, especially over environmental degradation or alleged development neglect of the oil-rich areas.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


303 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 14, 1997


Nigeria;
Canada Closes Its Diplomatic Mission In Nigeria


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - In what appears to be a retaliatory move, Canada has closed its High Commission in Lagos, signifying a deepening diplomatic rift between Ottawa and Abuja.

The high commission said Friday that while the mission "is closed, Canadian consular affairs will be managed by the Embassy of the United States in Lagos. "

It said visa services for people resident in Nigeria would now be available in Accra, Ghana. The measure came into effect Wednesday.

During the temporary closure, the chancery "will remain open and locally- engaged consular staff will be available to provide scaled-down consular services under the supervision of the United States Embassy."

A security guard was manning the entrance of the high commission's office Friday and diplomatic sources told PANA the mission's staff had all been recalled home.

The statement did not give reason for the closure but another statement quoted the Canadian foreign minister, Lloyd Axworthy, as saying Wednesday the action was for fear of the safety of Canadian diplomats in Nigeria.

Other diplomatic sources interpreted the action as a retaliation for Nigeria's decision to close its own diplomatic mission in Canada in 1996.

Abuja cited economic reasons for that closure but informed sources said Ottawa's move might be a reflection of its hardened posture against Nigeria since the 1995 Commonwealth meeting.

Nigeria was suspended from the British-led organisation following the November 1995 execution for murder of nine Nigerian minority leaders, including author Ken Saro-Wiwa.

After the suspension, Canada had been among the countries urging tougher actions against Abuja for alleged human rights violation.

But at their subsequent meetings, ministers of the Commonwealth Contact Group, would appear to have soft-pedalled, leaving Ottawa isolated on the issue of more sanctions on Nigeria.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


304 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 14, 1997


Zambia;
Jailed Editor Back In Lusaka Prison


BYLINE: Zambia News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Lusaka - The Zambia Independent Media Association (ZIMA/MISA-Zambia) reports Post newspaper editor Masautso Phiri was March 6 moved again to Lusaka Central Prison from Mwembeshi. He was moved to Mwembeshi prison March 3 to begin a three-month hard labour jail term. 

Phiri told ZIMA that prison authorities "probably decided to keep him in Lusaka because it was easier to take him to court from Lusaka than from Mwembeshi." On March 6, Phiri, together with the paper's editor-in-chief, Fred M'membe, appeared before a Lusaka magistrate's court on defamation charges arising from a story alleging that President Frederick Chiluba had a child outside marriage.

On March 17, the Supreme Court is to hear Phiri's application to review the decision jailing him for three months for contempt of court. Phiri has complained that he has not been officially notified in writing by the Supreme Court about the hearing, raising fears that prison authorities may not release him to appear in court. Phiri further complained to ZIMA that he was unable to prepare adequately for the case on March 17, in the absence of official notification.

Asked to comment, Home Affairs Minister Chitalu Sampa told ZIMA he had nothing to do with the movement of prisoners between prisons. "Once a prisoner has been jailed, he can be transferred anywhere in Zambia at the discretion of the Commissioner of Prisons, it is entirely up to the commissioner of prisons," he said. Sampa said he would "investigate the matter and if he finds there was something abnormal about the transfers he would act".

Edited report from Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA) 12/3/97


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


305 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 14, 1997


Zambia;
Zambia News Online


BYLINE: Zambia News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 854 words


 

Lusaka - Tribalism Sentiments On The Simmer: Tribal sentiments are constantly on the simmer in Zambia's North-Western province. The province encompasses three major tribes. People of one of the tribes, the Lubale, are now demanding that one of the towns in which they are dominant be renamed Luvaleland.

And in the Central Province, another tribal conflict is brewing. There the Lenje people are demanding that their language be taught in schools in their area, rather than Tonga, which is the most widely spoken language in the province. A spokesman for the Lenjes says the Lenje people can no longer tolerate being dominated by another tribe. 

HIV-Positive Zambian Doctor Stirs Local Concerns: The sacking of an HIV- positive Zambian junior doctor in England is stirring up concern among Zambians who now wonder if local medical staff treating them are subjected to an AIDS test before being allowed to handle patients.

Concern has been expressed in the press that the case of Dr Patrick Ngosa should hi-light how cautious Zambians must be when being treated by any medical worker, especially those who could accidentally contract the virus and pass it on to a patient.

Another MP Dies As Political Parties Reconsider Boycotting By-Elections: A fourth member of parliament has died in as many months since the November 18 elections. Mwembeshi MP, Yonah Shimonde, who had been ill for some time, died in Lusaka. His death means a by-election has to be held within 90 days.

Two other parliamentary by-elections are yet to be held. They too follow the deaths of incumbent MPs. One by-election has already been held in which the ruling MMD retained the Itezhi Tezhi seat

Meanwhile, the National Party says that it will be participating in by- elections because politics in Africa have proved that one does not win by boycotting elections. The Zambia Democratic Congress is also reconsidering its stance of boycotting by-elections, a position taken after being thoroughly beaten in the November 1996 elections.

Political Attention Shifts To Court: Zambia's political attention will, in the coming week, shift to the Supreme Court in Lusaka where the case of a petition against President Chiluba's legibility for presidency comes up in court. All the major political parties are among the petitioners who contend that President Chiluba might not be a born Zambian and therefore is disqualified from being a president.

The petitioners have lined up 53 witnesses, including Luka Kafupi Chabala, the man who claims to be the father of President Chiluba. Chabala has since left the public eye and is believed to be under the protection of the petitioners, because he is a key witness.

Students Stranded After Closure Of University: Hundreds of University of Zambia (UNZA) students were left, stranded and angry, after the institution's administration decided to close it for fear of student unrest becoming more violent.

Most of the approximately 4,000 students at the university in Lusaka had gone on a class boycott to demand for payment of their book allowances. The book allowances range between K150,000 and K280,000 (about US$170 and US$260). The university then announced that the institution was closed and every student should leave the campus that same day. Medical students and post- graduates were exempted from the forced vacation.

The university hired some buses to ferry the students to the inter-city bus station. However, the unexpected closure caught many students unawares, and many were forced, under police supervision, to immediately leave the campus whether or not they had sufficient funds for their transport fares.

Zambians Now Press For Sacking Of Soccer Coach: Despite having a clean slate with no defeats since taking over the reigns of coaching the national soccer team, fans seem unimpressed by coach Fred Mwila and want him out. The fans are particularly angered that Zambia could not beat Mauritius in an African Cup qualifying match, only managing a draw.

The pressure on Mwila is also said to be coming from some players who feel that his coaching techniques are out-dated and were doing more harm than good to the players and the team. He is also being accused of favouritism in selection of players.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


306 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 14, 1997


Zambia;
Get Rich Quick Schemes Entice Zambians


BYLINE: Zambia News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

Lusaka - The civil disorder that has broken out in Albania following a botched get-rich-quick scheme has compelled Zambian authorities to ban any such scheme in Zambia. It has been discovered, however, that the scheme, which promises handsome profits to those who participate in it, is still operating underground. 

Not many Zambians are aware of the direct cause of the conflict in Albania and regard that country as a distant problem, but the Central Bank of Zambia has taken note of the Albanian issue and has warned that it is illegal to run any such scheme in Zambia.

3. SHORTAGE OF LECTURERS WORSENS

The quality of graduates coming out of Government-run trades training institutes in Zambia is predicted to fall because of an acute shortage of lecturers. The government needs almost 400 lecturers to fill vacancies and lift the standard of graduates.

In some institutes, students are unable to go through the set syllabus because of the shortage, and it is now feared that this will result in "half- baked" graduates. Chairman of the Teaching Service Commission, Shenge Kapini, hopes that more Zambians will take up the challenge of joining the teaching profession as college lecturers. Poor conditions of service, however, discourage potential lecturers.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


307 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 14, 1997


Business and Finance;
Zambians Worry Over Sale Of ZCCM


BYLINE: Zambia News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 160 words


 

Lusaka - The privatisation giant mining conglomerate, Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines(ZCCM), has begun causing shivers of concern among some Zambians who fear that disposing of the firm will amount to selling the country.

The ZCCM is Zambia's major foreign income earner. The fear is that virtually all divisions of the conglomerate will be taken over by foreign companies who will be under no obligation to reinvest their profits in the mines or in any other part of Zambia. In Zambia, some potentially viable companies have collapsed since being privatised.

However, Finance Minister Ronald Penza has said that the fears are unfounded and that in most of the divisions of the firm, the new owners would will need to inject a lot of investment to get or keep the mines running.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


308 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 14, 1997


Zambia;
Zambian Women Wrangle Over Women's Day


BYLINE: Zambia News Online


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1387 words


 

Lusaka - A couple of weeks before March 8, the international women's day, several women were angered by some letters published in local newspapers. The authors of the letters were men.

They charged that women could, and would never, capably take supreme authority over men. The authors argued that women, especially those in Zambia, will always have to depend on men to succeed in whatever goals they hoped to achieve. The chain reaction that followed saw some men agreeing with the argument while many women regarded this as one of the major reasons why women were perpetually down-trodden. On March 8, the argument grew more intense as some women turned against each other.

On that day, thousands of women in various parts of the country organised marches to commemorate the day with general calls for equal opportunities. Many of them cast aside their political differences and walked side-by-side in the quest to talk with one voice to prove that what women were demanding went beyond the artificial barriers of politics. In Lusaka, the march was crowned by a speech by Nakatindi Wina, the chairperson of the women's affairs committee in the ruling MMD party. She said the occasion was important to remind people of the continued fight by women for equal rights, international peace and social progress. Some women also called on government to declare the day an annual national holiday. 

But, not all women saw the need to mark the occasion by marching on the streets or to be addressed by some dignitary or other. Thousands of other women were either ignorant of the occasion or chose to ignore it by going about their daily business. These included street venders, women who crush stones on road sides and women who do the cooking in makeshift restaurants. So it could be said that the women taking part in the marches were the more enlightened ones.

However, among the enlightened women who chose to keep away from the occasion was Zambia's only woman cabinet minister, Edith Nawakwi. She chose to spend the day working on a farm. Nawakwi, who is Agriculture, Food and Fisheries minister, condemned the tendency of women to mark women's day by marching on the streets rather than working. She contends that "Zambia lags behind in development because of such attitudes, by not finding a positive manner in which to mark the day." Nawakwi was a guest at a Field Day organised by 65 women engaged in agriculture production who chose to celebrate the day by demonstrating what they were capable of achieving in the field.

Nawakwi's condemnation of the march drew a sharp reaction from Wina and other women. Wina referred to on Nawakwi's remarks as "indiscipline" and said she would table the issue before a national executive committee meeting of the MMD, to which both belong. But, Nawakwi's remarks also drew support from other women, who said that she was right in calling for a new perspective by women in commemorating their day.

Such bitter differences among Zambian women are not new. In 1995, Zambian women were split on similar lines when they differed over how to present their case and on who was to lead their delegation to the Beijing Women's Conference. Zambia ended up having two delegations, each travelling separately with its own agenda. Against this background, and two years on, the one point all women seem to agree on is that the status of women has not improved. As Zambia Congress of Trade Unions (ZCTU) committee secretary Judith Chomba said, poverty and unemployment have risen while economic and political power is still concentrated among men.

The 150-seat Zambian parliament has only 13 women, with Nawakwi the only minister. And, although virtually all political parties proclaim in their manifestos that they would strive to enhance the status of the woman, this is not reflected in practical terms. In last November's parliamentary elections, the MMD fielded no more than 20 female candidates. The highest figure was fielded by the Zambia Democratic Congress with 25.

For many women, however, political positions are not the issue. All they care about is being able to raise enough money to buy food for their children and to send them to school. It is the inability of some of their husbands to support their respective families, that has forced many of them into such jobs as stone-crushing and the street vending of foods. And, despite AIDS and the renewed efforts of the police to curb prostitution, for some women, this has become the solution to their money needs.

Deputy Minister of Health, Professor Nkandu Luo, believes that despite the harsh economic climate, women could still find a "decent" way in which to earn a living, and that women should be seen to be helping their fellow women. Professor Luo, Zambia's first female professor of medicine, is a founder of a prostitute's rehabilitation centre.

Organisations like the Women's Lobby Group, contend that one of the solutions for inequality is ensuring that girls are given the best of opportunities and incentives for being in school. Girls' pass marks in government schools are lower than those of boys, as a deliberate government policy to ensure that more girls advance in school and eventually get into college or university. Some principals of privately-owned schools, however, argue that setting lower pass marks for girls could eventually work against the same people in the future because they would be advancing through the stages without being fully prepared for an independent and competitive life.

Others, however, argue that more should be done for the female pupil saying that government should also protect girls from early marriage. In rural areas, many girls are married before the age of 16.

For women like Cecilia Makota, however, the solution lies in farming. She notes that most women in the rural areas of Zambia are already engaged in farming and that this is what should be enhanced to improve their status. She contends that mere talk or "walking the street in marches" would not draw the support and sympathy of the government. Ms Makota, a successful farmer and business woman, says that if women are seen to be making personal efforts to succeed, government or foreign support would be easier to source.

Cultural barriers have also been identified as a major drawback in efforts to enhance the status of the Zambian women. In virtually all Zambian tribes, the woman must be submissive to the man. This often means that the woman does not have much, if any, say on issues like the number of children a couple is to have. Organisations like the Planned Parenthood Association of Zambia (PPAZ) has been lobbying government to pass a law that would limit a couple's number of children to four. The effort has so far drawn a minimal response.

Zambian women have evidently identified areas they would like to tackle in an effort to bridge the gap between themselves and the men. In some cases they have also offered steps that could be taken in getting solutions. In many cases, however, implementation of the proposals has been slow. And now, given what could be seen as this problem of differences amongst themselves, some men could just take advantage and reiterate that women will always need the guidance of men to achieve any goal.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

March 14, 1997


Ethiopia;
Trial of alleged red terror perpetrators to commence soon


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 106 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - The trial of alleged perpetrators of the notorious red terror will commence at the Federal High Court after a fortnight, Office of the Registrar disclosed yesterday. The trial will begin on March 26 and continue every other day through to April 2, it said adding, the cases were referred to the first, second and third criminal benches.

The Special Prosecution has charged 5,198 people with aggravated homicide, war crimes and genocide under the defunct Derg regime.

310 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 14, 1997


Science and Health;
Red fox found in North Wollo highlands


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 147 words


 

WOLDIYA (ENA) - A study has revealed the presence of the red fox, endemic to Ethiopia, in North Wollo highlands, zonal agriculture department said.

Red foxes were seen in two peasant associations in Delanta Woreda following a search mounted in the vicinities after the findings of the study were known. 

They were found at an area 3,600 meters above seal level, an ideal habitant for the red fox, it said. The department said it would take four years to know the number of the animals.

Chilada baboon, another rare animals found only in Ethiopia, roams Delanta, Wadla and Guba Lafto woredas of the zone. It was previously believed that the red foxes are found only in the Bale and Semen Mountains.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

311 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 14, 1997


United States and Africa;
Witness says US diplomat tortured in Derg " Bermuda"


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - A prosecution witness yesterday told the Federal High Court that he was an American diplomat suffering from an agonizing torture in Derg jail commonly known by the name "Bermuda".

The witness said Mr. Timothy Wilson was jailed for allegedly being a member of the Central Investigation Agency (CIA) and for supplying brochures to members of the "Ethiopian People Democratic Unity", an opposition group fighting the junta.

The witness said there was a communication break down between the diplomat and the young police investigators due to language barrier. The American was tied up and beaten turned up side down, the witness said. 

The 164th prosecution witness said the prisoner was also investigated by foreigners whom he thought to be nationals of the then East Germany.

"Ethiopia violates international laws", I heard him shouting said the witness. he showed the damage he sustained during tortures to the expatriate investigators, the witness added.

Four prosecution witnesses who gave evidence to the Federal High Court including the 164th, said they have suffered a great deal in 1984 in different jails but the misery they have passed through in the "Bermuda" was the worst of all.

The witness said they were arrested and their houses searched without arrest or search warrant. No one of them appeared before the court of law, the witnesses said.

The torture induced mental stress and pain in their hands and back are the living legacies of the Derg jails, the witnesses said.

The witnesses named eight inmates who they said have not returned to their cells after they were called out.

The court also heard testimonies of three prosecution witnesses who said they have learnt the death of their husbands following the demise of the Derg without any hint about their whereabouts for a long time.

One of the women said after her husband was taken to Addis Ababa Prison from Gondar, Major Melaku told her "not to bother about him as he was imprisoned for his misdeeds."

She said that she was frequently taken to the office of Major Melaku where she was intimated by pistol and insulted. She said she was forced to move to some other place though it was not to her liking.

The trial was adjourned until March 18, 1996.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


312 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 14, 1997


Ethiopia;
The aid distribution began in December last year


BYLINE: Abebe Gelaw, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

ADDIS ABABA - A management consultant noted here yesterday that the Region 14 Finance Bureau should take corrective measures to rectify some serious administrative bottle-nackes.

Speaking a day-long seminar aimed at improving the quality service rendered by the bureau to the tax paying public, Ato Ashebir Aberra, managing Director of Alpha-Omega Consults International, said that the finance bureau had to take a series of measures so as to put things in the right working order. He pointed out that the tax-payer should also be treated with due respect and quality service should be the motto of the bureau.

Ato Ashebir pointed out that the finance bureau has to maximize efficiency by improving performance, accepting new working techniques, ensuring greater motivation, increasing more internal cooperation and integration. "Such and other measures can be put into effect by embracing positive thinking and open- minded approach," he noted.

The consultant indicated that the finance bureau has a number of weaknesses including absolute rules and regulations, inefficient filing and documentation systems, lack of grievance reception, procrastination in decision making and absence of sufficient and up-to-date office equipment such as computers.

Ato Ashebir suggested such corrective measures as implementing laws and regulations timely and judiciously, devising ways of up-grading human resource development, improving incentives, working out mechanism for curbing corruption and nepotism, and creating harmony with the tax-payer.

Another speaker Dr. Minas Hiruy dwelt at length on the significance of administrative ethics which he said was vital for organisational strength and efficiency.

the head of the Region 14 Finance Bureau, Woizero Genet Aberra, said earlier that the seminar would help identify problems of tax collection service and overcome them duly.

Over 900 participants part in the seminar drawn from the regional, zonal and woreda finance bureaux.

Africa News


March 14, 1997


Ethiopia;
DPPC calls on donors to assist drought victims


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - The Disaster Prevention and Preparedness Commission (DPPC) has appealed to donors for emergency food aid in bid to mitigate food and water scarcity that has surfaced in the Somali Regional State, in Bale and Borena zones of Oromia and south Omo Zone in southern Regional State.

In a statement it issued yesterday the public relations office said ambassadors and representatives of donor countries and welfare organizations were briefed on measures so far taken address the natural disaster in those area. 

The call was made as the relief aid dispatched to the area was insufficient to address existing problems owing the to extent of the natural disaster in the drought affected areas, the statement said.

The commission said so far it has dispatched relief food, water tanked trucks, tankers, twenty heavy duty trucks in addition to financial assistance in a move to alleviate the problem.

A team had been deployed to the area to study the magnitude of the problem particularly shortage of water, it said.

The commission called on humanitarian organizations to support efforts being made by pertinent government bodies in addressing health problems in these area.

Representatives of governmental and non-governmental organizations following briefings and consultations have pledged in its efforts to assist the drought victims.

Meanwhile, the Disaster Prevention and Preparedness Department of the Somali Regional State said it has distributed among drought victims of two woredas in Liben zone some 4,350 quintals of grain.

Ato Mohammed Yero said water is also being transported to the areas by tank- trucks. Some 2,650 quintals of grain planned to be distributed to people in two other woredas is expected to reach the area soon, he said.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


314 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 14, 1997


Science and Health;
Meningitis, Meningococcal - Togo, Burkina Faso & Ghana


BYLINE: World Health Organization (Geneva)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Geneva - Three countries (Togo, Ghana and Burkina Faso) have reached the epidemic threshold since the beginning of the 1997 meningitis season in early November 1996.

Togo was the first country to report an increased number of meningitis cases in the Savanes Region neighbouring Burkina Faso. The first cases were reported in late December 1996 and the epidemic threshold was reached on 5 January 1997 in Tone District. Mass immunization activities have covered 159 000 persons (100% of the population) in the Tandjouare and Oti areas neighbouring Tone District.

In other areas, efforts are being made to convince the population still reluctant towards vaccination.

Burkina Faso: The epidemic threshold has been reached in 5 districts since the second week of 1997. The weekly reported number of cases continued to increase; the epidemic has extended to more than 10 districts and continues to spread. Intensive vaccination campaigns are under way, as well as social mobilization to convince more people to be vaccinated in the affected areas.

Ghana: Cases have been reported from northern Ghana since the beginning of November 1996. The threshold was reached during the last week of January. Since then, the epidemic has continued to spread. The weekly attack rates are over 15 per 100 000 population in 6 districts in the Upper East and Northern Regions. The population at greatest risk is estimated at more than 1.7 million. The national crisis committee monitors the epidemic situation and determines the needs. Intensive vaccination campaigns are in progress.

Other countries (in the region) have reported sporadic cases. National health authorities have been re- quested to reinforce disease surveillance and initiate vaccination activities as soon as the epidemic threshold is reached.

(Based on: A report from the WHO Regional Office for Africa.) -0-


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


315 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 14, 1997


United States and Africa;
U.S. Great Lakes Situation Report No. 26


BYLINE: U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 4454 words


 

Washington DC - U.S. Agency For International Development, Bureau for Humanitarian Response (BHR), Office of U.S. Foreign Disaster Assistance (OFDA) . GREAT LAKES - Complex Emergency Situation Report No. 26 Fiscal Year (FY) 1997, March 14, 1997.

Overview

The Banyamulenge and the Banyarwanda people, who are Tutsi of Rwandan origin, settled in the Mulenge hills of South Kivu, Zaire, and the Masisi region of North Kivu, Zaire, more than 200 years ago. Sporadic ethnic violence in the Masisi region has occurred since 1959, but it again escalated in the fall of 1995 as the former Rwandan army (the ex-FAR) and the Rwandan Hutu militia (the Interahamwe) targeted the Banyarwanda in an apparent attempt to create an area of Hutu control. In September 1996, the situation in the Uvira region of South Kivu began to resemble that of the Masisi region, as government-sanctioned harassment of Banyamulenge Tutsis intensified. On October 14, fighting broke out between the Banyamulenge rebels and the Zairian Army (FAZ) near Runingo refugee camp, in South Kivu, forcing the roughly 220,000 refugees to flee. The Banyamulenge joined forces with other Zairian rebels to form the Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire (Alliance), led by Laurent Kabila. The fighting spread, moving up the eastern border of Zaire from Uvira to Bukavu, and south from Rutshuru (North Kivu) to Goma. As a result of shelling October 26 and November 1, hundreds of thousands of refugees from Kibumba, Katale, and Kahindo camps, near Goma, fled south to Mugunga camp. After Hutu attacks from Mugunga camp on Goma town, the Alliance counter-attacked from the east on November 14, forcing the ex-FAR and Interahamwe to retreat west and compelling hundreds of thousands of refugees to return to Rwanda, while others fled north and west into Zaire. During the last four months, the Alliance has continued its advances in Eastern Zaire, most recently capturing the towns of Manono and Moba in the south, and Lubutu and Tingi-Tingi camp in the north. It controls an area about 1,280 km long, and has driven as deep as 400 km westward into Zaire.

USG Humanitarian Assistance for Fiscal Year (FY) 1997 (to date): $124,747, 922

Numbers Affected Rwandan refugees: From November through December 1996, 1, 033,405 Rwandan refugees returned from Eastern Zaire and Tanzania to Rwanda, according to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR). Another 232,000 Rwandans reportedly have returned from Eastern Zaire and Tanzania this year. The UNHCR claims there are up to 376,590 Rwandans stranded in Eastern Zaire, including at least 160,000 who fled on March 1 from Tingi-Tingi to Ubundu. About 75,000 are in Ubundu and others are believed to be hiding in the forests. Approximately 600 have reappeared in Tingi-Tingi, too weak to move onward. About 125,000 others dispersed in smaller groups in South Kivu and Maniema provinces, including 25,000 to 40, 000 refugees believed to be between Shabunda, Kalima, and Kindu. About 20,000 refugees and internally displaced persons (IDPs) have gathered in Punia, Maniema province, and more refugees are reportedly headed there.

Burundian refugees: Of the 143,000 Burundian refugees originally in the Uvira area, some 64,000 refugees have returned to Burundi and about 13,500 have arrived in Tanzania. The UNHCR states that 39,675 refugees are missing, with many believed to be between Fizi and Kalemie, in Zaire. There are about 274,000 Burundian refugees in Tanzania, and 3,355 in Rwanda. A small number of Burundians are returning daily to Burundi from the Ngara camps in Tanzania.

Zairian refugees and internally displaced: At least 85,000 Zairians have fled to Tanzania, and in Rwanda there are 13,959 Zairians who fled the Masisi region last year. Only 4,820 Zairians remain in Uganda, down from 11,000, the UNHCR reported. Before Kindu fell to the Alliance, there were about 19,000 IDPs there. About 35,000 Zairian IDPs have gathered in Kisangani, the World Food Program (WFP) reports. To date, about 7,500 Zairian refugees have fled to Zambia, most of them arriving in Mpulungu. The Government of Sudan has appealed for UNHCR aid to assist the 10,000 Zairian refugees it reports are in the Bazi area of Western Equatoria. The number of displaced Zairians grows as the Alliance continues its advances and the FAZ retreats, looting everything in its path.

Current Situation

The Alliance overran the Tingi-Tingi camps on March 1, causing the roughly 160,000 refugees to abandon the area before the rebels arrived. Alliance forces have proceeded northwest toward Kisangani, the third largest city in Zaire. Accounts of the Alliance's proximity to Kisangani vary from 10 km to 40 km. Alliance leader Laurent Kabila announced that his troops had met determined resistance outside the city on the road running northeast to Bafwasende, the first serious fighting of its kind between the FAZ and the Alliance since the war began. Land routes surrounding the city have been mined, resulting recently in two injuries, a U.N. official reported. News reports on March 6 told of hundreds of residents trying to flee Kisangani by boat.

Elsewhere in Zaire, the Government of Zaire (GOZ) on March 9 conceded the loss of Moba, the southernmost Zairian port on Lake Tanganyika. The GOZ no longer controls any ports on the lake. Reuters, quoting U.N. officials and diplomats, reports that in recent weeks Angolan troops have been involved in the fighting in Zaire, with Angolan government troops supporting the Alliance, and about 2,000 fighters from the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola (UNITA) engaged with the FAZ.

By March 13, about 75,000 refugees from Tingi- Tingi had reached Ubundu, in GOZ-held territory, about 150 km south of Kisangani. The WFP this week estimated that 35,000 IDPs were in Kisangani, with 3,000 to 4,000 arriving daily. On March 9, a U.N. interagency survey team, led by Regional Humanitarian Coordinator for the Great Lakes, Martin Griffiths, went to Tingi- Tingi. They identified 600-1,000 vulnerable refugees who had recently emerged from the forests because they were too ill or weak to flee further. The team also visited GOZ-controlled Punia, where they saw about 200 refugees near the landing strip. The U.N. is planning to launch a renewed relief operation in Eastern Zaire, after Alliance leader Laurent Kabila appealed to the U.N. to help the Tingi-Tingi refugees. U.N. officials hope their presence at Tingi- Tingi will attract refugees from the forests nearby.

On March 13 in Kisangani, a WFP-chartered Ilyushin-76 landed at the municipal airport with 30 MT of food. The food delivery was part of the U.N. 's effort to feed the IDPs in Kisangani, and the refugees in Ubundu, which Kabila has said he would not attack. Relief efforts in the area are stymied by heavy rainfall.

On March 8, Kabila declared his willingness to negotiate along the lines of a U.N. peace plan, but refused to suspend the Alliance's effort to seize Kisangani. The Government of Zaire (GOZ) called for the implementation of the U.N. plan on March 5, but has refused to agree to the establishment of humanitarian corridors in Eastern Zaire. The U.N. plan, endorsed by the Security Council on February 18, calls for an immediate end to hostilities; the withdrawal of all external forces, including mercenaries; the reaffirmation of respect for the national sovereignty and territorial integrity of Zaire and other states of the region; protection and security of all refugees and displaced persons, and the facilitation of access for humanitarian assistance; the rapid settlement of the crisis through dialogue and elections; and the convening of an international conference on peace, security, and development in the region.

In Rwanda, ethnic violence continues. U.N. and local officials reported that 20 people died during the weekend of March 1-2. On February 22, unknown gunmen in Kibungo prefecture killed 21 Hutu, including 16 children. On February 9, eight Rwandan Tutsis were killed and three were wounded when gunmen attacked a convoy of minibuses about 20 km from Kigali.

The killing of foreign humanitarian workers in Rwanda in January and February led to the curtailment of most relief activities and human rights monitoring. The victims included a Canadian priest, three Spaniards who worked for Medicos del Mundo (MDM), and two expatriate human rights monitors and three Rwandans working for the U.N. Human Rights Field Operations in Rwanda (HRFOR). Radio Rwanda on March 6 reported the surrender of 50 people who authorities claim are implicated in the murder of the HRFOR workers.

On March 13, a two-man BHR/OFDA Disaster Assistance Response Team (DART) was dispatched to Nairobi. From there the team will travel to Kigali and Kampala. The DART will consult USG, UN, NGO, and local authorities to collect information, facilitate planning for humanitarian assistance for refugees and war-affected Zairians and IDPs, and send reports on the humanitarian situation to Washington.

Political/Military Situaltion In South Africa, indirect "proximity" talks are in recess, with representatives of the Alliance and the GOZ in consultation with their respective leaders in Zaire. The talks began on February 25, when Kabila met with President Nelson Mandela. There have been no reported meetings between Alliance and GOZ representatives.

The Government of Kenya (GOK) will host a regional summit on the Zaire crisis on March 19, however, the GOK has not invited representatives of the Alliance, or the governments of Uganda and Rwanda. Kenyan President Daniel arap Moi has not yet announced the agenda.

On March 7 at the International Criminal Tribunal on Rwanda (ICTR) in Arusha, Tanzania, Theoneste Bagasora pleaded not guilty to charges of genocide and crimes against humanity. According to the indictment, Bagasora, a colonel in the Rwandan defense ministry, assumed control of military and political affairs in Rwanda following President Habyarimana's death in April, 1994, after which the FAR and Interahamwe executed the genocide. To date, the ICTR has indicted 21 people, of whom 13 are in custody.

On February 26, the U.N. fired the chief administrator and deputy prosecutor of the ICTR, after the U.N. Inspector General reported waste and mismanagement. In the genocide trials in Kigali, Froduald Karamira was sentenced to death on February 14 for helping to plan and undertake the genocide in 1994. He appealed the verdict.

A report released by HRFOR states that human rights has "drastically deteriorated" since the new year. In January, HRFOR received reports of at least 424 killings in 55 incidents, which was the highest number of killings since early 1996. of the 424 killings, 311 occurred in the four prefectures bordering Zaire; 228 were in Ruhengeri prefecture alone. HRFOR reports that insecurity has forced it drastically to curtail its monitoring work.

In Burundi, government authorities reported on March 13 that a plot to kill the leader of the government, Major Pierre Buyoya, had been foiled. The authorities also reported that five people, including a Rwandan, had been arrested in connection with the alleged plot to kill Buyoya. The announcement came several hours after three land mines exploded in different parts of Bujumbura, killing seven people. For the next two days, the American Embassy has recommended that Americans in Bujumbura avoid travel between 7 p.m. and 5: 30 a.m., and that all vehicular travel be restricted if possible to heavily- travelled, paved roads.

Relief Efforts

The U.N. announced that its Consolidated Inter- Agency Appeal for the Great Lakes Emergency will be launched on March 19 in Geneva, for $326 million.

Zaire: The 40,000 refugees who walked from Amisi to Tingi-Tingi on February 7 are among the 160,000 Rwandan refugees who are proceeding to Ubundu, which remains in GOZ-controlled territory, after Tingi-Tingi was abandoned on March 1. The WFP-chartered Ilyushin 76, which has begun flying food from Mwanza, Tanzania, arrived at the Kisangani municipal airport, which unlike the larger military airport 16 km outside the city is undefended by the FAZ. The WFP plans to fly up to 80 MT of food daily to Kisangani, where some of it will be distributed to the IDPs. The rest will be transshipped to Ubundu, 100 km south, and to Punia, 240 km southeast of Kisangani. Before the relief flights began, the WFP on March 8 organized a food shipment by rail to Ubundu from existing stocks in Kisangani. However, heavy rains impeded the delivery of 65 tons of food, which eventually arrived at Ubundu on March 11. Mud further delayed the distribution of food from the railhead to the refugees. Another rail shipment of 120 tons is planned this week.

The location of approximately 25,000 Rwandan and Burundian refugees who were fleeing toward Kindu in late February remains unknown. Before Kindu fell on February 28, the refugees were known to be walking from Kalima southwest toward Kindu.

In Punia, the WFP flew in 12 MT of food for distribution by workers with the Catholic non- governmental organization (NGO), Caritas, during the first week of March. As of March 7 there were about 5,000 refugees there, and WFP earlier this week believed another 10,000 were on their way to the town.

In Kingulube, east of Shabunda, the UNHCR has set up a way station, manned by 10 relief workers, to provide high-protein biscuits and medicines to assist refugees and IDPs emerging from the jungle. A joint U.N.-NGO team that travelled there last month encountered great logistical difficulties while trying to find and help refugees in the area. Another UNHCR team has gone north of the town to investigate reports of refugees gathering in Nzofu.

On February 10, the ICRC reopened its office in Uvira, and also operates in Goma and Bukavu. In Lubumbashi, the ICRC has a team that flies a DC-3 and a Beechcraft to identify victims of the conflict.

In Kinshasa, the GOZ's relations with U.N. agencies is strained as a result of the government's expulsion from Zaire of nine permanent U.N. workers who had evacuated Kisangani on March 1.

Rwanda: The UNHCR reports that 1,300,582 refugees returned to Rwanda in 1996, and as of February this year about 232,000 refugees have returned from Zaire and Tanzania. Regular U.N. convoys transporting humanitarian assistance under military escort have begun between Kigali and Cyangugu, Kibuye, Gisenyi, and Ruhengeri. The WFP has also instituted regular flights to Gisenyi and Cyangugu. From February 24 to March 2, the WFP distributed 2,678 MT of food to 428,000 people, with 65% of the food going to returnees. During the same period, 1,329 returnees arrived via Cyangugu, and 446 came via Gisenyi. More returnees are expected as a result of the recent fighting in Eastern Zaire, the WFP claimed.

Burundi: The GRB recently announced the establishment of regroupment camps in Bujumbura Rurale and Bururi provinces. The practice of regroupment is already being enforced in the provinces of Karuzi, Kayanza, Cibitoke, Bubanza, and Muramvya. Local press reports state that, in practice, military authorities inform Burundians living in particular areas to move to the regroupment sites. If the peasants do not move to the camps, the military considers them rebels, and they could be killed.

Although conditions in the camps are satisfactory at the start, the health of the population slowly deteriorates from the increasing effects of crowding, inadequate potable water, sanitation, lack of medical care, and the inaccessibility to farm land. In recent weeks, the increased rate of forced displacement of the population has imposed a growing burden on the relief community, imperiling their neutrality.

In Kayanza on February 12-13, the BHR/OFDA Emergency Disaster Response Coordinator (EDRC) visited three regroupment camps. Although the provincial governor told the EDRC that the camps were temporary, he did not say when the army would allow residents to move closer to their homes. At Buraniro camp, also the site of a military base, children appeared healthy and people were cultivating nearby fields. Water supplies were available. At Ninga, created in January, the camp lacked a health center. At Nyarurama, also created in January, food and water sources appeared available.

Typhus is reported to have spread throughout the Burundian provinces of Kayanza, Muramvya, and Karuzi. The World Health Organization (WHO) first reported the outbreak of typhus in Burundi in early February.

In the first week of March, the WFP distributed food assistance to 115,480 beneficiaries in Burundi, including 43,755 displaced, most of whom live in regroupment camps, 43,637 people who were either returnees or internally displaced, 2,217 refugees or Burundians who received general distribution rations, 10,932 vulnerables, and 14,939 participants of WFP diversified programs.

A recent Food and Agricultural Organization/WFP study found that food security in Burundi has deteriorated this year. Civil strife, population displacement, and the regional economic embargo have reduced food supplies, increased food prices, and made food less accessible. From February 24 to March 2, 1,745 Burundians repatriated from Kibangira camp in Cyangugu prefecture, Rwanda, the WFP reported.

Tanzania: As of March 13, there were about 359,000 refugees in Tanzania, the UNHCR reports. At least 274,000 are Burundian, and the remainder are Zairian. In the Ngara camps, there are 105,000 refugees; of the total, 59,000 are in Lukole camp, with the remainder in the former Lumasi camp, now called Lukole C. In the Kigoma region, there are about 254,000 refugees. As of February 28, there were 23,195 refugees in holding areas in Kigoma town. Ninety percent of them are Zairian. Tanzania is receiving about 1,000 refugees daily.

USG Assistance

On October 26, BHR/OFDA deployed a USAID/DART to Kigali, Rwanda, to conduct assessments, report on the situation, and provide funding to NGOs, U.N. agencies, and international organizations for programs to assist in repatriation efforts. USAID/DART completed operations on February 25. On November 7, 1996, U.S. Ambassador to Rwanda Robert Gribbin declared a disaster, noting that the refugee crisis in eastern Zaire posed a humanitarian emergency for Rwanda. On November 12, U.S. Ambassador Daniel Simpson declared a disaster in Zaire as a result of the violent break-up of refugee camps in eastern Zaire. On November 18, the USG pledged $140 million in humanitarian and development assistance to address needs in the Great Lakes region. On November 25, Ambassador Morris Hughes declared a disaster in Burundi as a result of continuing civil strife. From February 12 to 26, BHR/OFDA deployed an assessment team to Zaire, to evaluate relief needs in the GOZ-controlled areas of Eastern Zaire. Prevented from travelling outside Kinshasa, the team met daily with NGOs and U.N. agencies in the capital.

USAID FY 1997 Assistance to date:

BHR/OFDA Assistance

Grant to AMREF for medical services: $212,129

Africa News


March 14, 1997


South Africa;
Former Policemen Lead TRC To Secretly Buried Bodies


BYLINE: Truth and Reconciliation Commission


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

Cape Town - A number of former security policemen from Durban and Pietermaritzburg have led the Truth and Reconciliation Commission's investigators to five (5) sites throughout KwaZulu/Natal where they murdered and then disposed of the bodies of ten (10) former political activists.

The six security policemen have applied for amnesty and their applications contain details of the identities of people they allegedly murdered. 

TRC investigators, working with a team of body exhumation specialists, pathologists and South African Police Services video unit have thus far uncovered two bodies on a farm previously occupied by members of the security branch.

The team is currently involved in the exhumation of a further two bodies. The amnesty applicants took TRC investigators to a site on the banks of the Tugela River and confirmed that two people were shot and their bodies were weighted down with rocks and thrown into the river. They then led the TRC investigators to other sites at Bulwer and at Phoenix near Durban.

The applicants also confirmed that four more people were blown up in such a way that very little remained of their bodies

The TRC is in a process of confirming the identities of the deceased and notifying the next of kin and a press conference would follow in due course once the information has been confirmed.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

317 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 14, 1997


Business and Finance;
Mboweni tells SA unions to act on discrimination


BYLINE: Alide Dasnois, Business Editor, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Cape Town - The trade union movement is lagging far behind in tackling discrimination against women, Minister of Labour Tito Mboweni has charged.

In a speech to the national bargaining conference of the Chemical Workers' Industrial Union in Johannesburg, Mr Mboweni said he had the impression that organised labour was committed to tackling race inequality but not gender inequality.

"The union movement is lagging far behind Parliament, Cabinet, Government and even business. It is now time for the union movement to address this in action without making excuses or simply passing resolutions," Mr Mboweni said. 

"And have you really taken steps to address inequalities in the workplace?

"How long is it going to continue that women are restricted to the low-wage jobs in the sector?" he asked.

The minister said the ball was "primarily in management's court".

But he asked the union: "Are you explaining the need for change to your members or are you sitting back and blaming management?"

On the controversial issue of labour market flexibility, Mr Mboweni said " much nonsense" was spoken about this.

Job creation had to be a priority, with unemployment estimated at up to 33 percent. And in some sectors, he said, wage levels and labour unrest did discourage job creation.

"There is no running away from this. Wage levels which are unrelated to productivity and the structure of that sector may lead to fewer jobs. And labour unrest may lead employers to favour machinery rather than people - which is one of the major reasons for improving our dispute resolution system. "

Mr Mboweni said South Africa's labour market was not efficient enough.

"Our approach is that where there are unnecessary rigidities in our labour market and in our economy and they must be removed. But this should not be done in ways which undermine labour security and union rights in particular.

"We do not support the view which calls for deregulation," he said, noting that in some areas more regulation, not less, was needed. In other instances, the market was too inflexible," said Mr Mboweni.

Examples cited by him included:

* A "one size fits all" approach to wage setting which in some cases did not take account of differences in regions, sectors and small or new businesses;

* Restrictions on firms working on a continuous basis, reducing employment levels and productivity of investment;

* Excessive overtime, with social and health effects and a regulatory framework which should be changed so that more people worked rather than the same number of people working more; and

* Archaic and complex employment conditions set by some bargaining councils which protected labour security in "a narrow and old-fashioned way" and which could discourage small businesses.

His department's call for "labour security with flexibility" was not a " compromise between the left and the right", he said.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


318 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 14, 1997


Science and Health;
Chris Damerell: a universe to study...but first an old boys' dinner


BYLINE: Gorry Bowes-Taylor, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1267 words


 

Cape Town - A cat sunny side up in the sitting room; just beyond its paw is Professor Chris Damerell, a physicist at the Rutherford Appleton Laboratory in Oxford, and visiting professor at Brunel University, London.

He's among more than 1 600 past pupils of Rondebosch Boys High in Cape Town for the school's centenary dinner tonight, at which the guest speaker will be former South African Chief Justice M M Corbett.

Later, Chris will talk to the Rondebosch Boys' High School science club and do a presentation at UCT.

The cat's tail frisks crisp scientific diagrams and papers. This is the world of atoms, empty spaces, colliding loops of electrons and positrons, whizzing quarks and quirky events15 billion years ago. 

Chris is as lean as a laser; his is one of those remarkable minds that is able to beam the complexities of his lifelong scientific passion with clarity.

"My love of science was cultivated firstly in Mr Van Oort's biology lab, where I spent many happy hours after school using his microscope.

"This was followed by the inspirational teaching of physics by Mr Jayes, and of mathematics by Mr De Jager.

"I remember an inspiring talk by Allan Cormack, who was later to win the Nobel Prize."

Chris was awarded the Duddell Medal and Prize at a grand dinner at London's Savoy Hotel recently, a medal awarded annually to a person who has made outstanding contributions to the application of physics.

His wife Joan puts her head around the sitting room door: "Don't get too complicated explaining it all!"

Put simply, Chris developed the micro-chips of the type used in video cameras, as detectors of sub-atomic particles.

"When high energy particles pass through these chips they release a trail of electrical charges that can be used to measure their path with unprecedented accuracy.

"This 'tracking microscope' opens the eyes of the scientists to the heavy quarks that comprise some of the building blocks of sub-atomic particles."

Chris and his group recently assembled 480 of these micro-chips into a $4- million instrument at the heart of a 4 000-ton detector, which has been installed in a $60-million project at the Stanford Linear Accelerator Centre in Silicon Valley in California.

If you'd expected the absent-minded professor about Chris, well, you wouldn't get it.

There's no hair standing on end, or dotty socks - all is fine tuned as a cat's whisker, and his ability to inspire bodes well for the budding scientists at his old school.

Joan and Chris's daughter, Silvana, is studying public relations in Leeds. Their son, Richard, is studying Russian and at the moment spending a year in Voronezh in the former Soviet Union.

But let's go back 15 billion years when the universe was a gas.

"People say, 'so what,' you found those quarks, they live for almost no time, what use are they? You can answer that on two levels, to one of which I made a small contribution.

"Applying the laws of physics and calculating the extremely small universe 15 billion years ago with its tremendous concentration of matter and energy, you'd expect by now to have just cold diffuse gas spreading throughout the universe.

"Instead we have galaxies and stars and planets.

"Where does our universe come from? Well, the law of physics that governs the very small scale is called the quantum theory, a theory that allows fluctuations.

"In the super-hot quark soup of the early universe, fluctuations meant that some regions would be slightly more dense than others.

"Worked on over billions of years by gravity, these would pull in matter from other areas.

"When this matter reached a certain density it would ignite and form stars and galaxies.

"That's scientifically why we're interested in this tie-up between the very biggest and the very smallest."

"The other level is the practical one, as technical and medical benefits flow from the acclerators and detectors developed originally to study atoms and quarks.

"There are plans to build a detector 10 times larger than the one at the Stanford Linear Accelerator Centre.

"This has to do with revolutionising the pulsed-power industry.

"The next phase will be a couple of multi-billion dollar global laboratories, and new inventions are changing the way we will use them.

"The World Wide Web was invented by Tim Berners-Lee, also a Duddell Medal and Prize winner, so that we scientists could communicate data, then it exploded from there!"

We're talking at a good time, Chris says. The electron was discovered in 1897, there are big centenary celebrations in the United Kingdom.

Accelerators began to be developed in the 20s, became national facilites around the 60s, when he was a graduate student, and these days we have expanded to regional facilities.

From under the cat's paw, he pulls a final sheet of paper.

He's listed a remarkable number of people from Rondebosch Boys' High and UCT graduates who've excelled in this area of science - Godfrey Stafford (Director of the Rutherford Laboratory), Allan Cormack (Nobel prizewinner), John Thresher (director of a laborary in Geneva), George Ellis (applied maths professor at UCT and a great authority on cosmology), David Dorfan (Dean of Science at Santa Cruz) and his brother, Jonathon (Stanford Professor), David Ashman (UCT Professor of Physics) to name some.

"This globalisation means that hopefully from now on we South Africans don't have to emigrate.

"It should be possible to get groups together at the unversities who will via the web participate in this stuff.

"If we're only going to have two accelerators in the world the hope is that we can make these things really accessible to scientists everywhere to genuinely participate completely in this research."


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.
