Africa News


March 14, 1997


Business and Finance;
Development Guaranteed But When is Enough, Enough?


BYLINE: Lissa Pelham, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 947 words


 

Addis Ababa - Off to Asmara and Johnnie Walker wishes you a safe journey; travel to Langano and Black Label accompanies you to Debre Zeit; head for Ambo and Winston and Marlboro loom on the skyline.

Despite international misconceptions of Ethiopia as a country ruined by war, famine and disease, world-wide companies have not been made blind to the huge marketing potential of Ethiopia. Is it this, or does a government desperate for economic expansion and investment make Ethiopia easy prey for exploitation by international money-grabbers?

Business is expanding fast - the last five years have seen a huge increase in advertising: Coca-Cola glares out at street corners, international airways signs drip from the buildings, even to the extent of sponsoring restaurants in the capital; Benetton has reached Addis and at every petrol station, there is a rival defiantly standing opposite. There can be no arguing that these developments have supplied thousands of jobs, that many people's lifestyles have been improved with an expanding economy, that increased investment results in greater opportunities; that the ongoing commercial developments will allow Ethiopia to gain standing in the international market, but do all these marketing and publicity campaigns spell affluence? 

It would appear that companies both local and international have free run over us and our lifestyles. Adverts dominate street corners, companies sponsor every programme on Ethiopian television. The government needs the money and thus allows advertising too much freedom. At a cost. The cost is to the environment and the culture into which the next generation is growing. How many parents fight a weekly battle with their children on Sunday afternoons when their children become glued to their television sets for the next gripping installment of "Acapulco Bay?"

"The Cosby Show", "That's Incredible", "Empire", "Matlock"...Do companies give no consideration to the standard of programme they are sponsoring - is there nothing more informative? Should television always be portraying a glitzy glamourised image of America which cannot help but become a role model for viewers? Unless the government takes a firm hand to closely monitor the suitability, quality and timing of programmes aired, we are in serious danger of becoming sponges, soaking up out-dated Americanism and harbouring ideals and ambitions that we do not wish the future generations to possess.

One wonders if advertisers are really considering the interests of the consumer. Does roadside advertising really see us so happily on our way or welcome us to Ethiopia? What do you want to see when you arrive in the country- the real Ethiopia, or the money that companies are determined to make out of you during your stay? It is doubtful residents are really happy seeing huge boards blocking the views of the Entoto mountains.

Let us catch the problem before it runs too far. It's up to the government to see beyond the flashing birr signs and look long-term to examine how much advertising is really worth and at what cost to the future. We are being exploited . For what standards do we sacrifice beauty and how much do we allow business to dominate the growth and development of the next generation?

Advertising promotional offers are zooming up. Shell's offer of a free trip to the 1996 Atlanta Olympics resulted in a 20-30% increase in sales. By 2000, manufacturers will be spending over half of their marketing budget on promotional offers such as these.

Pepsi sponsors Ethiopian athletes; Gillette brings global sport to our screens and both privately-run Awash Bank and the government-owned Commercial Bank have recently initiated leaflets explaining their services to their customers: there is no doubt that promotional advertising is beneficial to the public.

But the West seems to think that we are easy prey - marketers are upping their ethnic advertising budgets in a climate where the minorities will account for 46.2% of the American population by 2050 and yet there is clear evidence to show that they give nothing for our welfare. We must boycott exploitation tragedies such as the Nestle Baby milk Developing- world campaign where free supplies of Nestle baby milk were given to breast-feeding mothers in African villages so that they stopped feeding and became dependent on a powdered milk which could not be afforded once their gratuity month's supply of formula milk had run out, by which time, their breast milk had dried up. Every tin of Nestle's Nido bought , contributes to allowing international companies to believe they can dominate us, that we will sit back and allow ourselves to be exploited.

Competition makes marketing strategies and tactics ever more fierce. They are playing a game in which we are the die being rolled without a choice. what's more, the government appears to be joining in. Isn't it time that we take a second look at the direction in which marketing is heading us?


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


396 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 14, 1997


Business and Finance;
A Digest of the Major Economic Statements by PM Meles


BYLINE: Our Economics Correspondent, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2507 words


 

Addis Ababa - A number of important economic statements were made by Prime Minister Meles Zenawi in his six-month report to the 29th ordinary session of the council of Representatives on February 6, 1997. Below is presented, in condensed format, an enumeration of most of the salient statements with economic content made by the Prime Minister which were not constrained in our Feb. 14 edition:

* the role of the government in the Ethiopian economy is composed of the following development objectives:

* to expand social and economic infrastructures

* to create a policy framework conducive

* to draw up a rural-and farmer-based development strategy and implement it

* to build the capacities necessary to implement all the above development objectives

* 26 new road projects are under feasibility and design study, 12 of which are expected to be completed within the current 1996/97 fiscal year and the other within the next fiscal year of 1997/98;

* Construction work on the Addis Ababa - Jimma and Addis Ababa-Awassa road projects is expected to start next year; construction of five additional road projects may also commence next year if work proceeds according to plan;

* the study on the restructuring of the Ethiopian Road Authority has been completed and its implementation may start in the current year;

* Twenty-five middle-level construction training institutions are being set up in all the regions;

* A proclamation providing for the establishment of a road maintenance fund has been approved by the Council of Ministers and is now before parliament for similar approval:

* during the first five months of the 1996/97 fiscal year, 58.4 km of asphalt roads and 78km of gravel roads have been constructed;

* 228 million birr has been earmarked for telecommunications development from own funds and foreign loans;

* 480,000 additional telephone lines will be laid out in the next two or three years as compared to 160,000 lines now existing;

* 300 rural towns will be provided with telephone lines when the telecommunications programme being implemented is completed;

* Internet services will be commence this year;

* a study is under way to start a Mobile telephone service for Addis Ababa and its environs;

* maintenance and expansion work on Bahir-Dar and Dire-Dawa airports has been completed;

* construction of a new airport in Addis Ababa is about to begin;

* construction work on Arba-Minch, Gondar, Lalibela, Axum and Mekele airports is progressing well;

* priority will be given to the implementation of the Gilgel-Gibe hydro- electric power project;

* the plan to purchase 60-megawatt diesel generators is proceeding according to schedule;

* the first geothermal power project in our country at Aluto-Langano is being implemented;

* the 70-80 megawatt Tisabay hydroelectric power project will be under construction at the beginning of next year;

* maintenance and strengthening work on the existing Tisabay, Fincha and Koka hydropower stations is going on well;

* Bahir-Dar-North Ethiopia and Gedo-Nekemte-Gimbi electric transmission lines are being constructed

* The Ethiopian Electric Light and Power Authority (EELPA) does not even have enough money for its day-to-day operations, let alone for the construction of new electric generation projects; this is largely because of low electricity tariff. 

* electricity subsidies will be discontinued in the next twelve months and a new tariff will be issued shortly to implement the cancellation of subsidies;

* 597.67 million birr has been allocated to water resources development during the current fiscal year; In addition 508.9 million birr has been appropriated by regional administrations for medium-scale irrigation and water resources development projects;

* the only irrigation project being carried by the central government is the Gode project and it is behind schedule in its implementation;

* Most of the health and education sector projects are being implemented by regional administrations;

* budgets will continue to be transferred from development projects whose implementation is lagging behind to those which are being implemented fast;

* At present, the government annual recurrent budget and up to fifty percent of the capital budget are covered from our own financial resources;

* the government's strategy is to reach a stage where the country can cover a large part of the development budget through improving revenue collection, reducing non-developmental expenditures and making government development - oriented institutions more or less financially self-sufficient;

* top priority is being accorded to manpower development and civil service reform, including government finance policy on which a proclamation has been submitted to parliament for debate and approval;

* a proclamation on the restructuring of the Customs Authority is now before parliament;

* Similarly, a programme to reform the inland revenue service is under way;

* the telecommunications agency is now operating under its greatly reformed organizational and operational structure;

* last year regional administrations used their own budgets as security to borrow loans from banks and to on-lend to farmers;

* some 400,000 farmers participated in the government's agricultural extension service package last year;

* the government's agricultural extension programme is being expanded to cover animal and bee resource development;

* Among the economic policy objectives of the government, special attention is being paid to:

* Creating a stable macroeconomic environment;

* implementing the principles of a market economy stage by stage;

* putting in place a conducive economic policy and implementation framework;

* the government has succeeded in controlling inflation, reducing deficit financing and the supply of money;

* the government has stopped borrowing from the domestic banking system;

* the government repaid 978 million birr of its outstanding bank debt during the last five months of the 1996/97 fiscal year;

* importers are supplied with foreign exchange for the importation of all goods except used clothing;

* the rate of exchange is to be maintained within five percent of positive or negative variation;

* from Tir 1987 to Tikimt 1984 one hundred sixty-four retail shops, 54 small-sized hotels and restaurants, 42 factories and 2 big hotels were put up for auction. Of these, 109 retail shops, 16 medium-sized hotels and restaurants and 17 factories have been privatized;

* the trade licensing law which has now been submitted to parliament after having been endorsed by the Council of Ministers stipulates that applicants should be able to obtain trade licenses within 5 days from the date of application provided basic requirements are fulfilled;

* Similarly, imported goods should be cleared through the customs in seven days;

* Corruption will be penalized with long imprisonment, not with only monetary fines as is the case now;

It is all very nice to hear all this good economic news and be told about the very positive plans for the future, but millions of Ethiopians especially in urban areas, are still suffering acutely from lack of food security, employment, housing, potable water, electricity, and health and educational facilities; with respect to economic plans drawn up for the future, the problem, as always, is the divergence of words from deeds. Why was nothing said about the number of new jobs created during the first five months of the 1996/97 fiscal year? Practically no housing construction is being undertaken by private individuals in urban areas because of the unavailability of land and water and electricity shortages.

It is surprising to note that despite the grand road construction plan, what has actually been achieved in the entire country during the first five months of the current fiscal year is the construction of only about 136 km of roads, 78 km of which are gravel. The Gilgel-Gibe hydroelectric power project is still lagging behind in the midst of an electricity shortage nation-wide that is threatening to seriously arrest the country's economic development. On the other hand, the plan to purchase 60 - megawatt diesel generators reverses the previous government's strategy of converting to hydropower motivated by the high cost of fuel-based electricity generation. Concerning geothermal power, some twenty years ago a German expert on an IMF mission here asked an Ethiopian geothermal power expert who said the first geothermal power project was being implemented, "when may we expect the first electric light bulb powered by this project?" The Ethiopian expert blinked his eyes and said, "in about a year's time!" There is still no such electric light bulb twenty years later!

EELPA is said to be strapped for money; how come it is buying a lot Tof government treasury bills and bonds? Looking at the amounts of the face values of treasury bills for which EELPA has been bidding on the T. bills auction market, one would think it is awash with cash, not hard up for money, that is, unless one wants to use cash shortage as a pretext for raising the electricity tariff! Regarding irrigation, the only irrigation project being carried out by the central government is the Gode project which is way behind schedule.

This is rather strange for a country that professes to have achieved self- sufficiency in food. Fertilizer is no use without water! On the question of budget transfers, care should be taken not to let this procedure be abused. There have been instances where transfers have been effected to favoured regions on this pretext. It is often argued in this regard that mere financial regional budget allocations are not enough if state-owned and often private construction, transport and other implementation capacities are deployed in favoured regions as a matter of priority.

The trick is simple enough: give a region a budget; send all the construction firms to the favoured regions or region; complete all the projects in the favoured region way ahead of schedule; tell the first region," hard luck! we are taking your money because you haven't been able to use it!"

On the issue of bank borrowing by regional administrations, a dangerous precedent is being set in a situation where the financial management of regional administrations is highly unreliable. Regional administrations are being allowed not only to borrow money on their own account, but also to engage in lending , which is a highly specialized area of finance usually restricted to banks and other financial institutions.

Expect widespread financial mismanagement and default!

On the issue of expanding the government's agricultural extension programme to the livestock and other animal breeding sectors, caution should be exercised to back it up with in-depth domestic and external market studies. Also, care should be taken in the screening of hybrid livestock imported from abroad, especially since the so-called mad cow disease can no more be taken lightly!

With respect to the claim that the government has stopped borrowing from the domestic banking system, what about government treasury bills bought by the CBE, Awash International Bank and other private banks? In fact, what about loans being taken by regional administrations, which are part of the government structure? Isn't the Ministry of Finance taking any direct advances from the National Bank of Ethiopia? Hard to believe!

Finally, the promises to grant an applicant a trade license in 5 days, and clear goods through the Customs in seven days are great if they can be implemented. We have our doubts, though, because we are not getting land in sixty days in Addis Ababa, like it was promised in the revised investment code, although 60 days is far too long. Is there any good reason why investors and home builders cannot have access to land on an hourly basis!?


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


397 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 14, 1997


Arts and Entertainment;
Theodros Teshome - Ethiopia's New Film-Maker


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1080 words


 

Addis Ababa - Theodros Teshome's 'Gilbet Alem' was screened at the German Cultural Institute Monday and received warm applause. 'Gilbet Alem' is a 130 minute film set in the town of Jimma. The story begins with a fire that causes the death of a farmer and his wife. The film is fast paced and smooth as it follows the life of the only survivor, their son young Muluken (played by Muluken Teshome) as he tries to find his sister and make a living in Jimma. Moreover, not only has Muluken, a simple country boy, to deal with the strangeness of town life, but as luck would have it his life is in danger when he witnesses the murder of an undercover policeman by a notorious gang.

'Gilbet Alem' is the first film for Theodros--a purchasing and supplies management graduate. Preferring not to go to Muger, where he was stationed, Theodros chose instead to stay in Addis and continue to work at a small photo studio--as he had done all through college. Soon, Theodros who had been taking photographs since grade eight, began to get offers from other studios in city. Working for the highest bidder seemed to be the order of the day as Theodros made his way around the well-known studios such as Kulibi, Photo Fili and Photo Fine. 

It was the secondary school leaving certificate that put an end to the only career that Theodros wanted to follow because of family influence-- to be a lawyer like his uncle. Nonetheless, it was a neighbour from his Jimma days that had a big impact on his life. "I was turning out to be somewhat of trouble maker," he recalled, but the man who owned a photo shop asked Theodros' parents if it would not be a good idea if they let the boy come and 'work' with him after school. They readily agreed and from the 'bad boy' image that he was fast cultivating, Theodros began to develop a passion for photography.

Though exceptionally talented at photography, it was only while at the Addis Ababa Commercial College that he first used a video camera. "I was at a wedding to take photos when the video man failed to turn up. As I was the only one there whose task was remotely related, they asked my to fill in. I knew nothing about video cameras but I did not let on. I pretended I was used to another kind of camera and casually asked the groom how this particular one functioned. " Theodros never did see the video he took but since he was given more money than they agreed, he figures it could not have been that bad. From then on taking videos of weddings and such became a normal thing for him. Theodros has not had any professional training and "Those places that do offer courses had nothing new to teach me," he says. How he learnt to improve was by looking at videos taken by professionals.

During a talk with one writer, Theodros began to get interested in the possibility of making a film. Nothing came out of this and when his mother died, he went back to Jimma where the rest of the family lived. The eldest of six children, Theodros felt a deep sense of responsibility. While there he saw his brother Muluken in a play and was very impressed . The fate of Muluken, who had dropped out of school and turned to bad habits had weighed on Theodros' mind for some time. "I knew if I just gave him money he would spend it in no time, so I approached him with the idea of taking part in a film. He agreed but did not put much faith in it succeeding." As Muluken went about finding the cast, Theodros gone down to the serious business of writing the script. Not satisfied with what he wrote he approached several script writers to help him out. Some wanted high fees while others asked for a share in the profits. A script writer from Jimma, Endale Chanko however only asked for one thing--that his name appears on screen. This was an acceptable proposal and Theodros' film--that was begun with 3,000 birr and finally cost 24,000 birr-- started to take shape. (The cast's expense was covered by him and all have been promised a share in the profits.)

Of the total 23 casts (Theodros himself had a small part), only six were members of a drama club. The rest came from different backgrounds including a driver, an Amharic teacher and a martial arts instructor. The parts he had great difficulty in filling were that of the leading actress and the main character's sister. That problem was solved however when he went to the small town of Agaro to cover a wedding and saw one of the bridesmaids. When her sister turned up and he saw the uncanny resemblance between her and his brother it made up his mind. With the help of the girl's uncle, Theodros managed to get them to agree to take the parts.

"When I had money we filmed, when there was nothing everyone went their separate ways," Theodros said, explaining that it took a year to wrap up production. Filming was done on a VHS camera and that affected the quality especially of the colour--but what Theodros found most constraining was not owning the video camera and the loss of 'experimental freedom' he lost as a result of it.

The end product was nonetheless impressive. "I was very much astonished and surprised that one young man could do such a thing," exclaimed Mrs Sabina Hagemann, director of the German Cultural Institute. To her Theodros is someone with potential and his commitment to portray the good about life in the countryside, is commendable.

Theodros Teshome is waiting expectantly to see how 'Gilbet Alem' will do. In the meantime a new idea for a second film has already begun forming in his head. With the promise that, "the first 10,000 birr will go to buy a proper video camera," Theodros' second film promises to come out more polished and well worth seeing.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


398 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 14, 1997


Ethiopia;
Swiss Mission Looks into Ways of Assisting Decentralisation


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Addis Ababa - A two-man Swiss mission left Monday 10 March after conducting a preliminary evaluation into ways their government could assist Ethiopia in its ongoing decentralisation process.

During their two-week stay, Luc Vodoz from the Swiss based C.E.A.T, -a firm engaged mostly with urban and country planning ("anything to do with territory") in connection with local economy, transport, energy and conflict management--and Dr. Valentin Zellweger from the foreign ministry of Switzerland met with bilateral donors, various officials including those from the prime minister's office, as well as the speaker of the federal council . Switzerland being a federal country-- and conceding that while in its case it was a bottom up approach, for Ethiopia it is the reverse-- Dr. Zellweger noted, "We have a particular interest in knowing your experience, in knowing if there is a way for Switzerland to try to assist you to think about our experience we have with decentralisation." According to the mission, the Swiss government will , at the latest, make its decision on their recommendation by September. 

The mission visited Jijiga in the Somali region where they concentrated on the judiciary and administration. "We wanted to concentrate on an emerging region," they said in explanation as to why that particular region will act as the 'testing ground'. The two were suitably impressed by what they encountered in the region and found themselves, "very surprised to find so many people who are convinced that they need to look into the future." What the region needed, Dr. Zellweger said, was financial assistance. "It is impressive," he remarked, "everything is there. But it is like a mould, you have to put in the funds, the infrastructure needs and the capacity building."

Switzerland has assisted several countries such as Bolivia, Madagascar and Burkina Faso when they were undergoing federalisation.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

March 14, 1997


Ethiopia;
Ethio-Indian Tie Strengthened After PM's Visit


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

Addis Ababa - A visit to India by prime minister Meles Zenawi concluded on Sunday with both sides pronouncing it a success. Meles met with all the senior officials of government in India to discuss ways of furthering bilateral relations. 

The Indian Embassy in Addis Ababa told Addis Tribune that discussions were held with members of the business community as well as the agricultural sector. Whilst in the Punjab, Meles visited an agricultural university and witnessed Indian methods of integrating academic knowledge and research results with practical hands-on farming. India will maintain its policies concerning Ethiopian nationals studying there; a policy which sometimes forfeits a place for an Indian national, said the embassy.

The visit was in fact extended, a rare occurrence for official visits, and the feeling from both countries was a productive one. There will be a catalogue fair of Indian products at the end of this month, disclosed the embassy.

March 14, 1997


Ethiopia;
Black Lion's Director Hopes to Make Further Contribution


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Addis Ababa - Professor Johannes Bircher first came to Ethiopia in January 1974. He was with a mission of 46 Swiss people who set out to run and equip the dormant Black Lion Hospital, then the Prince Mekonnen Hospital. He was forced to leave shortly after due to the political situation but returned for a visit in 1995.

This month Prof. Bircher was back in Ethiopia serving as external examiner at the Department of Medicine of the Medical Faculty of the Addis Ababa University (AAU). He told us that six physicians took the examination as specialists in internal medicine and all passed. Prof. Bircher said he had the opportunity to congratulate the staff and wrote a good report.

In addition, the professor met Her Excellency the German Ambassador to Ethiopia, to explore opportunities for co-operation between the Medical Faculty of the University of Witten/Herdecke in Germany, where Professor Bircher is Dean, and their counterpart at the Addis Ababa University. This was met favourably by the German ambassador. Consequently, the professor visited the Academic Vice President of the AAU, DR. Hailu Ayele, and the Dean of the Medical Faculty, Dr. Milkias Shamebo, who were both interested in the idea of co-operation.

401 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 14, 1997


Ethiopia;
Letter: Tourism and Ethiopia


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1587 words


 

Addis Ababa - As an American who is residing in Ethiopia and who has traveled extensively in the country, I read your February 28th article on tourism in Ethiopia with great interest. I have several comments about it.

It is clear from the article, if not the headline, that there were nowhere near 95,000 actual tourists in Ethiopia in 1994. The table on page 4 lists only 79,125 persons, of which only 18,056 were here on vacation. Businessmen are not tourists. Neither are transit passengers. On page 4, your economics correspondent states that the majority of "tourists" spent only one day in Ethiopia. These people may be transit passengers forced by airlines schedules or cancellations to spend a day or a night in the country, but they are clearly not tourists. No one can pretend to be a tourist if he spends only one day there. If you add the categories of "Transit" and "Not stated" in the table on page 4, you account for more than 47% of the people in the table. 

People do not come to Ethiopia to see wildlife, other than birds. The big game in Ethiopia has been, and is still, being killed. When I was in Mago National Park in November 1995, an elephant had just been killed but the game wardens could do nothing about it because they had not a single vehicle to patrol the park or chase poachers. Tourists and animal lovers go to Kenya, Tanzania, Botswana, South Africa, etc., to see game.

Is it undoubted that Ethiopia offers more historical monuments and sites than any other country in Africa, except Egypt. But visiting those sights is not a pleasant experience. The Goha, Roha and Yeha hotels in Gondar, Lalibela and Axum are considered to be the best hotels in those towns. Their prices are fairly low by international standards ($36 per night). But their accommodations are very far below foreigners' expectations in comfort and facilities. The beds in all of them are so soft as to be uncomfortable, none have hot water all of the time (and the Roha seldom has hot water at any time or any water at most times), none have room service, electricity is sporadic at best and telephones are poor or nonexistent.

The domestic service of Ethiopian Airlines is, in a word, terrible. It is insulting to tourists to charge them more than the service is worth -- at least more than the local people are charged for the identical service. (Foreign tourists get discounts in other countries -- such as Eurailpasses in western Europe.) For their high fares, they get unreliable or nonexistent service. In three trips around the Historic Route, involving a total of 15 flights, I can count fewer than half which were on schedule (that is within an hour of the timetable). In April 1996, flights were simply canceled on the pretext of lack of airplane fuel. (As if a company which has the huge foreign exchange earnings of Ethiopian Airlines did not have the money to buy fuel! Far worse is the suggestion which I heard that management had not ordered the fuel in time to have it available when needed.)

In addition, the airline shows its incredible inefficiency and its contempt for its passengers' convenience by making them appear at the airport 11/2 hours before a flight, even in a place like Lalibela. What does one do at the Lalibela airport hut for 11/2 hours? The government also shows its indifference to tourists by having no facilities for passengers at airports for the two major tourist sites in Ethiopia - Lalibela and Axum. ( I know that new facilities, runways at least, are being constructed.)

Unfortunately, one of the greatest barriers to tourism in Ethiopia is the Ethiopians themselves. Ethiopians are perfectly delightful and gracious in their homes and in other personal contacts. But in the street and in public facilities they are harassing and rude. How many times have you been at a postal clerk's window, being served, when another person puts his or her envelope on top of yours, demanding to be served immediately? How many times have you seen a foreigner (especially a white one) being followed by children and adults demanding money, trying to pick a pocket, persistently shouting " farengi", or throwing rocks? The first comment any foreigner who is resident in Ethiopia makes about another African or Asian country he has visited is that the people leave him alone. Taking a walk in Addis Ababa or any other town else is simply an unpleasant experience. In addition, the staff of many hotels and other facilities do not usually make a tourist feel welcome. Smiles are few and far between. A tourist seldom hears polite phrases such as, "we hope that you enjoy (or enjoyed) your stay here". Most people employed in the tourist industry treat the tourists as if they were doing him a favor by providing the service which the tourist pays for. This will not change until Ethiopians have enough self respect, self discipline and respect for other people that they change how they behave in public.

Another serious drawback to tourism in Ethiopia is the high cost of getting here. Airfares to Addis Ababa from Europe or the United States are outrageously high. Apparently, the Ethiopian government does not permit very much competition in fares. I am sure that this is done to protect Ethiopian Airline's very high fares (which your economics correspondent seems to believe should be a high priority).

The two discount airlines, Egypt and Saudia, have only two flights each per week. It costs much less to fly from Europe or North America to Nairobi or even Cape Town than it does to Addis Ababa, even though both of them are farther away. In Cape Town, one sees advertisements for fares to Chicago, USA of less than US$950 round trip. It costs over US$1800 (the discount fare) to make the round trip from Addis Ababa, even though the trip from Addis Ababa is thousands of kilometers shorter. So long as the government uses its power over landing rights to protect Ethiopian Airlines' high international fares, the rest of the tourists industry will suffer.

With its current primitive tourist facilities, Ethiopia can attract only the adventure traveler. The adventure traveler makes appeals to those who want to go far off the beaten track. This kind of traveler will forego creature comforts taken for granted in Europe, Kenya, Southern Africa, etc.; communication with family back home; adequate medical care if injured or ill; reliability in travel arrangements and a pleasant experience for the sake of being somewhere his friends have not been. Obviously, Ethiopia cannot pride services like reliable transportation, medical care, telephones, potable water, etc. to foreigners when these services are not available to citizens either. But it cannot expect tourists in any significant numbers to subject themselves to the conditions which exist here.

Word of mouth advertising is almost the only advertising there is for travel in Ethiopia. One certainly does not see advertisements for Ethiopia in newspapers and magazines published in Europe or North America. And, unfortunately, word of mouth reports of travelers in Ethiopia have many negative aspects. Especially this is so when the travelers compare their experiences here with their experiences in Eritrea, Yemen, Kenya, Zimbabwe, etc.

As your economics correspondent pointed out, tourism is the world's largest industry. In many developed countries, it is disliked as a low wage, low skills employer. In a country with high illiteracy, low levels of skills and high unemployment, tourism would be a boon to people who have no other prospects. Hotels employ gardeners, maintenance personnel and others who do not need to know English or other languages because they do not deal directly with guests. Expansion of the tourist industry in Ethiopia would bring many benefits to the people and the economy. But expansion will not happen until tourists leave the country with more pleasant than unpleasant experiences. And that will not happen until the tourists services are improved and tourists are treated with the respect that they deserve.

I think that Ethiopia could offer one of the best experiences the world has to offer tourists. Its climate (about eight months of sunshine outside of the rainy seasons), historical sites, trekking, mountain climbing, river rafting and animal viewing have much potential. But the industry will remain only a potential industry until tourists are made to feel comfortable and welcome and receive good value for their money.

Michael P. Porter, Addis Ababa


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


402 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 14, 1997


Ethiopia;
Attacks on the Press (Editorial)


BYLINE: Tamrat Bekele, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

Addis Ababa - The Committee To Protect Journalists (CPJ) reported today that 185 journalists were in prison in 24 countries at the end of 1996, and 27 were killed in the line of duty. This is a grim statistic that is published in Attacks on the Press in 1996. 

Sadly, Ethiopia is mentioned as one of the offenders in the CPJ report. Eighteen journalists are in jail. Theoretically, Ethiopia has included all it takes in the Constitution to assure freedom of speech and the right of journalists. Article 29 of Ethiopia's Constitution enumerates the right of thought, opinion and expression. But we don't practice what we preach.

We have to learn and build a tradition that the individual is the best judge of how to write and speak. We have to destroy the perception that freedom of expression is a threat to government. Citizens should be encouraged to be an active citizenry "discussing without fear, the conduct of the public Servants, in every department of the government."

We pray that Ethiopia shall not be mentioned as an offender in CPJ's 1997 report.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


403 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 14, 1997


Ethiopia;
Gojam Farmers Appeal to Federal Government


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Addis Ababa - A large number of farmers from Gojam have made their way to Addis Ababa to appeal to the federal government against what they saw as unfair treatment against them in their home province.

Camped out at the St. George Church park, the men voiced complaints against officials back in Gojam who labelled all farmers who had any involvement in the various associations during the former government's time as "bureaucrats". Ever since two months ago, the fleeing farmers said, the so called " Bureaucrats" have had their land confiscated and only allowed a tiny plot of land. Similar action has reportedly been taken against the family's of those who have held posts during Emperor Haile Selassie's time.

"When we asked them what we shall feed our children they told us to give them stones," the farmers bitterly recalled. They also showed papers they say they had to smuggle in. These contain signatures of all those in their locality that had their land taken from them.

Some of the men claim that apart from the food they get from the city's inhabitants, the Red Cross had also extended its help. However, Ato Kassahun Indayalu head of the Addis Ababa Red Cross Branch denied any knowledge of the farmer's presence in the city.

According to some of the farmers, they will not go back home until they get assurance that they will get equal share of the land and moreover will not be punished for having come to Addis Ababa.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March 14, 1997


Sports - General;
Ethiopia's Haile Set to Dash for a Million


BYLINE: Our Staff Reporter, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

Addis Ababa - Sportswear giants Adidas announced that it would sponsor a winner-take-all $1 million race on May 31 between two of its world-renowned clients, Noureddine Morceli of Algeria and Haile Gebreselassie of Ethiopia.

The $1 million prize will be awarded only if the runner runs his two-mile race at Helengo, Netherlands, in less than 8 minutes, something that has never been done at the rarely contested distance. The next day in Toronto, two Olympic sprint champions, Michael Johnson and Donovan Bailey, will race against each other at 150 metres in a similar, privately sponsored $2 million race.

Adidas will try to promote its head-to-head match as a logical follow-up to Roger Bannister's conquest of the 4-minute mile. Athletes and sponsors have been arguing that athletics needs to increase its profile, and these boxing- style promotions are a good start. But the age-old protectors of track and field are worried that shoe companies such as Adidas and Nike will organize their own competitions to the detriment of Grand Prix meets, world championships and the Olympics.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


405 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 14, 1997


Ethiopia;
Unorthodox Economics (Rent Hikes by Ethiopian Orthodox Church)


BYLINE: Our Economics Correspondent, Addis Tribune (Addis Ababa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1734 words


 

Addis Ababa - "... if merchants, paying and accepting market prices, made gains, this was all right, and if they suffered losses, this was bad luck or else a penalty for incompetence so long as gain or loss resulted from the unhampered working of the market mechanism though not if it resulted, for example, from price fixing by public authority or monopolistic concerns"

- "Scholastic Doctors and Natural Law Philosophers", History of Economic Analysis, Joseph A. Schumpeter.

"We have seen that he (Aristotle) condemned monopoly prices. It is not far- fetched to equate, for Aristotle's purpose, monopoly prices with prices that some individual or group of individuals have set to their own advantage".

So, free-market prices were accepted as just even by the ancients, but monopoly pricing or price fixing was unforgivably condemned. We are alluding to the hoary concept of "Just price" in connection with the very substantial rent increases made by the Ethiopian Orthodox Church on its real property recently restituted to it after having been nationalized by the Derg. The rent hikes are remarkable for at least two things: the swiftness with which they came so soon after restitution; and their unorthodoxly unconscionable magnitude. 

The latter feature could be assessed from the following mini-sample of the rent increases made:

Previous rent(in birr) -- New rent (in birr) -- %change

Gebre-Tensai pastry: 1280 -- 22,000 -- 1,619

Saba Snack: 400 -- 3,000 -- 650

Photo Lina: 450 -- 3876 -- 761

Mohammud Music Shop: 420 -- 6728 -- 1502

Seiko Pastry: 288 -- 18,700 -- 6393

Awash Power Engineering: 650 -- 8,265.40 -- 1,172

Mohammed Awal Tailor Shop: 70 -- 1,142.40 -- 1532

Source: "Reporter" (Amharic), Megabit 1, 1989 E.C.

Hence, there is hardly any doubt that the rent increases are stratospheric. They are to be effective as of March 10, 1997. The rent increases are based on three different rates per square meter of floor space in church-owned apartment and other buildings used for commercial purposes. Rooms and flats on first to third floors are charged at the rate of 85 birr per square meter while fourth and fifth floors and rooms above sixth floor are assessed at the rate of 76 birr and 68 birr, respectively. The comparative average rate for government-owned buildings is reported to be 92 birr per square meter.

Lessees affected by the rent hikes petitioned the Patriarch of the Ethiopian Orthodox Church, his Holiness Abune Paulos, on March 6, 1997 on the premises of the Patriarchate. The concerned spokesman of the Patriarchate told the gathered petitioners that the rent increases were based on studies made on house rents charged for similar government-owned and private-owned houses. He underscored the contention that market forces guided the measure to revise the rents. Among the important reasons which necessitated the upward revision were, he said, uncertainty about the continuation of government subventions for the church, the obligation to pay wages to church personnel and the need to maintain church-owned buildings and improve their facilities.

After launching into the history of the Ethiopian Orthodox Church and the trials and tribulations it passed through over the years, the Patriarch, His Holiness Abuna Paulos, told the petitioners on his part that the rent increases were necessitated by the uncertainty of financial support from the government budget in the future and not out of cruelty or bad intent. "There was a time as when the Ethiopian Orthodox Church owned a third of the country's land, but what should it do in times of financial distress?", said the Patriarch.

On the other hand one petitioner bitterly commented "I am dismayed to the discover that the spiritual father who I thought would reverse the decision which increased the rent spoke not as a father but as an economist. I shall henceforth have neither the strength nor the stamina to stand on the premises of the church."

The Patriarch did however give room for discussion by agreeing to meet with the group again. He in fact suggested the lessees go and study the changes, and then return with suggestions. Inside sources say that the Patriarch as a spiritual leader would probably accommodate the request of the business group to a certain extent. As a result, lessees on Thursday met at the Addis Ababa Chamber and have elected 13 people to prepare a proposal for the Patriarch. Interestingly, unlike the case of Region 14, both the Church and the businessmen have taken the route for consultation instead of confrontation.

What would an economist say about the rent hikes? If it is the free market that made the increases, then it must be a very special kind of free market. It is not often that free markets send rents skyrocketing by as high as over 6000 percent! Without a shadow of doubt, papal economics of the brand of the Roman Catholic Church of the Middle Ages would denounce it as outrageous. It would be unorthodox in the extreme because it would violate the guiding principle of the "just price", which essentially upheld the fairness of market-determined prices, but ran counter to monopoly pricing or price fixing by any organized body or organ. Hence, Thomas Aquinas, the great medieval religious philosopher, would have condemned rent increases of the above magnitude and their manner of determination. Similarly, Aristotle, the encyclopedic intellect of ancient times, would have described them as grossly unethical.

But we are now on the doorstep of the third millennium. Would it be appropriate to invoke the economic reasoning of the Middle Ages and ancient times? The essential truth of the matter is that it would be. Monopoly pricing and price fixing are still heavily frowned upon. Are the rent increases made by the administration of the Ethiopian Orthodox Church a result of monopoly power? There is a considerable body of evidence to show that they are. Let us, for now, simply try to pursue the following rudimentary line of reasoning: land is a state monopoly in Ethiopia; as a result, its supply on the market is heavily controlled; as a result of which its current prices are sky-high; house rents are extremely high not only because of exorbitant land prices, but also because the supply of houses is severely restricted by the artificial shortage of land created by the restriction on its supply which in turn is created by the said state monopoly on land; Hence, house rents are determined not in a context of free markets for land and houses, but rather in a context of state monopoly on land and the derived control on the supply of houses and buildings. So, the administration of the Ethiopian Orthodox Church made the rent increases in a situation where the supply of houses and buildings is restricted by state monopoly on land.

Further, the state itself owns 51 percent of the urban housing stock, compounding the monopoly position of the state in the housing sector. Clearly, the rent hikes were based not on the free play of the forces of demand and supply, but on the forces operating in a highly controlled housing market. Monopoly pricing is unethical and usually unbearably high, which was why the affected renters were bitter about it all. We would also suggest that government budgetary support for the Ethiopian Orthodox Church continue until such a time as the church is able to generate sufficient revenue to carry out its mission. Unorthodox economics would be hopelessly out of place in a church renowned for its orthodoxy.

Moreover, the misconception that all business people are by definition overly rich and therefore can afford and bear any rent, price or tax imposed on them should be put to rest. Actually, most people in business earn just decent incomes enough to support themselves and their families and to keep their businesses going, and with a bit of luck, expanding. Hence, any excessive increases in the costs of doing business, like the rent increases discussed above, would adversely affect not only their incomes, but also the employment opportunities they have created for their compatriots.

Occasionally, moderate rent and price revisions may be justified, but abrupt and precipitous rent increases of the magnitudes now made by the authorities of the Ethiopian Orthodox Church would be unjust. Further, it would badly tarnish the public image of the officials of he Ethiopian Orthodox Church to be embroiled in pecuniary disputes at a time when they confronted by multifarious controversies of the religions and spiritual nature. We would strongly advise the authorities of the Church to err on the side of mercy and moderation.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


406 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 16, 1997


South Africa;
Massive funeral for assassinated taxi drivers


BYLINE: Mzilikazi wa Afrika & Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

SESHEGO - More than 10 000 mourners attended the joint funeral of four independent taxi drivers on Sunday who were murdered execution style two weeks ago and dumped in a cave in the Northern Province.

Speakers at the ceremony at Seshego Stadium near Pietersburg turned the funeral into a campaign against taxi violence in the province, accusing warring taxi organisations of using the lives of their passengers and drivers as commodities in their bids for increased power and profit.

"We are supposed to be driving our clients safely to their destinations, but instead thousands have been killed to further the interests of the taxi owners," said Federated Long Distance Taxi Association (FELDTA) president, Fanyana Manganyi. 

"This monotonous warfare must end before our passengers decide to desert the taxi trade altogether and start using some alternative transport system."

Praising the police for reacting swiftly to the murders of Tutus Molepo, Silas Nkoeng, Paul Letsoalo and Michael Mathenya, speaker after speaker called for the death sentence to be imposed on the 14 rival taxi drivers who have been arrested for the killings.

The 14 men were arrested by police last week shortly after the bodies of the four Bosekaboeja Taxi Association (BTA) drivers were found in caves near Burgersfort.

According to police, the four deceased were abducted by rival drivers from the South African Long Distance Taxi Association (SALDTA) after attempts to encourage BTA driver to defect and join SALDTA were unsuccessful.

All four men had had their hands tied behind their backs before being shot numerous times in the head.

During the clashes, another BTA taxi driver was robbed of R1500 cash, which he used as a diversion to escape from his pursuers. BTA treasurer, Abraham Mokoadi (39) was also shot in the leg while leaping

out of the BTA office window after SALDTA driver stormed the place two weeks ago.

Both men will testify for the State against Lucas Morena, Andries Mmaru, Petros Mosotho, Steven Mhlala, Mathews Magoale. Petro Makanyane, James and John Maopane, April Kgole, Johannes Mashigoane, David Mafiri, Samuel Mathaba and Samson Makofane when the men appear in the Lydenburg Magistrate's Court on March 17.

Heavily armed police monitored the funeral from armoured vehicles on Sunday but no incidents of violence were reported by 14h00.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


407 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 16, 1997


South Africa;
Disgraced MP begins prison sentence


BYLINE: Mzilikazi wa Afrika & Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 600 words


 

Nelspruit - Not even former ANC senator Patrick Mogale's ancestors and muti could keep him out of prison this week when police arrested him at a court hearing in Graskop for refusing to pay maintenance to an under-aged girl he impregnated in 1992.

Police whisked the belligerent former politician and current sangoma away on Wednesday to begin serving a three year prison term in Nelspruit Prison.

Mogale was kicked out of parliament and banned from the ANC for 5-years after the Sunday Times revealed last year that he had got the 14-year-old daughter of his best friend pregnant. 

During the court case where his attorney branded journalists as "dirty liberal Jews", Sunday Times also discovered that Mogale had previously been investigated by the KaNgwane Government for allegedly operating a sex-for- marks ring at the Mshadza Senior Secondary School, where he was the principal.

He was never charged, but was instead transferred out of the region after parents protested.

Mogale was still a school principal in 1992, when he allegedly raped his best friend and neighbour's daughter on two separate occasions. Her parents only found out about the incidents when she realised she was pregnant.

Although they confronted him, Mogale refused to accept financial responsibility for the girl or his child and so they sued him in the maintenance court.

An arrest warrant was issued for Mogale after the ignored the court's order to pay R300 per month, but he managed to evade the police for more than one year by moving between his home in Bushbuckridge and Parliament in Cape Town. After Sunday Times reported on the police search, he handed himself in to police in Cape Town.

Almost immediately after loosing his R15 000 per month senator's salary and brand new Mercedes Benz, Mogale signed up for a crash course at a sanusi school and became a popular Bushbuckridge sangoma.

He, however, continued to refuse to pay the R300 per month maintenance and R4000 arrears he was ordered to by the court and also swore that he would never "bow to Western Law when this is clearly a traditional matter".

Not even a contempt of court and statutory rape charges managed to sway his insistence on the issue and he instead offered to give the girl's family a goat and possibly marry her.

The outraged girl's family, who are devote Christians, rejected the offer.

Finally, more than two years after his first court appearance in the Bushbuckridge Magistrate's Court, Mogale was arrested at the Graskop Magistrate's Court where he had appeared yet again for refusing to pay maintenance.

Warrant Officer George Qwabe confirmed on Friday that Mogale was in a communal cell at Nelspruit Prison, where he will be put to work in the prison's administrative section for three years because of his "academic record and achievements".


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


408 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 16, 1997


South Africa;
International incident brewing over Dolpin Deal


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service (South Africa)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2160 words


 

Nelspruit - Mpumalanga's contentious multi-billion rand deal with the Dolphin Group is threatening to boil over into a fully blown diplomatic incident after the alleged fraudulent use of Kenya president Daniel arap Moi's name by the head of the Mpumalanga Parks Board (MPB).

MPB chief executive officer, Alan Gray insisted last month that he had received a personal letter from Moi vindicating the Dubai-based Dolphin Group's president, Ketan Somaia of any dubious business dealings or other scandals in Kenya.

He has since however refused to make copies of the letter public, or take calls from Kenya's High Commissioner in South Africa, Justice Mudavadi.

Gray's other business dealings also came under the spotlight this week, after a Mail & Guardian investigation discovered that at least two of his companies hold significant contracts with the MP.SOURCE&DATE

.TEXT 

The existence of the letter from President Moi, which allegedly clears Somaia of all wrongdoing in a R35-million security equipment tender for which he was paid seven years ago but for which the government never received any goods, has been repeatedly denied by Moi's office.

Dolphin, which cut a secret 50-year deal with Gray for the commercial monopoly of Mpumalanga's key tourism attractions, including the Blyde River Canyon, various state owned game reserves and Pilgrim's Rest, has also attempted to prevent M&G reporting on the use of Moi's name.

Widespread public outcry to the deal, however, forced Mpumalanga's provincial government to step in and negotiate amendments to the contract, including a 25-year reduction and the exclusion of Pilgrim's Rest and the Manyeleti Game Reserve.

"We do not care about the contract or the deal. But the use of our President's name is serious. Despite phoning him numerous times over the past three weeks, I have failed to speak to Gray or even get past his secretary - instead I am always told he is out or in meetings," explains Mudavadi.

"I have left messages for him to return my calls, but have yet to receive any reply."

Insisting that it was "inconceivable" that President Moi would ever personally send a letter to Gray, who is described by Mudavadi as a " relatively junior official", the High Commissioner said on Wednesday that " this whole thing still sounds very strange to me and my fellow diplomats".

"We want to know if this supposed letter really exists and if so, what is Gray doing with it. The only letter vindicating Somaia and acknowledged as being from Kenya is one from Public Accounts chairman Michael Wamalwa - and it has been withdrawn after it was revealed to be irregular," he added.

A senior High Commission official, who traveled to Nelspruit last week in an attempt to get further information about the letter told M&G that "Gray is playing cat and mouse games with us.

"The president is very touchy about people using his name and he vehemently denies ever writing the letter. We also have a big problem with Somaia's explanation of this episode," said the official, who refused to be named.

"Somaia insisted to us that Gray meant the letter was from him as president of Dolphin and not from Moi. But how can Somaia, who is at the very centre of this controversy, write a letter clearing himself - especially when Gray tries to use the letter to refute those allegations on national TV. It just doesn't hold water."

The possibility that Gray had perhaps been given a fraudulent letter from President Moi's office, signed in the name of the president and clearing Somaia, had been considered, the official said.

Internal investigations into the possibility were being conducted, he added.

Gray has previously insisted that he cannot make the letter public until he receives council from both his and Somaia's legal advisors. He has consistently refused to be drawn on why he would need to consult with Somaia's attorney's when the letter supposedly comes from President Moi.

When quizzed about Mudavadi's attempts to reach him this week, Gray refused to give either a telephonic interview or answer any questions verbally but he did request written questions for his immediate attention.

However, when these were submitted, his office replied that he was unavailable to answer them as he was "an exceptionally busy person (who) is not available at your beck and call ... our office runs on a very tight schedule and cannot attend to matters at your request whatever the time of day."

His personal assistant, Alison Zweers, also denied that any previous attempts had been made by M&G to contact Gray on the issue.

Amongst the questions M&G wished to put to Gray on Wednesday were queries about the size and terms of his package with MPB after an earlier confirmation that he is not a civil servant but instead serves as CEO on a fixed-term contract basis.

Former business associates allege that Gray has signed surety papers indicating he earned more than R50 000 per month.

Environmental MEC, David Mkhwanazi, also declined to specify exactly how much Gray earned but said that his salary was based on what a private-sector managing director, who controlled a company with an asset base equivalent to the MPB, would earn. "His salary is also directly linked to his performance and to how much money he is able to generate for the MPB," added Mkhwanazi.

Gray was appointed CEO after serving in the KaNgwane Parks Board as its financial director.

As a contract worker, Gray seems entitled to continue running his string of tourism, transport and medical rescue companies - most of which have significant contracts with the MPC.

All MPB employees, for example, are contractually obliged to take out membership with the Nelspruit based medical rescue company, Life Crisis - which is fully owned by Gray.

The vast majority of MPB's aerial game counting, darting and capture contracts are also awarded to Lowveld Helicopter Services - again a company that Gray has significant shares in.

Most other provincial government departments, including Environmental Affairs and the Premier's Office also make extensive use of Lowveld Helicopter Services without any tender procedures being followed.

While admitting that it is compulsory for MPB employees to sign up with Life Crisis, and that the company was appointed without being submitted to a tender process, Gray stressed last week that he had reclused himself from the decision-making process.

He insisted that the medical rescue service provided by Life Crisis was essential for MPB staff because of the dangerous nature of their jobs but said that his management would "soon be assessing the desirability of taking a fresh look at the issue".

Gray cited the "replacement" of the original, non-profit 'Section 21' Life Crisis company with a profit driven (Pty) Ltd operation, as the major reason for this reassessment.

The Section 21 company was dissolved and replaced by Life Crisis Management Services (Pty) Ltd last year after Lowveld Helicopter Services brought an urgent liquidation order against it for outstanding accounts.

Just before the liquidation order was served, all Life Crisis contracts and some of the Section 21 company's assets were transferred to Gray's new wholly- owned profit-driven company.

His partners in the Section 21 company are still paying back more than R600 000 to the liquidators but because Gray didn't sign surety, he owed nothing.

Absa is, however, investigating Gray in connection with the alleged irregular transfer of funds between various bank accounts and the depositing of cheques. Other than confirming the investigation, Absa's Nelspruit office refused to comment on the issue.

Among the higher profile government contracts awarded to Lowveld Helicopter Services were repeated "flips" around the province by the now-disgraced former government consultant, Eugene Nyati, various trips by Premier Mathews Phosa, environment MEC David Mkhwanazi and colleagues, as well as site-seeing tours by various Dolphin Group executives.

Lowveld Helicopter Services also flew a special MPB and Legislative delegation down to Parliament in Cape Town two weeks ago in a luxurious King Air fixed-wing plane and provided a helicopter to M-Net's Carte Blanche while they filmed an insert on Dolphin's deal with MPC.

Gray however refused to say this week how much money MPB had spent to date with Lowveld Helicopter Services (LHS), insisting that this type of information could only be demanded by the provincial Legislature.

"The MPB is not required to answer random enquiries about its detailed expenditure figures - but this should not be construed as the organisation not being publicly liable," he said.

He also refused to comment on the view that disclosing the expenditure was in public interest in light of his shareholding in LHS.

Lowveld Helicopter Service staff, however, suddenly stopped using the company's name when answering the phone this week and instead welcomed callers to "Air Excellence".

According to sales staff at the office, all Lowveld Helicopter Service's assets, staff, contracts and helicopters had simply been transferred to Air Excellence and "business is continuing as usual".

Gray also refused to comment on a R3,5-million breach of contract law suite against LHS and against himself in person by the world's biggest private helicopter company - the Russian registered TyvmenAviaTrans.

According to regional TyvmenAviaTrans manager, Andre Denasov, the Russian company entered into a joint venture contract "amazingly similar to the Dolphin deal" with LHS in 1993 but by 1996 they were still allegedly owed over R2,2-million in profits and staff expenses.

"Because Gray had drawn up the contract and designed the financial system, we didn't even have access to the joint venture's bank accounts or books," explained Denasov.

"We were smooth talked into this thing by Gray, who even offered setting us up as President Mandela's personal helicopter courier company, while selling the idea to us." Numerous other disgruntled former business associates of Gray also contracted M&G, all with stories of how their companies had been liquidated by Gray, who allegedly walked away all the contracts and remaining assets of the various companies, while they were left with setting the debts. Other companies in which Gray currently has interests include : Helicopter Investment Services, Eastern Transvaal Ambulance Services, Emergency Vehicle Hire Services, Corridor Management Services, Eagle Helicopters and Zambian Tours.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English
