415 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 17, 1997


Business and Finance;
Mozambique's Economy Starts To Grow


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 957 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - Mozambique's economy showed that it was on the path of recovery with the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) growing at about 6 percent in 1996.

Announcing this in his state-of-the nation address to parliament in Maputo Monday, President Joachim Chissano said there was also a 24 percent leap in commodity exports while inflation declined from 54 percent in 1995 to 16.6 percent last year.

The other "tangible advances", Chissano said, included the low depreciation rate of the national currency, the metical, by only 5 percent during the past year. 

He attributed the success to government's continued austerity policy to strictly control public expenditure, thus allowing the banks to make credit available for the private sector "without producing inflationary pressures."

According to Chissano, 1996 was "a year rich in political, economic and social achievements." He told the Assembly of the Republic that living conditions were gradually improving, as indicated by statistics showing an increase in life expectancy, an increase in the number of schools functioning, and an expansion in the health network.

The President said, however, that about 400,000 Mozambicans had been affected by the recent flooding in the Pungue, Buzi and Zambezia river valleys. The floods had forced about 20,000 Mozambicans into exile in Malawi and Zambia.

In the two worst affected provinces, Sofala and Tete, preliminary estimates were that 173,000 hectares of crops had been lost.

"Many of the flood victims have lost all their means of survival," said Chissano, adding that " efforts are under way to guarantee a three months food supply to the 125,000 people worst affected."

He said with the rescue operations in flood-stricken areas now over, the top priority was "to normalize the life of the population, guaranteeing the supply of food and other necessities, and the rebuilding of their homes."

Chissano told parliament that Mozambique also had an excellent harvest in 1996, which "has helped reduce dependence on imported grain."

He, however, expressed concern at the alarming rise in crime last year. " Our police has faced criminals working with modern and sophisticated equipment," he said.

"Some policemen have succumbed to bribes and some have even worked hand-in- hand with criminals. A lot still needs to be done to make our police a credible force."


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


416 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 17, 1997


Business and Finance;
Air Zimbabwe Pilots, Flight Engineers Continue Strike


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - The strike by Air Zimbabwe pilots and flight engineers entered its fourth day Monday with passengers continuing to be inconvenienced by disrupted flights.

"So far there has been no progress on the strike and the team comprising members of the airline's management and striking pilots and flight engineers has not been set up yet," Davis Mwenga said. 

Mwenga, the airline's public relations manager, said that the four aircraft leased from Nationwide of South Africa continued to carry passengers to most of the local and regional destinations. The London flight has remained cancelled since the strike started Friday.

"We are still flying passengers and one of our planes is still in use, using contract pilots," he said.

The leased aircraft were covering destinations such as Lusaka, Johannesburg, Victoria Falls, Hwange and Kariba. Inconvenienced passengers to London were being booked on other airlines.

The strike comes after several months of negotiations between the pilots and management.

The estimated 70 pilots and flight engineers are demanding higher salaries and perks which compare favorably with those of other airlines.

They are reportedly demanding an annual salary of about 350,000 zimdollars (31,818 U.S. dollars), excluding allowances for captains.

Management has said that, at this stage, it could not afford the increments due to the low profits the airline has made.

The airline, with a fleet of nine aircraft, employs some 2,000 people.

Other passengers to domestic destinations were being booked with the Zimbabwe Express Airlines, the country's only private airline.

"We are trying to move passengers as much as possible but we are acknowledging the fact that we have inconvenienced passengers and we apologize for that," Mwenga said.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


417 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 17, 1997


United States and Africa;
Hillary Clinton Arrives In Dakar


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - Hillary Clinton, the wife of the United States president Bill Clinton, arrived in Dakar, Senegal, Monday, on the first leg of a six-nation African tour to promote democracy and civil society.

She was initially due to arrive Saturday but was delayed by the brief hospitalization of President Bill Clinton, who underwent knee surgery.

Hillary Clinton is accompanied by ranking U.S. officials, and her 17-year old daughter, Chelsea. 

George Moose, former U.S. ambassador to Senegal and now the deputy secretary of state for African affairs is also on Clinton's entourage.

In a statement to the media, Clinton said she was determined to strengthen the already good relations between Dakar and Washington.

"My visit to the village of Saam Ndaye and the United States Peace Peace Corps Training Center will give me the opportunity to see how to work, hand in hand, towards the development of relations between the two countries," she said.

The former slave island of Goree, some three kilometres from Dakar, in the Atlantic Ocean, was, she said, "a symbol of the historical relations between our two nations."

It was also, she said, "reminiscent of the horrendous memories of slavery but constitutes at the same time a testimony of the force of human spirit."

She added: "The United States of America has benefited from the genius of men coming from the African continent".

She said Senegal had maintained a "strong and vibrant" democratic tradition and had been active in peacekeeping and conflict settlement operations around the world.

Clinton is scheduled to meet Senegalese President Abdou Diouf today and later visit Goree island, where she will be shown the women's museum and the house of slaves.

She will also visit in the Peace Corps training facility Saam Ndaye, in the Region of Thies, 80 km (50 miles) East of Dakar. Then, she will tour U.S-. sponsored development projects on democratic institutions and the education of African woman.

After Senegal, she will fly to South Africa, Zimbabwe, Tanzania, Uganda and Eritrea for similar tours.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


418 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 17, 1997


West Africa;
Benin, Burkina Faso, France and Togo Plan Joint War Games


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 174 words


 

LOME, Togo (PANA) - Joint military manoeuvre code-named "Exercise Nangbeto 97" will be held from 19 to 21 March in Benin and Togo with troops from France and Burkina Faso also participating, according to a statement released Monday by the Togolese ministry of defence in Lome.

The exercise, will be launched by Togolese president Gnassingbe Eyadema. 

It will involve Over 4,000 troops and vehicles, some 30 warplanes and helicopters as well as four ships, which have been assembled for the purpose.

It said observers from Ghana and Nigeria will watch the games.

"the exercise which involves three neighbouring countries, in cooperation with French forces, is aimed at designing, implementing and jointly managing a multinational group of armed forces for mainly military and humanitarian mission," the statement added.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


419 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 17, 1997


Business and Finance;
Nigerian Airlines Hike Fares By 100 Percent


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Private airlines operating in Nigeria have increased fares on domestic routes by 100 percent after government rejected a 200-per cent hike they proposed a month ago.

There was no official announcement, but a check at the Lagos airport showed that two major private airlines, the Aviation Development Company (ADC), and Bellview Airlines began implementing the new air fares Sunday. 

Their officials said they had government approval for the increase, which aviation sources said was meant to come into effect Monday.

Passengers expressed surprise at the increase, saying the government should have given the public at least one-month notice.

Under the new rates, a one-way ticket from Lagos to Abuja INL002 from SSS. 064 (970317-17:52) QN PANAINL .PANADKR MSG063G/02E PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PAN(2) jumped from 2,925 naira to 6,150 naira (80 naira = 1USD).

The new rates include five percent Value Added Tax on the tickets.

The Airline Operators Association of Nigeria had been campaigning for the hike, because of high aircraft running costs.

The operators had planned a unilateral fare hike of 200 percent last month, but were forced to abandon the plan after the aviation ministry threatened to ground their planes, if they implemented the hike.

The last air fare increase on domestic routes was in 1994.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


420 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 17, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Nigeria Ready To Host OAU Trade And Tourism Fair


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 854 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - At least 21 countries and 100 multinational companies are participating in the 7th All- Africa Trade and Tourism Fair taking place in Nigeria's northern city of Kaduna, March 29 to April 6, Nigerian commerce and tourism minister, Rear Admiral Jubrila Ayinla announced in Lagos Monday.

The minister told a monthly forum organized by the Pan- African News Agency (PANA) and the News Agency of Nigeria (NAN), that facilities were in place for the fair.

He said that egypt was among countries already putting finishing touches to their stands at the fair pavilion.

Ayinla, a member of Nigeria's ruling Provisional Military Council said the fair to be opened by Nigerian head of state, Gen. Sani Abacha "is to provide a forum for the exchange and dissemination of information on intra-African trade." 

According to official figures, recorded total intra-African trade is put as low as 10 percent, while the greater percentage of business transactions remain unrecorded.

"In spite of the vast potentials and great possibilities that exist for fostering intra-African trade to the mutual benefit of all member-states, the sector is not having the desired impact on economic development in the continent," the minister said.

However, he said, these potentials "can be immediately developed by concerted efforts to exchange facts, ideas and existing resources through an appropriate forum like the one provided by the all-Africa trade fair."

Ayinla said the fair approved and supported by the Organisation of African Unity (OAU), was part of efforts to boost continental integration under the African Economic Community, whose treaty was signed in Abuja in 1991.

"The fair is in line with the permanent 'buy African goods' campaign within the framework of the Lagos Plan of Action," the minister said.

At the national level, he said "the fair provides Nigeria with the opportunity to package and showcase her enormous potentials as well as demonstrate our well-acknowledged hospitality to the African business community and its partners all over the world."

Ayinla, commandant of Nigeria's National War College for two years before he was appointed minister in July 1996, said the emergent trend in the world today dictated that "political problems in Africa can best be tackled through improved economy."

"We have no alternative than to cooperate, otherwise we will continue to depend on donor-nations, he said, adding that Africans should strive to dismantle "the artificial barriers of history and colonialism," that tended to keep the continent perpetually marginalized.

"Given the unfavorable developments in the multilateral trading system and the emerging trends of globalization and liberalization of the world economy, Africa is presently faced with the serious challenges of marginalization," the minister added.

He said there was no reason for instance, why other West African countries should be buying Peugeot cars from Europe, when Nigeria had a Peugeot assembly plant, or why Africans should troupe to Europe yearly on holidays, while tourism resorts abound on the continent.

The Nigerian minister said in spite of political differences between Abuja and Pretoria over democracy and human rights issues, "South Africa will be one of the largest exhibitors" at the Kaduna fair.

"Africa should form its own free trade area," he said, "to explore the abundant resources god has given us. Let goods and services flow freely."

The 65th OAU ministerial council session held last month in Tripoli, Libya, urged all members countries to effectively participate at the fair, which has the theme: "Promote Africa's Development -- Buy African Goods --Tour Africa."

The fair is divided into three components: a buyer-seller forum, an investment platform and a tourism segment.

Originally scheduled to take place in Lagos in November 1996, it was postponed and relocated to Kaduna because of what Nigerian officials called logistic reasons.

The 6th African trade fair was held in 1992 in Bulawayo, Zimbabwe.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


421 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 17, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Conflicts Take Kofi Annan Back To Africa (Analysis)


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 894 words


 

United Nations (PANA) - Conflict resolution will dominate the agenda of UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan, when he makes his first official trip to Africa this week.

Political conflicts have succeeded one another on the African continent, more than 30 years since most of its countries won their flag independence. These range from the six-month-old rebellion in eastern Zaire to the decades- old civil war in Angola.

Since he assumed office in January, Kofi Annan has consistently said that the resolution of the conflicts was a necessity if africa is to attain the much-needed social and economic stability. 

Specifically, Annan wants africa to take the lead in efforts to resolve the conflicts in its domain, in line with the trend in other regions of the world.

To illustrate this point, the Ghanaian said recently that: "when we look at the peace-keeping operations around the world, there is a strong regional dimension to it." He was speaking in a recent interview ahead of the African trip.

"In Bosnia, it was the European countries...France and Britain and others... who underpinned the operation, (and) in Cambodia, the Asian countries played a very important role even though troops from other regions joined them," he said.

"So Africa has to be able to organize itself to play its part even if it is a UN operation and other governments are going to join in...this is a message I have repeated and I intend to get across," he added.

The Secretary-General has chosen an appropriate forum -- the summit of the Organisation of African Unity's central organ for the prevention, management and resolution of conflicts in Lome, Togo, later this month -- to deliver the message.

Before attending the summit in Lome, Annan will travel first to South Africa to confer with President Nelson Mandela and other officials. Mandela has been making efforts to bring about a negotiated solution to the conflict in Zaire.

Annan will meet Mandela a few days after the seizure of Kisangani, Zaire's third largest city, by rebels of Laurent Desire Kabila's Democratic Alliance for the Liberation of Congo/Zaire.

His other stops in the 11-day trip are Namibia, for a meeting with President Sam Nujoma, and Angola, to give a final push for a peaceful end to the internecine conflict that has ravaged the country.

In Angola, Annan is to hold separate meetings with President Jose Eduardo Dos Santos and the UNITA leader, Jonas Savimbi. The former guerilla leader has been reluctant to join a national unity government and this has impeded the full implementation of the Lusaka peace accord his movement signed with the Luanda government on Nov. 20, 1994.

However, Annan's intention is to use the March 26-27 Lome summit to make a pitch for urgent action in the continent's most-desperate conflict today, in eastern Zaire.

His message to leaders in Lome will be that African countries must be part of any multinational force that might be sent there to help the thousands of Rwandan refugees who have been forced out of their camps by the fighting, between the rebels and the government forces.

That proposal, backed by France, has been repulsed by other United Nations Security Council members.

"I definitely intend to talk to the African heads of state about effective participation in any force that may be put on the ground in eastern Zaire," he said. He revealed that Egypt, Ethiopia and Tanzania had offered to participate in the proposed force.

To date, the Secretary-General's repeated calls for the deployment of a multinational force to help the refugees, many of whom have died of hunger and diseases while foraging in the forest, has met with a tepid response. Only France, of the western countries with the capability to provide logistic, material and financial support for such a force, has backed the call.

Perhaps a stronger indication, by African countries, of the intention to be involved in any proposed plan to end the crisis may galvanize support for the Secretary-General's call.

Annan's trans-atlantic trip, which will last from March 18 to March 28, may well be worth it if it can provide the continent with the badly-needed tonic for self-help.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


422 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 17, 1997


Western Sahara;
Sahara Weekly News Update (03/10 - 03/16)


BYLINE: Western Sahara Referendum Support Association


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Geneva - About the eventual nomination of James Baker: reactions (07.03.97)

The Moroccan Minister of Foreign Affairs declared to be in favour of Baker as UN special representative for Western Sahara. The representative of the Polisario Front at the U.N. considers it as "a great step on the way to resolve the conflict."

International Women's Day (08.03.97)

A delegation of NUSW (National Union of Sahrawi Women) visited Sevilla, Spain. They met many official representatives and members of women organizations of Andalusia. These encounters allowed also the implementation of cooperation projects for Sahrawi women. At this occasion the NUSW received the award of the International Women's Day of Andalusia. 

11.03.97 Polisario expresses readiness to cooperate with UN mission

After the meeting of the Secretary-general with the Sahrawi representatives M'hamad Khaddad and Achmed Boukhari, the Polisario Front has expressed readiness to cooperate with the UN Secretary-general in efforts to eliminate the inaction preventing the implementation of the peace plan in Western Sahara. It's glad of the nomination of Mr. James Baker as new Special Representative for Western Sahara.

12.03.97 The Secretary-General's report on Western Sahara discussed by the Security Council.

13.03.97 Morocco objections to U.N. Secretary-general report

In a letter to the U.N. chief , Moroccan U.N. envoy Ahmed Snoussi expressed his disagreement with the recent report of Mr. Annan, indicating that the Secretary-general did not show the responsibility of the F. Polisario for the stalling of the voter identification process. He said Polisario was trying to restrict the right of Sahrawis to participate in the referendum "by limiting that right to persons whose names appear in the Spanish census of 1974, a census whose omissions and flaws have been acknowleged by all forums." Snoussi claimed that, "while Morocco remains committed to the settlement plan, the other party is doing its utmost to delay the referendum process and even prevent it from taking place."

14.03.97 Mohamed Abdelaziz in Washington

At a meeting with American lawyers at Washington the SADR President said to be glad of the next nomination of James Baker, adding that if self determination could not be realized in W.S. the region will not be in peace. Abdelaziz asked the US government to pressure Morocco in order to accept the UN mandate. He appealed also to ban the selling of American arms to Morocco.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


423 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 17, 1997


Uganda;
Humanitarian Situation Report On Uganda (03/15)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 4547 words


 

Nairobi - INTRODUCTION: 1. This report follows two recent DHA/IRIN field trips to Uganda and describes developments affecting the humanitarian situation during January and February.

The first section of the report describes the current situation in Kitgum, Gulu, Arua and Kasese districts. Part two reviews the changing situation along Uganda's borders with Zaire and Sudan and looks at relations between Uganda and its neighbours. The report concludes by discussing the prospects for an improvement in the humanitarian situation.

2. Readers are encouraged to read this report in conjunction with IRIN's Humanitarian Situation Report of 4 December 1996, which provides an overview of the situation in Uganda. Readers are asked to note that this report focusses on the complex emergencies in Uganda and does not discuss Uganda's general food security problems, which have been the subject of a recent Government of Uganda emergency appeal. 

THE CURRENT SITUATION

Kitgum District

3. In mid-January a group of Lord's Resistance Army (LRA) rebels launched a series of attacks on Kitgum's civilian population, leaving an estimated 312 people dead and 60,000 people displaced from their homes (1). The attacks took place in the north of the district, close to Uganda's border with Sudan, primarily in and around the villages of Lokung, Palabek and Padibe. According to reports from people displaced by the violence, the LRA entered their villages and distributed leaflets telling them to leave for Kitgum town. The rebels then attacked village residents with axes and clubs and set ablaze their houses and granaries.

4. Families fled in terror towards Kitgum town, along with injured people who had managed to escape. A number of people with deep head wounds and other injuries are currently being treated in Kitgum hospital. According to estimates compiled by the local authorities and provided by AVSI, the Italian NGO, there are some 12,113 displaced persons at the public school in Kitgum and another 4,669 at a hill top in the town. In and around the villages themselves, there are an estimated 22,140 displaced people at Palabek, 11,941 at Lokung, 4,062 at Padibe and 6,987 at Atanga (2).

5. The health of the displaced persons, crowded into the temporary sites, is a matter of growing concern. There are reports of about 100 cholera cases in Palabek, Padibe and Hill Top camps and of measles cases in Palabek, Attange and Gandyang, a newly-established camp. Water and sanitation is reported to be poor, especially in Palabek and Lokung. The displaced persons are currently being assisted by the Government of Uganda and UN agencies and NGOs which are scaling up their programmes. They include WFP, UNICEF, UNHCR, AVSI, OXFAM, CRS, MSF and World Vision. Relief activities within the district are coordinated by the Kitgum Disaster Committee.

6. The LRA's attacks, which continued into February, and the large-scale displacement they caused, took the district completely by surprise, as Kitgum had until January enjoyed far better security than Gulu district, its westerly neighbour. Kitgum, reported to be the LRA's transit point into and out of Sudan, has experienced attacks and abductions in the past, but the present scale of violence is without precedent. John Bosco Oryem, Kitgum council chairman, said that 'the January attack was a new development' because 'normally the rebels pass through the district and abduct in small numbers... (b)ut this time they killed and the numbers were enormous.' (3)

7. The attacks have prompted debate within Uganda as to the reasons for the current series of LRA atrocities. According to the accounts of former abductees reported in the national press, the LRA is avenging the population of Kitgum for its alleged cooperation with the Uganda People's Defence Forces (UPDF), and for the reportedly high levels of desertion from the LRA of rebels originating from the district. It also appears that the rebels may be seeking to displace populations in order to establish bases within Kitgum and points where they can deposit arms. This seems to be confirmed by national press reports of the UPDF discovering arms caches in Kitgum, including ammunition near Palabek and 29 anti-tank mines found near Lokung.

Gulu District

8. Insecurity has become a major fact of life for most of Gulu's population in recent years, and during January a series of attacks in Gulu town's suburbs highlighted the vulnerability of civilian populations to the LRA's campaign of terror. According to reports from the government-owned New Vision newspaper, attacks in the suburbs of Gulu town left 12 people dead during the weekend of 4/5 January and 14 dead on 18 January . The killings in the countryside continued during January; among the incidents reported was the 15 January killing of an estimated 26 people in villages around the River Olik, about 15 miles north-west of Gulu town. Military engagements between the LRA and the UPDF were also reported during January and February.

9. Every evening, about 13,000 people enter Gulu town from neighbouring villages to spend the night in the town for their own protection (4). Meanwhile, around Gulu district as a whole, most of the district's population of 390,000 people are now living in so-called 'protected villages'. According to figures from the local authorities, there are now 281,000 people living in 15 such sites around the district, a figure which includes resident populations and the displaced people who have joined them (5). Since November 1996 the UPDF has been encouraging people to move to these locations for their own protection. Politicians and soldiers are also on record as saying that the villages will be an important part of the UPDF's strategy to isolate the LRA and deny its members food, freedom of movement and the ability to re- group.

10. The World Food Programme (WFP) has decided to implement its food relief to the sites through the UPDF, arguing that the security situation in Gulu is such as to prevent any other way of working. WFP's emergency operation aims to provide food for 70,000 vulnerable people in Gulu district between March and August, as well as 40,000 people in Kitgum. The agency hopes that the Government will step in to address other food relief needs arising from the current emergency.

11. Humanitarian agencies and NGOs are divided as to whether to assist in the 'protected villages'. It appears that basic services in the villages are inadequate and that public health will be threatened unless international agencies intervene. Humanitarian agencies are, however, reluctant to be seen to be helping implement what they regard as a military strategy, while also questioning whether the villages will protect people or actually make them more vulnerable to attack. The LRA has already stated its opposition to the villages and attacks have taken place despite the presence of UPDF troops.

12. The 'protected villages' are a risky strategy; by gathering people together in crowded conditions, with little to do except wait for the next relief handout, there is a danger the Government will further alienate the very people it would like to count as supporters. This danger will of course be greater if services in the villages are inadequate. It remains to be seen which agencies will decide to provide the assistance which will undoubtedly be needed. Agencies and NGOs currently working in Gulu town include UNICEF, World Vision, Oxfam/Acord and MSF-Holland as well as the Church of Uganda and the Catholic diocese.

13. The insecurity in Gulu has undermined the livelihoods of most people, which are overwhelmingly dependent on agriculture. While the cattle population has been decimated over the course of several years, the recent insecurity has also undermined the ability of farm families to harvest their crops and prepare for the forthcoming rainy season. The last harvest, which would have been a bumper crop due to good rains, rotted in the fields as farmers were too frightened to spent time on their land. The ongoing insecurity and mass displacement, as well as the burning of granaries and the destruction of tools by the LRA, threaten to prevent farm families from planting for the next rains, which will lead to food aid dependence well beyond the period envisaged in WFP's current emergency programme.

14. The education and health systems, which were in a state of collapse prior to the establishment of protected villages, will now need to be revived to meet the needs of Gulu's population in the changed context. It is also to be hoped that measures will be put in place to enhance the protection of children, who have been victims of a horrifying LRA abductions campaign which continues unabated, and to combat the spread of landmines, which remain a source of death and injury and an obstacle to the resumption of agricultural activity.

15. As the UN system seeks to respond to the array of humanitarian issues created by the current situation, UNDP in January created a UN Disaster Management Team (UNDMT) for Uganda, as a forum for policy deliberations and the coordination of UN humanitarian assistance to displaced populations across the north of the country. In this context, UNDP recently launched a $5, 357,000 inter-agency appeal to provide assistance to over 180,000 displaced people in northern Uganda.

Arua District

16. Arua district, bordered by both Sudan and Zaire, has been subjected to widespread insecurity over recent years as a result of the activities of the West Nile Bank Front, which for many years had bases in Zaire. The insecurity continued during January, with several incidents including attacks on Sudanese refugees in Rhino camp, an ambush on a convoy accompanying two MPs, an attack on the hospital at Yumbe near the Sudan border, as well as cattle rustling and looting.

17. During February Imvepi camp was attacked by the Uganda National Rescue Front II, a splinter group of the WNBF, and six Sudanese refugees had their ears cut off. Later in February, Ikafe refugee camp was attacked by 30 unidentified men and 6 refugees were shot dead, 7 were injured, and one had his ears cut off for alleged cooperation with the UPDF. These acts of mutilation, which bear a strong similarity to similar atrocities in Gulu, are the first of their kind in Arua.

18. Arua district is home to about 100,000 Sudanese refugees, almost half of Uganda's total Sudanese refugee population. They were settled in four camps; Koboko, Ikafe and Imvepi, to the north-east of Arua town, and Rhino camp to the south-west. As a result of attacks by the WNBF, however, many of those refugees have been displaced. Within the Ikafe camp area, for example, an estimated 33,000 people out of an original camp size of 55,000, have been displaced from their homes. The insecurity in Arua has also displaced Ugandans from their homes; there are reported to be several thousand displaced people in Koboko town and in the counties of Maracha, Terego and Obongi.

19. Displaced refugees find themselves struggling to survive in often desperate conditions. Whereas before they were able to supplement food rations with their own cultivation, having been displaced from the land they are now solely dependent on food relief. This is of particular concern given the fact that insecurity has made it very difficult to truck food relief to the district and WFP is currently supplying half-rations.

20. The attacks against the refugees appear to be politically motivated, as the WNBF is believed to suspect some Sudanese refugees of supporting the Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA), which is fighting a protracted war against the Islamic Government of Sudan. The Ugandan Government, for its part, has alleged on numerous occasions that the WNBF is being backed by the Sudanese Government, along with both the LRA and the Allied Democratic Forces (ADF), which is active in western Uganda (see below).

Kasese, Kabarole District

21. Since mid-November 1996 a group of Ugandan rebels called the Allied Democratic Forces (ADF) have caused insecurity and population displacement in the Kasese area to the east of the Ruwenzori mountains. Initially the ADF took control of Mpondwe border post and the nearby town of Bwera, but the UPDF soon regained control of the area. Most of the 25,000 people who had been displaced from their homes into the plains gradually returned to their villages.

22. The ADF continued to mount attacks during January and February and there have been a number of serious incidents, including killings of abductees and an attack at a burial service in Bushenyi in which five people were killed. Most of the incidents, however, have been acts of banditry, such as attacks on buses and trading centres. The rebels are reported to have split up into small groups and to have moved further afield than previously, towards Fort Portal to the north and into Queen Elizabeth Park to the south. A number of reports in the New Vision state that the rebels are short of food and ammunition.

23. The scattering of the ADF rebels within Uganda is the result of the takeover of eastern Zaire by the Zairean ADFL (Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo/Zaire) rebels lead by Laurent Kabila. As the Zairean rebels pushed northwards along Zaire's border with Uganda during January, the Ugandan rebels found themselves unable to operate out of Zaire. Ugandan security sources, quoted in an article in the New Vision, welcomed the capture of Beni and Bunia airports by the Zairean rebels, saying that it would prevent the ADF from obtaining further supplies from Sudan, which the Ugandan authorities accuse of backing the rebels (see below).

UGANDA'S RELATIONS WITH ZAIRE AND SUDAN

24. Many observers of Uganda argue that prospects for peace in the country are bound up with Uganda's relations with Zaire and Sudan, and in particular the situation along their common borders. The border situation is currently changing, as Zaire's ADFL have established control along Uganda's border with Zaire and as the SPLA seek to regain lost territory in southern Sudan, along Uganda's northern border. These developments have been accompanied by increasingly hostile accusations and recriminations between Uganda, Zaire and Sudan.

25. In January the Zairean Army made a statement accusing Uganda of sending several thousand Ugandan troops to support the ADFL rebels. The Ugandan Government, in a Foreign Ministry statement, described the accusations as 'false and baseless' and reiterated its support for Zaire's territorial integrity. The same statement also noted that President Mobutu had never acted on promises to disarm ex-Rwandan Government soldiers and Interahamwe militiamen who were destabilising neighbouring countries from within Zaire. In February the Zairean authorities claimed a Ugandan military cargo plane carrying soldiers and equipment had crashed on the Zairean side of the Ruwenzori mountains, citing this as proof of the Ugandan army's involvement in the war in eastern Zaire. The Ugandan army denied the charge.

26. Whatever the truth of these allegations, it is clear that as the Zairean ADFL rebels have pushed northwards they have established control over territory where the ADF and WNBF had their bases. Indeed, as the ADFL moved north, taking Beni, Bunia, Mahagi, Aru and Ariwara, there were several reports in Ugandan newspapers of direct clashes between the Zairean rebels and the ADF and WNBF. With the ADFL controlling Uganda's entire western border with Zaire, it appears that the ADF have entered Uganda and broken up into smaller groups, while WNBF fighters have scattered eastwards into Uganda and north into Sudan. In the medium- and long-term the loss of Ugandan rebel bases in Zaire is expected is widely expected to improve the security situation in western Uganda.

27. The war of words between Uganda and Sudan also escalated in January and in February Sudan twice bombed Moyo town in northern Uganda. The accusations began with statements by several Sudanese Ministers that Uganda was massing troops along Sudan's southern border in preparation for an attack, and that Uganda was conspiring with Ethiopia and Eritrea, accused of backing rebels in eastern Sudan, to overthrow the Government in Khartoum (6). The Ugandan Government repeatedly denied the allegations, describing the conflict in southern Sudan as 'an internal problem'.

28. Museveni's statement echoed previous remarks on relations between Uganda and Sudan, in which he has welcomed efforts to broker peace between the two countries while expressing scepticism about Sudan's willingness to live up to its commitments. In his New Year address to the nation, Museveni said that following the signing of an Iranian-sponsored peace accord between Uganda and Sudan on 8 September 1996, Sudan was bombing Uganda 'before the ink was dry'. He suggested the Sudanese government 'is not serious about peace. They seem to have an agenda which they must carry out at all costs.'(7)

29. During the weekend of 8/9 March, the SPLA began an offensive in southern Sudan, and since then are reported to have gained control of several towns: Kaya, Gumuli, Kajo Kaji, Bazi, Kimba, Foki, and Morobo. Sudanese army spokesman General Mohamed al Sanousi Ahmed accused Uganda of having led the attack on Kaya, a claim denied by Eriya Kategaya, Uganda's Foreign Minister (8). The spokesman for the Sudanese army also claimed that attacks against Yei and Bazi were launched from ADFL-held areas in eastern Zaire (9). The SPLA offensive is currently ongoing.

30. The Ugandan Government has alleged for many years that the LRA is based in southern Sudan and receives the active support of the Government of Sudan. Certainly, people displaced in the border area by LRA attacks claim that the LRA came out of, and retreat back into, southern Sudan. It may therefore be expected that as the SPLA moves to establish control over southern Sudan, this will have implications for the security situation in northern Uganda. On previous occasions when the SPLA has controlled Sudan's southern border, LRA activities have been curtailed (10).

31. Within Uganda, political debate continues as to the best way of bringing peace to the north. The Parliamentary Committee on Defence and Internal Affairs released its report on the war in the north, recommending continued dialogue between Uganda and Sudan and strengthening the UPDF to deal with the rebels militarily. The Committee stopped short of calling on the Government to talk directly to the rebels, but in a Minority Report two MPs from the north, Omara Atubo and Norbert Mao, called for direct talks, saying no stone should be left unturned in the search for peace.

32. In the past, President Museveni has expressed his unwillingness to talk to the rebels unless all of the LRA's victims say they are in favour of talks. In his recently-released autobiography, 'Sowing the Mustard Seed', Museveni states that, 'On the issue of security I refuse to talk to the bandits, not because they are armed opponents of the government, but because they are criminals... What Kony's bandits are doing is not a crime against the state: it is a crime against the population. They kill peasants, who have nothing to do with state power; they kill young people or kidnap them to make them cannon fodder; they rape women; they marry girls by force; and they spread AIDS in the north. These are crimes against humanity on a massive scale. I find it completely distasteful that people do not condemn with one voice these crimes of Kony and his bandits.'(11)

CONCLUSION

33. The current humanitarian situation in northern Uganda remains grave. Attacks on civilians and refugees are a daily occurrence, often resulting in deaths and horrific injuries. An estimated 100,000 people are displaced within Gulu district and swelling the size of existing settlements designated as 'protected villages', raising serious concerns about public health. In Kitgum an estimated 60,000 people have been displaced from their homes by LRA violence, while in Arua tens of thousands of Sudanese refugees have been displaced from their camps by WNBF attacks. While this situation prevails, the food security of communities across the north is rapidly being eroded, raising the spectre of famine or future dependence on food relief. The insecurity also severely impedes access for agencies attempting to provide humanitarian assistance.

34. Medium-term prospects for an improvement in the humanitarian situation in northern and western Uganda are inextricably linked with developments along Uganda's common borders with Zaire and Sudan. The takeover of eastern Zaire's border with Uganda by ADFL rebels appears to have made it more difficult for both the Ugandan ADF rebels and WNBF fighters to operate out of Zaire. This is widely expected to lead to improved security in western Uganda over the coming months. The situation in northern Uganda is also expected to be affected by developments in southern Sudan, where the SPLA is seeking to regain control of towns currently under Sudanese Government control. In the past, SPLA control over southern Sudan's border with Uganda has curtailed LRA activities in northern Uganda.

35. In the long-term, Uganda will also need to address the development gap between southern and northern Uganda if lasting peace is to be secured. Northern Uganda's current state of crisis merely exacerbates a situation in which the north has lagged behind the south in terms of agriculture, industry, infrastructural development, education and health services. This situation has fuelled resentment and grievances in the north and created a context in which northerners have a lower stake in Uganda's development than their southern counterparts. Unless and until this situation is addressed, something which in turn depends upon improved security in the north, Uganda will find it difficult to achieve lasting stability and economic development.

FOOTNOTES

1. The figure of 312 killed was compiled by the New Vision, based on lists from local councils and chiefs and reported in the New Vision, 22.1.97. The figure of 60,000 is based on estimates by the local authorities and was provided by AVSI, the Italian NGO. The precise estimate is that 61,912 people had been displaced by the violence as of 27.1.97.

2. AVSI, Internally Displaced People in Kitgum District, 24.2.97.

3. AFP, Rebels visit terror on northern Ugandan residents, 27.1.97.

4. Based upon figures compiled by the local authorities and MSF-Holland.

5. The locations and sizes of the 15 'protected villages' are known to DHA/IRIN and can be provided to interested humanitarian agencies.

6. AFP, Sudan accuses Uganda of joining plot, 27.1.97.

7. BBC Monitoring, Radio Kampala, 31.12.96.

8. AFP, Uganda denies it attacked Sudanese town, 10.3.97.

9. IPS, SPLA rebels occupy Sudanese town, 10.3.97.

10. Africa Confidential, Uganda/Sudan - Bordering on war, 21.7.95.

11. Yoweri K. Museveni, 'Sowing the Mustard Seed', Macmillan, 1997.

(ENDS)

Quotations or extracts from this report should include attribution to the original sources mentioned, not simply "DHA".)


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

424 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 17, 1997


South Africa;
Civic leader shot nine times


BYLINE: Mzilikazi wa Afrika, African Eye News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

SECUNDA - A well-known Mandela Village squatter camp civic leader was shot nine times by a gang of unidentified men on Sunday as he walked out of a tavern in the squatter camp, police said on Monday.

The incident is the lastest in a string of drive by or other unexplained shootings in the Langverwacht area, near Secunda, by the gang. 

Police spokesperson, Sergeant Anina van Breda, confirmed that Simjolakgile Patrick Ndamazi (38) died immediately after being shot five times in the chest and four times elsewhere.

He was, she said, well-known in Embalehle township as a civic and political activist. The police have no idea yet why he was killed.

Investigating officer, Sergeant Jan Sithole, told African Eye news Service that four people had been shot to death at Mandela Village since the beginning of March.

He said all the shots that struck Ndamazi were fired from the same 9mm pistol.

* In two other possibily related incidents a mother and daughter were shot at least six times at Mandela Village two weeks ago. Nosezile Mlotshwa (61) and her daughter, Sibongile Mlotshwa (33) were killed by two unknown men who witnesses said did not speak at all during the shooting.

Sibongile was shot at seven times while building a shack and her mother shot six times ten minutes later in another shack. Police say they do not know of link between the shootings. -African Eye News Service

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


March 17, 1997


South Africa;
MPB, Dolphin to finalise controversial contract


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

Nelspruit - Embattled Dolphin Group president, Ketan Somaia, is scheduled to meet with senior Mpumalanga officials in Johannesburg on Monday afternoon to finalise proposed amendments to his 50-year contract with the Mpumalanga Parks Board (MPB).

The contract, which was signed secretly in November last year, gave the Dubai-based Dolphin Group a monopoly on commercial development and transverse rights in six State owned game reserves, Blyde River Canyon, Pilgrim's Rest, Loskop Dam and Manyeleti Game Reserve. 

Community outrage however forced provincial politicians to step in and send a "rescue mission" to London to demand a re-negotiation, including the exclusion of Manyeleti and Pilgrim's Rest.

Other suggested amendments are the scrapping of a 50-year secrecy clause, a reduction in the length of the contract from 50 to 25-years, improved community involvement in joint venture companies and other facets of the proposed developments.

The MPB, whose chief executive officer, Alan Gray originally brokered and signed the deal, was not represented on the "rescue mission" and will apparently not attend the finalisation of the contract in Johannesburg later today.

"Since the rescue team returned from London, Dolphin and our attorneys have been working on the proposed amendments and will probably be finalising them this afternoon," said Mpumalanga's Environmental Affairs spokesman, Gary Sutter.

"But I cannot say if the final deal will be signed today or not- we cannot pre-empt a thing like this."

Sutter confirmed that MPB will not be attending the meeting. He was also unable to say who from the Mpumalanga government would be representing South Africa.

Dolphin's public relations company declined to comment on the meeting today, saying they were having trouble contacting their client. - African Eye News Service

March 17, 1997


Ethiopia;
Number of elementary school students rises


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

BAHIR DAR (ENA) - The number of students learning in elementary schools in the Amhara Regional State has increased, the social sector of the regional council said.

Speaking at the end of an appraisal meeting Friday, head of the sector Ato Ahmed Seyid said over 800,000 students are learning in elementary schools this academic year, thus raising the enrolment by 5 per cent as compared with the previous year. 

he ascribed the increase on the number of students to the intensive efforts of educational professionals and administrative bodies to raising awareness of parents to allow their children join schools.

The construction of 15 elementary schools in the region with the loan secured from the World Bank was completed, according to Ato Ahmed.

Extension to be carried out on 20,485 demonstration sites

ARBAMINCH (ENA) - Extension programme will be undertaken in North Omo Zone this year on 20,485 demonstration sites in a bid to increase farmers' productivity.

The ongoing third regular congress of the zonal council said favourable conditions have been created to supply select seeds and fertilizers to the farmers incorporated into the programme.

Speaking on the occasion, Ato Eyob oda, chairman of the council said the number of farmers embraced in the programme this year grew twofold from that of last year's.

The farmers in the zone involved in the programme last year have repayed 1. 3 million of the 1.9 million birr they borrowed for the purchase of inputs, it was noted.

Africa News


March 17, 1997


Business and Finance;
Unemployment drops from 40 to 30 per cent in Addis


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 574 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - Unemployment has dropped from 40 to 30 per cent here in the capital in four years time, head of the region 14 Administration reported yesterday.

Ato Ali Abdo told a popular gathering convened to assess performance, discuss future plans and identity other priorities that the rate of unemployment which stood at 40 per cent in 1985 E.C. has dropped to 30 per cent in the following three years.

He attributed the positive trend to the opening of private firms the formation by the region of small-scale job creations schemes and the expansion of development works undertaken by the administration. 

The head, however, said despite the encouraging trend, the prevalent unemployment rate itself vividly shows the impoverishment of metropolitans.

In a related development, a document prepared by the regional council indicated that 3.3 billion birr is needed for the execution of water supply projects.

The document says the regional government spend about 208 million birr for the implementation of water supply projects during the past four years.

It also says the execution of the ongoing water projects costs 865 million birr until 1992 E.C. alone.

The ongoing projects include the Life-saving Water Survey and Construction, the Emergency Sub-terranean Water Development and the Dire Dam and Water supply Study and Control, according to the document.

The implementation of most of the water supply projects would be completed in the coming year, it added.

It also says that the regional administration over the past four years constructed and maintained roads, bridges, sewers and gravel roads at a cost of 92.8 million birr.

The construction of medium level drains the administration planned to execute in the coming five years demands more than seven million birr, according to the document.

With regard to the acute shortage of residential units in the capital, the document says associations and individuals have built over 6,600 houses with some of them still under construction.

Investors willing to construct houses for rent were also given land, it says adding that the regional administration on its part has plans to build close to 50,000 houses in the next five years.

The plan the regional administration adopted to alleviate the shortage of residential units is constructing 10,000 houses every year until the completion of the programme.

The two-day popular gathering attended by representatives of residents of all kebeles in the capital discussed economic issues yesterday and is expected to deliberate on social affairs today.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March 17, 1997


Ethiopia;
Donors agreed to fund social sector projects


BYLINE: Seifu Mahifere, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

Debre Zeit - bilateral and multilateral donors participating in the " government-led workshop( on Ethiopian social sector investment programmes and indicative budgetary support of donors" have agreed to give sum of 665 million US dollars for projects related with the vital sector of health and education in Ethiopia, the resident representative of the World Bank in Ethiopia, Mr. Fayez Omar, said at the conclusion of the three-day workshop.

He pointed out that out of the 665 million dollars, 323 million dollars was meant for the health sector which he added was the very amount calculated to be needed for the sector. He, however, noted that the sum of 332 million dollars for the education sector accounts for just 80 per cent of the expected amount and that it was short by a hefty 148 million dollars, elevating the total required funds to not less than 480 million dollars. but he said that there is a room for optimism as there are many donors, who did not participate in the workshop and hence couldn't propose their pledges and that this gap in the financing of the education sector could be filled when they show up with their pledges. 

Formally closing the workshop the Minister in Charge of Social and Administrative Affairs in the Office of the Prime Minister, Dr. Kebede Tadesse, expressed great pleasure with the invaluable contributions the donors pledged to bring to reality the improvement in quality and quantity of the vital sectors of education and health. "We are very much assured to go further with out efforts to improve these sectors because of your subscriptions today." Dr. Kebede said. He further appreciated the need for holding such dialogues between government and donors adding that 'we have very flexible attitudes allowing for mutual learning and cooperation to every extent possible.'

It was also noted on the occasion that the largest share of the pledges was made by the World Bank, which pledged to allocate 340 million dollars, out of which 150 million dollars will be disbursed for the health and the remaining 190 million for the education sector. It is to be noted that these pledges are to be paid our of the 2.5 billion dollars pledged by donors and lending agencies at the December world Bank consultative Group meeting.

March 17, 1997


Science and Health;
Addis Science Faculty Opens Door To Public


BYLINE: Kisut G/Egziabher, Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 454 words


 

ADDIS ABABA - The Science Faculty of Addis Ababa University (AAU) has organized a two-day "Science Open-Day" with the overriding aim of familiarizing relevant governmental and non-governmental institutions and the public at large with its overall activities.

Faculty Dean Dr. Sebsebe Demissie sad at the opening ceremony here yesterday that the move was aimed at reversing public perception, and at times of the government as well, that the university is an Ivory tower.

According to Dr. Sebsebe the event also signifies the faculty's readiness to become a partner with various governmental and non-governmental institutions as well as the private sector to meaningfully contribute to national development. "We need to have a regular contact with policy makers so that they will make learned decisions where our institution is concerned." 

In his opening address, AAU President Dr. Mogessie Ashenafi said that research works within the faculty need to be attuned to solve national problems. He commended the faculty's "good begining" in this direction and hoped others would follow suit.

Invited guests, which included representatives of relevant government offices, embassies, the private sector and members of the press, visited the various research activities being conducted in the six departments within the faculty.

These are the departments of: biology, Chemistry, Geology/Geophysics, Mathematics, Physics and Statistics.

One of the first two faculties, the Science Faculty, was reportedly established in 1950 with the founding of the then University College of Addis Ababa. At that time it was giving basic trainings in engineering, medicine and biology and students used to be sent abroad for their first degree.

Faculty sources indicate that advancing science through excellence in teaching and research and contributing to the growth of science and technology in the country remain the main mission of the faculty.

the faculty is staffed with 142 academics of whom, 73 are PH.D holders, 50 with MSc, and the remaining with BSc.

The research activities and findings of the faculty remain open to the public today as well.

South Africa;
Thieves make off with expensive coffins


BYLINE: Benjamin Shabalala, Africans Eye News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Nelspruit - The annual ritual of reburying their dead after heavy summer rains have washed graves open prompted the residents of Ermelo Trust, near Nelspruit in Mpumalanga, to petition their councillors this week to provide alternative cemetaries for the town, which is sited on a rocky hillside.

Residents also complained in the petition, delivered to council offices on Sunday, that because the ground was so hard they could only dig graves two metres deep. 

"This means that we have to build expensive concrete and brick covers on the graves just to stop thieves from stealing our loved one's coffins and dumping their bodies next to the graves," explained one of the mouners at Petros Nhlanhla's funeral on Sunday.

"Good coffins are so expensive that families have to save for years to afford them and then thieves dishonour both these family's sacrifice and the dead by stealing them."

Although Ermelo Trust also doesn't have house to house water and electricity connections, the petition for better cemetaries is the first such concerted campaign by Trust residents. - African Eye News Service

South Africa;
Police puzzled at how youths escaped


BYLINE: Mzilikazi wa Afrika, African Eye News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

ERMELO - Police are puzzled as to how four youth, who had been arrested for house breaking, managed to escape from their police cell at the Ermelo Police Station without damaging the cell.

Police officers found the youth's cell door standing wide open but undamaged at 19h00 while doing their nightly rounds. 

"The youths were moved to the cell from another one earlier in the evening after the light bulb blew, but the officer who moved them is adamant that he locked the youths in," said police spokesperson, Sergeant Anina van Breda.

"At this stage we don't know how they got out. Once in the corridor, the youth appear to have scaled a barbed wire fence and ran off into the night."

The four escaped youths are; Madada Nkosi (15) who was found in possession of "house breaking tools", Thabo Maseko (14) who was arrested for house break, Vusi Shabangu (15) arrested for house break and Skhumbusza Vilakazi (14) who was arrested for house break and rape.

Police appealed to the surrounding communities to contact the nearest police station should they see the escapees. - African Eye News Service

South Africa;
Body of flash flood victim recovered


BYLINE: Mzilikazi wa Afrika, African Eye News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 187 words


 

Graskop - The body of 32-year-old Paulinah Khuiane was recovered from the Blyde River by police divers on Friday afternoon after the bakkie she was travelling in with her son and neighbour was swept off a bridge by a flash flood one week ago.

Khuiane's body was found 2km below the popular tourist attraction of Bourkes Luck Pot Holes just after 16h15 on Friday. 

It is possible that her body was trapped in the pot holes for some time before being washed down river, where police found her.

Khuiane's son, Collen (13), managed to swim to safety and cling to a tree but both his mother and the bakkie's driver, George Sekatane (54) were swept away by the strong currents.

Police are still searching for Sekatane but don't expect to find him alive. - African Eye News Service
