433 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 17, 1997


Arts and Entertainment;
David Douglas: chance encounter led to the big, big screen


BYLINE: Iain MacDonald, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 987 words


 

Cape Town - Take the incredible coincidences that created The Beatles, for instance. Imagine if John Lennon had been born in Cape Town and Paul in London and they'd never met.

Well, here's a story something like that.

Some 25 years ago, in Galt, Ontario, a high school student tried to get out of a history project by telling his teacher he'd make a short film instead. 

So he made a four-minute thing shot on 16mm, and it worked. It was about springtime around a farm.

This got him fired up on film, but, Galt being a sleepy little town with buildings no higher than two stories and he couldn't find anyone in the town to advance his budding interest in film.

He spoke to his girlfriend, who casually said he should talk to her father, who was involved in film.

"I thought maybe he worked for Kodak or something, so I didn't speak to him for a while," the young man said.

But when he did, he discovered Robert Kerr and his partner Graham Ferguson " inventing the IMAX system, right there in Galt".

"They were as surprised as I was to find someone interested in film-making in Ontario," he said.

And so one of the world's most intriguing partnerships was born, with the young man, David Douglas, becoming one of IMAX's best-ever film directors, and the small, home-grown IMAX industry made up of "four guys from Galt" growing to colossal proportions worldwide.

Douglas is a man who's dedicated to everything Hollywood doesn't stand for, who has a vision of a new film system that's "akin to live theatre, in which the audience is also a player".

IMAX, incidentally, is a super-huge large-format film type shown on giant screens. It deals mainly with documentary subjects - ranging from wildlife and outer space to The Rolling Stones live in concert - and it packs people in like no other form of film-making does, because it's a sensation, an experience, rather than a movie.

Making these giant films is an equal experience, according to Douglas.

"There's really nothing like it. It's a very generous medium and it raises the level of what filmed entertainment should be about.

"IMAX evolved in an atmosphere where film was in a phase of decline to the rise of TV, and it balanced TV. It was hatched outside the Hollywood system and developed by documentary film makers in a tradition of experimental cinema.

"I often wonder if it would have remained true to itself if it had happened in Hollywood, but we had a long term view and wound up with new technology and a new tradition of film-making based on the spectacular photo- extravaganza.

"It's a 1990s version of what the National Geographic Magazine was to the 1950s.

"To make these films, one has to understand the experience of the audience in the theatre. It's a participatory medium and the audience has many choices to make on what to look at on such a giant screen. A good film should support all their choices well.

"It becomes an experience instead of a linear story. It's broadband - everything is included. Watching it is like being a fly on the wall of life, and the film can carry any number of storylines, many themes in the same image, whereas the small screen forces the viewer to go through a story only one way.

"It's a complex medium, but so is life. When IMAX works properly it's like life," he says.

A veteran of more than 30 IMAX films as director or director of photography, Douglas says two of his favourite films are the pair he did with his producer wife, The Fires Of Kuwait and Survival Island.

Fires was a "dark and serious" experience for him, which he admits "left me feeling drained emotionally", as he stared through the lens at the inhuman devastation of the oil-well fires in Kuwait following the Gulf War.

"The flip side to that was Survival Island which was hopeful and positive, and balanced my emotions. After Fires I just needed to be around life, so we spent five months on South Georgia Island among fantastic numbers of creatures.

"It was an expedition in small ships with little chance of support if anything went wrong. We got off the island just before the big winter storms came in."

In total contrast was his project on the Rolling Stones.

"We just got on to what I can only describe as the Rolling Stones machine and we weren't in control of anything, travelling with this small army of some 400 people across the world. It was a fantastic combination of the medium and the show."


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


434 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 17, 1997


South African video dealers go up against distributors


BYLINE: Llewellyn Jones, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Cape Town - The highly competitive home video industry is coming under the spotlight at the Competition Board after bitter complaints from video store owners.

The Competition Board said last week it was launching an investigation into the pricing policies and any alleged anti-competitive behaviour of the two leading video distributors, Nu-Metro Video and Ster-Kinekor Video, which has resulted in widespread dissent and a civil suit to be heard in the Pretoria High Court next month.

Competition Board director of investigations Steve Abraham said this was not the first spat between Nu-Metro Video, Ster-Kinekor Video and video store owners to come before the Competition board. 

In 1989, the board had to intervene when it became apparent that some distributors were engaging in restrictive practices which were subsequently outlawed.

"The complexities and the competition law implications of the relevant issues raised by the latest round of allegations and counter-allegations - coupled with irreconcilable differences of opinion between the distributors and the dealers on those issues - requires a formal investigation," said Mr Abraham.

The leading complainants are Ultra Videos of Pretoria, Steers subsidiary Blockbuster Videos, and Cape Town-based Omega Videos, but Mr Abraham said the board had also received complaints from many other smaller dealers.

Spokesmen for both Nu-Metro and Ster-Kinekor said they "welcome the investigation" and "believe it will bring stability to the market". They declined to comment further as the matter was now sub-judice.

The main concerns expressed by the dealers were Nu-Metro's and Ster- Kinekor's policies and pricing on bulk buying and the treatment of franchises.

Dealers said videos were sold to them in packages of four or five videos - which normally included one blockbuster, two "medium" films and two "weak" films.

The result is that if a small store wants to buy top titles, it has to buy too many titles to get decent prices as low as R200 or pay top prices, as much as R320, for blockbuster films.

But perhaps more damaging in the longer term is Ster-Kinekor and Nu-Metro's refusal to recognise franchises as bulk buyers, instead insisting on dealing with franchise outlets on an individual basis. As one dealer said, this practically removed franchising as an attractive vehicle for development, by " robbing" them of the discounts normally attributed to franchise bulk buying.

Ster-Kinekor and Nu-Metro also strictly disallow franchisors to sub- distribute their wares. "In the event of us not performing exactly the way prescribed by the 'majors', which includes the signing of a "conditions of sale agreement for Ster-Kinekor", we simply receive a threat of non-delivery, which can be potentially disastrous to any video store," the dealer said.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


435 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 17, 1997


South Africa;
The Argie turns 140 (Editorial)


BYLINE: Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Cape Town - Today the Cape Argus marks its 140th anniversary with much cause for celebration. Over the past six months it has undergone the greatest rejuvenation in its existence and it has emerged from the exercise with renewed vitality and strength, having passed the most critical test of all - the verdict of its readers, who now number more than before the rejuvenation began, confirming the Cape Argus as the biggest, oldest, favourite newspaper in the Cape metropolitan area - by far. 

But as we look back on the past 140 years there is much more cause for satisfaction. A newspaper which was launched in the time of Cecil Rhodes and which then unashamedly defended the imperialist ideal stands firmly and proudly today as a part of the new South Africa. That transformation has been momentous, but no more so than the changes that have shaped the Western Cape and the country itself; changes wrought by seminal events like the South African War, the two great world conflagrations in which Cape Town and South Africa played such a critical role, and the arduous struggle for the equality of all South Africans.

The Cape Argus was in the thick of these events, bringing its readers the information and informed analysis they needed to shape their own lives. But through it all there were also more intimate changes, catalogued in the daily notices of births and deaths, engagements and marriages; the political, intellectual, cultural and sporting highlights of a changing society, the fluctuations of the economy.

It is an exciting history which has brought with it new challenges for South Africans to face. The country, the Cape and The Cape Argus will face them together - as we have done for the past 140 years.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


436 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 17, 1997


South Africa;
Police drown in Khayelitsha's human flood


BYLINE: Lindsay Barnes, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1680 words


 

Cape Town - Khayelitsha police station is sinking under the weight of the township's population explosion and needs a radical face-lift to reach service levels found at formerly white stations.

Its staff members are battling with seemingly insurmountable problems in their aim to provide a professional service.

The township needs at least three police stations if staff are to cope, said station commissioner Hennie Haarhoff.

Serious problems such as a huge backlog of cases, a shortage of vehicles and staff, the difficulty of retraining poorly-educated "kits konstabels" and a clash between the state and the traditional laws of the Xhosa-speaking township are hindering effective police work.

Staff members are alleging further problems are caused by a lack of transformation towards a more enlightened style of policing the community. 

The sprawling township's population has more than doubled in three years - from 300 000 in 1993 to more than 650 000 last year - due to a mass migration from the former homelands of Ciskei and Transkei.

A new report compiled by Khayelitsha police station management focuses on the internal and external factors adding to the police's frustrations in the area.

The report was released to members of the Provincial Service's standing committee on safety and security last week.

Compared to other areas where police are viewed as more effective, Khayelitsha residents lodge a relatively low number of complaints - about 600 a month as opposed to 1 700 in Bellville which has a far smaller population of 180 000.

These figures indicate a lack of trust and co-operation from residents.

"The crime is there, but it doesn't get reported," said Director Haarhoff.

Despite the relatively low reporting of cases, detectives have been swamped with investigations, but do not have the staff to deal with the cases.

A special task team had been called in to tackle a backlog of 3 000 cases, some 2 000 of which relate to serious crimes.

He said it was estimated that 75 percent of the population was unemployed.

Armed robbery was escalating due to an increase in businesses in the township.

Due to a lack of accommodation at the police station the detective branch had been relocated to Harare police station, about six kilometres away. But this split hindered effective co-operation between the two stations the uniformed branch in solving cases.

He explained that people making complaints at the charge office have to be transported by police members to the new detective premises for the case to be investigated.This unnecessarily ties up staff and vehicles, both of which are in short supply.

Police are also having to fetch and transport witnesses to court or they will not appear due to a lack of public transport.

"Unless we divide the area into smaller sections, I don't see how things can improve," Director Haarhoff said.

Director Haarhoff said they needed an office block housing all support services such as finances, logistics, administration and human resources.

Vigilante action in the community also poses an ongoing problem.

Residents who apprehend a thief may beat him badly before taking him to the police station. As a result such a person needs urgent medical attention before investigations can proceed.

According to the report, Xhosa-speaking people, especially those who recently moved from rural areas in the Eastern Cape, do not always understand legislation and its enforcement.

Police functioning is often foreign to them and sometimes not acceptable to the community as a whole, the report reads.

The introduction to Khayelitsha police station of 150 "kitskonstabels" in 1987 has proved to be a massive problem too.

Many had little or no education and their retraining in the new dispensation is difficult - especially those who are illiterate.

Director Haarhoff said these difficulties posed on-going obstacles to effective policing.

A solution, he said, would be to transfer some of the "kitskonstabels" to other stations in exchange for more supervisors, of whom Khayelitsha had a drastic shortage.

Staff say the untenable situation at the police station is exacerbated by racism, little affirmative action, poor management, a language barrier between staff and residents and the continuing existence of the old "brute force" policing style.

Two police members, who are known to Cape Argus, but spoke on condition of remaining anonymous, said only two black policemen had been appointed to management level and more were needed.

They said the community did not trust Khayelitsha police because many of the coloured and white staff still treated residents abominably.

Suspects were often beaten by police who also break people's front doors to apprehend suspects.

"White police officers must learn to treat the people nicely, to joke with them and ask first if they can search their homes instead of just breaking the door down.

"They must change their style if they want to work well in the community," one of the sources said.

The two said the language barrier was a problem for Afrikaans and English- speaking coloured and white staff, many of whom declined to work in the charge office because they could not take statements from Xhosa-speaking complainants and witnesses.

On duty, these police often had to be accompanied by a black police member to translate for them, adding further to the staff shortage.

It was alleged the top management frequently refused suggestions made by black police members wanting to change the policing style to one more understanding of Xhosa culture.

Management also failed to resolve problems put to them by black staff, such as the transport crisis. It was alleged that white staff take home the station's best vehicles, thus depleting the inadequate pool of cars for reaction to crises.

"Hardly any cars are left for duties after 4pm," a second source said.

But Director Haarhoff denied that many of the vehicles used for shift work were being taken home by white officers.

The best vehicles were allocated to the shifts and some of the cars were used by officers on duty at night, he said.

He has applied for a 36-seater bus to help transport staff to and from work and this will free up other vehicles used for this purpose.

Responding to allegations of a lack of affirmative action, Director Haarhoff said he expected the third round of appointments at the level of captain and superintendent to be made shortly.

"It's not a case of us holding back promotions. We must wait for the process to be completed," he said.

Workshops had been held with the local community policing forum to thrash out problems between the police and the community.

More workshops were planned for transforming the style of policing of members still in the old way of thinking when dealing with residents, he said, adding that police members only smashed down front doors if they had a search warrant to locate illegal firearms.

"In this case we can't knock to warn the occupants because they frequently fire through the walls when they realise the police are outside and there are no brick walls to hide behind," he said.

On the language issue, he said that in Cape Town Xhosa-speaking police were in demand at stations serving an area with a large Xhosa population and that there were not enough of these members to go around.

But 40 black police reservists had recently joined the station and another 50 were being trained.

Many changes had been made at the police station, but there was still a long road ahead.

"We are not going to solve our problems overnight. We do the best we can," he said.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


437 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 17, 1997


South Africa;
Boesak in city court today


BYLINE: William-Mervin Gumede and Chene Blignaut, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1054 words


 

Cape Town - Anti-apartheid campaigner Allan Boesak, back home to appear in court today on fraud and theft charges, is believed to have had a private meeting with President Mandela soon after arriving yesterday.

Professing his innocence, Dr Boesak, who faces 21 counts of theft and nine of fraud involving nearly R2-million, received a hero's welcome at Cape Town airport after more than a year in the United States.

He appeared in Cape Town Magistrate's Court today, but the case was postponed to August 4 in the Cape High Court. An African National Congress spokesman said the trial was expected to last at least eight months. 

Dr Boesak was given a red carpet welcome at the airport by about 3 000 supporters, led by Justice Minister Dullah Omar, who has come under fire for supporting Dr Boesak openly.

Mr Omar said he had gone to the airport to meet Dr Boesak at the express request of Mr Mandela.

This was confirmed by a spokesman in the president's office, who said he did not understand what the "fuss" was about.

The spokesman said he "thought" the president met Dr Boesak privately yesterday but could not say what the meeting was about.

"Dr Boesak is a human being who does not deserve to be hounded in this way. He is no longer a public representative. He is a citizen who is entitled to be supported by friends and those who know him when he faces difficulties," said the spokesman.

He said Mr Mandela had indicated a need for South Africans to treat one another humanely throughout his presidency.

"In that context the president would want to look at Dr Boesak not only as a citizen, but also as his son.

"The president often says the strength of a person is not never to fall, but to rise every time you fall," he said.

Because of South Africa's "dented" history and the fact that many people in high places had been pardoned or forgiven and still played an important role in public life, the president urged public commentators and political parties to have "a global view" when looking at the affairs of the country, the spokesman said.

Dr Boesak returned to Cape Town with his wife Elna and their five-year-old daughter Sarah-Len after several days consulting lawyers in Pretoria.

His four children from his previous marriage, Lieneker, Allan, Belen and Pulani, and his 84-year-old mother Sarah were at the airport to welcome him.

Dr Boesak was carried shoulder-high by chanting supporters as hundreds more tried to touch him.

He said if he were found guilty, the anti-apartheid struggle would stand condemned for what it had done. "I have come back to this country, my country, my home, because I am not afraid to face those who have charged me; because I am, as they know, totally innocent of the charges they have levelled against me."

Mr Omar, who has been criticised by the National and Democratic parties for publicly pledging his solidarity with Dr Boesak, said he had been told by Mr Mandela to welcome him home. "Comrade Mandela told me: 'Dullah, you're going to the airport.' I welcome Comrade Allan on behalf of the entire African National Congress," Mr Omar said to thunderous applause.

The DP and NP say Mr Omar, as political head of the justice system under which Dr Boesak is being tried, should not show open support for him.

The National Party said it was "unacceptable, unsuitable and unjustifiable" for a minister of justice to intervene with comments on behalf of an accused while the case against that person was pending.

They were specifically critical of the minister's comments that "struggle bookkeeping" might be to blame for the charges against Dr Boesak, saying the minister should remember the background of rampant commercial crime and corruption against which the case would be heard.

"The minister should also remember that the most damaging aspect of the Boesak case was the heightened scepticism of foreign donor agencies channelling much-needed aid to legitimate local NGOs."

Mr Omar denied any conflict between his public support for Dr Boesak and his position as minister of justice. He said the criticism came from elements of the old apartheid era who were still operating in the new democracy. As minister of justice he had not interfered in the legal process.

Mr Omar said although 1994 had brought political change, most public institutions - media, police and judiciary - were still in the hands of those who controlled them in the apartheid era. In a marquee outside the airport, supporters chanted "Boesak, Boesak", toyi-toyied, and jeered the two Afrikaans newspapers, Die Burger and Rapport, whom they accused of hounding Dr Boesak.

Dr Boesak told the crowd he was totally innocent of the charges and said he had faced worse tribulations in his life.

South Africa's history and the nation's collective conscience would have to explain how it had come about that he had to return to Cape Town to stand trial while murderers of children were free, he said.

"How is it possible that I stand accused while those who took the lives of our children sit in Parliament?" Dr Boesak asked.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


438 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 17, 1997


South Africa;
Truth Panel Sets May 30 Deadline for Media Submissions


BYLINE: Truth and Reconciliation Commission


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Cape Town - Statement by Adv Denzil Potgieter SC, Chairperson, Media & Communications Committee, Truth and Reconciliation Commission, March 16, 1997

The Truth and Reconciliation Commission has set May 30 this year as the deadline for submissions on the role which the media played in South Africa during the period from 1960 to the 1994 election.

The TRC's working group on the media -- set up by the Human Rights Violations Committee of the Commission -- is pleased to report that it has already begun to receive submissions in connection with a possible special hearing on the media. Submissions from a number of individual journalists, as well as organisations, are expected. 

Submissions received so far support the impression given by the current public debate that there is considerable interest in this matter, not only within the media but also from the public.

Submissions, whether from individuals or organisations, should be sent to any regional office of the Truth Commission, or to the head office at P O Box 3162, Cape Town, 8000, to reach the Commission by 30 May 1997.

A decision will then finally be made as to whether a special hearing on the media needs to take place, and what form it should take.

The Commission has been given the responsibility by the Promotion of National Unity & Reconciliation Act to "establish the truth in relation to past events". These events specifically involve "gross human rights violations" erpetrated within a political context between March 1960 and 10 May 1994.

The Commission has a dual responsibility here, which suggests two sorts of submissions from the media: firstly, to offer victims, particularly those journalists whose stories of abuse under apartheid have not been heard, the opportunity of telling their stories; and, secondly, to provide "as complete a picture as possible" of the "nature, causes and extent of" such abuses, including "the antecedents, circumstances, factors and context of such violations..."

So it is not simply a question of looking at the role of the media during the apartheid years, and the experiences of individual journalists during those years, but also of describing the context in which the media functioned.

At the same time, the Commission has the added responsibility of producing a final report in which recommendations are made to Parliament as to the future of those sectors covered by Commission hearings. This too provides all sectors of the media with an opportunity -- and a challenge -- to make suggestions for their future development.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


439 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 17, 1997


East Africa;
Emergency Update No. 129 on the Great Lakes (03/17)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2374 words


 

Nairobi - Zairean rebels of the Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire (ADFL), capitalizing on their Kisangani victory, are advancing to the west and south of Zaire. Retreating FAZ troops are reported to have reached Yangambi, about 50 km west of Kisangani.

ADFL spokesman Raphael Ghenda told AFP that on Friday rebels had taken Pweto, a town on Lake Moero which straddles the Zambia-Zaire border. Humanitarian sources today confirmed to IRIN the takeover. Sources also report looting soldiers passing through Luanza, south of Pweto. To the west, two disorderly soldiers were reported killed recently by the local population in Kikondjo, a riverside town southwest of Manono. Soldiers are reportedly fleeing towards Kolwezi, to the west of Lubumbashi and not far from the Zambian border. "Lubumbashi is the next big target", rebel leader Laurent- Desire Kabila told a news conference in Goma on Saturday. "We are still advancing," he added, reports Reuters. 

* The ADFL continues to reject calls for a ceasefire, and Kabila is reported as saying that only face-to-face talks with Mobutu might "constitute some kind of pause", reports Reuters yesterday. Joint OAU/UN Special Representative Mohamed Sahnoun and UN Humanitarian Coordinator Pierce Gerety met with Kabila on Saturday in Goma, but made no statement after the meeting. The Kinshasa government has indicated its willingness to respect a ceasefire. UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan is reported to be adopting a "wait and see" attitude, while the European Union on Sunday appealed to all parties to " respect both the refugees and the Zairean population."

* Joseph Kabila, Laurent Desire's 25-year-old son, who described himself as "operational commander of the northern sector" for the ADFL, told Reuters that the biggest problem after capturing Kisangani was a "carpet" of mines on roads leading to the city, except the one used by the FAZ for retreat. He said demining was his priority. He denied that aircraft had been destroyed by retreating soldiers and mercenaries, saying his forces had found no airplanes at the airport. He said no mercenaries appear to have died in the battle for the city, according to CNN. The government of Zaire alleged today that the battle for Kisangani involved "heavily armed regular units of the Ugandan army equipped with sophisticated weapons."

* The UN High Commissioner for Refugees, Sadako Ogata, urged the ADFL not to attack Ubundu, where up to 100,000 Rwandan and Burundian refugees have congregated. Ogata, in a statement from Geneva yesterday, said that Ubundu " is the last place where we can locate them and help them." "The refugees are at the end of their strength. Their harrowing odyssey through the wilderness has to stop now, or many more lives will be lost", the statement says. Even if security can be established, the diplomatic and logistical challenges in supplying Ubundu - still technically under Zairean government control - will be formidable.

* The hazardous crossing of the Zaire river and capsizing of boats at Ubundu had left refugees stranded on rocks in the middle of the river on Friday, several sources say. An AFP correspondent, flying overhead, reported seeing the wreckage of three rafts and a large canoe stuck on the rocks in the river. Recent reports say that about 40 canoes are taking passengers across the river for a fee, while rafts are being constructed from plastic sheeting, bamboo and empty barrels.

* Three European NGOs (ACF, MSF-France and MSF-Belgium) have attempted to investigate the feasibility of establishing a new airlift route to Ubundu using an airstrip at Bokungu, 300 km southwest of Kisangani as a base. The team left Kinshasa on Friday, but were not permitted to fly from Bokungu to Ubundu by local officials.

* Maj-Gen Paul Kagame, Rwandan vice-president and minister of defence, said that any multinational force for eastern Zaire could "contribute to the deterioration of the situation" because "those who are looking for this kind of intervention have other motives altogether". In a broadcast on Radio Rwanda, referring to the plight of Rwandan refugees in eastern Zaire, he said that the majority of Rwandan refugees had returned home, and that "these ones (still in Zaire) particularly refused to return to their country. And there is not much we can do about it. I think they will have to pay a price for not making the correct decision...The issue is just to continue urging the refugees to return".

* An emergency cabinet meeting was called by the Zairean government in Kinshasa today. Sporadic gunshots were reported overnight in Kinshasa, Reuters reported. A communique from today's meeting urged people not to give in to "unwarranted panic", according to AFP.

* While ADFL rebels declare that "the Mobutu era is over", Zairean politicians and western diplomats are re-aligning themselves in the expectation of a further decline in the health of the Mobutu regime, analysts say. President Mobutu Sese Seko's return to Zaire from France has been delayed until next week, according to aides, and he has remained in hospital since Sunday. French Foreign Minstry spokesman Jacques Rummelhardt told a news briefing that "Mobutu's health is an additional source of concern in the Zairean crisis", Reuters reports. Belgian Foreign Minister Erik Derijcke said today that "the Mobutu era came to an end some time ago" and that Kabila " cannot be ignored".

The Secretary-General of the Union for Democracy and Social Progress (UDPS), the party of opposition leader Etienne Tshisekedi on Friday said that the UDPS and ADFL were pursuing the same objectives - "the eradication of dictatorship and the establishment of a state that respects the rule of law." According to Gabonese radio, Adrien Mpongo Kunda said the UDPS took credit for weakening the government through non-violent means, thereby easing the progress of the rebellion. Adrien Mpongo further suggested that a Zairean roundtable conference be part of the Nairobi III diplomatic initiative. He further proposed a merger of the FAZ and ADFL forces as part of a future peace deal.

* Following his visit to Goma, Mohamed Sahnoun met with Pierre Buyoya, Burundi's military ruler yesterday, but no details of the meeting have emerged. The Burundi regime now claims that the anti-tank mines which killed seven people in Bujumbura were part of last week's coup attempt. Five people have so far been arrested on charges of plotting to assassinate the regime's leader, Pierre Buyoya. A number of western embassies and aid agencies in Bujumbura have recommended their expatriates observe an informal curfew from about 7 pm onward. The official curfew - from midnight until dawn - is unchanged.

* The UN Emergency Relief Coordinator, Yasushi Akashi, has announced the appointment of Pierce Gerety as UN Regional Humanitarian Coordinator for the Great Lakes Region. Gerety succeeds Martin Griffiths, who has resumed his functions as Director the Geneva Office of the Department of Humanitarian Affairs. Gerety, who most recently served as UNICEF's Emergency Coordinator for the Great Lakes, will be based in Nairobi.

* Independent Belgrade-based radio B92, monitored by BBC, reported yesterday that a mercenary, known only as "V.N." revealed that 60 mercenaries from southern Serbia are to leave this week to join others already in Zaire fighting on the government side. "V.N." said that a three-month contract would earn him $6,000, while his family would receive $100,000 if he dies during the mission.

An international Convention against mercenaries adopted by the UN General Assembly in 1989 has been ratified by only 11 countries. The Convention can enter into force only after 22 states have ratified or acceded to it.

* The trial of Georges Rutaganda is to start tomorrow at the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda in Arusha, Tanzania. Rutaganda, allegedly a leader of the notorious Interahamwe militia, was charged last May with eight counts of genocide and crimes against humanity. The Tribunal ruled on March 6 that 16 witnesses for the defence in the trial of Rutaganda were being sought. The witnesses were last known to be in Tingi-Tingi refugee site in eastern Zaire, and the Tribunal ruled that they should be located and placed under the protection of the Tribunal.

* Honore Rakotomanana, the deputy prosecutor the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda who resigned last month, will return to his native Madagascar, reports AFP. Rakotomanana and registrar Andronico Adede of Kenya both handed in their resignations to UN Secretary-General kofi Annan after an UN investigation into the Arusha operation accused Adede of mismanagement and said that Rakotamanana had failed to persue masterminds of the 1994 Rwandan genocide. In a statement, Rakotamana said that he had resigned "because of divergences of views between my hierarchial superiors and myself and in the superior interests of the population of Rwanda". Twenty-one people accused of masterminding or being involved in the genocide have been indicted by the Tribunal.

In Rwanda, 128 new judges were sworn in at the National Assembly on Friday. The cases of four suspects accused of crimes against humanity in Kibungu prefecture are expected to resume tomorrow, according to Rwandan radio.

* The latest round of talks between Uganda and Sudan are reported to have ended in failure after intensive discussions in Entebbe which concluded on Saturday. The Ugandan Sunday Vision reported that the two sides failed to agree on the wording of a proposed communique, with Uganda seeking to condemn abductions of children in northern Uganda and Sudan refusing mention of this in the communique. On Friday Ugandan radio reported President Museveni condemning 'Sudanese-sponsored terrorists who mutilate Ugandan civilians and kidnap schoolchildren.'

The talks, chaired by Iran's Minister of Foreign Affairs Ali Akhbar Velayati and also involving Malawi's Foreign Minister, Dr A.G. Nga Mtafu, sought to improve relations between Uganda and Sudan, under growing strain over Sudanese accusations of Ugandan support for the SPLA offensive in southern Sudan and Ugandan claims of Sudanese support for the LRA and WNBF. Iran's minister of Foreign Affairs announced on Sunday that the next round of talks will take place in June in Tehran, at foreign ministers' level. Uganda's Minister of Foreign Affairs, Eriya Kategaya, had criticized Sudan the previous day for sending a civil servant, Under Secretary Ali Elnimari, to represent them in the recent talks. Earlier talks had either involved heads of state or ministers.

The SPLA offensive continued over the weekend, with the SPLA reportedly capturing Lainya on Saturday afternoon. Lainya, a former Sudanese army garrison town, lies about halfway along the main road between Yei and Juba. The capture of Yei by the SPLA was confirmed over the weekend, after initial denials from the Sudanese Government. On Sunday, the Sudanese Government reported that it had recaptured the eastern town of Chali el-Fil from the SPLA, which took the town in January. Chali el-Fil lies is in Blue Nile state about 30 km from the border with Ethiopia.

The Ugandan Sunday Monitor reported yesterday that Colonel Juma Oris, commander of the WNBF, was killed on Saturday during fighting near the Uganda- Sudan border between the WNBF and the UPDF. The report cited 'military sources' in Kampala but gave no further details. Juma Oris was previously a minister in Idi Amin's Government. The New Vision reported last Thursday that Morobo, a town close to Sudan's border with Zaire, which was taken by the SPLA on Wednesday, had since 1985 been the operational and training headquarters of the WNBF.

Nairobi, Monday 17 March 1997, 14:05 GMT (ENDS)

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. Quotations or extracts from this report should include attribution to the original sources mentioned, not simply "DHA".)

440 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 18, 1997


Sudan;
Appeal for 31 Detained Sudanese Officer


BYLINE: The World Organisation Against Torture (Geneva)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1134 words


 

Geneva - The International Secretariat of OMCT/SOS-Torture has received new information concerning 31 officers detained in the Sudan.

Brief reminder of the situation: In September of 1996 OMCT was informed of the arrest and detainment of a number of Sudanese Army officers in Port Sudan on 15 August. The officers were transferred to Khartoum, where reports suggested that they had been tortured. The officers were also denied the right to receive visits from family and lawyers, so was impossible to ascertain their fate or exact whereabouts. It was believed that some had been executed. 

New information: According to a reliable source, the right to a fair trial is allegedly being violated in the case of 31 army officers and civilians currently on trial for attempting to overthrow the government.

OMCT has great concern over the defendants' right to a fair trial for three reasons. First, several of the defendants are civilians, and are being judged by a military court tribunal. Second, the trial is not open to the public. Third, the tribunal ordered the immediate submission of the defence council's final statement. When the defence council asked for time to prepare the statement, they were told that the tribunal would file for judgement by the end of the day whether the defence statement had been submitted or not.

The following persons are among the accused (given the circumstances the complete list is unknown) :

1. Colonel Jamal Yusuf

2. Lt. Col. Al-Abbas Ali Abbas

3. Lt. Col. Othman Abdel Rahman Hamid

4. Lt. Col. (Navy) Isma'il Ahmed Mohamed Isawi

5. Lt. Col. Mohammed Mahmoud

6. Lt. Col Bader Al-din Al Haj

7. Lt. Col (Engineer) Tariq Muhammed Ahmed Abu Obeida

8. Maj al-Dardiri Al-Haj Ahmed

9. Maj Kemeilio Oltario

10. Maj al-Bashir Hamid Breima

11. Maj Salah Hamid Karbus

12. Capt. Ali Fkash Mohamed

13. Sgt. Maj. Issai Deen Gasmal Seed Mohamed

14. Sgt. Yahia Duin Musa

15. Col. (Ret) Omar Mohamed Othman Abdel Rahman

16. Col (Ret) Abdel Marouf Hussein Abdel Rahman

17. Col. (Ret) Fadi Al Seed Abdalla

18. Mr. Al Daawi Ibrahim Al Sheik

19. Mr. Abdel Monien Hassan Sharwani

20. Salim Borainma Salim

21. Mr. Diyab Ibrahim Diayb

22. Lt. Col. Suliman Isma'il

23. Col. Jarnal Yusuf

24. Lt. Col. Isma'il Isawi.

It is feared that the court is acting under direct orders from the military and that the accused are likely to face a sentence of capital punishment.

OMCT notes that the Sudanese government has ratified the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and has signed the Convention Against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment which prohibit the infliction of any kind of physical or mental pain as a form of punishment.

Action Requested: Write to the Sudanese authorities urging them to:

i. take all the necessary measures to guarantee the physical and psychological integrity of those persons mentioned above;

ii. order that those accused be brought before a competent and impartial civil tribunal, particularly in the case of the civilians accused, and guarantee their procedural rights at all times;

iii. ensure in all circumstances the full respect of human rights and fundamental freedoms in accordance with national laws and international standards, including taking the necessary measure to abolish the death penalty.

Addresses: His Excellency Lieutenant General Omar Hassan al-Bashir, President of the Republic of Sudan, People's Palace, PO Box 281, Khartoum, Sudan. Telex : 22385 PEPLC SD or 22411 KAID SD - Fax : +249 11 71 724

Brigadier Bakri Hassan Salih, Minister of Interior, People's Palace, PO Box 281, Khartoum, Sudan. Telex : 22842 WZARA SD or 22604 IPOL SD - Fax : +249 11 71724 / 76554 / 77900 / 73046 / 70186

Mr. Abdel Basset Sabdrat, Minister of Justice and Attorney-General, Ministry of Justice, Khartoum, Sudan. Telex : 22459 KHRJA SD or 22461 KHRJA SD (via Ministry of Foreign Affairs) - Fax : +249 11 74 063

Mr. Ali Osman Mohamad Taha, Minister of Foreign Affairs, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, PO Box 873, Khartoum, Sudan. Telex : 22459 KHRJA SD or 22461 KHRJA SD - Fax : +249 11 74 063

Chief Justice, Khartoum Sudan. Telegram : Honorable Chief Justice, Khartoum, Sudan

Geneva, 18 March 1997

Kindly inform us of any action undertaken quoting the exact case number of this appeal.

For further information, contact Ben Schonveld, Projects Manager OMCT-SOS- Torture Fax 4122 733 1051 Ph 4122 733 3140. OMCT is l'Organisation Mondiale contre la Torture / The World Organisation Against Torture. OMCT@IPROLINK.CH http://www.omct.org/

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


March 18, 1997


Ethiopia;
Appeal for Three Journalists in Detention


BYLINE: The World Organisation Against Torture (Geneva)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 707 words


 

Geneva - The International Secretariat of OMCT requests your URGENT intervention in the following situation in Ethiopia.

Brief reminder of the situation: The International Secretariat had been informed by a reliable source of the detention and possible torture of five journalists in Ethiopia.

According to the information received, Goshu Moges, of Tobiya magazine, Aklilu Tadesse of Ma'ebel magazine and Dawit Kebede of Fiyamenta magazine were detained by security police on 12th, 11th and 10th December respectively. It was alleged that the arrest of these journalists followed the arrest, under similar circumstances at the end of November, of Taye Belachew and Anteneh Merid of Tobiya magazine 

The report also stated that none of these journalists had been charged and given the circumstances of their arrest, there were grave fears for their physical and psychological integrity.

New information: The International Secretariat has been informed by a reliable source of the following developments of the case in Ethiopia;

Taye Belachew, Goshu Moges and Anteneh Merid, three of the four arrested senior journalists, are reported to have been released on bail on7th, 10th and 11th February 1997 respectively. There is no news of Dawit Kebede.

Information received states that to-date, there are now twelve journalists in prison in Ethiopia, seven of whom are not convicted and are believed to have been in prison for over a year. Given the circumstances of their detention OMCT must express concern for their physical and psychological integrity

Action requested:

Please write to the Ethiopian authorities urging them to:

i. guarantee the physical and psychological integrity of all the above mentioned persons who are still in detention in Ethiopia;

ii. immediately release all the above mentioned detained persons in the absence of valid charges; If such charges exist bring them before a public tribunal and guarantee their procedural rights at all times.

iii. carry out an exhaustive and impartial investigation into the detention of all above mentioned persons in order to identify those responsible, bring them before a competent and impartial court and apply the penal, civil and/or administrative sanctions in accordance with the laws;

iv. guarantee the full respect of human rights and fundamental freedoms in the country, in accordance with national law and international standards.

Addresses: His Excellency Dr Negaso Gidada, President of the Federal Republic of Ethiopia, Office of the President, P O Box 1031, Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. Fax : + 2511 552030

Mr. Mahteme Solomon, Minister of Justice, Ministry of Justice, P O Box 1370, Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. Fax : + 2511 550722

His Excellencey Dr Negaso Gidada, President of the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia, Office of the President, PO Box 1031 Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. Fax : +2511 55 2030

Geneva 18 March 1997

Kindly inform us of any action undertaken quoting the exact case number of this appeal.

For further information, contact Ben Schonveld, Projects Manager OMCT-SOS- Torture Fax 4122 733 1051 Ph 4122 733 3140. OMCT is l'Organisation Mondiale contre la Torture / The World Organisation Against Torture. OMCT@IPROLINK.CH http://www.omct.org/


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


442 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 18, 1997


Ethiopia;
The Week in Brief


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Addis Ababa - "Significant performance" -- House Speaker Dawit Yohannes said the House had registered significant achievements over the past 18 months. he told journalists that the House, besides issuing proclamations to implement the five-year development programme and provisions enshrined in the constitution, is closely assessing and following up the activities of the executive bodies.

The House has reviewed the performance of the executive body with an objective to look into constraints, he said, adding despite capacity limitation in some sections the overall endeavour was satisfactory and commensurate with the constitution.

Meanwhile, a proclamation providing for the establishment of the federal police delineating its structural organization with an aim to consolidate democratic working procedures is in the pipeline. 

Relief aid

Over 900,000 quintals of emergency relief aid is needed for drought victims in Somali Region, Borena, Bale and Omo zones, officials of the Disaster prevention and Preparedness commission disclosed recently. The officials said the relief food will be dispatched to pastoralists in the area until June this year.

It was stated that the number of the drought victims stood at 986,000 with the expense needed to dispatch medical drugs estimated at 622,000 birr.

Culture Draft Policy symposium

A four-day symposium on the draft culture policy was held recently at the Yared Music School. the participants, who were drawn from the various regional states, deliberated on the various issues that were included in the draft policy.

In her closing remark, Bisrat Gashaw-Tena, Vice Minister of Information and Culture, said that the country follows democratic principles and added that the government also encourages the full participation of the general public in matters pertaining to popular issues.

She added that people have now, more than any other time, realized that respect to one's identity means respect to one's cultures.

Donors support

Bilateral and multilateral donors participating in the "government-led workshop on Ethiopian social sector investment programmes and indicative budgetary support of donors" have agreed to give a sum of 665 million US dollars for projects related with the vital sector of health and education in Ethiopia, Mr. Fayez Omar, disclosed at the conclusion of a three-day workshop.

formally closing the workshop, the Minister in charge of Social and Administrative Affairs in the Office of the Prime Minister, Dr. Kebede Tadesse, expressed satisfaction with the invaluable contributions the donors pledged to bring to reality the improvement in quality and quantity of vital sectors of education and health.


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


443 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 18, 1997


Ethiopia;
Gold Cross stolen from Lalibela Medhanialem Church


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

LALIBELA (ENA) - A gold Cross weighing five kg. and believed to have seen eight centuries was stolen from the Medhanialem church in Lalibela. The mystery of the theft still revolves around those serving in the church.

The Bugna Woreda police office has detained some 13 of the church-men in connection with the robbery. 

The church administrator claimed to have gone home after alerting the guard that he has left to the latter's dismay who said he had been slumbering in a nearby cave following a shower of rain that night.

The cross, which covers the chest of a man of a medium height, was stolen last Sunday late in the night with only one of the doors leading to the church broken into.

The church administrator said he discovered that the main door leading to the nave was broken with the entrance to the sacristy in tact when he entered the church for his night prayer at 1:15 pm. after midnight on Sunday.

"When I looked into the box in which sacred objects are kept I missed the cross. it is only then I rang the bell," he said.

Woreda police chief corporal Alemnew Bahiru said the church administrator is one of suspects as he has left open the metal door including the lid of the box, the store for the invaluables.

Chalices, Jewellers and other crosses were found intact further reinforcing suspicions that the theft was carried out by somebody who knows the in and out of the church, he said.

The ancient golden cross was used only for ceremonial purposes but otherwise kept at one place, it was learnt.

A slab was reported to have disappeared some two years back was found in the church compound.

The ten rock-hewn churches, monuments of the magnificent craftsmanship built in the 11th century during the reign of King Lalibela are situated in Lalibela thrown some 640 km. north of Addis Ababa.


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


444 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 18, 1997


Ethiopia;
Government, Metropolitans urged to act together


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 907 words


 

ADDIS ABABA (ENA) - The head of the Region 14 Administration urged the government and metropolitans to join hands to alleviate economic and social problems in the capital.

Ato Ali Abdo said at the closing of the two-day popular gathering on Sunday that, the meeting has helped the regional administration gather from the participants constructive ideas vital for future activities.

The meeting had ratified a document on economics social and administrative affairs. The meeting had also discussed performances and problems encountered by administrative bodies, police and the judiciary. 

Meanwhile, the regional council announced that some 331,000 residents of the capital will have access to telephone service n the next four years with 83,000 others to get electric power supply.

The federal government has allocated over 661 mil. birr for the installation of the new telephone lines, a document presented to the popular conference disclosed over the weekend.

It said, in the past four years, fax, telex and telephone lines were installed for over 17,000 clients in the capital with an outlay of 11.3 mil. birr.

The service the Telecommunications Authority is rendering is by no means commensurate to the need for modern communication systems though its performance so far was encouraging, the document indicated.

The central government, on the other hand has finalized plan preparations to supply electric power to 83,000 dwellers at a cost of 185 mil. birr. The plan will be implemented in the next five years.

Over 23,000 new clients were beneficiaries of electric power in the past four years with government budget amounting to 28.7 mil. birr allocated to this end, according to the document.

In a related news story the administrative council announced that the construction of the Addis Ababa ring road which was brought to a standstill will resume in March 1998.

The council told the public conference on Saturday preparations are being made to put in a tender for the revised project design.

Some 108.9 million birr has already been utilized for the execution of the project out of which 56.6 million birr was paid in compensation.

The council estimates that the project cost a total of five hundred million birr.

The construction of the road is expected to be completed in June 2000.

In a report presented on the activities the council over the past four years in the health, education and various others sectors.

It was indicated that two health stations and two clinics were constructed at a cost of 2.2 million birr government budget during the stated period.

There are 375 medical doctors and 963 nurses in the state-run health institutions serving the 2.3 million cosmopolitans, it said.

An average of 182,145 children below five years of age have received free medical services annually, the report pointed out.

It said 159 certified private clinics are currently operating in the region while 33 donor agencies with a combined capital of over 20 million birr are engaged in the sector.

Health institutions were also maintained at a cost of 3.3 million birr, according to the report.

The services health institutions in the metropolis render are plagued buy inefficiencies and flaws although they are better in comparison with those in other regions, it remarked.

In the education sector, the report said, eight new senior secondary schools admitting 15,951 students were constructed at a cost of 2.6 million birr.

Similarly, eight primary and junior secondary schools were built with 207, 830 birr government budget.

Senior secondary schools were also expanded at a cost of 13.1 million birr enabling them to enrol 1600 additional students, it said.

The report added 39 elementary and junior secondary schools were expanded with 10.5 million birr government budget.

It said 51 primary, junior and senior secondary schools are being refurbished at a cost of 9.5 million birr. some 59 kindergarten have also been opened. The council further indicated food, clothings and household utensils worth 38.6 million birr were provided to displaced people.

The conference has discussed and approved the document presented to it.


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

445 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 18, 1997


Business and Finance;
Ethiopia: Economic Policy Review


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2494 words


 

Addis Ababa - Issued by the Economic Policy Advisory Unit Office of the Prime Minister

Overview

During the first quarter of 1996/97, internal balance of the economy was well maintained. Inflation levelled-off at a negative rate, growth of money supply decelerated, and the government budget attained an overall surplus. In the external sector, trade imbalance widened while foreign exchange market segmentation narrowed substantially. On top of last year's high growth rate, imports rose sharply and net foreign reserves declined marginally, due to both trade deficit and capital outflows, though still remaining ample with a coverage of several months of imports. At the same time, the exchange rate premium in the parallel market declined sharply following the termination of the franco valuta import trade in July, except for used vehicles which was allowed to continue until the end of September.

Inflation

Inflation stood below zero during the quarter. Year-on- year inflation rate for the quarter as a whole was negative 7 per cent, and that of 12-months moving average was minus 1.7 per cent. Thus both in terms of trend and quarterly figures the general price level was declining. The fall in prices was most pronounced in cereals which showed a decline of 14 per cent, compared to the same quarter of the previous year, while prices of non-food items decreased by 2.3 per cent. For food items in total, the quarter-to- quarter fall in prices was minus 8.8 per cent. 

The negative inflation rate witnessed during the first quarter of 96/97 was, as in previous quarters, largely due to the impressive growth of food production during 95/96. Food prices appear to be set to stay constant for the current year as a whole, as agricultural output from the 96/97 main crop(Mehir) season is expected to show further growth.

But, the decline of the inflation rate of manufactured goods and services (i.e. non-food items) over several months, which reflects both increase in domestic production and imports, is also of significance, though of lesser amount. It attests to prudent monetary and foreign exchange policies, in addition to growth of the non-agricultural sector. Price changes were limited between the first quarter of 96/97 and the last quarter of 95/96. The general price level decreased marginally by 1.3 per cent despite seasonal price increases of cereals by 2 per cent. But,. prices of non-cereal food items decreased by a significant amount of 2.8 per cent, or an annualised rate of 11.2 per cent. As for manufactured goods and services, the price index was virtually constant, having decreased by a mere 0.2 per cent.

Within the quarter itself volatility of prices was negligible. Except for the index of non-food items, the other indices for cereal and non-cereals showed no fluctuation of prices. Even for non-food items, price fluctuation was of a significant amount only once, between august and September, in which it amounted to nearly 3 per cent.

Money supply

Money supply in the first quarter compared to the last quarter of the previous year increased by a small margin of 1.2 per cent (annualised 4.8 per cent). Net foreign assets declined by a significant margin of a quarterly rate of 5.7 per cent, whereas net domestic assets increased by 5.8 per cent. The decrease in net foreign assets was largely due to a single capital outflow, which accounted for three-fourth of the fall. Growth of net domestic assets, on the other side, was nearly all accounted for by an increase in net claims against the government at the end of the fiscal year, counter-balanced by a reduction of nearly half of this amount by expansion of residual(or uncleared balance) bank liabilities. Credit to the private sector accounted for a mere 5 per cent of the quarterly increase in net domestic assets.

Credit to the private sector increased at a quarterly rate of 0.4 per cent, whereas compared to the same quarter of the previous year it stood at 36.3 per cent higher. This indicates seasonality of credit expansion, which tends to be concentrated in the second half of the fiscal year. Given that net foreign assets are likely to decrease in dollar terms from the September level, and that net of the fiscal year, growth of money supply for the current year should be expected to fall well within the target rate of 9.1 per cent without any need to apply credit ceilings.

Broad money grew by 195 mn Birr, of which 171 mn was quasi-money and only 24 mn was narrow money. Within narrow money, currency in-circulation, in fact declined by 364 mn Birr, while demand deposits increase marginally higher, by 389 mn Birr. Hence, the quarterly increase in money supply is essentially attributable to a change in the composition of broad money, with a decrease in the ratio of currency to deposits. This is partly a continuation of a trend observed in recent years. But, the sharp decline of currency outside banks by 6.4 per cent between end-June and September 96 appears to be connected more with the termination of the franco valuta trade and the shrinking of the parallel market for foreign exchange during the quarter. As demand for cash holding declined due to the partial disappearance of the parallel market, dealers in foreign exchange have shifted, it seems, to deposit holdings.

The year-to-year growth of broad money in September amounted to 9.2 per cent which is within range of the 96/97 target of 9.1 per cent. As the base figure of broad money will be increasing significantly in the subsequent quarters, the prospect of meeting the target of money supply by the end of the current fiscal year appears reasonably good.

Exchange Rate

Several changes are envisaged in the foreign exchange regime, conforming with the policy to introduce an inter-bank foreign exchange market within the coming three year. As a first step, the existing auction was made more frequent by establishing weekly markets starting from 27 July. At the same time, franco valuta import trade was terminated, with a deadline of end-July later extended to end-September.

During this quarter the marginal rate of the auction market stayed stable, with slight changes from 6.35 Birr per US dollar at the end of June to 6.33 and 6.34 at end of July and August respectively. By the end of Septmeber, though, the rate increased significantly b a monthly rate of 0.8 per cent reaching 6.39 Birr per dollar. In real terms, the Birr, in fact, depreciated more as domestic prices fell by a quarterly rate of 1.3 per cent.

In the parallel market the rate fell sharply in July by as much as 5.3 per cent from 7.6 Birr per dollar to 7.15. this fall was triggered by the announcement of the termination of the franco valuta import trade as of the end of July, and the deregulation of the current account envisaged for the future. In the following month the premium of the dollar widened with the rate rising to 7.27 Birr, in response to the extension of the deadline for the ending of the private sector franco valuta imports. By the end of September the rate had almost reverted to its previous position, decreasing to 7.18 Birr per US dollar.

The differential between the auction and parallel market rates narrowed markedly during the quarter. Having stood at 18.9 per cent at the end of the previous quarter, the gap narrowed to 13 per cent in July and further to 12.3 per cent in September. Although the marginal rate did increase in September, the reduction of the premium was predominantly due the appreciation of the Birr in the parallel market.

Government Finance

Although government revenue in the first quarter declined 18.6 per cent below the same quarter of previous year, total expenditure as well fell 15.5 per cent below, resulting in overall budgetary surplus. compared to 96.97 budget, the revenue performance of the first quarter is, however, unsatisfactory.

In the current fiscal year, total revenue is expected to increase by 7.9 per cent, with a growth of 9 per cent in tax revenue and 5.3 per cent of non- tax revenue. Against these budgetary figures, comparison of this year's first quarter with last year's show that revenue fell by 18.6 per cent, due to a fall of non-tax revenue by 37.5 per cent. Moreover, the revenue of both direct and indirect taxes in the first quarter compares unfavourably with the budgetary estimates for the fiscal year. The latter foresees an increase of 14.2 per cent in indirect tax revenue coupled with a constant level of direct tax revenue, while the result of the first quarter shows an increase of only 6.4 per cent for revenue from indirect taxes and a decline of 11.1 per cent in direct tax revenue.

Still, strong conclusions should not be drawn from the performance of a single quarter, because of certain irregularities in the variations of revenue collection between fiscal years. Profit taxes, which account for no less than two-thirds of direct taxes, are payable by second week of November, more than a month after the first quarter. Actual payments, in fact, get made through out the year. Non-tax revenues also depend on profits of government enterprises, and additionally on proceeds from sales of government enterprises which has its own pace.

But, it would be valid to make year-to-year comparisons of quarterly revenue collection from indirect taxes, as these are largely free from irregular variations. thus the weak performance of the first quarter raise some doubt on the attainment of the current year's indirect tax revenue budget estimate. Revenue from taxes on foreign trade are apparently on target, so it is that of domestic sources which is lagging behind.

Expenditure, on the other side, was markedly below the same quarter of last year as well as the budgetary appropriation for this year. Recurrent and capital expenditures in the first quarter fell by 15.7 and 15.1 per cent respectively compared to the previous year. The contraction of expenditure is even greater when viewed in terms of the budget for the current year which envisages an increase of 10.9 per cent in the recurrent budget and a 36.2 per cent rise in the capital budget. A relatively small part of the lag in the recurrent expenditure is due to a lower to seasonality. But, overall, the indication from the performance of the first quarter is that there could be greater savings on the recurrent budget than foreseen, and that the appropriations for the capital budget might not be fully utilised.

Real Economy

The quarterly review will no longer report on the manufacturing sector. this is because of limitations of the available data, which, being confined to a fixed set of enterprises, do not cover new factories that are being established. consequently, it will be only foreign trade that is included in the discussion of the real economy.

In the first quarter the value of exports of coffee maintained the same level of last year despite falling prices due to a sharp rise in volume. compared to the first quarter of the previous year, the quantity of exports of coffee surged by 24.7 per cent. this increase indicates that a substantially high level of stocks were held at the end of 95.96 coffee season, as exports of first quarter originates entirely from stocks. Other, non-coffee exports, on the other hand, declined by about 12 per cent. although variability of seasonal changes could be an important factor, this decline of non-coffee exports is significant enough to adversely affect the export level for the year as a whole unless it is offset by the performance of subsequent months. In the first quarter it led to about 4.7 per cent decline in the total value of exports compared to the same quarter of the previous year.

Authorised imports by NBE(National Bank of Ethiopia), decreased by a quarterly rate of 2.4 per cent(annualised 9.6 per cent) compared to the previous quarter, but in comparison to the same quarter of last year (excluding fuel) increased by an annual rate of 12.2 per cent. Imports of consumer goods, however, rose sharply whether compared to the previous quarter or same quarter of last year. According to the former it rose by 27.2 per cent, and the latter by 56.4 per cent. This is partly a reflection of the re-direction of importers from franco valuta trade to official banking channels. But the figures also show real growth, perhaps of a substantive scale. Indeed there is, it seems, a continuation of pent-up demand from last year imported consumer goods, parallel with the high growth rate that is being registered tin the economy. It could take the whole of this year to exhaust this pent-up demand.

With imports poised to grow at a high rate while exports lag behind, the trade deficit in 96/97 should be expected to widen.


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1997

Africa News


March 18, 1997


South Africa;
Dolphin negotiations nearing completion


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 547 words


 

Nelspruit - High level negotiations between the Dubai-based Dolphin Group and Mpumalanga provincial government on the future of Dolphin's proposed monopoly of key State-owned tourist attractions in the province are expected to be completed later today. No announcement on an amended contract will, however, be made today said Dolphin spokesperson, Mike Sharpes.

Dolphin was forced into the re-negotiations by the provincial government after a wide-spread public outcry against a secret 50-year agreement between Dolphin and the Mpumalanga Parks Board (MPB) gave the controversial international company all commercial development and transverse rights to six State-owned game reserves, the entire Blyde River Canyon, Pilgrim's Rest and Loskop Dam. 

The MPB was sworn to complete secrecy about the contract's contents for the full 50-years that the contract was in force by a special clause which was included at Dolphin's insistence.

In return, Dolphin undertook to pay MPB's budget deficit for 50-years and to invest at least R300-million in capital development in the region. MPB officials estimated the deal to be worth R12,2-billion to the government and possibly R55-billion to the local economy.

After two months of public, NGO and media objections, the provincial government intervened and sent a "rescue mission" to London demanding alterations to the contract to "save the deal".

The final phase of negotiations, which began in Johannesburg on Monday and which is led by Dolphin's embattled president, Ketan Somaia, are expected to ratify a list of ten proposed significant changes to the contract.

These changes include the exclusion of the secrecy clause, the exclusion of Pilgrim's Rest and Manyeleti Game Reserve from the deal and the cutting of the contract from 50 to 25-years.

Legislative experts have, however, expressed concern that Dolphin has withdrawn its blanket offer to underwrite MPB's budget by pointing out that this is the only reason MPB was originally mandated to seek private sector investment.

Mpumalanga environmental affairs MEC, David Mkhwanazi, who is heading the governments delegation at the negotiations, said on Monday that he had never really supported the original contract but he was unable to say why he did not object to it sooner or why he had allowed it to be signed at all in November last year.

Unconfirmed reports indicate that Premier Mathews Phosa paid a short visit and informal to the negotiations on Monday afternoon before flying to Mozambique where he is scheduled to visit South African farmers who have resettled in that country. - African Eye News Service

LANGUAGE: English

447 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 18, 1997


Business and Finance;
Invicta looks set to reap bumper profits


BYLINE: Llewellyn Jones, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 547 words


 

Cape Town - Invicta Holdings, the Cape Town distributor of agricultural and construction equipment and parts, is on line to reap bumper profits for the year ending this month.

Speaking at a special meeting to place new shares with two institutions and increase the company's authorised capital yesterday, managing director Mike Rose-Innes said it was "safe to say profits will be well up on last year".

In the six months to September, Invicta saw net profits jump 102 percent to R15,1 million. 

The company is currently trading at around 500c a share, just shy of its all-time high of 520c reached just over a week ago.

Shareholders voted at the meeting in favour of issuing three million shares at an issue price of 475c a share for a total consideration of R14,25 million to Old Mutual Asset Manager and Coronation Asset Management.

Mr Rose-Innes said Invicta had been approached by the two institutions about six weeks ago for new equity, and "we decided to go ahead with a private placing and take some debt off our balance sheet".

"We run a very conservative company in an industry where you don't want excess debt on your balance sheet."

The industry has certainly treated Invicta well over the past two years, and the company is now eagerly eyeing the privatisation of co-operatives.

"Privatisation of co-ops will have a very good effect on Invicta because for the first time they will have to become totally profit oriented," Mr Rose- Innes said.

"The farmers have much more choice now and certainly our market share has in some areas has increased dramatically."

Perhaps more the important side to Invicta is its construction equipment business.

"We bought the construction equipment business of CSE in July and, while it wasn't profitable when we bought it, it has ceased losing money.

"We have begun to see a lot of positive signs in the construction industry - there are a lot of new contracts coming out and trading in that company is reasonable."

Mr Rose-Innes said Invicta now used the same warehouse for its agricultural and construction equipment, and the CSE branches were selling agricultural equipment, and Northmec branches were selling construction equipment.

"CSE, in effect, goes from five branches to 14, and Northmec from nine branches to 14," Mr Rose-Innes said.

This had increased the distribution for both businesses with little effect on service because most of the engines used on both agricultural and construction equipment were the same.


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English
