448 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 18, 1997


South Africa;
Political row grows over Omar backing for Boesak


BYLINE: Clive Sawyer, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Cape Town - The storm over Justice Minister Dullah Omar's backing for Allan Boesak as he faces a fraud trial is building, with a call for a parliamentary debate on the issue.

Mr Omar's protestations that his support for Mr Boesak is being demonstrated in his capacity as an African National Congress provincial leader - rather than as Minister of Justice - have been rejected by opposition parties.

The Democratic Party's Doug Gibson, who called for the parliamentary debate, said: "Has Mr Omar taken leave of his senses? He has lent his support to an attack on the rule of law, with which he has been entrusted with protecting and upholding." 

The DP said Mr Boesak had the right to be presumed innocent until proven guilty. "Instead of addressing the charges against him, however, Mr Boesak has chosen to present himself as a political martyr and to smear the justice system with the claim he is now fighting 'the same people' he was compelled to fight under apartheid," Mr Gibson said.

National Party spokesman Patrick McKenzie said it was clear that the " struggle" would be used to discredit the judiciary and the legal process, by turning the Boesak trial into an O J Simpson-style event.

Mr McKenzie said South Africa risked being labelled a banana republic by what he termed the direct interference of the minister of justice in a legal process.

The NP also supported the principle that a person was innocent until proven guilty. "However, it seems as if the ANC and the minister of justice have already found that a person involved in the struggle is innocent and will remain so - regardless of the legal process."

Mr McKenzie said the precedent this set would be that anyone could excuse a crime by blaming it on the struggle.

The Pan Africanist Congress also expressed misgivings about ANC government members supporting Mr Boesak.


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


449 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 18, 1997


South Africa;
Disaster and triumph - and we were there!


BYLINE: Don Lilford, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1014 words


 

Cape Town - The Cape Argus is 140-years old this year. And the biggest local story in it's history? Unquestionably it was Nelson Mandela's release from jail on February 11, 1990.

On that emotion-charged day, a legend was born - a beginning made in a relationship between a revered leader and his people which is probably unique in the world.

To stay with the story and reflect all the passion, the drama, the expectation and the joy of that momentous occasion, the Cape Argus was stretched to the limit. 

Not far behind, if only because of its element of surprise, was news of the world's first heart transplant operation, which brought international fame to Chris Barnard and Groote Schuur Hospital.

Heart transplants are routine operations today. But in 1967, the world caught its collective breath at the sight of Louis Washkansky being kept alive by the beating heart of pretty Denise Darvall, who had died hours earlier in a motor accident in Main Road, Observatory - a stone's throw from the hospital. The historic heart transplant operation took place on December 3, 1967. Mr Washkansky died, from rejection, 18 days later, on December 21.

For sheer drama, it would be hard to beat the stranding of the vessel Seafarer on the rocks at Mouille Point during a violent winter storm on July 1, 1966.

Noel Harford, Cape Argus shipping reporter at the time, was in a deep sleep in his Rondebosch home when he was jolted awake by the ringing of the telephone. The caller was the newspaper's works manager, Edward "Teddy" Jenkins, living then at Three Anchor Bay.

"You'd better get over here fast!" Jenkins said tersely, "There's a great big bloody ship on the rocks, right under Mouille Point lighthouse!"

When daylight came, under leaden skies, the predicament of those on board was frighteningly exposed.

Seafarer was fast on the rocks, broadside on to gigantic winter Atlantic swells, which thudded against her hull, broke over her fo'csle and showered her superstructure with spray. The cries of the terrified people on the bridge could be clearly heard.

Within a short time, a crowd of several thousand had gathered on the lawns at Three Anchor Bay to watch the unfolding drama. Those who came (it was before the days of television) saw one of the most dramatic rescues in South Africa's history.

Just when it seemed that the terrified people on board would perish while thousands stood helplessly by, Alouette helicopters from the SAAF squadron at Ysterplaat arrived. Displaying breathtaking skill in the atrocious conditions the SAAF pilots lifted the marooned people, one by one, to safety on the lawns.

The Seafarer broke in two a short time later and Harford led the paper for a full week with his stories of the rescue and subsequent Seafarer developments.

The year of 1966 produced another dramatic story when, on September 6, Prime Minister Hendrik Verwoerd was fatally stabbed in the House of Assembly by a parliamentary messenger, Dimitrio Tsafendas. Within minutes, veteran parliamentary reporter, Tos Wentzel, was on the phone dictating the stunning news.

Three years later, on the night of September 29, 1969, the Boland town of Tulbagh was hit by an earthquake. Several people died and the homes of many of the poorer families were reduced to rubble. The shock was felt even in Cape Town.

In 1974, the Rosenkowitz sextuplets, born on January 10, made headlines. Their story was followed by Cape Argus as they grew into adulthood.

On January 25, 1981, a snap message on the telex from a country correspondent was the first intimation of the disastrous flash flood that swept through Laingsburg. Immediate reaction was: "Floods in Laingsburg? What's this, then, April 1?"

But the news editor took the message seriously and sent off a team by car. Pronto. As a result the Cape Argus was well placed to report on the appalling devastation caused when a "wall of water" thundered down a normally dry Buffels River after a freak cloudburst some distance away.

Throughout the apartheid years the Cape Argus - described by State President PW Botha as being "beyond redemption" under the editorship of John O'Malley - reported the heroic struggle of disenfranchised people.

Stories that made headlines included the notorious Trojan Horse incident on October 15, 1985, when police sharpshooters, hiding in a railway truck, opened fire in Thornton Road, Athlone, killing three young people and wounding 15.

These are only some of the Big Stories of the last 50 years, not to mention reports that made headlines in the 90 years before that. Or any of the big international stories of the past 140 years - Neil Armstrong's walk on the moon, for one.


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


450 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 18, 1997


South Africa;
Giving street people a goal is the Big Issue (column)


BYLINE: Andrea Weiss, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 987 words


 

Cape Town - I'm grappling to settle on a topic for this week's column when my telephone rings and by the tone I recognise it as an internal call. It's our security desk downstairs telling me that there's a Philip wanting to speak to me.

Philip is a vendor for the Big Issue, the new magazine which has hit the streets of Cape Town to provide homeless and long-term unemployed people with a dignified alternative.

The Big Issue follows in the footsteps of its famous London counterpart which helps people on the street earn a living by allowing them to keep a portion of the cover price of the magazine. 

The Cape Town project has the full backing of its London sister publication, which is rooting for its success.

Here vendors keep R2 of the R3,50 selling price and they're expected to buy their own stock after a start-up allocation.

Philip, who is 68 and came to Cape Town for an eye operation, has come to deliver a complimentary copy of the second edition of the Big Issue to me.

This is after after an article which appeared in the Cape Argus about a month ago about the magazine and its operation.

Philip's had the eye operation (the hospital called him the day after the article was published) and he's ready to hit the streets with his bag bulging with the latest edition of the Big Issue.

It's a glorious day outside and, with his upbeat attitude, he's bound to do good business as he heads towards St George's Mall, his trade-mark green hat planted firmly on his head.

A good portion of his market is likely to be the tourist trade, people who recognise the title from the streets of London and who know the philosophy behind it. The residents of Cape Town are fast catching on.

I am deeply touched that someone in Philip's position is able to make the gesture of giving away a free copy for the purposes of promoting the product.

It speaks volumes for what the Big Issue project is all about.

What I didn't tell Philip was that I had already procured the latest edition of the Big Issue from a vendor the day before and it struck me, as I paid over the money and looked the seller in the eye, that this was a venture that deserved the support of every Capetonian.

How often before have I averted my eyes from people on the streets because they make me feel uncomfortable?

By paying over money for something I want, even my body language changed.

So, I accepted Philip's gift in the spirit it was offered, and resolved in the lift on the way back to the newsroom to use it to promote the cause - hence this column.

You see, by backing something like the Big Issue, you have nothing to lose and the city as a whole has everything to gain.

Companies which give advertising or in-kind donations can honestly claim that they are putting their money where their mouths are by supporting a social upliftment initiative, instead of simply complaining about the problems on the streets.

People who buy the magazine will know that their money is going directly to people who find themselves on the proverbial skid-row, but who have taken the conscious decision to help themselves.

The Big Issue's credo is "A Hand Up, Not a Hand Out".

And then, to boot, you will discover that the Big Issue is a professionally produced and highly readable product which has some interesting, off-beat and well-written stories along with listings of arts and culture events in the city.

Ideally, those behind the project are hoping that the magazine will virtually sell itself because of the content, and the vendors will happily have no trouble in finding buyers.

Street people have been in the news again recently.

They are accused of robbing city coffers by vandalising parking meters (although one can't help wondering to what extent a rudderless traffic department has contributed to the parking debacle).

Then there are the stories of robbed tourists and the recent arrest of a gang of suspects whom the police described as street kids.

And finally, there's the Chamber of Commerce and Industry's proposal to legislate against sleeping in doorways.

In a South Africa filled with impoverished people and in a region where alcoholism is an unquantified social problem, we have to accept that there is no short supply of people trying to earn a living on the streets - whether they sleep there or not.

Ultimately, the solutions lie in finding economic alternatives for those who can be helped, lobbying for the social programmes and day-centres which can provide shelter for those who might be too damaged to be able to help themselves, and dealing with crime firmly and fairly.


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


451 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 18, 1997


South Africa;
Due process matters most (Editorial)


BYLINE: Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Cape Town - Anti-apartheid cleric Allan Boesak returned to South Africa to a tumultuous welcome - and a fresh controversy involving the government.

The past is still so closely with us that there is a danger of it being exploited with relative ease. In a country where, within our recent memories, political trials were illegitimate and punitive, it is a simple matter to invoke that era in the cause of confusion. 

This is what appears to be happening in the case of the Rev Allan Boesak, on trial for fraud. The controversial cleric and important figure in the resistance movement of the 1980s is quite within his rights to argue his innocence, but so is the public within its rights in questioning his broader assertions.

Boesak says it is the struggle against apartheid which is on trial, and we say that is manifestly not true. He is on trial, and not for his politics.

This is where the recent statements of Justice Minister Dullah Omar become problematic. He has at the very least given the impression to the public that he - and by implication the party he represents - has concluded that Boesak is innocent. There is a nobility in refusing to ditch former comrades, but there are limits too: it would be one thing if Omar expressed the hope in his personal capacity that the courts would clear Boesak, entirely another if he appears to pre-empt their findings.

It is quite wrong for the media, or anyone else, to try someone in public before due process has taken place. This newspaper has studiously avoided stoking hysteria in its coverage of the Boesak case. But it is equally wrong, especially in the democratic South Africa, for major public figures to prematurely declare innocence without adding the rider that they will abide by the decisions of the courts. These courts are now people's courts in the proper sense of the word: let them do their work and let us discuss their findings once they are made.


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


452 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 18, 1997


South Africa;
Taxi war: enough is enough


BYLINE: Joseph Aranes, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Cape Town - After yet another outbreak of Cape Flats taxi violence - in which two men were killed - the Western Cape taxi task team is to embark on a New York-style strategy in a bid to end the killings.

The team, which includes police, the Defence Force, traffic authorities and provincial political leaders, is to embark on a so-called "broken window" approach to root out violence and crime in the minibus taxi industry.

The highly successful anti-crime strategy, pioneered in New York recently, entails following up even the smallest violation (for example, breaking a window), which, it is believed, eventually leads to the elimination of bigger crimes. 

This follows a shootout between members of the Defence Force and taxi drivers in Nyanga yesterday in which two men were killed and a woman was seriously injured.

The conflict started after the soldiers arrested a taxi driver, during a routine anti-crime operation, for allegedly being in possession of an illegal firearm.

The shooting was condemned by Western Cape premier Hernus Kriel, provincial Police Minister Gerald Morkel, Transport Minister Leonard Ramatlakane and the mayors of the Cape Town and Tygerberg councils, Theresa Solomon and Lukas Olivier.

In a joint statement, they said taxi violence necessitated firm action and announced the formation of a special task group comprising police, soldiers and traffic officers to help the provincial task team on taxi violence, which was established last year.

"We as political office bearers...are serious about efforts to stamp out lawlessness and to bring about an effectively regulated taxi industry.

"Flagrant violations of the law must come to an end and will not be tolerated," the statement said.

Police Ministry spokesman David Frost said the new anti-crime campaign plan required all those involved to take part in a multi-agency approach, which would be used to address the situation and enforce the law.

Mr Frost said the implementation of the plan in Cape Town would need the support of the authorities and specifically that of taxi commuters.

Police are investigating the Nyanga shootings.

It is not clear who fired the fatal shots, but ballistic results are expected later today.


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March 18, 1997


Zaire;
Diamond Smuggling Increases In Zaire


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 174 words


 

KINSHASA, Zaire (PANA) - The National Expertise Commission (CNE) on precious stones of Zaire believes that more than one third of Zaire's diamond production worth about 300 million dollars are smuggled out each year.

According to European diamond dealers, between 300 and 400 million dollars worth of diamond are smuggled out of Zaire every year. 

The commission based its statement on the fact that although diamond mining was on the upswing in the Kasai area, official production figures slumped from 9.5 million carats in 1990 to 4.8 million carats in 1994.

To redress the situation, the Zairian government has arrested a number of black market diamond dealers in recent months.

According to the CNE, 500,000 people live directly or indirectly from the smuggling of precious metals in the Zairian region of Kasai.


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


March 18, 1997


Africa-at-Large;
Call For An African Language Thesaurus


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - A Kenyan linguist attending a three-day meeting on African language policies in Harare on Tuesday proposed the establishment of a thesaurus on African languages.

Presenting a paper at the inter-governmental conference on language policies in Africa, the Kenyan delegate said it was likely that all present day languages originated from Africa either as hieroglyphics or phoenician and later progressed as Greek and other European languages.

The expert said linguists had a huge task because of the existence of tens of thousands of different languages in the world today. 

He said some African countries such as Nigeria had over 400 different languages and yet only three, Hausa, Ibo and Yoruba were national languages.

The Kenyan expert, however, expressed hope that a thesaurus of African languages could be established by the next generation.

"I hope as experts gathered here today we can reach an agreement and form an association for linguistics and comparative linguistics or establish a university of linguistics as well, which could probably be funded by UNESCO so that as Africans we could slowly realize our dream," he said.

He said Africa was a paradise for linguistics and comparative linguistics.

Other delegates to the conference highlighted the use of African languages as the best way of ensuring participation of Africans in society as well as in the planning and management of development projects.

The conference is expected to examine and adopt a document to serve as a reference framework for a ministerial conference which begins here on Thursday to evaluate language policies and practices in member states.

Some 30 African and European countries are represented at the conference.

Opening the conference on Monday, Zimbabwe's education minister Gabriel Machinga said african languages had been relegated to the background because of historical situations.

He said recommendations by the experts would constitute a landmark in African thinking as to which direction africans ought to take on the language issue, given the complexities of the different situations.

Machinga said the discussions by the experts would also contribute towards the production of a language atlas, which would be a useful tool for Africans to chart new paths in the area of policy formulation.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March 18, 1997


Zambia;
Zambian Journalist Withdraws Apology To Court


BYLINE: Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - A Zambian journalist, serving a three month jail term for contempt of court, on Tuesday withdrew an apology he had made to the Supreme Court in February, saying it had acted unfairly in handling his case.

Speaking during the opening of his appeal in Lusaka, Masautso Phiri, News Editor of the privately-owned Post newspaper, said that he had apologized not because he was guilty, but because of his recognition of the Court.

Phiri was on Feb. 11 charged with contempt of court and consequently jailed for three months, for publishing an article which purported that in November 1996, seven Supreme Court judges were bribed by the state to throw out a petition filed by the opposition parties. 

The parties complained about President Frederick Chiluba's nationality.

He had alleged that the judges were paid one million U.S. dollars each by the state to dismiss a petition in which the opposition parties are challenging last November's presidential and general elections.

In his apology last February, Phiri expressed regret and apologized to the court for his "erroneous" article which, he said, was not meant to ridicule the bench.

Reversing that position Tuesday, Phiri, who is partly representing himself, said that had he been given a chance to make a plea, he could have pleaded not guilty and taken the line of defence.

"What transpired on February 10, without even giving me chance to take a plea made my heart bleed and I wondered what was happening to the integrity of the judiciary.

"As a journalist, we must be partners with the judiciary in monitoring democracy and good governance in this country," he said.

He said he was also withdrawing his apology because it would serve no purpose, since even when he had offered to apologize, judge Matthew Chaila had told him that even if he apologized he would not accept his apology.

Phiri has also demanded the withdraw of three of the seven judges who heard his case because of the differences he has had with them during the course of his duties.

He claimed that his relations with judges Chaila, David Lewanika and the Deputy Chief Justice Bornaventure Bweupe were not good.

He applied to be granted bail, in the interest of justice, so that he can defend himself.

Africa News


March 18, 1997


Business and Finance;
Ugandan Coffee Coffee Exports Drop


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

KAMPALA, Uganda (PANA) - Uganda Coffee exports dropped by 10 percent to 496, 378 bags in February, The government-owned New Vision newspaper reported Tuesday, quoting officials.

It quoted the Uganda Coffee Development Authority monthly report released last week as saying the drop was due to the scaling down of the coffee season in central and eastern Uganda. 

The decline in international prices during the first quarter (October- December) was also blamed for the drop.

It said during the period, farmers sold large quantities of coffee stocks in order to meet their financial needs. This depleted stocks at the farm level.

But in spite of the drop in exports, prices paid to farmers in February increased drastically, the report said.

The average price for Kiboko rose from 500 shillings a kilo in January to between 600 shillings and 700 shillings per kilo at the end of February (1, 000 shillings = 1 USD).

Similarly, Fair Average Quality coffee prices ranged between 1,300 shillings and 1,450 shillings a kilo and Arabica parchment 1,600 shillings and 1,700 shillings per kilo.

The report said the slight improvement in prices in the coffee market led to an increase in sales registration during the month. Sales made during February totalled 743,431 up from 522,253 bags in January, it added.

Cumulatively, exports during the first five months of the 1996/97 season reached 2.3 million bags worth 173.6 million U.S. dollars, compared to 1.8 million bags valued 185.4 million dollars realized in the same period last season.

This represents an aggregate rise in volume of 25.1 percent and 6.39 percent drop in value.

Africa News


March 18, 1997


Nigeria;
Abacha Reviews Nigeria's Saturday Council Election


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 800 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigerian head of state Sani Abacha has said that noticeable lapses from Saturday's multi-party council elections would be corrected in future polls under the military regime's transition to democracy programme.

Exchanging views Monday with a 38-member election monitors from the United States in Abuja, the Nigerian capital, he described the polls as "a cornerstone" to the transition programme, scheduled to end October 1998.

"No elections in any part of the world, including the United States could be perfect and hitch-free," he said. 

Members of the team, representing the Autonomous America for Democracy in Africa, the American Bar Association and the Congress of Racial Equality, said they monitored voting in 63 polling centers in different parts of the country, including Abuja, Lagos and the western city of Ibadan.

Abacha told them to be objective in their appraisal and to shun sensation, adding that independent assessments would help the government to correct mistakes and prepare for future challenges.

He restated his commitment to the transition programme and said it was regrettable that some countries had chosen to castigate and refused to recognize his government's democratization efforts.

Abacha urged the United States to abandon its cold disposition towards Nigeria.

"We have always regarded America as our friend and we equally expect the United States to be closer and be of assistance to Nigeria in her time of crisis," he said.

He described his administration's transition programme as "absolutely transparent with no hidden agenda."

In their individual assessments, the poll monitors generally agreed that Saturday's elections "were free and fair as there were no deliberate attempts from any quarters to either intimidate voters or cause any disturbances."

They said they observed mainly logistic problems in the conduct of the polls, especially late arrival of materials to polling stations.

For the future, the group suggested extensive training of electoral officers and the setting up of arbitration teams to go round and settle on- the-spot problems that could arise during INL002 from SSS.078 (970318-17:09) QN PANAINL .PANADKR MSG077G/02E PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PAN(2) balloting.

Meanwhile, preliminary results from the elections showed that the United Nigerian Congress Party continued to lead four other rivals across the country.

Congress was reported to have clinched at least 230 council/chairmanship seats, with strong showing in Lagos, the northern states of Katsina, Niger, Borno, Kaduna; the eastern state of Enugu, the southeastern state of Akwa Ibom and the western states of Ogun, Ekiti, and Ondo.

The Democratic Party of Nigeria is second. It has some 128 council/chairmanship seats with impressive performance in the western states of Oyo and Osun, the northern states of Kano and Sokoto and the eastern state of Imo.

The National Center Party of Nigeria, along with the Grassroots Democratic Party and the Congress for National Consensus are trailing. They have run- off/by-elections planned in at 147 councils or wards, where polls were either cancelled, failed to take place or were stalemated Saturday.

Some 8,000 councillorship and chairmanship seats were at stake from the 776 councils in the 36 states within the federation, with an estimated 56 million eligible voters.

Nigerian newspapers reported Tuesday that four election-related deaths were recorded in the southeastern state of rivers and midwestern state of Delta between Saturday and Monday.

There was no official confirmation of the deaths, which reportedly occurred over electoral disputes.

Africa News


March 18, 1997


Mozambique;
Police In Southern Africa Seize 344 Stolen Cars


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - Police from Mozambican, South Africa and Zimbabwe have seized 344 apparently stolen cars in joint operations that began in January, the Maputo daily newspaper, Noticias, reported Tuesday.

According to Raul Freia, a superintendent in the Mozambican Police Public Relations Department, 221 of the vehicles were recovered in Mozambique. All were apparently stolen in South Africa and most of them are four wheel drive vehicles.

In Zimbabwe, 92 vehicles were seized. Freia said that five of these had been stolen in Mozambique. He did not know the origin of the others.

In South Africa, the police recovered 31 cars, all of which had been stolen in Mozambique.

Freia said that the number of cars to be returned to their legitimate owners could rise, since the operation had not yet finished.

He confirmed what many Mozambicans have been saying ever since the operation began Jan. 25: that in some cases the real crime was not car theft but insurance fraud. In such cases, South Africans sell their cars in neighbouring countries, wait a few weeks and then report them stolen and claim the insurance money.

During the operation, one South African, whom Freia named as Van der Back, was caught red-handed in just such a fraud. He sold a car in Mozambique, then reported it to South African Police as stolen. But the Mozambican buyer was able to identify Van der Back, who is now under police custody.

Freia said that people falsely reporting their cars as stolen would face " severe penalties."

LANGUAGE: English

459 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 18, 1997


Business and Finance;
Kampala Stock Exchange Opens For Business In Two Months


BYLINE: David Musoke, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1080 words


 

UGANDA, KAMPALA (PANA) - Uganda's first stock exchange, expected to take of within the next couple of months, will assist in the divestiture of loss- making and poorly-managed public enterprises through public flotations, Ministry of Finance officials said.

The chairman of the state-run Capital Markets Authority, Leo Kibirango, said last week the long-awaited Kampala Stock Exchange will begin business within one to two months.

A former governor of the (central) Bank of Uganda, Kibirango made the announcement during a two-hour news conference on the licensing of seven stock brokerage firms/dealers and investment advisers. These would be authorized to deal in the buying and selling of stocks and shares. 

According to the authority's statute, a minimum of three competing stock brokers are needed to establish a limited liability company which would be licensed to establish the stock exchange.

"The ball is now in the court of the licensed brokers to put their act together and apply for permission to launch the long-awaited stock exchange," he said.

Formation of the exchange, he said, would be a private sector initiative. Therefore, its launching would depend on how soon the players make their request to the authority.

Excited by the news, the executive director of the Enterprise Development Project under the privatization department, Leonard Muganwa, said: "The Kampala Stock Exchange will quicken the pace of privatization and economic reform and make the country more attractive to interested investors."

The exchange, he added, will also "provide a venue for the prospective market professionals to be partners in building Uganda's future," he said.

Over 20 major enterprises are targeted for divestiture through public flotations within the next two three years. They include some of the country's most potentially profitable enterprises.

Companies to be privatized through public flotation include, the Uganda Commercial Bank, Uganda Posts and Telecommunication Corporation, Uganda Grain Milling Company, Deffe Marketing Board, Uganda Consolidation Properties Limited, Uganda Airlines Corporation, National Insurance Corporation and the National Housing and Construction Corporation.

In response to public criticism that public enterprises were being sold to foreigners and big magnates and that the small man was not having a stake in the "national cake," the government decided to introduce the method of public flotations of shares in government owned firms which could be picked up and bought by small businessmen.

Under public flotation, a strategic investor would be allowed to buy majority shares of 51 percent in a given enterprise in order to provide the much needed initial capital, management skills and technical know-how as well as technology transfer.

The remaining shares would be offered to the general public either through off-the-counter transactions or sold through the stock exchange.

"The public flotation method will go a long way in removing anxiety among the general public that the national cake was going entirely to foreigners," said Anne Bwomezi, the information officer of the Privatization Department.

"It will also democratize ownership and management of these enterprises," she added.

The World Bank inspired privatization of public enterprises was meant to have covered about 85 percent before the end of 1997. But has been delayed partly because of the delays in the take-off of the country's stock exchange and the criticisms levelled against the measure by some vocal politicians, parliamentarians and individuals.

Since its inauguration in May 1996, the authority's board of directors has worked out a plan aimed at achieving three major objectives.

These are the creation of an institutional framework within which the demand and supply of securities will be managed and facilitation of financial intermediation in the economy, the promotion of investor confidence through the establishment of a regulatory regime for the securities industry in order to protect investor interests, particularly those of the small investor.

The authority's board is also aiming at the promotion of a regional East African Stock Market by cooperating with the capital markets authorities in Kenya and Tanzania, with the major aim of standardizing the regulatory market procedures.

"This would facilitate cross border listings of shares and would also provide adequate levels of liquidity in the market to attract foreign investor capital," Sarah Walusimbi, of the authority, said.

The attraction of highly experienced and reputable brokerage firms to form a stock exchange was recognized by the authority's board as one of its priority tasks in the work plan, according to Kibirango.

He said that the first seven brokerage firms to be licensed had to fulfil the criteria of character, competence and possession of adequate capital to provide financial services to the public.

Among the brokerage firms licensed, so far, is the African Alliance Uganda Limited. It is a subsidiary of the Capital Alliance Holding Company of South Africa with a capitalization of 300 millions U.S. dollars.

When established the Kampala Stock Exchange will join 16 other active African equity markets with a combined value of 260 billion dollars.


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March 19, 1997


Zaire;
Zairian Parliament Votes For Removal Of Premier


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo (PANA) - As rebels continue to make territorial gains in eastern Zaire, the country's High Council of the Republic, that is, the Transitional parliament has voted a motion to remove Prime Minister Leon Kengo Wa Dondo from office.

Radio Zaire reported on Wednesday that the premier was sacked because of his "incompetence" in dealing with the war being waged by Laurent Desire Kabila's Democratic Alliance for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire.

According to the radio, monitored in Brazzaville, Congo, his departure was " massively" endorsed by members of parliament during an extraordinary session on Tuesday night. The law makers accused him of failing in his mission. 

The parliament also called for the negotiations with "the enemy" (the ADLC rebels) but ruled that the peace talks should not be conducted by Kengo's government. Kengo was elected prime minister in June 1994.

Well informed sources in Brazzaville said the cabinet was expected to meet on Wednesday to review the political situation after the removal of the prime minister.

The cabinet session will be held in the absence of Kengo, who has travelled to Nairobi, Kenya, to attend the Great Lakes summit on the Zairean crisis.

In another move, deputies who attended Tuesday's parliamentary session expressed their intention to recall Mgr. Laurent Monsengwo, the former speaker who was elected by the country's National Conference.

The Roman Catholic bishop was dismissed two years ago by a parliamentary coalition of supporters of President Mobutu, Kengo and Etienne Tshisekedi's radical opposition.

However, the Union for Democracy and Social Progress abstained from the vote to oust Kengo, on the ground that the legitimate prime minister was still Tshisekedi, who was elected by the National Conference in December 1991.

Meanwhile, on Tuesday morning, travellers from Kinshasa said there was great panic among people in the Zairean capital. after the capture of Kisangani, the country's third largest town, by Kabila's troops.

The chairperson of the Congolese Red Cross, Ida Victorine Nze, revealed Tuesday that members of the Mobutu family had fled to Brazzaville. Among the refugees is Mobutu's son, Capt. Kongolu Mobutu, sources said on Wednesday.

A diplomatic source said small groups of U.S. nationals have also arrived in Brazzaville from Kinshasa.

Mozambique;
Chissano Dismisses Social Welfare Minister


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - Mozambican President Joaquim Chissano has dismissed Social Welfare Minister Alcinda Abreu, and the deputy minister of culture, youth and sport, Salomao Manhica.

A release from the president's office announced that Deputy Social Welfare Minister Filipe Manjate will take over Abreu's responsibilities on an interim basis. 

No reason was given for the dismissals, but it is known that Abreu has not been working at her ministry since she suffered a serious car accident over a year ago.

An article published by the independent newsheet "Mediafax" in January accused her of using her period of convalescence to undertake independent consultancy work from her home, while still drawing her ministerial salary.

As for Manhica, who is the country's foremost musicologist, press reports over the past year have claimed that his relationship with his minister, Mateus Katupha, is fraught with tension.

Chissano has not indicated any replacement for Manhica.

462 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 19, 1997


Science and Health;
Health Agency Launches Plan Against Female Circumcision


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 614 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - The Brazzaville-based World Health Organization (WHO) regional office for Africa has launched a 20-year plan of action to speed up the elimination of female genital mutilation (FMG) which reportedly affects some 100 million women on the continent.

Unveiling the plan on Monday, the WHO Regional Director for Africa, Ebrahim Malick Samba, said his office was committed to assuming a leading coordinating role as "WHO's campaign against the practice of female genital mutilation cannot be compromised."

A news release during the occasion said the 50-page regional plan seeks to boost country activities for the prevention and elimination of FGM and other harmful traditional practices which affect the health of women and children in Africa. 

Female genital mutilation or female circumcision is a general term used to describe the cutting of the internal or external parts of the female sex organs with sharp objects for reasons which are not medical.

It is performed on infants, young girls between the ages of five and 10 years, adolescents and even older women of childbearing age.

In some African cultures, the practice is regarded as an obligatory rite for a girl's transition from childhood to adulthood.

Because the practice is often carried out without anaesthesia by mostly village women or traditional midwives, or in some cases, male barbers, under unhygienic conditions, its effects on the health of women and children have been devastating.

The practice is associated with negative health consequences such as pain, shock, bleeding, urinary tract infections and the risk of blood-borne diseases such as hepatitis B and the HIV, which causes the incurable acquired immune deficiency syndrome, AIDS.

The WHO plan to accelerate the elimination of the practice in the next two decades is in phases.

The first short-term phase, covering 1996-98, is estimated to cost 2.1 million U.S. dollars.

Then there will be an eight-year medium term (1999-2006) to be followed by a nine-year long term (2007-2015) implementation periods, which are to be developed and costed separately.

The plan of action, to be undertaken in collaboration with partners at national and international levels, aims to reduce the practice by 40 percent in the number of females undergoing FGM in the 1-20 years age group.

Another objective is to increase by 55 percent, the number of countries implementing supportive programmes aimed at stopping the practice.

Some 27 of the 46 WHO member countries covered by the regional office practice FGM.

These are Benin, Burkina Faso, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Chad, Cote d'Ivoire, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Gambia, Ghana, Guinea, Guinea-Bissau, Kenya, Liberia, Malawi, Mali, Mauritania, Mozambique, Niger, Nigeria, Senegal, Sierra Leone, Tanzania, Togo, Uganda, Zaire and Zimbabwe.


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March 19, 1997


Liberia;
Meeting To Discuss Repatriation of Liberians


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

ABIDJAN, Cote D'Ivoire (PANA) - Representatives of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) in Cote d'Ivoire, Ghana, Guinea, Liberia, Nigeria and Sierra Leone are expected to meet next Monday in Monrovia to lay down modalities for the return of exiles to the war-torn country.

The Liberians had fled to neighbouring states to escape more than six years of factional fighting, which left at least 150,000 people dead. 

At the two-day meeting, the UNHCR officials will harmonize their points of view on issues like voluntary repatriation, the monitoring of refugee convoys and transit points.

They will also re-examine the repatriation exercise's cost, which was estimated at 62 million US dollars in 1995.

The refugees are expected to be home when Liberia holds its INL002 from SSS. 070 (970319-18:06) QN PANAINL .PANADKR MSG069G/02E PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PANA PAN(2) UN-organized multiparty elections in May this year. Cote d'Ivoire currently hosts 350,000 Liberian refugees.

Zaire;
Mobutu's Son Takes Refuge In Brazzaville


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo (PANA) - Congolese Police confirmed Wednesday that Capt. Kongolu Mobutu, the son of Zaire's ailing president, Mobutu Sese Seko, had fled to Brazzaville with other members of the president's family, following the rebel capture of Kisangani, Zaire's third largest city.

A police official, who declined to be named, told PANA that members of the Mobutu family were being protected by the government. The are living in a villa downtown Brazzaville, the Congolese capital.

The children of Zaire's deputy prime minister and minister of defence, Gen. Bolongo Likulia, and those of Mobutu's former security adviser, Seti Yale, are also under Congolese protection.

Brazzaville lies on the opposite bank of the Zaire river from Kinshasa, Zaire's capital. In October 1996, it had to accommodate 1,500 Zairian and Burundian Tutsis fleeing mob violence in Kinshasa.

The Congolese government has set up a crisis committee to manage the flow of Tutsi refugees from Kinshasa.


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


465 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 19, 1997


Mozambique;
Parliament To Establish New Elections Commission


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - The Mozambican parliament, the Assembly of The Republic, agreed Wednesday to establish a new national elections commission to manage the forthcoming municipal polls.

The government bill on local election procedures, which was debated February, did not envisage such a commission.

It put day-to-day management of the elections in the hands of the Electoral Administration Technical Secretariat. This body is a branch of the civil service, with the possibility of an appeal against the secretariat's decisions to the Constitutional Council. 

The Mozambican constitution decrees that it is the Constitutional Council that supervises elections. But the council has never been established. So, its functions are exercised, on an interim basis, by the Supreme Court.

During the debate, opposition deputies objected to this scheme. They demanded the establishment of a National Elections Commission as an " intermediate body," in between the secretariat and the Constitutional Council/Supreme Court.

The issue was remitted to the assembly's Commission on Agriculture and Public Administration, and this eventually produced a unanimous opinion that such an intermediate body should be created.

Its proposal was for a nine member National Elections Commission, whose chairman would be "a person of recognized moral and professional integrity, who can provide guarantees of impartiality, and who will be appointed by the president of the republic."

Seven members of the commission (also persons "of recognized moral and professional integrity") will be elected by the assembly, on a basis " proportional to parliamentary representation."

This should mean that the majority Frelimo party will choose four of them and the opposition benches the remaining three.

The ninth member of the commission will be "a technical expert appointed by the government." In addition, the director of the secretariat will be allowed to attend meetings of the commission but without the right to vote.

Government has agreed to draft a bill establishing the National Elections Commission along these lines and will deposit it with the assembly by the end of this week.


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


466 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 19, 1997


Ethiopia;
Former Ethiopian Deputy Charged With Abuse Of Power


BYLINE: Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 400 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - Former Ethiopian Deputy Prime Minister Tamrat Layne, who was fired in 1996, has been charged with abuse of power along with eight other alleged accomplices, the ministry of justice said Wednesday.

It said that he was due to appear in the Federal Supreme Court next week in Addis Ababa on three counts of abuse of power. 

The alleged accomplices include a government official believed to be one- time aide and secretary to Tamrat, and seven alleged business associates. No names were given.

The announcement also gave no further details.

Tamrat was fired Oct. 24 from his post of deputy prime minister and minister of defence. He was also stripped of his seat in the federal parliament and his post as secretary-general of his party, the Amhara National Democratic Movement, and as deputy chairman of the ruling Ethiopian Peoples Democratic Revolutionary Front coalition.

The night he was sacked, Tamrat appeared on state television admitting to fellow parliamentarians that he was guilty of "gross misconduct."

He said he was resigning his post "for acting contrary to the principles for which his party, the ANDM, had stood for over a decade and a half."

At the time, the party informed the ruling coalition of Prime Minister Meles Zenawi to inform the federal parliament of Tamrat's sacking.

Tamrat's party, one of the four ethnic-based parties in the coalition, played a key role in the armed struggle, spearheaded by Meles' Tigray People's Liberation Front, to oust former dictator Mengistu Haile Mariam in May 1991.

Tamrat was named Ethiopia's prime minister during the country's transition period from 1991 to 1995.

With a new federal constitution and Ethiopia's first multiparty elections in 1995, he was named deputy prime minister and minister of defence.


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


467 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 19, 1997


Nigeria;
Nigeria Seeks European Countries' Help On Bombings


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 547 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigeria has initiated moves to send detectives to Britain and the United states in pursuit of investigations into recent bomb blasts in the country, the inspector-general of police, Ibrahim Coomassie, has said.

He told journalists in Abuja, the Nigerian capital, Tuesday that the country was particularly keen on following the investigations in the United States because of a recent state department warning about bomb blasts in the country.

"We want to know how they (U.S.) knew about it (the bombings)," he added. 

The state department in a widely publicized statement warned U.S. nationals in Nigeria and those planning to visit the country of likely bomb blasts in Lagos between December 1996 and Jan. 17.

During the period, no fewer than three bomb blasts occurred in Lagos, all targeted against the military and killed at least three people. The authorities have blamed the country's opposition groups, some of whose members are self-exiled in Europe and the United States, for the bomb explosions.

Coomassie did not say whether the investigation would involve interrogation of Nigerian exiles in the U.S. or Britain, charged last week in a Lagos magistrate's court with treason in connection with the bomb blasts.

A total of 16 people were charged, four in absentia, since they are exiled abroad.

They include nobel literature laureate Wole Soyinka, former chief of army staff Lt. Gen. (rtd) Alani Akinrinade and opposition National Democratic Coalition leader Anthony Enahoro. They have in separate statements from their bases in either U.K. or U.S. denied the charge.

Coomassie did not explain if these countries would cooperate with Nigeria on the extradition.

Nigeria has mutual legal assistance accords with the United States and Britain on drug related issues. But it was unclear if this could be extended to include other criminal cases.

Diplomatic sources in Lagos said the countries would likely feel reluctant to cooperate if the case had to do with politics, especially with their cool diplomatic relations with Nigeria over democracy and human rights issues.

The U.S. and European countries have maintained a regime of limited sanctions on Nigeria since the return of military rule following the annulment of the 1993 presidential election by the last military regime.

The measures were toughened in the aftermath of the November 1995 execution for murder of nine Nigerian minority leaders, among them, author Ken Saro- Wiwa.


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


468 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 19, 1997


Ethiopia;
Court continues hearing testimonies against Derg


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Addis Ababa (ENA) - A prosecution witness yesterday told the Federal High Court that Derg investigators used to entertain at Sodere after they throw into pits corpses gathered from various prisons.

The witness, then a driver of the Central Investigation said he had transported many corpses from the Central Investigation and a detention centre known as "Bermuda" to the Kotebe Teacher Training College and saw the bodies put in grave dug earlier.

The witness, now a pensioner, also said he had found his car stained with blood, adding that he also saw many other corpses burried into newly dug pits. 

The clothes of the deceased which the witness, 50 claims to have transported from the Central Investigation to the college were also set on fire over the graves few days after the execution of the prisoners, he told the court.

He added that he had witnessed investigation heads and their colleagues entertaining at Sodere for they were presumably tired of burying corpses.

Two other witnesses, then members of the Prisons Administration, have also testified that they, under the order of chiefs, had brought about 20 prisoners from Kombolcha in October 1986 and handed over them to then heads of the Addis Ababa Central Investigation.

Three witnesses of the prosecutor who said has spent long years in "Bermuda" and other prison cells since 1976 EC explained to the court overall situation of the prisons including torture devices and mechanisms used by their tormentors. They also displayed the bodily harm they had received during the torture and named other prisoners who did not return after being called out of their cells.

Another witness who said was taken away from her work place, Addis Ababa University in July 1969 E.C. had suffered long hours of torture with her limbs bound rightly, blind folded and mouth gagged.

She said she had languished in different prison cells before her release in 1973 E.C. for allegedly being a member of the Ethiopian Peoples Revolutionary Party (EPRP) and s spy for the C.I.A. She also called out the names of five inmates including a-14-year-old girl who did not return after being taken away from the prison.

The Special Prosecutor has requested the court to see for itself the mass grave in the Kotebe Teacher Training College.

The trial was adjourned until tomorrow, March 20, 1997.

Ethiopia;
Charges filed against former deputy PM, accomplices


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 174 words


 

Addis Ababa (ENA) - Former Deputy Prime Minister Tamirat Layne will appear before court next week on charges of power abuse. 

The Addis Ababa Office of the Ministry of Justice told the Ethiopian News Agency that Ato Tamirat will be tried with eight alleged accomplices.

The alleged accomplices include one government official and seven businessmen.

The former deputy prime minister will face trial on three charges of power abuse, the office said.

The trial will begin next week in the Federal Supreme Court.

Ato Tamirat was relieved of his post as deputy prime minister, defence minister and member of parliament for disciplinary reasons on October 24, 1996.

470 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 19, 1997


Business and Finance;
Ethiopian mining, energy projects well under way


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 307 words


 

Addis Ababa (ENA) - The Ministry of Mining and Energy has announced it is undertaking a geological survey of eight out-standing and new mining energy projects with an outlay of 13,857,000 birr.

The purpose of the survey is to provide information on the locations and volume of among other, gold basemetals, agrominerals, coal ceramic, water and geothermal energy. 

A study is under way to economically utilise the gold and basemetal deposits at Bure and Abergale in Gojjam, now that the geology and geochemistry research of the minerals has been completed, according to mineral projects follow-up team head Ato Teshome Abamegal.

Ato Teshome said 84 percent of the exploration and study of the phosphate mineral at Bikilal area of west Wollega have been accomplished.

similarly, the quantity and quality of the coal deposit in Wuchale and Mersa woredas are being studied following the completion of works of geological mapping, excavation and survey, he said. surface and subterranean water deposit exploration in Bale and Sidama zones has also been completed according to schedule.

He, however, indicated that the planned geophysics study, collection of soil, water and stone samples as well as work on geological map in the zones is being undertaken at a relatively slower speed due to various constraints.

The money for the implementation of the projects was secured from the government and from foreign aid.

Africa News


March 19, 1997


Business and Finance;
Investment said promising in Ethiopia


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 974 words


 

Addis Ababa (ENA) - The general manager of the Ethiopian Investment Authority says the nation's call for investment has been met with " satisfactory" response from both domestic and foreign entrepreneurs.

In an interview with Merewa, a magazine published by the Press and Information Department in the Ministry of Information and Culture, Ato Tadesse Haile, said favourable conditions have been created fro entrepreneurs to invest their capital in the various fields.

The incentives the Investment Code offers has attracted more and more local as well as foreign entrepreneurs to engage in different sectors, he said.

Efforts are being exerted to show to the world the immense resources and wide-range of investment opportunities the country has at its disposal, the general manager told the bilingual magazine. 

A thirty-minute documentary video film has been produced on Ethiopia, he said, and indicated that it is being distributed.

Ato Tadesse indicated that 3,186 domestic and foreign investment projects with a combined capital of 22.3 billion birr and creating employment for 169, 846 people were approved up until December 1996.

He said 1610 of the projects were certified by the authority while the remaining were given licences by the regional investment offices, Ministry of Mining and Energy and the National Bank.

The manager said 541 projects with a capital of 3.5 billion birr and employing 22,548 people had already been put into effect up to June 1996.

Some 524 projects creating job opportunities for 29,655 people are in their implementation phase, he added.

Of the total projects, forty are owned by foreign investors, he said, and pointed out that seven of these which cost 197.6 million birr have already been implemented.

Ato Tadesse further indicated that three of the projects are in the industrial sector, one in the field of agriculture, two in construction and one in the area of mining.

He said nine additional foreign investment projects with a capital of 170 million birr will soon begin operation in the field of mining.

Speaker says student councils should initiate members to engage in development activities

Addis Ababa (ENA) - Students' associations to be set up at the Addis Ababa University and other schools, besides working for the respect of the rights of their members, should encourage students to understand prevalent social problems and engage in development activities, Speaker of the House of Peoples' Representatives has said.

Ato Dawit Yohannis, who was a member of the leadership of the University. Students' Union of Addis Ababa (USUAA) during the reign of Emperor Haile- Silassie, has said that "this generation should give priority to development activities."

He said students' associations, in addition to their effort for the respect of academic freedom, should also create a forum through which they could raise the political awareness of their members.

The improvement in political awareness would also help students appreciate the development problems of the public which later would enable graduates to be active participants in development endeavours, he said.

"As students have already begun participating in development activities during summer vacations, they would understand the development problems of the country," the House Speaker added.

The struggle awaiting the new generation in development the country demands no less commitment than the fight waged against dictators, he added.

Recalling the activities of USUAA - Ato Dawit said the work of the union had helped most of the students raised in towns to understand the severity of tenancy and national oppression in rural Ethiopia."

The union was also a source of inspiration to continue the struggle in various directions, the House Speaker added.

As the struggle was conceived during the time when Ethiopians had no right to assemble, he said, students took to streets to agitate the people to fight for their freedom.

Tagel a publication of the union, was also a good forum to broaden the scope of understanding of the general public, Ato Dawit explained.

Ato Dawit, who then was nicknamed as "bodyguard of USUAA" - said the union emerged stronger after Tilahun Gizaw assumed the presidency.

The transitional council of students, set up last year at the Addis Ababa University, has reported the preparation of a statute vital for the establishment of the council proper that would take part in academic, and administrative affairs of the university.

According to a report by the Ministry of Education, students' councils would be set up in all junior and secondary schools across the country.

Africa News


March 19, 1997


East Africa;
UN Issues Great Lakes Appeal


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 680 words


 

Geneva - While the humanitarian situation throughout the Great Lakes region remains precarious, the United Nations appealed to-day for US$ 324.5 million to meet the emergency humanitarian needs of over 1.4 million refugees, internally-displaced persons and returnees affected by the ongoing emergency.

The United Nations Consolidated Inter-Agency Appeal for the Great Lakes Emergency, prepared by the United Nations agencies and non-governmental organisations operational in the region, covers the period January to December 1997. Programmes and activities within the Appeal will address emergency humanitarian needs for 460,000 internally-displaced people and refugees in Zaire, 615,000 internally-displaced people and refugees in Burundi, 326,000 in Tanzania, 33,000 in Uganda and Zambia. Acting on the specific request by the Government of Rwanda, humanitarian requirements for Rwanda are not included in this regional Great Lakes Appeal. 

In Eastern Zaire, the conflict between the Government and rebel forces continues to have a devastating impact upon innocent civilians as it spreads deeper into the interior of the country. Hundreds of thousands of Rwandan and Burundian refugees remain unaccounted for and the number of war-affected and internally displaced nationals within Zaire has grown considerably. In Burundi, over a million people have been uprooted and tens of thousands killed in the civil war and violence that has engulfed that country. Tanzania, facing pressure from the presence of a remaining caseload of Rwandan and Burundian refugees within its borders, and Uganda, which is threatened by a spill-over of the crisis, are also adversely affected by developments in the region.

In order to respond rapidly and adequately to the fluid situation, projects within the Appeal have been drawn up on a regional basis in a manner which allows material and human resources to be transferred at short notice to where there is the greatest need. The main requests are for US$ 116 million for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), US$ 145.5 million for the World Food Programme (WFP), US$ 35 million for the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), US$ 8.5 million for the World Health Organization (WHO), and US$ 8.1 million for the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights (UNHCHR).

The assistance sought from the international community will be aimed at preventing suffering, promoting voluntary repatriation of Rwandan refugees and providing sufficient assistance to enable internally-displaced and conflict-affected persons to return to normal economic and social standards of living.

The international community is now faced with one of the worst humanitarian crises and is calling upon donors to respond generously and without delay to this appeal.

For more information, please contact: Madeleine Moulin-Acevedo (+4122) 917 28 56. (For more information on this emergency see ReliefWeb - http://www. reliefweb.int)

(Via the UN DHA Integrated Regional Information Network "Wire" mailing list. The material contained in this communication may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. Africa News


March 19, 1997


Zaire;
Amnesty: Troops Continue Gross Human Rights Violations


BYLINE: Amnesty International


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2080 words


 

London - Zairian soldiers retreating from the country's Kivu region have pillaged, raped and killed with virtual impunity in recent months, with people in many towns and villages living in constant fear that they will become the next victims of such human rights violations, Amnesty International said in a report released today.

The fears have escalated in the past month, after the government launched a military counter-offensive to recapture territory lost to the L'Alliance des forces democratiques poiur la liberationa du Congo-Zaire (AFDL), Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire.

"As evidence of brutal human rights violations mounts and military actions are stepped up, we are calling on the international community to put pressure on the Zairian government now to stop further human rights violations by its security forces," Amnesty International said.

Since the mass exodus of refugees at the end of last year, the human rights situation in Zaire has fallen off the international agenda. Other governments have appeared unwilling or unable to take action to help people suffering gross human rights abuses in Zaire and plans for a humanitarian intervention force foundered after the forced repatriation of refugees to Rwanda. 

Women, members of religious groups and non-Zairians, many of Rwandese or Burundian origin, have been among those specifically targeted by Zairian troops.

On 5 or 6 December , according to several local sources, soldiers of the Forces armes zairoises (FAZ), Zairian Armed Forces, brutally raped school girls at the Lycie Likovi secondary school in Bunia. The soldiers are alleged to have raped the young girls savagely and systematically, leaving seven of them dead. In a similar event, a witness reporting that FAZ soldiers who went to Bunia raped and kidnapped young girls in late November, said: "This has turned disgust with FAZ to bitter hatred".

Church workers have come under sustained attack, with local officials in Kisangani accusing the church of collaborating with the rebellion. Church buildings have been repeatedly searched or looted, and church personnel have been harassed and intimidated.

Since the start of the conflict in eastern Zaire, the Zairian authorities have detained Zairians of Tutsi ethnic origin, refugees, journalists and human rights activists who have tried to investigate abuses against Tutsi or speak out against government policies in the conflict zone.

In Kisangani, capital of Haut Zaire region, at least 80 Rwandese and Burundian prisoners were being held 'for their own safety' since November 1996 in detention centres run by the Service national d'intelligence et de protection (SNIP), National Intelligence and Protection Service. Unconfirmed reports say that they may have been transferred to the remote Osio prison, 17 km from Kisangani, where conditions are appalling.

Amnesty International has appealed directly to the Zairian Prime Minister to release these people immediately if they have not been charged with recognizable criminal offences.

In early January, the Minister of Defence, General Likulia Bolongo, announced that the armed forces have to rid themselves of "criminals, runaways, pillagers and vagabonds". This announcement led to the arrest of scores of soldiers on charges of looting and desertion. On 21 January, 14 soldiers were sentenced to death by court martial in Kisangani.

The organization believes that the death penalty is an inhumane violation of the fundamental right to life and has therefore appealed to the Zairian Government to have these death sentences commuted.

Amnesty International calls on the Zairian Government to ensure that its forces respect the human rights of the unarmed civilians -- including the displaced and refugees -- in the conflict zones and elsewhere. The organization is also asking both the Zairian Government and the AFDL to allow full access to territories under their control to human rights activists and others investigating reports of human rights violations in Zaire.

"Government around the world should also prevent further transfers of light weapons and associated military equipment, as well as military personnel, to the government forces and to the armed groups in the region," the organization said.

ENDS(

**************************************************************** You may repost this message onto other sources provided the main text is not altered in any way and both the header crediting Amnesty International and this footer remain intact. Only the list subscription message may be removed. **************************************************************** To subscribe to amnesty-L, send a message to <listserv@oil.ca> with "subscribe amnesty-L" in the message body. To unsubscribe, send a message to <listserv@oil.ca> with "signoff amnesty-L" in the message body. If you have problem signing off, contact <owner-amnesty-L@oil.ca>.

News Service 24/97 AI INDEX: AFR 47/10/97 RWANDA: AMNESTY DELEGATES BACK FROM RWANDA REPORT NEW WAVE OF HUMAN RIGHTS ABUSES

There has been a significant increase in incidents of human rights abuses in Rwanda since the forced mass repatriation of refugees from Zaire and Tanzania in November and December 1996, an Amnesty International delegation returning from a visit to Rwanda said today.

The delegation reported a series of worrying developments, including an increase in unlawful executions by the Rwandese Patriotic Army (RPA) -- especially in the context of reprisal operations, deliberate and arbitrary killings of civilians by armed groups believed to be composed of soldiers of the former Rwandese army and interahamwe militia, killings of Hutu civilians by Tutsi civilians and "disappearances".

"There have been killings in Rwanda on an almost daily basis, especially in the northern and western regions, and several hundred people are estimated to have been killed since the beginning of the year -- the majority unarmed civilians including young children," the Amnesty International delegates said.

The northwestern region of Ruhengeri has been especially affected by the recent upsurge in human rights abuses. For example, in Kinigi, at least 20 Tutsi civilians were killed on 25 January by armed men believed to be soldiers of the former Rwandese army or militia. The following day, at least 140 people lost their lives in what is believed to have been a reprisal attack by Tutsi civilians in the presence of RPA soldiers who appeared to do nothing to protect the victims.

Following the killing of three Spanish members of the organization Medecins du Monde in Ruhengeri on 18 January, scores of unarmed civilians were reportedly killed by RPA soldiers during military search operations in the surrounding areas.

On 4 January, in Nkumba -- also in Ruhengeri -- at least 55 unarmed civilians were reportedly killed by RPA soldiers after they surrounded a house where there were suspected infiltrators.

At least 60 returnees from Tanzania were beaten to death by Tutsi civilians in two separate incidents in Rusumo, in the eastern region of Kibungo, in mid January. Some of the bodies were reportedly found in ditches, others in latrines. Several people have reportedly been arrested in connection with the killings. In a separate incident, in the same area and around the same period, approximately 20 people were reported "disappeared".

Tutsi families as well as Hutus believed to be collaborating with the current authorities in denouncing infiltrators have been targeted by groups allied to the former Rwandese army. For example, in Taba, Rural Kigali, around 20 people were killed in two separate incidents on 23 December and 5 January. On 9 February, at least 11 Tutsis were reportedly shot dead after being forced to get out of vehicles on the road at Tare, also in Rural Kigali.

Several members of the former Rwandese army recently returned from Zaire have also been killed, in some cases while in detention, in other cases in their homes along with their families. The identity of the perpetrators is not always known. Between 18 and 23 January, a former Major, Jean de Dieu Bizabarimana, his wife and their children were killed in Nyarutovu, Ruhengeri, and former Major Francois-Xavier Uwimana and his six children were killed in Nyamyumba, Gisenyi.

The recent increase in violence is spreading fear among a population already tense and suspicious of reprisals on both sides in the aftermath of the return of more than one million refugees, many of whom are suspected of having participated in the 1994 genocide.

"The fear in Rwanda is tangible. People are terrified to speak and many told us that they no longer dare travel to certain regions. We were informed of cases of unexplained killings and 'disappearances' occurring even in the capital Kigali," the delegates said.

These fears are affecting the local population and foreign organizations alike. The killing of five United Nations human rights workers in Cyangugu, in the southwest, on 4 February has had a particularly devastating effect, preventing international and local organizations from carrying out independent investigations into human rights violations in certain parts of the country.

Amnesty International believes this could herald the start of a dangerous situation where the perpetrators can carry on killing defenceless civilians with no independent observers left to testify.

"The government of Rwanda must take immediate measures to prevent a situation where such acts of extreme violence become a fact of a daily life," Amnesty International said.

"The government should exercise control over its own security forces and ensure that officials involved in human rights violations are suspended from their duties and brought to justice. All incidents of human rights violations should be the subject of an independent and impartial investigation and the results should be made public."

Amnesty International is also urging armed opposition groups to immediately stop carrying out deliberate and arbitrary killings of unarmed civilians.

Rwanda's government cannot be held accountable for the actions of armed opposition groups; however, it has a responsibility to ensure that there are no reprisal killings by its own forces, the organization said.


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English
