474 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 19, 1997


East Africa;
Emergency Update No. 131 on the Great Lakes (03/19)


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1934 words


 

Nairobi - Zaire's Transitional Parliament (HCR-PT), voted yesterday to remove Prime Minister Kengo wa Dondo from office. About 470 delegates of a total 738 attempted to oust Kengo in a vote "by consensus" shortly after he flew to Kenya to attend a summit in Nairobi to discuss the Zairean crisis. The vote also called for a ceasefire and talks with the rebels. It was not immediately clear whether the vote carried legal authority; many of Kengo's supporters stayed away. Kengo had been re-appointed Prime Minister of the Crisis Government by President Mobutu in December 1996. Kengo said in Nairobi today that he was still Prime Minister, according to Kenyan KTN television. EU Special Envoy Aldo Ajello told KTN that the Parliament's decision was " illegal". Zaire's deputy Prime Minister Lambert Mende Omalanga is quoted by AFP today as saying the vote was "unconstitutional". Zaire has suffered from constitutional chaos since the early 1990s. Anzuluni Bembe, a senior Zairean parliamentarian, told Reuters that a three-quarter majority would be needed fo rthe vote to be valid. 

* CNN showed pictures of troops of the former Rwandan government captured in the battle for Kisangani. They claimed they were forced to fight by the Zairean Armed Forces. Hundreds of Zairean government troops were reported to have handed over their weapons to rebels at a military camp outside Kisangani. The ex-FAZ troops are to be "re-educated" re-trained, rebel commander Joseph Kabila, son of rebel leader Laurent-Desire Kabila told Reuters. Serb mercenaries based at Kisangani are accused of executions and torture of civilians by local people. An IPS report from Belgrade yesterday reported that despite Serbian government denials of official involvement in mercenary operations in Zaire, CNN TV pictures had shown Yugoslav-made uniforms, sniper rifles and fighter planes being used in Kisangani. A mercenary recruiter in Bosnian Serb army said that Croats and Muslims had also been recruited; " Imagine, we'll be on the same side now", he is reported is saying. In a CNN interview, Jospeh Kabila denied that the Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire (ADFL) was receiving help from either Angola or Uganda.

* ADFL rebels claim to be over 100 kms west of the Zaire river, and have taken Kasongo and Kibombo, south of Kindu. In an AFP report, Kabila is reported to offer the Zairean military the opportunity to lay down their weapons and "await the army of liberation." He threatened those who continue fighting with trials in special tribunals. Well-placed sources told IRIN of looting by retreating FAZ forces in Kabinda, 100 kms northeast of Mbuji-Mayi. Isangi, 150 km west of Kisangani has also suffered looting, the sources say. Lebanese businesspeople in Lubumbashi have started to evacuate their families, according to Reuters. Twenty-five Lebanese women and children were evacuated to South Africa last night.

* The diaspora of Rwandan refugees in eastern Zaire continues to spread. Humanitarian sources say some up to 2,000 refugees have arrived in Lodja, over 250 km west of Kindu. They are thought to have come from a group earlier collected at Kalima. The refugees remaining at Tingi-Tingi, despite being in poor condition, are being moved to Amisi by ADFL authorities. A further 28 unaccompanied minors were flown by UN agencies from Tingi-Tingi to Goma yesterday.

* A 35 metric ton WFP IL-76 cargo flight headed for Kisangani from Mwanza had to turn back today when it was ordered to land at Goma. A later flight succeeded in reaching Kisangani. A smaller plane carrying an interagency team flew from Goma to Kisangani to meet the cargo flight and make preliminary assessments. Rebel authorities in Kisangani broacast a demand to the local population to return looted relief food seized from aid agency warehouses within two days or "face severe consequences". Two truckloads have so far been returned. WFP currently has about 150 MTs in stock in Kisangani, and an additional 100 MTs or more may have been looted during the takeover of Kisangani and retreat of FAZ troops last weekend. The re-opening of the airlift route bodes well for the supply of food to 35,000 displaced Zaireans in Kisangani, but means of reaching refugees at Ubundu, 30,000 of whom have now crossed to the west of the river, remain uncertain.

* US State Department Spokesman Nicholas Burns said that reports of the involvement of neighbouring countries in the Zaire conflict was "an extremely troubling development... that Zaire is threatened on all sides." Burns also mentioned "men in arms coming across the Angolan-Zairean border." US military specialists and contractors are due to arrive in Brazzaville, Congo, on Wednesday to make preparations for a possible evacuation of US citizens, reports AP. Reports from Congo indicate that several dozen US citizens have already taken refuge in Brazzaville. Belgium has recommended that its citizens quit Zaire if their presence is not essential. The foreign ministry announced that there were 2,800 Belgians living in Zaire at the beginning of the month.

* President Mobutu Sese Seko's son, Nzanga Mobutu, said that rumours concerning his father's health "criminal and irresponsible", and said he would invite the press to Mobutu's villa near Nice, France to "clarify the situation" as soon as the ailing president is discharged, reports AFP. Close aide Honore Ngbanda Nzambo Ko Atume announced that Mobutu would return to Zaire at the end of the week. Le Monde reported Tuesday that Mobutu was receiving blood transfusions to compensate from "bladder hamorrhaging."

* The Nairobi summit today included the presidents of Kenya, Congo, and Zimbabwe as well as Vice President Thabo Mbeki of South Africa and Prime Minister Peter Mafany Musonge of Cameroon. International envoys Howard Wolpe (US) and Aldo Ajello (EU) as well as Joint OAU/UN Special Representative Mohamed Sahnoun will attend as observers. Senior US diplomat George Moose and Salim Ahmed Salim, OAU Secretary-General are also attending the summit. Canadian special envoy Marius Bujold was also in Nairobi today. Ajello said that one of the tasks before the meeting was to develop an agenda for the OAU- sponsored meeting in Lome on March 26, reports Reuters.

Rebel leader Kabila, not invited to the summit, has dismissed it as " irrelevant", and has scorned Kenyan President Daniel arap Moi as "another Mobutu", reports say.

* US Assistant Secretary of State George Moose and French Foreign Minister Herve de Charrette made a joint plea for Kabila to "accept the international community's invitation to a ceasefire and dialogue". French Foreign Ministry spokesman Yves Doutriaux said that continued operations by the rebels could have "extremely grave consequences".

* The population of Lugufu camp near Kigoma, Tanzania, housing Zairean refugees transferred from centres in Kigoma town, has swelled to 46,000. About 500 new arrivals (down from 1,000 a day last month) are registered every day in Tanzania, a mixture of Zaireans and Burundians. Kigoma region in Tanzania holds the largest concentration of refugees in the Great Lakes region. The combined population of Zairean and Burundian refugees in Tanzania has quadrupled in the last four months.

* A press release from the Ugandan President's office appeals to the UN Secretary-General to assist Uganda in securing the release of Ugandan abductees, alleged to be held in Sudan. The statement says that 24 school girls from St Mary's College, Aboke were kidnapped on 10 October 1996 and were being held in Aruu, southern Sudan. Another six girls were rescued by Ugandan forces, the statement says. President Museveni's letter to Annan said that the girls are among "thousands who have been abducted into Sudan by agents of thhe Sudan Government.. Many of these, according to evidence, are sold into slavery and others are gang-pressed into banditry activities." Uganda reserves the right to take "all legitimate measures to end such criminality", the statement said.

Another round of peace talks between Sudan and Uganda are scheduled for June in Iran. Sudanese Foreign Minister Ali Osman Mohammad Taha, announcing the talks in Khartoum, said, however, that Ugandan "agression" and "direct support" to southern rebels meant that the current crisis in relations would be hard to resolve, reports AFP. Sudanese SPLA rebels said on Wednesday that their forces had retaken Chali-el-Fil from government forces, near the Ethiopian on Monday.

* UNHCR Nairobi say that about 100 Rwandan detainees remain at Wilson airport, having flown in from Tingi-Tingi camp in Zaire just before it fell under the control of Zairean ADFL rebels. At the beginning of the week, unconfirmed reports say that some detainees are thought to have escaped.

* The UN today launched an appeal for $324.5 million for the Great Lakes region. The appeals covers needs in the countries of the region during 1997 excluding Rwanda, which has requested to be treated separately. The appeal describes programmes by UN agencies to provide urgent humanitarian assistance to 1.4 milllion refugees, displaced and war-affected populations. It also includes projects to repair environmental and social damage caused by refugee camps in eastern Zaire and Tanzania. Voluntary repatriation of Rwandan refugees remains a priority objective, while repatriation of Burundians is not currently promoted.

Two previous appeals for the Great Lakes launched in 1996, covering calendar 1996 plus January 1997, raised a total of $582.2 million.

Nairobi, 19 March 1997, 15:30 GMT (ENDS)

Africa News


March 19, 1997


South Africa;
Rural residents realise financial value of conservation


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Nelspruit - JOE Nkuna (54) is one of those poor and illiterate subsistence farmers that all game wardens fear.

He lives in a small impoverished village right on the fence of the Blyde Canyon River Reserve and counts the days before his clan's land claim is finally processed so that he can put his cattle onto the 'virgin' bush just beyond the hated fence which has locked him out of his ancestral home for the past 20-years.

The only good thing about wild animals, he believes, is that you can eat them. 

But now, within the space of two short months, Joe's entire set of lifelong beliefs about the best use of land and wild animals has changed dramatically.

And he's not the only one. Communities all around the Blyde River Reserve and a similar reserve at Loskop Dam have suddenly released that untouched bush and the 'pests' that live in it are worth billions of rands to foreign investors and tourists.

The paradigm switch in beliefs isn't, however, the result of an educational or community outreach drive. It has, in fact, been the result of the exact opposite.

Joe only realised that there was real money, and the chance at creating a sustainable local economy out of conservation tourism after "the Parks Board tried to steal our land for a second time and sell its use to foreigners for fifty years".

"This is even longer than apartheid lasted and, at my age, I won't last to see the land free again. But, when we heard how much these people were prepared to pay for use of the land, we didn't need a school education to know that there is a lot more money there than in just farming," he explained.

"So now, we'll keep most of our land as bush, like the conservationists want it, and will only reclaim a small part for our cattle and houses."

In return, communities like Joe's will receive 20 per cent shares in the joint venture companies Dolphin will form with MPB to run the reserves, as well as benefiting from massive infra-structure creation projects and the growth of a guaranteed 'feeder' economy to supply the reserves with essentials and other items such as curios and auxiliary attractions.

But, if there's one other thing that communities such as Joe's have discovered during the Dolphin debate, then it is that even small, isolated and rural communities have a voice.

Already this voice can be heard asking why if Dolphin is prepared to offer 20 per cent, then surely there must be someone out there willing to offer 25 per cent? - African Eye News Service


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


476 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 19, 1997


South Africa;
Parks Boards learn about accountability the hard way


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1507 words


 

Nelspruit - IF nothing else, the Dolphin Deal debacle has taught State funded Parks Boards that they are answerable to mere mortals - even if those mortals are dirt poor and illiterate communities living along their boundaries.

The days when Parks Boards, which control the World's second biggest canyon at Blyde River and a clutch of popular reserves in Mpumalanga, simply decided what was 'best' for conservation and for affected communities are gone forever.

But so are the large State subsidies and other resources which ensured that South Africa can today boost of Africa's best run reserves.

Accepting that reserves will be eroded by land and resource pressures unless they can be made to pay for themselves and at the same time uplift surrounding communities and economies, conservationists agree that controlled commercialisation is the only realistic option. 

It's not ideal, as demonstrated when Dolphin president, Ketan Somaia, conceded that he would never be able to buy the sweeping monopolistic rights to similar sites in the First World, such as the USA's Grand Canyon, as he was being offered here.

All he would say was the "Africa is different - its a completely different game down here". MPB officials agree. It's eat or be eaten, they insist.

Unfortunately, the MPB's bungling of its commercialisation programme has also been used as an excuse by government leaders in Mpumalanga to re-exert direct political control over the previously autonomous parastatal.

Under the guise of "rescuing" the multi-billion rand deal, which gives the controversial Dolphin Group the right to commercially develop various state owned game reserves in the heart of South Africa's 'safari' region, the government slashed the financial and executive powers of both the MPB and the independent watchdog Environmental Council.

It also limited MPB's mandate to only six provincial reserves and announced an immediate restructuring process of both the MPB's Board of Directors and its internal structures.

Despite continuing doubts about the business credibility of Dolphin's president, Ketan Somaia, who is involved in a R35-million tender dispute in Kenya, the government also recommitted the province's key tourist attractions to Dolphin's control for at least 25-years.

This is a halving of the original contract which gave Dolphin a complete commercial monopoly of the six reserves, plus the historic town of Pilgrim's Rest and Africa's reputed last undeveloped "Big Five" bush game reserve at nearby Manyeleti.

The revised contract expressly excluded both Pilgrim's Rest and Manyeleti and also tones down the 'exclusive rights' enjoyed by Dolphin via a zoning of reserves into bands of exclusive Dolphin and public access operational areas.

Normal South African tourists, hiking fundis and even back-packers, who were collectively referred to as the "sub-economic" market by Dolphin when the deal was first announced, will therefore continue to have free access to at least parts of the affected game reserves.

Almost as important is the MPB's recognition of the principal that game reserves are a common resource used by surrounding hotels, lodges and other tourist establishments to attract visitors.

If any one company gets complete development and transverse rights to these 'magnets', the entire subsidiary industry is effectively destroyed - just to subsidise the budget of one small government

department currently employing less that 600 people.

Other, and by now well publicised, amendments to the contract include the dumping of a 50-year secrecy clause, the removal of a "get-out" escape clause for Dolphin should they find the deal less profitable than expected, and greater equity ownership of joint venture companies by surrounding communities.

Although Dolphin pointedly withdrew its initial blanket offer to cover MPB's budget deficit for the full contract period, it did commit itself to underwriting the parastatal's budget for at least 10-years while simultaneously paying the MPB 25 percent of any profits it generated.

The financial guarantees will enable the MPB to develop or expand other community reserves and to pro-actively tackle nature conservation in the province.

MPB insists that it had no choice but to seek private sector investment. It asked government for a R55-million personnel and salary budget for the 1997/ 98 financial year but was told it would only receive R11-million.

Even if it had received the R55-million it asked for, this would still have only covered its basic running expenses and would have made absolutely no provision for capital growth, expansion or upgrading of reserves.

"We had to ask quite simply whether there was even a future for conservation in the region unless we found a joint venture partner. And despite our recent experiences, MPB still believes that unless we commercialise, our parks will go exactly the same way as those further north in Zimbabwe and elsewhere in Africa," explains MPB spokesman, Gary Sutter.

"We have no choice - it's commercialise or stagnate and eventually die."

The political intervention and close media scrutiny has also led to a rethink by the MPB of some of the scheme's more contentious development projects - such as a massive 'White Mischief' theme hotel in the parastatal's flagship Songimvelo Game Reserve.

Although previously virtually unknown to tourists, Songimvelo experienced wide exposure when the Michael Douglas movie 'Ghost & the Darkness' was shot on the reserve's magnificent grasslands.

Building on the Victorian Age theme of pioneer Kenya, MPB proposed that a 300 bed R250-million hotel with a number of smaller 'boutique' camps be built at the reserve.

Guests would have to leave their vehicles outside the park and would be transported to the hotel by period steam train, via the railway station which was built as the principal set for the movie. Even the hotel's safari vehicles would be built to resemble 1940 vintage cars and rangers would be called 'Askaris' and dressed in appropriate Kenyan costume.

The Askari idea was quickly dropped when journalists had to disbelievingly explain to MPB officials that the word has violently political connotations in South Africa.

Conservationists and archaeologists have also objected to the importation of a Kenyan theme to South Africa, when Songimvelo already has extensive ruins of stone walled settlements, possibly related to the gold civilizations of Great Zimbabwe and Thulamela.

The more sarcastic critics quip that the Lost City or a recreation of history visionist Cyril Hromnik's (check spellling) Dravidian colonies would be more appropriate and just as marketable.

Other grandiose projects that have been shelved, for now, include a cable car in the Blyde River Canyon and an American South paddle steamer, possibly with a small casino on board, on Loskop Dam.

Definite developments or innovations which are going to be implemented include the introduction of hot air balloon safaris, white river rafting safaris on the Blyde River and R400-million worth of new hotels and lodges over the next three years.

These new developments will also be 'branded' or 'themed' to make them unique, but officials assure that the themes will be less contentious than the Songimvelo project. - African Eye News Service


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


March 19, 1997


South Africa;
Dolphin turns out to be more than just Ketan Somaia


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Nelspruit - IS Dolphin really the environmental boogeyman that it's made out to be in the media?

Almost without exception, the multi-billion dollar company has been portrayed by the press both here and in Kenya as a ruthless profit obcessed monster, headed by a president who successfully defied the Kenyan Parliament for seven years after allegedly failing to deliver on a R35-million tender he won.

But, Dolphin with its 20 000 employees, 29 odd subsidiaries and various other interests is more than just Ketan Somaia or the Mpumalanga parks deal. 

It is also Block Hotels - at 70-years Africa's oldest and one of its most respected hotel groups which dominates the tourism lodge industry in Kenya and is making fast inroads into Zimbabawe, Namibia and South Africa.

Supporting this, is the 50-year old UTC Destination Management, voted Tour Operator of the Year 1995, which claims to bring more than 750 000 tourists to Africa every year.

Dolphin is also Delphis Bank, a newspaper group, a TV production company, a music studio, a cinema chain, commodities trading, vehicle manufacturing fanchises, a sugar refinery, a vehicle rental company and a long string of casinos, restaurants and heath clubs.

Dolphin's president, Somaia, started life as simple Mombasa trader but quickly built himself into one of Kenya's most powerful figures through a series of controversial take-overs and buyouts.

A Mpumalanga legislative team, which visited Dolphin operations in Kenya and Dubai were "completely awed by their standards of proffessionalism, vast interests and reputation", with opposition politicians drooling over Dolphin suggestions that it would pick up the tab for the province's first international airport, an offer to pump millions into small business development and also pay to set up an international standard tourism college.

"Look, Africa isn't for sissies. In anycase, if you look at the amounts involved in the alleged fraud in Kenya, then the alleged misappropriation is a drop in the sea compared to the Kenyan economy - or even the Dolphin economy. All businessmen have at least some deals that go sour and some that work out," explained Freedom Front whip, Hein Mentz. - African Eye News Service


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


478 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 19, 1997


South Africa;
CEO's career on the line after Dolphin fiasco


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1080 words


 

Nelspruit - It seems unlikely that the revised and "sanitised" contract between Mpumalanga's Parks Board (MPB) and the Dubai-based Dolphin Group which was announced yesterday will save the career of MPB's outspoken head, Alan Gray.

The new contract, which was drafted during often strained all-night negotiations in Johannesburg earlier this week, slashes Dolphin's hopes for a 50-year monopoly of state owned game reserves in Mpumalanga to a watered down 25-year right to operate in a limited number of reserves.

Dolphin will, even then, only enjoy exclusive operation rights in certain zoned areas of affected reserves.

But even this revised contract seems destined to be brought into question after the national Portfolio Committee on the Environment sent a letter to Minister Pallo Jordaan on Monday demanding a full investigation into the desirability of the deal, based on the premise that the game reserves involved are a national asset which should not be commercialised simply to pay for the running of a single government department employing less than 600 people. 

Almost immediately after the revised deal was clinched on Wednesday provincial politicians, who had up until now been unusually silent about widespread public criticism on the deal, began directing blame for their embarrassment at Gray.

Even Gray's own environmental affairs MEC, David Mkhwanazi, told the Mail & Guardian on Tuesday night before releasing internal and confidential government memorandums from a 'special file' that "I never once supported the original contract ... it was steamrollered through".

"I set out all my reservations in a memo to Gray in October last year before he signed the original contract - but he never listened. If he had, none of this would have happened."

The memorandum, dated ten days before the contract was signed on November 1 last year, stresses Mkhwanazi's unease about the commercial monopoly that would be created if one company was granted sole rights to all the reserves and also question's Gray's commitment of government funds to the deal without cabinet approval.

"Even though I clearly instructed him to put the matter before the cabinet for ratification before signing anything, this was not done. Instead we were given a colourful slide presentation by the MPB," added Mkhwanazi.

Under the guise of rescuing the multi-billion deal, Mkhwanazi also announced that he had "re-exerted" his political control over the supposedly autonomous parastatal, was busy changing legislation so he could scrap the MPB's internal tender committee, was severely curtailing the powers of Gray and was placing severe financial limitations on the Board.

He also stressed that the government was taking over control of salaries at the MPB after complaints that people in equivalent posts were earning widely different salaries.

M&G incorrectly referred to Gray as a consultant last week but has since established that he serves as the MPB's chief executive officer on a 5-year fixed term contract with a cash salary of between R34 000 and R40 000 per month, plus various benefits and perks worth an additional but unspecified sum. Gray's superior in the Department of Environmental Affairs, to whom he supposedly answers, earns only R13 800 per month.

In a lengthy lawyer's letter this week responding to the M&G's revelation that many of his private companies enjoyed the patronage of the MPB, Gray also denies that he personally brokered the deal with Dolphin, insisting that Dolphin was introduced to him by Mpumalanga Finance Corporation head, Sam Cronje.

Sam Cronje was until late last year a partner in Air Excellence - the company which shares office space with Gray's Lowveld Helicopter Services (LHS) and which LHS staff insist has taken over operations for LHS.

Cronje failed to respond to M&G's repeated attempts to contact him.

Gray also continued to refuse to say how much money the MPB had spent with LHS to date, or to explain why the parastatal had ordered a fixed-wing aircraft from the helicopter company to fly politicians down to Cape Town three weeks ago, to brief parliament on the Dolphin Deal.

Because LHS doesn't have any fixed wing-planes, Gray's company was forced to sub-lease a King Air from a rival Nelspruit company. It is unclear whether LHS added its own 'commission' on to the charter price.

Although he denies still being involved with Air Excellence, the listed director for the new company is Gray's good friend, Sean McMurray.

McMurray serves on the MPB's board of directors and also leases the MPB its regional offices in Witbank. Gray denies that he has any business links with McMurray.

McMurray accompanied Gray and his MPB team on their investment seeking trip to the east, where he met with Dolphin at similar times as MPB in both Dubai and London. During the meetings, he sold half of his interests in his Royal Hotel in Pilgrim's Rest and Promenade Hotel in Nelspruit to Dolphin.

The MPB also recently appointed McMurray as chairman of the Somalanga Development Company, which will develop MPB's flagship Songimvelo Game Reserve in a joint venture with Dolphin.

The Michael Douglas film, Ghost and the Darkness, currently on circuit, was shot at Songimvelo. - African Eye News Service


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


479 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 19, 1997


Business and Finance;
Sam Montsi: bird breeder who gives black business a flying start


BYLINE: Alide Dasnois, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Cape Town - Cockatiels and budgies are easier to bring to maturity than business projects, says Sam Montsi, who heads the fast-growing black empowerment group Siphumelele.

Breeding birds in his Bishopscourt garden is the new passion of the man whose company hit the headlines last year, when Siphumelele took a R330- million stake in the industrial conglomerate Johnnic.

The Johnnic stake was negotiated through the National Empowerment Consortium, a grouping of black trade unions and business, and puts the Siphumelele group up alongside better-known partners in the consortium, such as Cyril Ramaphosa's New Africa Investments and Wiseman Nkuhlu's Worldwide Africa, giving Montsi a seat on Johnnic's new board of directors. 

Unlike the other big stakeholders in Johnnic, Siphumelele is rooted in the Western Cape - a factor which encouraged the banks to fund the transaction, Montsi says.

Shareholders in Siphumelele range from estate agents in Athlone and community leaders in Kensington to doctors and lawyers in Paarl and fruit dealers in Pniel.

The Johnnic deal will give them an indirect stake in a range of businesses from SA Breweries and the Premier group, with its retail, food and pharmaceutical interests, to M-Net and Times Media, owners of publications including Business Day and the Sunday Times.

Born in Orlando, Johannesburg, Montsi went to school in Lesotho, " to escape the Bantu education system, which stunted people" and worked for years as managing director of the Lesotho Development Corporation. He came to the Western Cape in 1987 to work as general manager in SA Breweries' beer division and left six years ago to start his own consulting business.

"My friends said, Why leave? You have a nice house, a comfortable life and plenty of free beer. I said, I am a man who likes to ride wild horses.

"I like to create new things and make things happen."

Operating out of offices in a Newlands house, Montsi and Associates' main activity is linking black entrepreneurs with mainstream business.

A contract with the Anglovaal group enabled Montsi to turn R6-million of Anglovaal business towards black entrepreneurs last year and R26-million in the same direction this year.

He has a similar contract with the National Industrial Chamber, an arm of the National African Federated Chambers of Commerce (Nafcoc) funded by USAid.

Fishing - Montsi and Associates has a small hake quota and own a fishing vessel - and property development are other arms of the business.

Projects completed include the Nyanga Station shopping centre and the conversion of the old Diep River bus depot into a business village which opened last year.

The newest project is the R9-million restoration of the historical Bree Street- Shortmarket Street block in the city centre. The project includes plans for a hotel, restaurants and crafts shops, including a blacksmith.

Sam Montsi is married to Fazila and they have four children who do not see enough of their father, he says.


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


480 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 19, 1997


Business and Finance;
Empowerment grouping buys stake in Fedics


BYLINE: Alide Dasnois, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Cape Town - As the first step in a move into the services industry, Western Cape investment group Siphumelele has taken a R120-million stake in Fedics in partnership with two other black empowerment groupings.

Fedics shareholders ICS and Servgro have each sold a 16,67 percent interest in the group to the consortium, which consists of Siphumelele, KwaZulu-Natal- based Investments Progress Holdings and Gauteng-based Nozala Investments.

Siphumelele director Tiisetso Tsukudu will sit on the board of Fedics, which will be chaired by Nozala director Dawn Mokhobo. 

Siphumelele chief executive Lionel Jacobs told the Cape Argus the Fedics investment was in line with plans by the group to move into the beverages, hotels and leisure industry.

Headed by Sam Montsi, Siphumelele has 90 shareholders including the Food and Allied Workers' Union. Its interests include a stake in Johnnic, a 51 percent holding in Expercable in a joint venture with Phillips Business Electronics, a 6 percent stake in Channel 6 Television, a 20 percent holding in Cape Talk Radio and a 75 percent interest in a joint venture with Nedbank Investment Bank.

"This is our first completed move into the beverages, hotels and leisure sector," Mr Jacobs said. He confirmed that other investments in the sector were in the pipeline but he would not give details.

"This is not a passive investment," Mr Jacobs said. "We have joint control and we intend to be involved in active management at all levels.

"We have real expertise which we can add to this investment."

Fedics, which has a turnover of R710 million a year, has interests ranging from contract catering (through Fedics Food Services) to travel and tourism. The group owns two inflight catering companies - Air Chefs, a joint venture with Transnet, and Gate Gourmet, a joint venture with Swiss Air.

Fedics also has a 40 percent interest in Protea Hotels.

Managing director David Wigley said the transaction valued the company at R360 million which meant that the consortium was "getting a good price".

"We would get a rather better price on the public market," he said.

The deal would put Fedics in a strong position to compete for public sector contracts, he said.

"There are lots of opportunities in that market and we think this will enrich our chances in a market where we are reasonably successful already."


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


481 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 19, 1997


South Africa;
Kensington vagrants get shelter despite protest


BYLINE: Jermaine Craig, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

Cape Town - Despite vehement protests from some residents, the Kensington night shelter for vagrants is going ahead and construction has just started.

This is according to Lawrence Wakens, chairman of the Haven Night Shelter in Kensington, who said the protesters were "in the minority" and would not deter the night shelter committee.

A recent church service at the shelter site was marred when picketing protesters opposed to its location got involved in a slanging match with members of the Night Haven organisation. 

The shelter will be built on the corner of 13th Avenue and Dapperweg, the same site as the Kensington Sports Club, and will house 38 vagrants.

Although generally in favour of the idea of a night shelter, residents say they do not want it on the doorstep of their sportsclub, fearing the club will be affected by construction of the shelter and that the vagrants will cause an increase in crime and gangsterism.

This was rejected by Mr Wakens, who said night shelters in other areas had contributed to a decrease in gangsterism because vagrants were off the streets.

"How can looking after a vagrant aggravate gangsterism? That is very far- fetched. We are providing a service by taking the vagrants off the street and trying to rehabilitate them."

Mr Wakens said the Cape Town municipality's community liaison unit found the majority of Kensington residents supported the shelter.

The Haven had bought the ground and acquired a lease for 25 years.

The planning process went on for more than three years without objections until the establishment of the sportsclub last year.

He said the project was definitely going ahead.

* The popular Cape Argus Changing City series is reproduced on our Internet site. This is a valuable electronic record of the changes happening in our city as reported in our columns.

The site is updated daily from Monday to Friday. Access the site through a hyperlink on our main page at http:// www.inc.co.za/online/cape_argus or directly on http://www.inc.co.za/ online/cape_argus/changing_city.

482 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 19, 1997


South Africa;
Top W Cape policemen set to take packages


BYLINE: Johan Schronene and Lindsay Barnes, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Cape Town - Some of the Western Cape's top policemen are poised to take early retirement as their careers founder in the new South Africa.

Some cite affirmative action for blocking their career paths in the new police service and some also hammer the new constitution for imposing restrictions on police investigations of serious crime.

Top officers say there is no future for them in the police and that it was a case of leaving while the going is good. They said it would be suicidal to " pour our hearts out" because "anything could happen" and severance packages could be refused. 

Key officers believed to have applied for severance packages include West Metropole area commissioner Quinton Visser, provincial head of detective services Willem Smit, head of the Violent Crimes Unit Leonard Knipe, Priority Crimes Unit boss Boet Claasen, head of logistics Barney Engelbrecht and Mitchell's Plain's station commissioner Johan Kleyn.

Several of those contemplating early retirement also were recently implicated at the Truth Commission over the 1986 shooting of seven African National Congress activists in Guguletu. These include directors Knipe and Kleyn and public relations chief John Sterrenberg, Fanie Bouwer, provincial head of proactive policing and Senior Superintendent Sterrenberg are also expected to apply for early retirement packages.

Commissioner Visser confirmed he had applied for a package. "I've reached the age to retire. With 35 years' service behind me I have done my bit," he said.

Director Knipe, who would not confirm or deny he was leaving, said he was concerned about the mass walkout of experienced top police and the drain of expertise.

"Whether I'm leaving or not is between myself and the commissioner. But I will continue to be a police officer until my last hour in the service," Director Knipe said.

Director Knipe has indicated privately that the fettering of detectives investigating serious crimes is a contributing factor in resignations.


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


483 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 19, 1997


South Africa;
Pagad, marchers with a major mission


BYLINE: Joseph Aranes, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1534 words


 

Cape Town - What started out as a discussion among a few friends concerned about gangsterism and drugs on the Cape Flats, developed into People Against Gangsterism And Drugs (Pagad).

The organisation quickly captured the attention of the world when its supporters were allegedly involved in the fiery public lynching of gang leader and drug merchant Rashaad Staggie.

The birth of Pagad dates back to July 1995 when 10 friends, all of whom are still part of the organisation, began getting other people involved and highlighted drugs and gangsterism as a major problem.

A number of meetings were held to devise ways of addressing the issue and to talk about the failure of existing organisations to eradicate the scourge. 

As the attendance at these meetings increased, the need to establish an effective and dynamic campaign against gangsterism and drugs became apparent. The silent suffering of the people no longer sufficed and they sought ways to empower themselves against these social evils.

Pagad was seen as the means of empowering the people.

It was against this background that Pagad decided to invite religious leaders of all denominations and people from different backgrounds to take part and to broaden its base in articulating its objective of eradicating drugs and gangs from society.

Roman Catholic priest Christopher Clohessy was one of the many outspoken non-Muslim clerics to come out in support of Pagad's ideals of Pagad.

"The people need to be able to defend themselves. I'm one who wants a gun- free society. If the gangsters attack the people, they must be able to carry legal firearms and defend themselves," Father Clohessy advocated.

Initially, the organisation held meetings with government officials and departments at which they also raised the issue of corruption in government structures. Their concerns about drugs and gangsterism were also raised with the police, justice and correctional services departments.

Pagad national secretary Sharief Khan claims: "In spite of all these efforts by Pagad, no meaningful change was brought about by the police and justice system.

"In a nutshell, all avenues that could be followed concerning the problem were exhausted."

On May 11 1996 a march on Parliament was organised, calling for visual deterrents to gangsterism and drugs and more competent and effective legislation.

The organisation also handed Justice Minister Dullah Omar a memorandum listing their demands that:

* Those convicted of drug dealing should be hanged or given life sentences;

* Those suspected of drug dealing should be monitored constantly and their properties searched without warrants;

* Current lists of business people who were convicted on drug-dealing charges should be made known to the community;

* All assets of guilty drug dealers should be frozen and their property confiscated and used for rehabilitation purposes;

* The public should be informed about drug dealers linked to international syndicates and the type of drug routes and modus operandi of drug dealers; and

* Witness protection programmes should be established for people prepared to speak out against the criminals and all confiscated drugs should be publicly destroyed.

At the same time, the organisation took to the streets and marched on the houses of known Cape Flats drug dealers and gangsters. Some of their first marches were violent with some supporters damaging houses and torching vehicles.

Then, on a cold August night, a march on the London Road, Salt River, house of the Staggie twins led to the brutal public slaying of Rashaad Staggie.

This gruesome act was met with outrage by many people, including Pagad supporters, and evoked storms of protests and condemnation from a range of organisations.

It also led to the media being much more critical in their coverage of Pagad.

But the incident also spurred other groups in other urban centres to organise themselves.

During this period, the organisation's popular leaders, Ali "Phantom" Parker and Farouk Jaffer, were expelled from the movement because they were accused of bringing it into disrepute by allegedly inflammatory statements.

Both were invited on several occasions to attend a Pagad general meeting to face the people and answer their questions, according to the current leadership.

Both refused to show up and, were expelled without any opposition.

A number of further Pagad marches and protests also were marred by violence.

One at the Waterfront resulted in the death of Achmat Najjaar while most of the regional leaders were arrested during a confrontation with the police at the airport.

Mr Khan said their goal of eradicating gangsterism and drugs was a tremendous task.

"It is remarkable that after 66 marches in the Western Cape, only three ended in confrontation.

"If Pagad succeeds, the entire country and all its citizens will benefit and reap the fruits of the tears, sweat and blood of those who selflessly fought in the struggle against gangsterism and drugs," he said.

After numerous marches, it became apparent that the strategy was working as drug dealers started cracking under the pressure.

Many stopped trading while others desperately tried to relocate their operations and began pushing up the prices of the drugs.

But the organisation came in for a lot of stick from the government because of Pagad's insistence on carrying firearms and covering their faces during their marches.

Mr Khan said: "At a later stage, the wearing of facial covering and the carrying of firearms in a legal march became illegal.

"It seemed as if the police wanted to stop Pagad from growing."

In spite of these obstacles, Pagad, which was at one stage merely a local organisation progressed to become a nationally structured body and will hold its next national conference in Cape Town at the weekend.

Mr Khan said there was no organised or systematic approach to ridding society of gangs and drugs.

No single agency or level of government had taken responsibility for the eradication of the scourge in its broadest sense and there was currently no special plan to manage and co-ordinate crime prevention.

Strategic initiatives were developed without adequate analysis of the root causes of the high crime rate and have focused on only a few aspects of the problem and existing crime prevention efforts have relied on reactive strategies.

He said Pagad did not want to reduce the crime rate, it wanted to totally eradicate gangs and drugs from society.

"We argue that everyone is affected by the problem.

"Let us not wait until we become victims, we already have seen how our children have been raped by gangsters...we have seen how our fathers and mothers have been brutalised and we have seen how our tourists have been robbed, raped and terrorised.

"Pagad says we are sick and tired of this scourge and beg of you, as caring human beings, to stand up for yourselves and your children and join the fight against gangsterism and drugs," said Mr Khan.


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


March 19, 1997


Sports - General;
Ex-mayor upbeat on city's chances in race for 2004


BYLINE: Michael Morris, Cape Argus (Cape Town)


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

Cape Town - This city is in the Olympic race with a "very good chance" but must make the most of international sports events to project its bid.

This is the message Sol Kreiner, former mayor and a leading figure in athletics circles, has brought back from the World Indoor Athletics Championships in Paris.

Mr Kreiner felt the Cape Town bid team should have made more of the opportunity to promote its Games bid at the Paris event. 

"I think it was remiss not to have had someone there representing the bid," he said. However, he had done his bit. He had had breakfast with top African athlete Haile Gebrselassie, and gave him a bid T-shirt which he wore often for the remainder of his stay in the French capital.

Mr Kreiner said: "There were a number of International Olympic Committee people in Paris and I sensed from them and other observers that although there are favourites Cape Town has a very good chance.

"What has come across very strongly is that nobody has won or lost the right to host the Games.

"A lot can happen in the next six months and there are a number of events which could influence the final decision. A key example is the World Athletics Championships in August in Athens. The feeling in Paris was that if this was not very well organised it could seriously harm the Athens bid.

"So, South Africa is still in with a very good chance but clearly a lot of hard work must be done. There are 56 people Cape Town must convince if it is to win. This brought home to me how important it will be now to mobilise Africa's prominent athletes. One cannot overestimate the importance of establishing a presence at international sporting events of this kind and actively getting African athletes to back the bid."

485 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 19, 1997


South Africa;
Mpumalanga announces its "survival" budget


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 814 words


 

Nelspruit - Almost 92-cents of every one rand in Mpumalanga's budget for the 1997/ 98 fiscal year will be spent on civil service salaries and other recurrent expenditure because of the provincial government's bloated staff component, Finance MEC Jacques Modipane said on Wednesday.

Despite a cut of at least 6000 employees during the past year, this is an 11-percent increase in recurrent expenditure in last year's budget.

Capital expenditure, in comparison, has been reduced by 36-percent in order to allow the provincial government to meet the national GEAR growth targets by the year 2000. 

A further reduction in capital expenditure will also, Modipane said, be made during the next fiscal year.

Stressing that Mpumalanga's 1997/ 98 budget of slightly over R5-billion was an effective reduction of 8,5-percent on last year's total allocation to the province, Modipane added that the only way Mpumalanga would meet its targets was to slash the public service staff by a further 15-percent before the year 2000.

"The time for trade-offs, be they political, social or technological has dawned upon us. We will need to have the guts to offset the popular remuneration of civil servants against the provision of other goods and services," he said.

Finance head of department, Leon Botha, described the budget as survival planning and said that "if we can survive this, then we'll be able to survive anything".

In line with national policies, the education and health departments took the lion's share of the budget, while public works and housing followed fairly closely.

"This is not a budget which will change the lives of people this year, but it is a good start on our new multi-year budgeting approach, in which we will attempt to target very specific areas for accelerated development in a staggered three year budget plan," explained Modipane.

Stressing that Mpumalanga was playing a leading role in the expansion of own revenues, Finance head of department, Leon Botha pointed out that Mpumalanga had managed to collect R180-million from its own limited resources because of improved collection and enforcement systems.

Modipane dismissed criticism in the Steyn Report on the Remuneration of Traditional Leaders that Mpumalanga had grossly overpaid the members of its House of Traditional Leaders by saying that the province had a "duty to maintain the status quo and to keep the country intact. If we had decreased the chief's salaries, they would have embarked on guerrilla warfare".

Other interesting points in the budget included the decision not to make any provision for the Mpumalanga Parks Boards estimated budget deficit. Opposition MPLs pointed out that there is therefore no "safety net" for the parastatal if its controversial deal with the Dolphin Group fails to materialise.

Mpumalanga did also not budget for any remuneration packages for retiring teachers because, Botha explained, central government had merely asked the provinces to gauge how many civil servants would possibly seek retrenchment packages and had not asked them to budget for the packages.

"When we need the money, central government will transfer it to us," he added.

The province has also again neglected to budget for any capital investment to get Mpumalanga's first international airport off the ground, which Nelspruit based businessmen claim is costing the province at least R1-million per day in lost trade opportunities.

Botha did, however, say that they had made R200 000 provision for an additional feasibility study by foreign consultants later this year.

Opposition MPL's and parliamentary observers described the budget as a conservative yet focused and well researched attempt to bring government spending in line with its other macro growth strategies. - African Eye News Service


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March 19, 1997


East Africa;
Communique by Great Lakes Summit


BYLINE: UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 787 words


 

Nairobi - Text of Communique by the Summit of the Nairobi II Committee on the Crisis in the Great Lakes Region

1. At the invitation of H.E. President Daniel T. arap Moi of Kenya, Heads of State and Government forming the Committee of Four as mandated by the Nairobi II Summit of 16th December, 1996 namely Presidents Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe, Deputy President Thabo Mbeki of South Africa representing President Nelson Mandela, Prime Minister Peter Mafany Musonge representing President Paul Biya, current Chairman of the OAU, met in Nairobi on 19th March, 1997 to pursue the peace initiative of Eastern Zaire. President Pascal Lissouba of Congo and Prime Minister, Kengo wa Dondo of Zaire attended by special invitation.

2. Also participating in the Summit was the Secretary General of the OAU, Dr. Salim Ahmed Salim and Ambassador Mohamed Sahnoun Joint Special Representative of the Secretaries General of the UN and the OAU. 

3. The Summit examined developments in the region since Nairobi II and expressed grave concern at the rapidly deteriorating situation in Eastern Zaire, in particular the continued loss of lives, suffering of refugees, displaced persons and other victims of the conflict as well as destruction of property and infrastructure.

4. The Summit urged all parties to do their utmost to facilitate access for humanitarian assistance and invited all UN Agencies and other humanitarian organizations to provide this assistance.

5. The Summit re-affirmed its commitment for the respect of the unity, territorial integrity and sovereignty of Zaire as provided for in the OAU and UN Charters.

6. The Summit welcomed participation of Zaire and reaffirmed its commitment to the search for peace in an effort to achieve a lasting solution to the crisis.

7. The Summit reaffirmed the urgent need for the implementation of the OAU/UN Peace Plan as provided for in the UN Security Council Resolution 1097 of 18th February, 1997. It welcomed the acceptance of the Plan by the Government of Zaire and also took note of the acceptance in principle by the other party. The Summit urged all parties to the conflict to unconditionally accept and implement the peace plan.

8. The Summit urged the parties to the conflict to immediately cease hostilities, and create the necessary environment to facilitate a negotiated settlement.

9. The Summit resolved that diplomatic efforts should be intensified in the search for a lasting solution to the Zairean crisis and urged that, in doing so, all initiatives be co-ordinated and in this context welcomed the forthcoming extra-ordinary summit of the central organ of the OAU in Lome, Togo on 26th March, 1997.

10. The Summit underscored the importance of establishing a mechanism for monitoring the implementation of the OAU/UN peace plan. In this context, the summit stressed the importance of Africa making its own significant contribution to the mechanism. The Summit invites the Central Organ of the OAU Mechanism for conflict Prevention, Management and Resolution meeting in Lome, Togo on 26th March 1997 to address this issue.

11. The Summit expressed its appreciation to President Daniel T. arap Moi, the Government and the people of Kenya for hosting the meeting and for the warm welcome and hospitality accorded to the delegations.

Done at Nairobi on 19th March, 1997 (Transcribed by UN DHA IRIN, Nairobi.)

Africa News


March 20, 1997


Nigeria;
Nigeria Jails Poll Fraudsters


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Four people, including one leading candidate in one of the five political parties involved in last Saturday's local council polls, were sentenced to various jail terms Wednesday by a magistrate's court in Akure, western Nigeria, for electoral offenses.

The candidate for a council chair, Pojo Joshua of the Congress for National Consensus party, in the western state of Ondo, is to spend one year in prison without an option of fine for unlawful possession of a voter's card belonging to his son.

Reports from across the country said dozens of suspects were arrested for alleged offenses during the elections. 

Meanwhile, a government official has warned of severe punishment against anyone found to have engaged in sharp practices in the elections.

"We are going to descend on them (the offenders) and all those arrested will be decisively punished," Navy Capt. Joseph Adeusi, military administrator of the south-eastern state of Akwa Ibom, told journalists Wednesday.

He was speaking after a meeting between Nigerian head of state Gen. Sani Abacha and 36 state military administrators to review the conduct of the polls.

Adeusi said while some of the hitches were "human and understandable, we have resolved that some lapses will not be taken lightly."

Among practices considered grave, he said, were the removal of voters cards and ballot boxes during voting.

An estimated 56 million eligible voters took part in the polls to choose some 8,000 councilors and chairpersons from the 776 council areas in the country of some 100 million people.

Nigerian newspapers also reported four deaths in the south-eastern state of Rivers and the Mid-western state of Delta in poll-related incidents.

Otherwise, overall reports indicated that the council elections, the first multi-party polls under the military government's 36-month transition to democracy programme, went well.

The 38-member election monitors from the United States said apart from a few logistic problems, the council elections were free and fair.

The United Nigeria Congress Party has continued to maintain a commanding lead against four of its rivals in results so far released by the election commission nationwide.

Elected council chairmen are to be inaugurated Monday by the state administrators. They will in turn induct the councilors.

The electoral commission is to fix dates for run-offs or by-elections in councils were balloting were either stalemated, cancelled or did not take place Saturday.


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March 20, 1997


Ethiopia;
New Technology Hikes Food Output in Ethiopia


BYLINE: Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 387 words


 

WASHINGTON - Former U.S. president Jimmy Carter says a successful Ethiopian experiment in new farm technologies may help solve the problem of food shortages in Africa and other parts of the world.

In an article published in a U.S. newspaper on Thursday, Carter said new farm techniques introduced to Ethiopian farmers in 1986 had led to 200 percent to 400 percent yields over traditional methods, creating a record grain harvest in 1996. 

The "Simple" techniques, such as seedbed preparation and improved seed varieties, were introduced by the Atlanta-based Carter Center, a non-profit organisation; Nobel laureate Norman Borlaug and Japan-based Sasakawa Africa Association, under a partnership called Sasakawa-Global 2000.

The famine in Ethiopia and the surrounding nations in the mid-1980s prompted the partnership to work towards promoting efficient farming techniques in those countries.

"Knowledge about improved practices was available but not flowing from African research centers through government extension services to small-scale farmers," Carter said.

"We set out to break this logjam, and now more than half-a-million small- farm families have greatly increased their yields," he added.

The former president explained that unlike many other internationally- funded programmes, the partnership worked closely with each country's government, allowing a network to expand from the highest political officials to the individual farmer.

"What has happened in Ethiopia demonstrates that a plentiful food supply is possible for all nations.

"What is needed is the political and social will of the developed world to address the root causes of food shortages, not just donate money," Carter said.


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March 20, 1997


Nigeria-Gas One-Billion-Dollar Yearly Gas Revenue For Nigeria


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - The export of natural gas from Nigeria, tentatively slated to commence in October 1999, will fetch the oil-rich country an annual revenue of one billion U.S. dollars, the Liquified Natural Gas (LNG) company has said.

The firm, in which the Nigerian federal government has 40 percent equity participation, said in a statement it expected 22.5 billion dollars in revenue over 22 years. 

The LNG plant has capacity to produce 7.15 billion cubic meters of gas a year.

Prospective European buyers include Engas of Spain, Bota of Turkey and the French gas De France. A fourth buyer, Enel of Italy, which pulled out of the contract in 1996, is reported to have rejoined the venture after a flurry of diplomatic efforts between Abuja and Rome.

Nigerian economists say gas export is expected to displace oil, which currently accounts for some 90 percent of the country's total foreign exchange earnings.


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


490 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 20, 1997


Business and Finance;
Environmental Agency Challenges Oil Firms In Nigeria


BYLINE: Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 440 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigeria's Federal Environmental Protection Agency (FEPA), Wednesday gave oil firms operating in the country 60 days to furnish details of their dump sites for the purpose of determining compensation to oil producing communities.

FEPA acting director general, Adegoke Adegoroye, said the information required of the oil companies included history, description, geology, ecology, listing and photographs of the dump sites.

On receipt of this inventory, FEPA "shall commission studies to determine the level of pollution in each operation areas as a basis for future determination of response and remedy, and the calculation of compensation and liability," Adegoroye told the opening of a three-day international environmental conference in Lagos. 

The conference is organized in collaboration with Shell Petroleum Development Nigeria, operators of the joint venture with the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation, and multinationals Elf and Agip.

Describing some environmental problems as evidence of instability and chaos in nigeria and other parts of Africa, he said "to restore order in an otherwise chaotic setting, there must be laws."

FEPA was established to coordinate Nigeria's environmental protection drive in the aftermath of the 1988 dumping by an Italian firm of toxic waste in the mid-western port of Koko. That incident put Nigeria in the forefront of international anti-dump crusade.

Allegations of environmental degradation has, however, remained a major source of friction between country's oil-rich Delta communities, especially Ogoniland, and foreign oil companies operating in the country.

Ogoniland, in its anti-pollution campaign, is claiming some 10 billion U.S. dollars in environmental damages.

Adegoreoye said environmental offenses were indeterminate and continuous, and posed permanent danger as in the case of chemical spillage.

He said the "pollutant removal and site remediation required special technologies which if not applied will continue to make the pollutant destroy plants and animals in the environment and pose a threat to human lives."


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


491 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 20, 1997


Zaire;
Uphill Task For OAU On Zaire


BYLINE: Tambayi Nyika, PANA Correspondent, Panafrican News Agency


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1080 words


 

NAIROBI, Kenya (PANA) - The Organisation of African Unity's (OAU) ongoing efforts to resolve the five-month old crisis In Zaire through negotiations is likely to come unstuck as the anti-government forces have defiantly decided to settle the issue on the battle field.

The series of meetings so far held also appear to be fraught with flaws that the rebel movement, led by 56-year-old Laurent-Desire Kabila, is exploiting to its advantage and splitting the international community.

Even as Wednesday's mini-summit in Nairobi, the Kenyan capital, was going on, Kabila declared that the war would continue, describing the talks as " irrelevant."

The summit, hosted by Kenyan President Daniel arap Moi, was attended by Congolese President Pascal Lisouba, Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe, South African Deputy President Thabo Mbeki, Cameroonian Prime Minister Peter Musonge and Zairian Prime Minister Kengo wa Dondo. Also participating at the summit dubbed "Nairobi lll" to discuss solutions to a crisis, were OAU Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim and OUA/UN joint Special Representative to the Great Lakes region Mohamed Sahnoun. 

Previous summits in Nairobi (November 1996), South Africa (December 1996), Nairobi (January 1997) have all produced communiques demanding a cease-fire which analysts now say are out of touch with the realities on the ground in Zaire.

The rebels have now captured over a fifth of the country's territory and have vowed to proceed to Kinshasa, the Zairian capital, to end President Mobutu Sese Seko's 31-year-old rule.

Experts familiar with the conflict say African leaders' decision to isolate the rebel movement from directly participating in the talks is likely to harden attitudes towards any reconciliation and cease-fire.

This is so because the rebels have reportedly received overwhelming political support from residents of the four towns they have so far captured, including the garrison town of Kisangani, the third largest city, which they captured last Saturday.

African leaders have also not involved other leaders from Angola, Rwanda and Uganda, whose governments are reportedly providing logistical support for the rebels, while the former Angolan rebel movement UNITA, led by Jonas Savimbi, is said to be on the side of Mobutu's retreating government forces, thus further complicating the conflict.

"It is a mistake not to involve all these parties," said an official familiar with the African-sponsored initiatives. "The rebels have been given the impression that their side of the story is irrelevant. Kabila has already said the decisions of the meeting are not binding because he feels isolated."

He added that South African President Nelson Mandela and Sahnoun had already set a precedent by meeting both sides, yet African leaders were excluding Kabila.

This was clear during the final communique of the Nairobi summit, which referred to Kabila's rebel movement, the Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo/Zaire, as "the other party to the conflict."

Kabila is also said to be opposed to Moi hosting the talks because of his perceived friendship with Mobutu, especially after the participation of Kengo wa Dondo at the Nairobi summit as the official Zairian government representative. Moi also visited Mobutu in Gbadolite in January.

The rebels now view the African leaders' initiative as collectively biased against them and may not co-operate.

"They see Moi as not a neutral mediator because he has already publicly condemned Kabila and was against South Africa's hosting of both parties," the official said.

But Moi appeared to brush aside these concerns when he officially opened the summit, saying he was more concerned with pushing for a cease-fire which the rebels have rejected.

"I believe that with Zaire's participation and presence, the search for peace will indeed gain considerable ground. All the parties to the conflict should restrain themselves and guarantee a negotiated settlement. We must not relent until we are assured that this is attainable," he said.

The Nairobi communique expressed concern over the continued loss of lives, suffering of refugees and displaced persons as well as destruction of property and infrastructure.

But, it did not say what steps were being taken to bring the warring factions together despite calls for an unconditional acceptance of the five- point UN peace plan, which calls for a cease-fire, withdrawal of foreign forces and mercenaries, negotiations, protection of refugees and elections.

Mugabe insisted that the UN plan would be pushed for implementation despite Kabila's belligerence.

"That is the view of those fighting because they are fighting for a cause, especially if their fighting is making progress," he said. "But one important way of fighting which should never ever be rejected is negotiations. There comes a time when we say we have fought enough and must negotiate."

He added that it was important for Kabila and others to listen to those who want to see peace and the process of democracy taking place in Zaire.

Whether Kabila and his rebel colleagues will respond and participate according to the requirements of the UN plan is the big question which even the African leaders cannot answer with certainty.


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March 20, 1997


United States and Africa;
USAID sends Nelspruit officials to America


BYLINE: Sharon Hammond, African Eye News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Nelspruit - Nelspruit's ground-breaking move to form public/private partnerships has prompted the United States Agency for International Development (Usaid) to offer an all-expenses paid trip to council officials to attend a special course on such partnerships in America.

Spokesperson for the Nelspruit town council, Etienne Garnett-Bennett, explained Nelspruit was the first city in South Africa to establish public/private partnerships in the provision of water and sewerage, and had impressed Usaid with the procedures it followed. 

He said Nelspruit's town clerk, Roelf Kotze, and town engineer, Leon Hallat, would attend the Public Private Partnerships course in Washington and Florida.

"The programme will be particularly helpful in the council's efforts to analyse bids, negotiate contract documents and manage private participation in water and sanitation systems," Garnett-Bennett said.

He said Kotze and Hallat would also do a presentation of their own at the course.

The programme is being offered by the Institute for Public/Private Partnerships and will be held until March 28. - African Eye News Service.


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


493 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 20, 1997


South Africa;
MPB pledges support to Gray


BYLINE: Justin Arenstein, African Eye News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 640 words


 

Nelspruit - Mpumalanga Parks Board's (MPB) board of directors has come to the defence of their embattled CEO, Alan Gray, after the province's environmental affairs MEC criticised his handling of the Dolphin parks deal.

MEC Mkhwanazi said earlier this week that he had expressed his reservations about the deal's possible consequences to Gray in an urgent memo, before Gray signed the deal in secret last year November.

"I never once supported the original contract ... it was steamrollered through. I set out all my reservations in a memo to Gray in October last year before he signed the original contract - but he never listened. If he had, none of this would have happened," explained MEC Mkhwanazi. 

The memorandum, dated ten days before the contract was signed on November 1, stresses Mkhwanazi's unease about the commercial monopoly that would be created if one company was granted sole rights to all the reserves and also question's Gray's commitment of government funds to the deal without cabinet approval.

"Even though I clearly instructed him to put the matter before the cabinet for ratification before signing anything, this was not done. Instead we were given a colourful slide presentation by the MPB," added Mkhwanazi.

The MPB's board of directors, however, passed a strongly worded resolution pldging their full support to Gray on Wednesday.

Board chairman, Dr Patrick Maduna, said that despite "unsubstantiated accusations" against Gray in the press, including allegations that an aviation company owned by Gray had been patronised by the MPB, the Board had found no grounds to suspect his integrity.

Stressing that no 'evidence' could be found of any perceived or possible wrongdoing, the Board said in a statement that they were satisfied that Gray had conducted himself in a "highly professional" manner and would continue to have their full support and confidence.

Maduna later conceded to Sapa, however, that the Board had not examined the charges or attempted to verify whether they were correct or not.

"The memo from the MEC to Gray did not go before the Board but there is truth in the statement that the Dolphin deal counld have been handled better - no-one can refute that. The Board expressed its support for Gray based on the information before it," he explained.

Under the guise of rescuing the multi-billion deal, Mkhwanazi also announced that he had "re-exerted" his political control over the supposedly autonomous parastatal, was busy changing legislation so he could scrap the MPB's internal tender committee, was severely curtailing the powers of Gray and was placing severe financial limitations on the Board.

He also stressed that the government was taking over control of salaries at the MPB after complaints that people in equivalent posts were earning widely different salaries. Gray serves as the MPB's chief executive officer on a 5- year fixed term contract with a cash salary of between R34 000 and R40 000 per month, plus various benefits and perks worth an additional but unspecified sum. Gray's superior in the Department of Environmental Affairs, to whom he supposedly answers, earns only R13 800 per month. - African Eye News Service


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1997 AllAfrica, Inc.


494 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 20, 1997


South Africa;
Mpumalanga signs protocol agreement with Mozambican province


BYLINE: Sharon Hammond, African Eye News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 214 words


 

Nelspruit - Mpumalanga Premier, Mathews Phosa, signed a protocol agreement with the Mozambican province of Niassa on Wednesday as part of the general agreement of co-operation signed by Presidents Nelson Mandela and Joaquim Chissano last year.

Phosa emphasised the need to form a strong economic alliance in the region. 

"The time has come for us as a region to be known as the Southern African Economic Lions," he said.

According to Phosa's spokesperson, Oupa Pilane, Phosa and the deputy minister of agriculture, Thoko Didiza, also visited the first 13 South African farmers who left to farm in Niassa last year.

"Within four months of their coming to Niassa, 600 hectares of land have been ploughed and 400 hectors planted," he said.

He said Phosa and Didiza said they were committed to the success of the farming project and would ensure both countries benefited from it. - African Eye News Service.


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1997


LANGUAGE: English

495 of 781 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 20, 1997


South Africa;
Squatters win battle for houses


BYLINE: Sharon Hammond, African Eye News Service


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Nelspruit - For six years, squatters living on undeveloped land in Tekwane East near Nelspruit have pressured the Nelspruit town council to build them a township.

During the past few months, pressure was increased by a specially formed squatter committee and, on Thursday, the Nelspruit town council finally admitted defeat. 

Nelspruit's head of urban planning, Maggie van Rensburg, announced that contractors had been appointed to survey the area for the construction of 300 stands by May.

"The town council could not remove them from the area, because we don't have any other stands to which they could go," she explained.

She said the squatter committee had compiled a list of residents that would require stands, and that no further settlement would be allowed.

"If more people move into the area, they will be removed," she warned.

She said bona fide residents would have the opportunity to buy land, then obtain title deeds, and that ownership of the stands would make residents eligible for government housing subsidies.

She said no municipal services would be provided to the township yet, but the committee and council were investigating introducing services to the area at a later stage.

Each stand will be between 300- and 450 square metres in size and will be pegged in May.

The total cost for developing the township is not yet known. - African Eye News Service.


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 1997
